With the long wait for this game, the hype and expectations were quite high. I was one who was waiting for a great gameplay, but soon enough, the news about the troublesome development of this game was something that is seen on this game. Stuck between undestructible objects is something quite common, if it were not for the checkpoints, I would drop this game. Poor sound quality and mediocre animations are sadly, marks of this game.
The story is simple as the Duke Nukem 3D that I've played years ago. Aliens come to Earth and destroy everything, and Duke is the one to stop them. Duke's voice is the same, which I enjoyed very much. The NPCs acting are sufferable, maybe for comedy, but could not pull off. But Duke is still a badass no doubt, cliché over cliché, it's all there.
The graphics are quite nice, the attention on details are well done. The animation, not quite. NPCs and enemies, sometimes, moves like a tank. The level designs are great, nothing maze like or out of place for cluttering the map. I enjoyed the shrinked Duke maps, very creative ones. Most of the maps are quite big, but there isn't much to do with all that space.
The sounds are very unbalanced, any explosion or noisy factory map level, becomes an ear♥♥♥♥♥♥ Loudness isn't quality, and the sound designer just abused it, I had to lower the volume on the game, then after passing that certain part, raise it again. It was very annoying sometimes, imagine spending more than a minute on a puzzle noisy ambient. The music is quite nice, it shows up on battle moments mostly, and in cutscenes.
One detail of this game that I did not like is the lack of space to carry my weapons, on the first game, you can choose more than 4 weapons, which is restricted in this game. I had to always "sacrifice" a weapon for another. And no jet pack? I expected more, but maybe the troubled development is to blame.
The game is fun, there is no doubt in that. I had some great fun moments, and on others, not so much, due to the poor quality on software programming. I am not going to recommend this game, since it is very rushed, with obvious moments of terrible game planning. The impression that I have is that it released just to get rid of the project, instead of delivering something of better quality and worthy.
It could have been much more, and it was painful to hear Duke saying to a dead NPC that he wasn't going to be on the sequel.

Not sure if I've ever played a more frustrating game.  Not because of the difficulty which is complete trial and error (in a shooter!), but because there are some great things here all lost in a terrible, terrible sense of direction.
The rules of the game seem to change scene to scene, you will encounter endless one hit kill situations whether that's in yet ANOTHER phyiscs puzzle or because you die in just one or two hits from most enemies.
The bosses are all just frustrating, not satisfying.  There are endless vehicle driving segments and parts where you are shrunk.  GOOD LORD did they love the 'shrinking' mechanic.  I would guess that nearly 1/3rd of your entire playtime will be spent as a nearly powerless mini-Duke dying in various ways or slowly, slowly traversing the level and being unable to fight any normal enemies.
It's just relentless.  At this point I'm more hate playing it than anything.  I don't care about the immature humor (in this day and age it's actually refressing to have a non-PC character in a PC game), but the gameplay itself it's very good shooting, very frustrating insta-death puzzles, and then just a bunch of tedium.

Before we begin, I'd just like to say that, overall, I'd rate the good parts of Duke Nukem Forever (In other words, any part of the game that does not involve the plot or boss fights) a solid six out of ten. That's like a C+, which in most school systems is a passing grade. Anyway, now for why I think this is quite possibly the single worst AAA first-person shooter of all time.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Duke Nukem. It's a name that carries around a fair bit of weight, isn't it? The stoagie chomping, one-liner droping All-American mountain of machismo himself, and his... Let's just say varyingly successful game series. Well, how many people out there could say, in total honesty, that they thought Duke Nukem Forever was an amazing game? No rush, I'll give you a couple seconds. If you said "Not many", you'd be correct.
At its core, much like 2012's Doom 3: BFG Edition (Which I previously reviewed), Duke Nukem Forever is a game that has a good idea, and one that should be impossible to fudge up - A bombastic, balls-to-the-wall thrill ride starring none other than Duke "I Ripped Off Ash Williams" Nukem and a cast of characters mainly thrown together to be either cannon fodder, or exposititory elements. Oh, and the alien invaders, let's not forget them. There's a line, at the very start of the game, that rather ironically tells the entire story of Duke Nukem Forever's development:
"What about the game, Duke? Was it any good?"
Duke: "After twelve fragging years, it should be."
Now, that quip would have been funny - if it were true. See, Duke Nukem Forever started with a good idea, like I mentioned above. It was 1997, and 3D Realms was on a gosh darn roll with Duke Nukem 3D, third child in their Duke Nukem franchise (and the one people think of most when they think Duke Nukem), so they announced Duke Nukem Forever, for a release date that infamously devolved into the phrase, "When it's done."
"Wait, did he just-?" You may ask. "Surely, he put the wrong year." Nope. Development of what would become Duke Nukem Forever started right after 3D's release, and from the start it was meant to be bigger - Better graphics, better gameplay, level interactivity beyond that of even 3D. Then 2001 rolled around, and while a trailer was released, there was nothing to show upon the game's scheduled release date. It wouldn't be until TEN. YEARS. LATER. That Duke Nukem Forever was released, as the dated, yet reasonably polished turd that it was, for PS3, Xbox 360 and finally, PC. For most of its development, Duke Nukem Forever was in a state known as "Development Hell", wherein an ip has a rather protracted development cycle, with Duke Forever being the poster child of the phrase, at least in the gaming world.
In terms of basic plot, you are Duke Nukem, machismo personified and savior of mankind due to some shenanigans that happend "Twelve Years Ago" which resulted in the Los Angeles area being largely destroyed, heavily damaged, or otherwise rendered uninhabitable. Of course, this quick rundown of Duke Nukem 3D largely ignores the two-dimensional shenanigans of Duke Nukum and Duke Nukem 2, so... ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ I guess. After mucking about in your casino called the Ladykiller (I'm assuming Duke's super creative nickname for his dong), you descend into the bowels of the property and have a friendly little chit-chat with the President and General Graves (One of, like, two returning characters from the 2001 build of the game. Actually, I think he's the ONLY returning character), who inform you that the aliens have, indeed, returned but that you are NOT to engage. Duke, being Duke, says "Frack it, I'm taking matters into my own hands."
The combat in Duke Nukem Forever is, surprisingly enough, actually rather decent, once you get used to the inherently slightly-too-high-yet-not-high-enough mouse sensitivity and Duke's movement speed which is somewhere between "Geriatric Ninja" and "Obese Toddler". The weapons feel rather punchy (except for the fists, ironically enough), and they all deal a decent amount of damage, both to Duke and foe. It's rather difficult to play favorites for "Favorite Weapon in Duke Forever", since most of them are what one would expect from a mid-late 90s shooter - The pistol is practically useless, the Shotgun is a beast in close quarters and the Ripper is the game's dedicated assault rifle. New arrival the Railgun tries to add a bit of variety to the mix, but ultimately just doesn't make the gunplay as exciting as one would expect from the God Damn Duke.
Actually, let's side track and as ourselves, "What happened to Duke Nukem after 3D but before Forever?" Well, Duke Nukem had quite the journey from 3D to Forever. First was his console exclusive adventures (Planet of the Babes, Time to Kill, Zero Hour, to name a few) and a return to the second-dimension with 2006's Manhattan Project, it was clear Duke was still alive and kicking, but for how much longer? Duke Nukem Forever was still in semi-active development by this time, with no clear release date set (Again, "When it's done."). Ultimately, Duke Nukem Forever was released in June of 2011, to middling and negative reviews.
So, where is Duke Nukem now? Making a cameo appearance in Bulletstorm, that other FPS with a protagonist who isn't Duke Nukem but may as well be Duke Nukem, albeit voiced by Steve Blum (Not Duke, not actual Duke). Will we see a Duke Nukem threequel? It's hard to say, but with the Michael Bay-helmed motion picture in active development (I'm not even joking here, there's a Duke Nukem -movie-), maybe the future is brigher for our steroid addicted action hero.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overall, like mentioned in the header, Duke Nukem Forever's good bits amount to a game which is a solid six out of ten, but because of how spread out they are, between horrid vehicle sections, the strip club sequence and an uninteresting, I'd argue boring campaign, it makes sense to see how one could forget this game.

The real reason to get this is because the engine looks so great - there are issues with the sound, and the Megaton edition had more content. But this is easily the best looking version of Duke3d - the skyboxes are fantastic, and the new lighting makes the game look much better.

Mixed thoughts, mixed thoughts...
Duke Nukem 3D is an amazing game, alright? One of the more higher quality Doom clones that could actually claim the title of being as good as Doom. It has attitude, more realistic settings, a very risque sense of humor, absurdity all around, but the core game is also really good-- the levels are a bit more non-linear, each and every enemy has their own quirks and flaws, the soundtrack is great... the whole game is great, and is most definitely worth a shot, even today!
This specific remaster? It's... man,
much potential was wasted here, I wouldn't blame you... hell, I'd even
you to seek down a big boxed copy of the original Duke Nukem 3D (preferably of the Atomic Edition variety) instead of getting this version. This is technically the second time I've bought this game, and boy oh boy, the first time I played this thing, it was f*cking
The sound was all muffled, the mouse acceleration was overly sensitive, it performed like crap (even though this originally ran on SOFTWARE RENDERING AND THE HARDWARE-ACCELERATED VESA VARIANT WAS ENTIRELY OPTIONAL, AND EVEN THAT ONE RAN ABOVE 60FPS), so I refunded it almost immediately.
This time, my cousin bought it for me for the New Years, a gesture I still appreciate, and believe me when I say this-- the problems I listed above? Most of them are (kinda sorta) resolved, the sound isn't muffled anymore for one thing, so some progress
be being made to do this game justice, but still... are you seriously going to buy this when a boxed copy of it exists probably for even cheaper prices, or you could just get your hands on a Steam key or something of the more content-filled Megaton Edition? The one that comes with a native Linux port and has all of the previous standalone expansions installed on it?
Look, this remaster isn't
bullcrap, so you could do a helluva lot worse. For one thing, it's not Duke Nukem Forever. (Seriously, I've seen footage of that game, and it makes me want to commit game end.) It's also more or less the original game we've all known and loved for years, largely untouched from its original variety. Hell, you could also consider the new episode, the eponymous World Tour a nice addition, alongside the VALVe-esque development commentary and re-recorded Duke talk by Jon St. John himself a pretty good bang for your buck...
...but I'm not going to sugarcoat around, buster. If you want to play Duke Nukem 3D, this is
the optimal way to do it.
If you genuinely can't get your hands on the original game alongside its expansions, then I
this couldn't do much harm? But still... the king's got a long way to go before he can reclaim his crown.
5/10, proceed with caution.

I wasn't able to get past the first two hours. Gameplay is clunky, disconnected, and unsatisfying. I don't think I've played a game with weapons that were as unsatisfying to use. Game is clearly unfinished, animations are missing for all models, even the protagonist; Duke. His jumping and idle positions show his arms and hands fixed to the side pointed down like a mannequin. I was straining my eyes trying to focus on the graphics for the first hour until I disabled the 'advanced effects' which caused the screen to look like someone rubbed Vasoline across it. I figured that they would have fixed some of this stuff sometime after release. They never did. Released 13 years late? Not long enough.

The first of the classic Build engine games. When Duke Nukem 3D came out it was a huge step forward technically from Doom and clones. Even 20 years later it feels fresh and innovative. From the items, to the great level design to the rockin' arsenal to the small details, there is much thought put into the game. And it really feels.
There were so many features and details that really made it stand out. Much of it is thanks to the Build engine of course and you can see similar details in Blood and Shadow Warrior. There are quite many destructible parts ingame, many walls can be blown up to reveal secrets or alternative routes, sometimes the ground will open up. It's not like in Red Faction where everything you see can be blown up but considering the year Duke came out, it was very fresh. Or footprints. If you have walked in muck your footprints will reflect that. Over water, your footprints will be watery blue. Over a corpse, bloody red. Shell and bullet casings spread around where you shoot. There are security cameras ingame which you can watch the feed of through monitors. This is actually really helpful since you can often see where ambushes are and plan ahead on how to approach. Or the feed will have visual clues where you should head next if you cannot find a key. I'll mention one of the weapons here too, the pipe bomb. Basically it's a remotely controlled bomb. You throw it, push a remote control button and boom. Simple. Effective. However, you can take it to another level with the aid of the cams and monitors. On one level with some space tram cars for instance you can see the enemies on the next station waiting for you to come over if you look in the monitor. It's an ambush clearly. So what do you? You throw in a pipe bomb into the tram car, send it over to the next station, head over to the monitor and when you see the car approach you click the button. Boom. And you get a live feed from the camera body parts flying and all. Ingenious. You can send pipe bombs through lifts. Even teleporters.
Duke is actually one of very few first person shooters where the whole weaponry makes more or less sense, or you feel that every weapon has its specific purpose(s). You start with a handgun which might not be too useful, but it's a actually very accurate at distances and can be used on weaker foes to save ammo. Your melee weapon is actually a kick but you can also quick kick ingame items like trash cans, without the need to change the weapon you're holding, in hope to find some healing items or ammo. The shotgun feels just right, useful from close encounters to a moderate distance it actually feels quite realistic. The ripper chain gun is great for crowd control of lesser foes. Then you have a RPG which makes a quick mess of enemies. Useful for groups of enemies or stronger enemies to bosses it is a great versatile weapon. Then the pipe bomb which was already mentioned. There's also a shrink ray gun which literally shrinks enemies so you can stomp them to death! Hilarious. Devastator which fires smaller explosive missiles very rapidly. And a freeze gun which shoots freezing ice which can be used to freeze enemies into icicles. Then you can shatter them with a bullet or a kick. And lastly the laser tripwire mine which essentially is a trap. In single play its usage is quite limited unless you play on the hardest difficulty or you know where some enemies are coming from. In multiplay it's great fun. Put it over a teleporter for quick instakills.
Duke himself is of course a parody over 80's action heroes and he shares a similar mentality. He throws bad one-liners all the time, some of them are quite funny. And he's attitude towards women, well let's say he's slightly sexist. It's not meant to be taken seriously. There are many hookers ingame and some alien abducted babes too. It doesn't really distract or add that much to the game though.
This package also includes two expansions. The expansions add one episode each, some new enemies and weapons. They are worth playing but are not quite up to the quality of the original episodes in my opinion.
Overall, one of the great FPS games of the 90's. I had just as much fun replaying this as when I played it 20 years ago. Highly recommended.

Duke Nukem 3D has withstood the test of time surprisingly well. I've played it since the shareware version came out, so my view of it is slightly tinted by the nostalgic glasses I'm wearing as I get back to making these aliens pay for shooting up my ride.
I reckon most people who read the reviews for the 20th Anniversary are familiar with DN3D already, so there's little reason to go over the basics, but just in case someone's new to Duke, it's one of the most important games in the FPS genre along with id Software games like Doom and Quake. Whereas early id games were serious and gloomy, Duke Nukem took a humoristic approach, filled with toilet humour and steroid-pumped action film hero one-liners. It was (and is) juvenile, tasteless and over the top. And it's great.
The initial release boasted three episodes with various settings. The first one takes place in Los Angeles, in the second you travel to space, while the third one is a hodge podge of unrelated locales. All episodes have tons of secrets to look for, ways to clear the levels fast by speedrunning, and the usual alien massacre. The game lends itself to different ways of gameplay, which boosts its replay value.
The fourth episode was released in the Atomic Edition, and is in my opinion the weakest of the bunch. It has a few new weapons, new enemies and interesting levels, but from the viewpoint of casual gaming, it suffers from hard to avoid damage and shortage of ammunition. It's still a very good Episode, but with a few tweaks it would be platinum.
That brings us neatly to the new additions of DN3D20thAV (rolls right off your tongue, doesn't it?). There's a new episode with new music, a new weapon, newly recorded lines by the original VA for Duke, Jon St. John, and a few new features.
Since I already talked about the old maps, let's start with the new Episode: Alien World Order. It features 8 new maps in a variety of locations around the world and I'm glad to say they are all top notch from a level design point of view. They feel fresh but retain the old feel of the Build engine maps. This shouldn't come as a surprise, as the levels are actually made by the original DN3D devs and map designers. There are tons of enemies and bosses in almost every level so they are not for the faint of heart, but they're not insurmountable even on higher difficulties. They give you plenty of ammonition and health pickups to deal with the swarm of aliens, and much like in the old days, there are secrets in abundance. And no, I did not find them all, despite humping almost every wall imaginable. The new music tracks for the levels are really good are composed by Lee Jackson, the main composer of the original game. And since we're talking about originals, the original voice actor for Duke not only has new lines for the new episode, but the old ones are redone as well. This may be a turn-off for some people, but you have to laud them for the effort.
The new weapon, the Incinerator, works as a counterpart to the Freezethrower, and as its name implies it burns enemies to a crisp. It works wonders on low-tier enemies, but even mid-tier baddies are not much of a hassle. Especially since they give you tons of ammo for it through-out the game. Honestly speaking, I didn't use it too much, but only because I love my Shotgun, RPG and Devastator way too much. It's still a cool addition and fits in like a glove.
One of the cool new features is the replay option. Whenever you die, you can rewind to any point of the level and continue on from there. It's a nifty tool that saves you time from saving and loading constantly, and gets you in the action quicker. In other words, you don't have to worry about not saving constantly. In fact, I only saved at the beginning of each stage and used the rewind whenever I got killed. Some might think it's cheap, but the fact the game allows you to save at any given time anyway it's just a handy way to continue playing without accessing the menu every time you make a mistake.
Obviously I like this game, but there are a few issues I need to address, however small they are. First, while the technical side of things is smooth, there is a slight deadzone for the mouse when you try to make small adjustments to your aim. This is not a huge problem, unless you play with the auto aim turned off - I did, and trying to make pinpoint movements was something of a hassle. Honestly, I recommend playing with the aim turned on. Trust me - it makes for a smoother gameplay experience and doesn't make you hate vertical aiming.
Second, some programs may result in crashes when starting up the game. I use Rivatuner Statistics Server to limit the FPS of certain games, and unless I turn it off, the game hangs at start-up and will not run. I can't speak for other software, but if you have trouble starting up the game, I suggest trying to turn off background programs.
Third, the final boss fight was not so much a showdown that a letdown. After such a carefully crafted - and difficult - episode, I expected to face a real badass at the end. Unfortunately, I killed him without moving an inch and holding down the fire button. I don't know if something glitched out, but the new final boss is the easiest enemy of the game. That's a huge oversight.
Lastly, and this is not really a complaint but rather a preference: I would have liked to see the game sprites updated to voxels in the vein of Shadow Warrior. Having items that look more lifelike than the cardboard cut-outs we have now would've made the game look and play a little smoother. This probably would've taken more time than it was worth and I'm fine with how the game looks, but voxel sprites would've given the graphics that final touch.
I recommend any FPS fans or Duke Nukem veterans to give this a go. Contrary to what Duke says at the beginning of the first new level, he's most certainly not too old for this♥♥♥♥♥♥

I've been playing Duke Nukem since Duke Nukem 3D, and it has always been 1 of my favorite games.
I loved the enemies and atmospheres of the game, I really liked the many different areas and venues that you got to experience in that game world, and I was always highly amused by the secrets and oddities strewn throughout the game, and the silly things as well.
Once I heard Duke Nukem Forever was finally going to be released, I insta-bought it day 1 for Xbox 360 without knowing anything about the game other than Duke was finally back.
After release many people started to voice their disappointment because the game did not live up to their hopes.
I shrugged off the comments I had been seeing and still sat down excitedly to play through the campaign.
I completed the game and I enjoyed it. I play a lot of games, good and bad, and would rank this as a good game(For adults).
For me it was definitely better than what some reviewers were saying, but I do agree that it could have been even better and I would have liked for it to be a more "colorful" and interesting experience, but I could still see the work that the devs put into the game and was impressed.
For 30 years I've been playing as many games as I can, so I see just how many bad games are out there, the ones that especially trigger me are those that ask for 60$ or more and turns out to be something I would probably program better alone.
So what I am getting at is that may help cause me to appreciate DNF since I really am comparing it to the mass amount of bad games on the market and know it is in a league higher than them for sure.
Skipping ahead to recently, I was wondering if there were any new DN games, so I searched up Duke Nukem on Steam and seen that there was DLC for Duke Nukem Forever that I had never heard of, so I decided to buy the game again on PC and revisit it, and I am very glad that I did.
Now, all that I say here has nothing to do with the DLC, I've not played it yet.
Duke Nukem Forever is far better on PC and I am having fun with it all over again.
If you are into Duke Nukem, and you've only played this on console, I'd recommend you picking it up again on PC if the price is right since it feels like a different game and also feels more like classic DN3d with a mouse and keyboard.
1 change that I wasn't enjoying so much with DNF was that Duke can only carry 2 weapons at a time now, but lately I found In options that there is an option to allow you to carry up to 4 weapons instead, I'd recommend you use it for fun's sake, but the game looks to have been balanced around the 2 weapon limit so it can become too easy carrying 4 weapons around, especially with the abundance of ammo in the game. Just make sure to not play on the easiest difficulty or it may ruin the experience for you.
I think the developers did a good job and I have a lot of fun with all of the activities they've woven into the gameplay.
My favorite part of this game is probably how you can shrink things and be shrunk yourself, and it creates an entirely new world.
1 problem I had with the game is that it feels too short. The game did have a Duke Nukem vibe to it, but the complete campaign felt like it should be 1 episode, with at least 1 more episodes to play with different sights and atmospheres.
I was let down that I didn't get to take Duke to more areas, such as an amusement park, or a shopping mall, or a grocery store.
I also like dark and creepy levels, Duke Nukem 3d spent a lot of time in nighttime, which is part of why I liked it so much, but DNF spends a lot of time in daytime which sets a different mood.
I liked being able to control and use vehicles, but I have to comment that I didn't like the handling of the truck you can get in.
I would have liked for the devs to improve the feel of that gameplay because I felt I was spending too much time in the truck, and with not fun handling it feels like a burden.
DN3d captivated me from the enemies and weapons, I liked the look of them, and the colors, so I would say I was let down with the enemies and weapons of DNF because they were not capturing the same essence as the ones in DN3d.
They were all still good, and the pig cops often would startle me, but the point here is I wish they went in a slightly different direction, or more like at least stayed with the same direction.
I have completed the main campaign again, and will start the DLC campaign after a break so I can feel refreshed for more DN.
So let me finish with saying that Duke Nukem Forever is a fun PC game, especially for veteran DN players, and I look forward to more games that I will still probably pick up on day 1 because DNF was not as bad a game as others have claimed and I enjoyed it.

As you can see by my username, I've always been a huge Duke fan. I finished the old "Duke 3D" saga several times and wanted to tackle them from start to finish again with the release of the 20th anniversary title.
Some history first...
Even though Duke 3D is an old game, its source code was released years ago and allowed source ports to be created by the community. The most notable of which is EDuke32 and it's still the best one today.
However, we didn't have an "official" one (aside from DOSBox) until some time ago. 3DRealms, while still retaining the rights, released Duke Nukem 3D Megaton Edition, a port that contained the original game, plus the Atomic Edition (fourth episode) and the official expansions - Duke Caribbean, Nuclear Winter and Duke it Out in DC.
When those rights expired, the current franchise owner Gearbox released Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour after Megaton was removed. Sadly, copyright shenanigans or some such prevented it to ship with the the official expansions above (apart from Atomic). In their place, a brand new episode called Alien World Order was created with new enemies and weapons, in which Duke opens up a can of international whoop*ss on the alien scum.
The quality of the new episode shows in good looking new textures and sprites but a somewhat average level design, especially noticeable when compared to the incredible work from the fans nowadays (see the Roch series). Even though it can feel simplistic in its structure and pacing, the levels are on par with those of the older expansions, however.
It's great to have an official port and workshop for one of my favorite games, but it's a shame it doesn't have the older official expansions. On a less sad note, I still got Megaton in my library which I'll go through after I finish Duke 20th (no review will be possible, though).
If you're a huge Duke fan like me, this title is a solid "canon" entry to the classic series, but you may want to wait for a sale. What I do recommend again, though, are levels and mods created by the community which in fact have top notch design quality.
Be sure to check WGRealms 2, The AMC TC, Starship Troopers and other top TCs (Total Conversions - one of the words that duke modders use) in the
community. Most of them use powerful features of the EDuke32 port. They can be found in sites such as

...I'm going to be 2 sided on this game. For I wished Steam would give us a maybe recommendation on a game like this. I personally think this game is like an 8.5/10 on my fan scale of being a classic Duke Nukem 3D game. Though it feels like a 7.5/10. There really could be more done with the game than what we already got 20 years ago. If you want to read me on a rant, that will be on the bottom of this review. Where I'll be putting out on why you should and shouldn't buy this game. Most reason being is, you're replaying the 4 chapters you played years ago. And now can play a 5th new chapter to the game. Which features it's own new gun, new levels, and a new boss. It also features small commentary and if you die in the game, a rewind back to a state before you die. Instead of reloading from a last safe state. There's also multiplayer for playing the levels on a co-op mode, or playing death match. If there's anyone who's there to play.
Positives: Feels, functions, and plays just like the gane I remember 20 years ago. What more can I say? The game features full controller support. So you can play using a game pad if you don't want to use mouse and keys. The game features a level select too. So if you want to just skip ahead and play the last level of the chapters, go right ahead. At a cost of doing so, you'll only start off with your starting pistol and under powered from lack of weapons, items, and power ups. Not to mention, the secret levels are not selectable. You have to find them in the levels that take you to them. There is also a commentary of the guys from Gear Box talk about the game's production even back around 1996. There's only selective commentary on at least the 1st levels of each chapter and only features full commentary on the 5th chapter and all it's levels. So there'll be lack of replayablity if you plan to not hear it now and replay the game with commentary. Due to lack of it on 4 chapters and only on the 5th one. The graphics can now be filtered in and out of a true 3D background setting. So if you played the game in the past and want to see it what it would look like with better detail, you can do so with a push of a button/key. Just to compare to the past and present looks of the background. All the weapons are fun and add veriety to kill the enemies. Pumping them full of lead, using explosive weapons, shrink them down to size and stomp on them to death, setting up trip bombs, freezing them and kicking then down to shatter, expanding them to make them swell up and explode, and now burn them to a crisp with the new Incinerator weapon. A weapon redesign of the Freeze Thrower that would shoot out balls of ice to freeze enemies. This one lobs balls of napalm to the enemy in an arc. Once it lands on the ground, it will form a puddle of burning napalm. Enemies stepping on it or hit by it are burned to death. You traverse the maps from one end to the other. Finding keycards to open locked doors to progress. So you'll be back tracking to find them in certain rooms. There's also item pick ups you can find in the game that can be used  while you progress. The portible medkit that restores you back to 100% health while using a percentage out from it's 100%. Night vision googles in dark areas. And the most note worthy, the jetpack. You can fly up to high areas safely or you can't seem to reach from jumping or other means. There's a veriety of enemies to shoot down. Some are puny. Others can really hurt you or take a lot more fire power to take down. They added in a new enemy in the 5th chapter that will try to burn you to death. Depending on your difficullty level, will depend on how many enemies will be placed out on the map; Each end of the chapter has a boss battle against a powerful boss that will take a lot of fire power to take down, and they can try to kill you in one clear hit. If they're using rockets that shoot at your face. So straifing side to side is the only way to avoid rockets to the face, or find a moment to hide in cover to avoid more damage to yourself. The game also has a lot of secret rooms that lead to more health, ammo, and weapon pick ups. From blowing up certain cracks in the walls, to pressing the use button/space bar on certain walls or objects to open up secert rooms. A few you can walk right into the walls to find them. So if you're playing the game on a harder difficulty, be well in stock on ammo. Some certain game levels have a secret room that takes you to a secret level! So get the chance to find and play those hidden levels you can't select in the level select. The game does have a lot of classic/dated references of pop culture, to other video games or even movies. So, after 14+ years of development, Duke Nukem 3D's sequel finally gets released to a universal "wow, we waited 14 years for that?"  The common complaint is that this is a game that would have done great back in 2006, but missed that mark by several years.  Looking at it objectively, maybe that's true, but only because 2006 was a pretty bad year for FPS games.
I was told mixed things ranging from "it's awful" to "it's an underrated  gem" to "it's flawed but fun"  The latter was the most common and made me think that I might enjoy this, I still play a lot of older shooters, DNF being dated is literally no problem for me.
But then I was shocked at how dire it actually is.
The visuals are often blurry and many levels are too dark to really see what the hell is going on.  Duke has night vision that you can activate at any time and is unlimited, but a lot of areas are too bright for night vision, and too dark to actually see.  I ran through the whole campaign without getting a jetpack, even though the control options menu mentions one.  Most weapons are absolutely useless, meaning that you'll be going through this with the shotgun, ripper and pipe bombs for hte most part, and then using RPGs on the bosses.  The game is a linear slog through boring levels that don't offer much in the way of exploration (compared to a lot of the open ended levels of Duke Nukem 3D) and the same 3 or 4 basic types of enemies swarm you at pre-determined action-setpieces.
The REAL issue though is how often you're not actually playing Duke Nukem.  A lot of times you're playing a bad version of Half Life 2, trying to solve physics puzzles.  Sometimes you're in a racing game, and sometimes you're shrunk down jumping across hamburger patties (yes, really). Sometimes, you're shrunk down AND driving a car, because why not?
The interface is godawful, even if it had been released in 2006, which it wasn't, and most mechanics are fairly useless.  The game is very easy, but you'll die in cheap ways a lot due to not being able to see what's going on, or just randomly at some parts.  I'm told the DLC is better than the actual game, but I think i'd rather uninstall it than continue playing.
Lastly, the humor is just not my cup of tea anymore.  Duke Nukem was funny to me when Duke3D came out and I was a teenager.  Now, it's just very cringe-worthy, and even over a decade after his last big game, he still repeats the same 15 or so lines over and over again.
There are a few exciting parts, such as the highway battle that cumulates in a second battlelord boss battle, where he stomps around and kicks the cars that you need to use as cover, forcing you to adapt.  The last level escaping a dam that is flooding and collapsing is fairly exciting and the last boss is well structured, even if it is super easy (the one time I died was friendly fire from the AI allies attacking from helicopters).  The ending is almost non-existant, teasing at a sequel that likely won't happen.

I recommend you buy this when there's a sale first. I know a lot of "reviewers" out there like to call this game a bad game. Most noticably soccor moms and SJWs who just want to hammer on it still to this day. I have to disagree on that. Still wished there was a mixed choice for Steam's reccomending choice. It's not awful. More like a flawed game. It's more than par to those who are fans to Duke since the 90s. It maintains it here since it was released in 2011. It's a 7.5309 on my fan scale. 7/10 to anyone who plays it just for the single player. Which is by far the only reason to play this game. There's more to do on there than the multiplayer. Since it's a FPS, 3rd person driving, platformer, puzzle, simulator mini game in a game game. The multiplayer is dead. I've played this game when I got it on 360. So I'll tell you some improvements from my last playthrough to this.
Positives: It runs smooth for 60 FPS. The music is awesome to listen to in the background when you're shooting all the alien scum that's in your way. The game is a linier of get to point A to point B. Some bugs I've noticed have been patched out. Such as the Ripper machine gun reload animation is fixed. Texture pop in seems to be smoothed out now. Depending on your PC specs. The game removes the health and armor percentages for a more modren take of health called your "Ego" bar. You start off with 50% Ego. It reacharges when you're hiding in cover or when you're away from taking damage like any modren FPS out there today. To increase the maximum of it, you have to interact with certain objects in the world that Duke would find himself doing to increase his "Ego." The health bar is a joke within itself. Which can be anything you can interact with by grabbing them, playing various mini games, and defeating the bosses in the SP campaign. It's nessasary to increase it. As the enemies will increase and playing on harder difficulties can be a pain in most modren FPSs. Such as increase damage on the player and the enemies become bullet sponges. So finding certian weapons in the game can help out with that. Some can be over powering than others. While others are weaksauce and you need to be creative on trying to deal them out. Using the environment like explosive barrels or flammable canisters can help out. You can even pick them up and throw them at enemies! Any ways to conserve some ammo and supplies. You can only hold 2 weapons in the game. And all the classic weapons from DN3D are in this game. Plus the alien weapons you can now use. So choose wisely on what weapons you're going to use in the game. You can also carry around the classic pipebombs and the laser trip bomb that can not only be stuck on walls, but now on enemies. Some supplies from the classic DN3D game come back. The HoloDuke has been improved to make Duke invisible while a hologram of Duke fools the enemies for a short time. The steroids come back, but have more of a different effect. It will reduce Duke's Ego to 75% max, but in return, reduce damage taken from enemies slightly. Causing him to go in a roid rage and his melee punches will one hit death enemies in a single punch for a short time. The night vision goggles are replaced with "Duke vision." Which it used to see in dark areas. They added a new item that is the beer. Which one can can make Duke go in a druken state. Reduicing damage taken by enemies by a lot, but makes your vision blurry and hearing slowed down. Like being drunk for real. There's also a mix up of the action with puzzle/platforming. Trying to get one end to the other. You even have to get from one end to the other by shrinking yourself down to the size of a 12" doll. Kinda cool to see what size difference is when you're small. Not to mention Duke stays true with his witty one liners. And like the past Duke games, there's plenty of Easter Eggs pop culture references from other games and some movies. Only to those who may have played the games or watched the movies. So they might not age too well like any other game. Still welcoming to hear them. There is also turrent sections that have nice action to the game. There is also a driving section to get from one place to the other. While crashing enemies with your monster truck. The game does have some cheats you can use and turn on and off. However, doing so will turn off any achivements to get from the game in that playthrough. The enemy AI is alright. They'll attack you and will take cover as well.
Negative: I have to warm you this is a Mature game for a reason. If you're someone who takes offense immediatly for seeing women only naked with their top exposed, crude sexual jokes, and can't find humor of being a person escaping from real life to something that is fun, then please by all means, don't buy this game.  The bosses can be a mix of a little simple to beat, to a difficulty spike of killing you almost every single time if your timing is off. Causing you to restart from your last checkpoint over and over again. So trying to map out the boss patterns or the overwhelming enemy minons that will keep on spawning to slow you down on progression. Only explosive weapons can damage the big bosses. So weapon choices can be limited to them.When you finish the bosses off, you then have to walk up to them and do a quick time event (QTE.)  A few of the mini games can feel somewhat underwhelming and might not been play tested. So getting your Ego max can be a pain to others to those who want to be complitionists. The loading screen doesn't take long for those who say it does. It's much shorter load time on PC than on the console ports. Faster on today's good PCs now. The story is somewhat subpar. Could of been a bit better. You might end up at a point if you don't have enough suppliies or the right weapons for the harder parts of the game, you'll have to make due on what you got and try to huff it out with cover tactics and have the weapons you can find. Thought it won't be a problem on boss fights. Since they provide the weapons and ammo crates to restock on beating them. Since you can't carry 50 RPG rounds like in the last game. You can only use 5 rockets at a time. Try drivng segments in the game feel a little bit dead without any music to play in the background. Could of sounded a bit lively with some tunes on the radio maybe? The multiplayer is dead. So don't bother with it. Unless you have some friends to play to level up to unlock stuff for your "My Digs" area. Which unlocks stuff you can mess around with in the area and unlock some of the mini games you could play from the single player game.
All and all, if you're a fan of Duke Nukem, you play this game. If you're not, at least try it out for the single player story mode. Which is just a mix of crude humor, killing aliens, saving the babes, and laugh out loud fun. But if you're someone who's afraid of naked women and find this game to be the worst? I have nothing to say to you and move on to something else better. I had fun with this game. Hope all yinz do the same.

I rate the game Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour 4/5. While generally very good (and you do not need to run DOS box or anything like that to get this game working), this 20th Anniversary edition would have been truly excellent if it had included all (or at least most) of the various other major add-ons and other content which has come out over the years (Including but not limited to: Lame Duke, Duke Caribbean: Life's a Beach, Duke it Out in D.C., Duke: Nuclear Winter, Duke Nukem's Penthouse Paradise, Duke Xtreme, Duke It's Zero Hour, and Platoon just to name a few) instead of attempting to appease fans with only a single new episode (Alien World Order) in addition to the four previous official episodes (LA Meltdown, Lunar Apocalypse, Shrapnel City and The Birth).
The new episode, Alien World Order, is still fairly good (with some mildly confusing level design here and there) though.With the minor graphical upgrades and the major control updates (it is now perfectly easy to control your movement and aim using the now standard mouse/keyboard configuration), Duke Nukem 3D has aged extremely well despite its now silly looking sprite-based 2 dimensional enemies.
The sound effects remain pretty good (especially those nice booming, echoing explosions) and the re-made Duke Nukem dialogue is at least adequate. The enemy AI isn't that bright but the level design and basic enemy design and enemy placement within the levels is pure genius, even (or especially) when compared to modern games, especially all the fairly linear ones which have come and gone since Duke Nukem 3D first came out. The level design is truly clever, often squeezing tons of action into fairly confined layouts without usually feeling cramped (unless the game wants you to feel cramped) and often forcing you into some still fairly unique tactical situations.
While Duke Nukem 3D is a fairly linear game, it is not unusual for the levels themselves have multiple paths to reach an objective (usually a switch or a keycard to unlock a door). Also, as in the original versions of Duke Nukem 3D, every single level doubles (and often works fairly well) as a multi-player map and the hardest difficulty 'Damn I'm Good' functions as a hard difficulty intended for cooperative gameplay through the single player game wherein most of the enemies will come back to life a few seconds after you kill them. You can also play against computer controlled bots but their AI is extremely rudimentary and unlike in Unreal Tournament, playing against bots gets boring fast.
Still, the various multiplayer features (cooperative and player versus player) cause the replay possibilities to be quite impressive, especially compared to many other modern single-player oriented games. Duke Nukem 3D was clearly famous for a reason. It's a shame that you pretty much have to plan to play this game with someone you know as there are never any active rooms in the multiplayer lobby. Not very many people are still playing this game. It would have been really cool to have the option to do a Borderlands style "open" playing mode wherein random people could jump into your game and interact with you (hopefully cooperatively) on the extreme off-chance that someone does happen to be playing at the same time you are, but sadly this feature is not present.
The game's music is probably the Anniversary Edition's weakest point. While the music is a passable imitation of what an average-to-good sound card could have done with midi files at the time Duke Nukem 3D originally came out, the music could have been made to be far better. On Youtube I have heard re-mastered and re-orchestrated versions of every single one of Duke Nukem 3D's songs from all 4 original episodes which blow every single song in this Anniversary Edition completely out of the water (I'm not sure what's happened but most of the remastered song versions I'm referring to have been taken down from Youtube since the time I was listening to them a couple years ago). However, the versions of the songs included with this game are simply mediocre and their general lack of high quality seems lazy. Duke Nukem 3D has some musically excellent songs. Including classic versions of songs would have been okay but there should have been an option to turn on totally remastered music and help give some of the better Youtube musicians some official recognition in the process (whevever they are now, if they could be found).
To conclude, Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour is currently the preeminent version of this game which you can buy. It is good, works fairly well and has fairly few bugs and good, modern FPS controls. You do not need DOS box or any other hokey retro-ware to make this game run. It runs like any other normal Steam game. It runs at my monitor's native resolution of 1920 by 1080 with no problems and did not look distorted either. It's brightness seemed neither too dark nor too bright. The developer commentary is only present on certain, specific levels and is not particularly detailed though (a definite let-down).
Unfortunately, this Anniversary Edition is also currently the ONLY version you can buy. It's good but it has a lot of room to grow. It BEGS for additional DLC content in the form of all the various old add-ons that have existed. The old Megaton Edition had the first four episodes (but not the new Alien World Order episode but it did have a whole bunch of the various old add-ons that are now no longer available. The removal of the Megaton edition and replacement of that version with this altogether smaller, more limited version has understandably angered a LOT of fans and has mildly frustrated myself. I really love how well this version works but I hate how woefully incomplete this version is in terms of content. The people who play this game 20 years after it came out are usually going to be the biggest fans. It would be an obviously good idea to give them as much content as possible, even if the price ends up being quite a bit higher.

I really don't know how this happened. Actually I do know. 3DRealms shouldn't have even given Gearbox a chance. To debunk the arguements defending Gearbox, I'll go through them one-by-one.
Defence 1: It was in development hell at 3DRealms.
True, but that was with 3DRealms, not Gearbox. They should have taken their time.
Defence 2: Gearbox received a broken product/build.
That's not an excuse. They're a supposedly "AAA" game dev. If you get something that's broken, take the ideas you like, start from the ground up, and make something that isn't half-baked.
Defence 3: Most of the mechanics fans of the old games hated were included in the "game"/build 3DRealms gave Gearbox.
Hypothetically, let's say that's true (not sure if I beleive that, but let's say it is). That's STILL not an excuse. If the game has been out of the public eye for so long, it would take only a little common sense to just do some light research into Duke Nukem. Even with LIGHT RESEARCH, you can plainly see that Duke is abut a copius amound of guns and violence. It would have also been easy to include some fans in the testing phase. If the fan testers saw regen-ing health, limited guns, and severely linear maps, they would have cried foul.
A personal gripe I have is how they handled Duke's attitude. Duke Nukem is supposed to be a blatent hedonist; he likes smokes, beer, guns, and beautiful women. When 3DRealms handled this, they showed it in moderate amounts that the player ran into via the places and people Duke encountered. Yet another release of the classic Duke Nukem 3D for use with modern Operating Systems and very well done.
New Duke voice by the one and only Jon St. Jon with new one liners as it advertises adding another bonus for a full playthrough.  There is also the option in the menu to use the old Duke voices if desired in case you aren't a fan of the new ones for whatever reason there may be which is also nice.
The graphics enhancements are also a nice addition to the 20th anniversary and look pretty nice.  I myself disabled these graphical effects so I could enjoy the retro look while playing and also just to point out you are not forced to have the new look and can play with the old-skool look if desired.
Some complain about the audio being of low-quality.  I purchased the game while knowing there are Youtube comparisons between this and the Megaton version and a side-by-side comparison makes this very apparent, but... When I loaded up and was expecting this low-quality disappointment I was greeted with decent sound as I played and did not sound anywhere near as bad as what it seemed from internet videos and reviews.  I suppose it is also possible that the devs may have improved this prior to my downloading it recently.  Even if not and you haven't purchased it yet, THE SOUND QUALITY IS NOT ACTUALLY BAD!
Some complain about the mouse.  All I am going to say to these folks unless this bug was again fixed by the devs prior to my aquiring this version of the game... I don't know what they are or were talking about.  I had no problems with mouse control and it felt just as good as it did in Megaton edition.
The only complaint I can give to the 20th anniversary edition is at times there are buttons, switches and keycard activators that will require you to find the "sweet spot" before the use reticle will activate it.  I don't know what causes this, but it does not happen often.  When it does, I just align the crosshair slightly over buttons and press the quick kick to activate the button or switch.  When it happens with the keycard doors and elevators it is really annoying because you can spend a whole minute moving forward, back, sideways and turning while repeatedly hitting the use button before it finally responds.
Other than the aforementioned issue the entire game runs well, doesn't have any crashes (that I know of), stays true to the original, adds an extra episode (Alien World Order) as a bonus, takes up less than 500MB for a game with enhancements and extras and is fully enjoyable to play.
One other thing I almost forgot to mention which I really enjoyed was the snapshot save feature this version has.  If you are playing for a while and find yourself dead and haven't saved for a while, don't worry because this game saves your progress every so many seconds while you are playing and you can return to any previous point of the level you were at before with all your exact progress at that point even if you didn't manually save.  HOWEVER, do be sure to make a manual save BEFORE YOU QUIT as this feature only works while you are playing and the game is running.  Extremely cool, nevertheless!
It was even more worth the sale as I discovered especially since I grabbed my copy while it was on sale.  Definitely worth the purchase!  Despite what others are complaining about with the sound and mouse, at least as of late June of 2018 from whence I purchased it, these two things can be ignored and the game is well worth it!

Duke Nukem Forever is an action-based first-person shooter. Players take control of Duke as he navigate through a series of levels which take place on Earth. The game allows players to interact with various in-game objects, including urinals, water coolers and whiteboards which allow players to draw their own images. The gameplay is similar in some respects to the first-person shooter games of the past, with each level culminating in a boss battle in which Nukem has to fight and kill Battlelords.
Unlike in the previous games, Nukem can only hold two weapons at any one time in a manner similar to the Halo franchise, although Pipe Bombs and laser tripwires are considered inventory items and as such are not limited by this restriction. Items that have an effect on Nukem can be picked up by the player; these items consist of are steroids, beer, and a Holoduke. Steroids increase the strength of Nukem's melee attacks by a great deal for a certain time. Beer makes Duke much more resistant to damage, but blurs the screen. A holoduke creates a hologram of Duke Nukem that looks and acts in a very similar way to Duke, but often says slightly different versions of his one-liners. While the holoduke is in effect, Nukem becomes invisible and the AI characters do not recognize his presence. The Jetpack also returns, but only in multiplayer.
Instead of the health system featured in the previous Duke Nukem game, in which health would be depleted when Nukem was injured and would only increase upon finding a health pack, drinking water from fountains/broken fire hydrants or using the portable medkit special item, Duke Nukem Forever employs a system involving an "ego bar" similar to Duke Nukem: Manhattan Project. The ego bar depletes when Nukem is attacked; once it is fully depleted, Nukem is susceptible to damage. If the player avoids further damage the ego bar is restored, as is Nukem's health. The player can increase the size of the ego bar (thus increasing the amount of damage Nukem can take) by interacting with certain items throughout the game (for example, a mirror), and by defeating bosses. The game employs a saving system that is solely based on checkpoints.

This bundled re-package of one PC gaming’s technological pioneers is the perfect little game to be picked-up by anyone fishing for the nostalgic sweet spot or for anyone looking for a high quality glimpse of some of the best pre-2000 First Person Shooter content you’ll find available for purchase today. Featuring the original four campaign episodes, a full multiplayer “Dukematch” fragging-contest mode, an optional lighting and environmental rendering upgrade (which, incidentally, looks amazing), and a whole new level pack from original designers, titans of the industry, Allen Blum III and Richard “Levelord” Gray who also provide an all-new, in-depth commentary track to the maps which will surely pique the interest of any oldschool Duke fanboy.
The singleplayer combat feels just like it was back in 96’ – movement is fast and fluid, with top-speed run-and-gun feeling so refreshing after the recent industry standards of grindy shoot-and-loot and wall-cover mechanics burdening the player who might rather be using their own ability and shooter intuition to navigate alien-strewn levels instead. The basic story of the super-macho protagonist repelling a hostile space-alien invasion is an effective framing device to transpose the gun fun into a myriad of settings, starting out your roaring rampage in an earthquake-prone Los Angles wherein you acquire a private arsenal of guns, explosives, and fantastic space-age weaponry to turn on the invading hordes of lizardmen, terrifying giant flying Lovecraftian octopuses, literal mutated pig-cop enforcers and hulking behemoths of level bosses.
For all the nine-thousand pounds of weaponry and ammo on your person at any given time the game surprisingly manages to add an impressive amount of variety to the whole affair with much of the game’s second chapter taking place on occupied space stations and lunar bases before a massive bossfight on the alien command ship. During this chapter’s eleven hugely sprawling and atmospherically tense levels, Duke becomes the lone hero in a completely hostile environment, faced with unfamiliar locales and much more directly powerful enemies, you can take to crawling through airvents and looking for hidden circuitous routes from which you can make effective use of sneaky guerrilla tactics involving freeze-, and shrink rays, triggerbombs and tripwire mines to thin the alien ranks before a direct confrontation, especially on the harder of the game’s four difficulties, wherein a “Battlelord Overseer” might make mincemeat of you the second you open the wrong door.
The game continues past this point with another episode evidently designed with the philosophy of pushing absolutely every aspect of the 3D Realms Build Engine, with colossal fights with whole enemy armies amidst towering cityscapes all filled with explorable interiors and filled with secret pathways to the level exit. The original three campaign episodes round out with larger and larger onslaughts against the alien menace before a fittingly apocalyptic showdown in an arena brimming with weapons to use against the “Cycloid Emperor” himself.
However, this proves to be only a new beginning for the Duke as he can now traverse another level pack which originally debuted in the surprisingly obscure ‘Plutonium PAK’ expansion, which returned the series to the more horror-esque environments seen throughout the series which more challenging levels and the introduction to the strongest enemies to be seen in the franchise. That was, more or less, as far as Duke Nukem entered the sphere of gaming for some time with only a few re-skinned level packs from out-of-house developers and a tonne of generally sub-par fanmade shovelware packs before the long-awaited 2011 sequel was unfortunately panned by critics, received poorly commercially, and seriously destabilised the brand.
This re-release may however signal a change however, as the brand-new eight level episode exclusive to the 20th Anniversary displays the passion that the original designers-developers have for their creation decades later. Completely backed up with original talent including an all new soundtrack and dynamic score from composer Lee Jackson and the true voice of Duke, Jon St. John. Good things are finally coming back to this iconic series.
Once you’ve played through the story to your heart’s content, try out one of the multiplayer modes which have all been revamped especially for this release. Available in co-op mode for a team-based approach to levels so you and up to seven friends can speed through maps leaving a trail of alien bodies in your wake. Or, for those seeking a competitive twist to the classic formula, try out the “Dukematch” deathmatch mode to see which of an array of inexplicably re-coloured Duke clones can score the most frags against one another in a predetermined time limit, or who can reach a preselected amount of kills first. Either way Dukematch (which can be slayed solo with a team of highly competent bots solo) is some of the most-intense, highest-octane, fast-paced fun shooter gameplay I’ve ever seen, and it’s definitely something more games these days would be better off taking some pointers from.

This game isn’t for everyone, it’s known for having a purposefully “immature” sense of humour, and while there’s nothing wrong with that inherently, it will put people off, and the risqué portrayal of the game’s iconic scantily-clad women has raised some eyebrows and stirred up controversy in the past, while the best blood and gore sprites MS-DOS could provide are now almost campily quaint, this is still a decidedly adult game. Nevertheless, if you can pick this up around sale time like I did, running through the levels old and new while listening to the previously-unheard developer’s commentary and sweeping up a light and breezy roster of Steam Achievements is a great activity for anyone still chomping at that nostalgia bit.

So here's what I think, for whatever that's worth. If you can put aside the 13 year development cycle (and all the baggage that's associated with that), "Duke Nukem Forever" really isn't terrible. It's not great by any stretch, but its playable.
I can put aside the dated pop-culture references, the virtually non-existant plot, and the "ok" gunplay. What Duke really suffers from is a lack of identity (and load times/short levels). At its core, it really does feel like a succesor to Duke 3D. You can see Duke 3D's influences through out, whether it be by level location, weapons, one-liners, or paper thin plot. But digging a bit deeper, this game clearly had an identity crisis durring development; whether it be through abrupt tone changes, weird and sometimes poorly designed physics puzzles, or bizzare "mini-game" sections.
All that said, if you are a fan of Duke Nukem and you're willing to let go of the "controversy" surrounding its development, I would reccomend you pick this up when its on sale. As of the writing of this, I would hesitate to say it's worth $20 at this point. I would also say, I actually think (surprisingly) "Forever" is now far better after some time has passed since its initial release.

There will be two sides to this review: Duke 3D as a whole, and what 20th Anniversary brings to the table. So let's dig in.
There's this notion that the design of 90s shooters is outdated and that praise of them is largely propped up by nostalgia. However, for me I can say that is definitely not the case. I didn't play Duke 3D in the 90s, or even the 00s. It wasn't until 2010 that I played it for the first time, and I can say that it absolutely held up.
Duke 3D is a massive callback to pop culture, with an abundance of references to everything from Star Wars and Die Hard to Doom and cult classics like They Live. Duke himself is a charismatic one-liner spewing badass straight out of a cheesy 80s action movie. The whole game has this unique sense of fun, wit and charm about it that makes it great to come back to, whether it's taking down pig cops and other alien slime, or kicking♥♥♥♥♥in a burger joint, a supermarket or an amusement park. The everyday locations combined with an otherworldly menace really go well.
The gameplay is of course solid. The Build engine brings fast and frantic 90s action with some new additions like an inventory where you can store items like jetpacks and portable medkits. The gunplay is satifying, giving Duke the kickass arsenal you'd expect from him, including a powerful rocket launcher and a shrink ray that shrinks enemies and lets you squash them.
With that out of the way, what's new in 20th Anniversary? Well, you have the new campaign by some of the original level designers, a rewind function, and developer commentary. The new campaign is alright, although there are some major missteps like the final boss being a joke, and a truly bizarre new enemy that I don't think meshes well. I never used the rewind function as I'm used to quicksaves, but it seems to work as advertised. The dev commentary consists of Valve-style icons that you walk up to and activate. They are included in old episodes as well, but only in certain levels.
The big thing that sucks about this edition though is that you don't get the expansion packs (Duke it Out in DC, Nuclear Winter, Life's a Beach). Sadly only the Megaton Edition has these, and it's no longer for sale (officially).
Overall, if you're new to Duke 3D or maybe are only familiar with the abysmal failure that was Duke Nukem Forever, definitely get it. If you've played Duke 3D already, get this depending on how big of a fan you are, whether you feel it's worth the cost ($20 is steep for one episode) and how you feel about Gearbox/Randy Pitchford.

Well, it took me 7 years to try this game despite being a huge Duke 3D fan as a teen. When it came out it just didn't look very exciting, and it generally got bad reviews so I stayed away. But being a Duke fan I knew I had to play it eventually, and now that it's dirt cheap and we don't get that many single player shooters anymore, the time is right. And well... it's your typical 2000-2010 era scripted linear shooter with action set pieces, easy environmental puzzles and multi part boss fights. It's painfully by the numbers in that respect, and for some reason 1/3 of the game is literally an arcade driving game.
So why the recommendation? It's short enough where the level design doesn't get tedious (just bare through the slow start and boring mid game strip club sequence), most of the time it's actually interesting to see what they will throw at you next. There are also some highlights that rise above the mediocrity, like when Duke gets shrunk which exhibit some very clever level design. Shooting aliens also generally feels good, and I thought the new versions of the Duke 3D classic enemies like Pig Cops were well recreated. If you also like Duke 3D as a character like me you'll probably get kick out of the voice lines too, I genuinely laughed a few times.

So in conclusion stay away if you are looking for an original FPS, well written story or characters, or expect a Duke 3D sequel that actually plays like Duke 3D, because this isn't it. But if you are good with a linear, short single player fps experience where you get to blow up some aliens and listen to Duke say funny dumb♥♥♥♥♥♥ you'll have fun.

When it comes to first person shooters, the most groundbreaking games in the genre undoubtedly came out during the 90's. This time period was truly the golden age for the genre, releasing a ton of classics in the genre that laid the groundwork for much of today's titles in the genre. Wolfenstein 3D started it all but then we got titles like Doom, Rise Of The Triad, Blake Stone and eventually a game would come out that really carved its own unique place among other so-called "Doom clones". With its groundbreaking engine, impressive amount of interactivity and one-liner spouting titular action star protagonist, Duke Nukem 3D managed to create quite a few ripples in the gaming community despite the incoming Quake which would make its technology look a generation behind in comparison.
I practically grew up with Duke Nukem so the character holds a very special place in my heart. The very first game I remember ever playing was the very first Duke Nukem, an EGA platformer for DOS that was a really popular shareware title around '91. Already then Duke Nukem was established as a gun-toting badass who was Earth's only hope. In the first game he went after the evil Dr Proton and his army of Techbots, and while his personality was a bit derivative and referencing pop culture like watching Opera Winfrey show, it wasn't until Duke 3D his personality as a woman-loving pill-popping ultra-macho amalgation of 80's action heroes came into play. And in a way, Duke grew up with me. When Duke 3D came out I was about 8 years old and just about to enter my teens and with Duke 1 being my first game, it felt as if the character had grown up with me. I was always interested in a lot of typical boy stuff at that age, watching a lot of movies that I wasn't allowed to, playing games I wasn't allowed to and generally showing more and more of an interest in the kind of masculine entertainment that there was a lot of when I grew up. And a lot of it really influenced my tastes and shaped me to be the person I am today. I of course also liked feminine stuff, I hung out with other girls a lot, played with dolls and did all of that stuff, but I was also into guns and shooters and such things, and always have been. And something about the Duke Nukem games almost embodies all of those core interests. There's a dystopian and almost cyberpunk future feel to the games, and this carried on very well into Duke 3D although it has a distinctly more realistic feel than the first two games.
The story is pretty simple. After returning to Earth after defeating the aliens in Duke 2, Duke finds that another alien race has wiped out most of Earth's population and taken most of our women, and turned all the police into pigs. His mission becomes to wipe out most of the aliens on Earth and take the fight to their mothership in space, culminating with a battle with the one-eyed commander of the entire fleet and the alien queen in a bonus episode called The Birth.The story never takes itself seriously, with Duke at one point saying he'll♥♥♥♥♥♥down a boss' neck after killing him. And promptly does so. So yeah, it's not a huge story or anything but it's funny, works for setting the game's derivative tone and there's nothing really bad I can say about it.
Most of the gameplay revolves around grabbing keycards, much like in Doom, and reaching the end of the level. Interestingly a lot of the levels seem connected as you may seem parts of an upcoming level near the end of the current level and so forth, a concept that further evolved into the level structure of games like Half-Life. You also have babes scattered around a lot of the levels (particurarily the alien environments) who are trapped in vines. You can choose to mercy kill these poor women, though doing so will provoke the enemies and spawn in additional reinforcements. Of course, killing babes that are NOT trapped is NEVER okay and the game will punish you for this by spawning in enemies.
The most fun part of Duke 3D is the interactivity though and it's what truly set the game apart from its contemporaries at the time. You could blow up parts of the level (indicated by cracks in the textures), you could drink from fountains, use toilets, break toilets, drink from said broken toilets, play pool, oogle women, oogle yourself, you get the point. This helped a lot in making the game world feel real and believable in addition to the realistic level design. It was also one of the first games to rely somewhat on scripted events (something that would be greatly expanded upon in other Build games), with parts of the levels being restructured in a pretty impressive fashion, a great example being when Duke blows up a building in a level and climbs into the ruins, or creates and earthquake in another level to reveal more of the level. This kind of interactivity in the levels made the game feel much more alive and explosive than something like Doom and even Quake.
The game featured some pretty nifty lighting for its time, featuring light switches that could dynamically light up an area and coloured lighting that directly affected the player's sprite and everything around it. The developers really made sure to push as much as they could out of the engine and it shows. The screenshots in this review are from the latest version of the game which is the 20th Anniversary World Tour edition and it's probably the best looking version of the game so far.
Sound-wise the game presents some pretty cool MIDI tracks (in modern source ports like the aforementioned World Tour edition these have been remastered as ogg files) that have more of a rock feel to them than Doom did. None of the tracks aside from the main theme can really be called memorable though and most fall into the category of being pretty much background music. And of course, Jon St. Jon's portrayal of Duke is now legendary with the game's many one-liners being classic quotes even today, so not a single bad word about his performance. Although his re-recorded lines in the World Tour edition does lack a bit of their original punch. The weapons all sound really cool, ranging from the beefy shotgun and peppering chaingun to the satisfying explosion sounds makes the game a joy for the ears.
So a question remains, which version of Duke 3D should you get? Well, at the moment there is only a single version available and that is the World Tour edition. It comes with re-recorded lines from the Duke himself, improved graphics, as well as some rather lazy developer commentary (and most of it coming from Randy Pitchford himself, who isn't exactly popular among Duke fans nowadays), but for the most part is kind of lacking as it does not include the 3 expansions Duke It Out In DC, Nuclear Winter and Duke Carribbean: Life's A Beach. It does however include a new fourth episode which is worth playing. The earlier Megaton Edition did include these expansions and multiplayer but lacked some polish, especially on consoles, and the original DOS version was included as part of 3D Realms' Anthology pack but this pack has since been discontinued as well as the Megaton Edition, since Gearbox claims to own the IP and won't allow 3D Realms to release any of the original Duke Nukem games (which is highly ironic considering 3D Realms gave birth to the franchise...). So that's a kind of sad affair altogether. However due to how well the game has sold it's not hard finding physical copies online on places like eBay (which is where I bought my own boxed copy) and most of these physical copies work fine with DOSBox so however you obtain the game, it's definitely worth playing, cause even 22 years later, Duke Nukem 3D is still one of the most badass shooters in existence. I mean, it may seem a bit dated today but when this game came out, there was simply nothing like it.

This is what happens when you screw with the wrong man's planet! Duke Nukem is a badass ruthless alien-killer, and when his planet is invaded by space aliens, he goes through the city and kills them all, one by one. This game is 3D realm's take on the popular first person shooter, Doom, which captivated the world with its violent, but innovative first person gameplay. The thing I like about this game in particular is how it took the first person aspect and innovated it even further. In Doom, the player had the inability to jump or to look up and down from viewpoint; 3D realm would rectify that in their game. Duke can run, jump, look around his surroundings, and punch in a few one liners (which by the way, are quotes from various movies). The enemies themselves are all so well-designed, they don't look like typical bald-headed aliens you'd see in Roswell, or something; they look very menacing. The game features three Episode, all set in different locations. In Episode I, you fight the aliens in the city of L.A. In Episode II, you go into space through different stations and bases. Episode III is where you're back on earth and you fight the aliens in various locations. If you own the Atomic edition, you get an extra episode where you fight an Alien Queen. Now Since, this is the 20th Anniversary Edition, the game also features the option to play the game with inhanced HD graphics as well as a new fifth episode, where Duke goes on a world tour, so to say. Overall, this is a game I recommend to any FPS lovers out there. It’s not your typical everyday shooter, it’s unique in its own way.
