Includes the original three episodes, the fourth "The Birth" episode that started being included with Duke3D releases starting with Atomic, and an all new fifth episode exclusive to this package that was made by the original developers. This new episode also includes new music by the original composer, a new enemy and a new weapon. What's missing compared to previous packages are the three licensed expansions: Duke it Out in D.C., Life's A Beach, and Nuclear Winter. It also doesn't include the N64 or PS1 versions of Duke Nukem 3D, but no bundled release has done this yet (though the since cancelled Android collection was planned to include these and be the first truly definitive version - with the major downside of it only being available on Android). This collection is also missing the shovelware unofficial and unlicensed map pack collections, but those were extremely low quality and I only bring it up to mention they aren't here.
This release also includes a developer commentary mode which, when enabled, puts hovering interactive voice files all over the game that can be used to get more insight into the history of Duke Nukem, as well as some insights into the development of this release. There is also a "Playback" mode that can be enabled or disabled. When enabled, this allows you to rewind to any earlier section in your playthrough on that mission, so if you don't want to need to spam saves throughout every mission, or routinely forget to save and end up losing progress, you'll want to leave this on. It's worth noting this game doesn't autosave, not even when starting a new mission, so you will still want to make hardsaves.
Has some pretty brutal input lag which is caused by vsync, which can't be disabled in-game. You can however disable vsync by forcing vsync off through your GPU's control panel. Once you fix the input lag issues, this version controls the best as far as official releases are concerned, however the mouse control still doesn't feel as tight as what can be experienced playing the original in eduke32. It isn't reading the input as well for some reason. The Megaton version that has since been pulled from Steam had worse mouse input issues of its own that never got resolved. It also used an OpenGL renderer, as opposed to putting the game in a new true 3D engine, which is what this version does. You can turn on SSAO, and you can also switch between the classic and new engine with the press of the "C" key. The immediate difference is that the FoV has been corrected, and there are more light sources in addition to an improved lighting engine to make the game world look less flat. The improved lighting is nice visually, but also has the side effect of removing some of the game's tension, since a few areas that were once dark are now clearly lit.
I didn't play this version at launch, but have read that this release used to use different sounds than the original. That must have been addressed, because ever since I've been playing this, it sounds the same as the original. The sound effects and music don't seem to have as much depth as they could though. Duke's lines have been re-recorded with the same voice actor to get more audio depth to the old recordings - as well as having some new lines - but if you don't like the way the new lines sound, you can turn on the "Legacy Duke Talk" option, which lets you use the original tracks.  Some of the sound effects (mainly the alien noises) still have a lot of distortion to them, it was this way in the original as well so it's hard to tell if this was intentional for an effect or audio clipping that occurred and they never went back to fix it.  Either way it's really obnoxious and should have been fixed for this release, although it would have required re-recording those sound effects to be properly addressed.
Has an integrated game browser for coop and deathmatch multiplayer support, up to 8 players in both cases. I've never been able to find a game, so can't comment on multiplayer beyond the mention. It does allow for you to do offline vs bots (no coop with a bot however), but that gets boring fast.
This is a classic 90s shooter. You don't regenerate health, and starting with the "Let's Rock" difficulty you'll need to find at least some secrets in order to keep from regularly running out of ammo, and if you want to go above that, you'll likely want to be playing with a guide to ensure you get every possible pickup along the way. "Damn I'm Good" is Duke3D's version of Doom's "Nightmare" mode where enemies respawn, so the difficulty I would recommend playing on if you want a game that gets your pulse going without getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥shoved in for not being a master of the maps is "Come Get Some". "Let's Rock" is a little on the easy side. I want to say the levels start off simple and become increasingly mazelike as the game wears on because it's true, except that even the early levels can no longer be considered "simple" by modern standards. The vast majority of levels are non-linear. Most of the levels are fun to explore, but there are going to be times where you'll feel incredibly frustrated because you've been running around in circles and can't figure out exactly what to do next. Thankfully in this day and age that can be alleviated by alt-tabbing to a browser (or bringing up the same through a Steam overlay) and quickly discovering what your next move should be, but it is still worth noting that the 90s map design can be a little too obtuse for its own good at times. For the most part, the open maps are a lot of fun to play. They will just take you more time to get through than most modern shooters because there is a lot more to chew through in each mission.
The main issue with the missions that end up getting frustrating is that it's hard to see the switches you need to press to cause something to change in the level to allow you to proceed.  They end up blending in with the textures on the wall, it's been that way since the original and has been this way in every official release since.  There's an HD mod that addresses this, although it dramatically changes the rest of the art style and whether or not this is a positive is going to be up to personal taste.  Although purists may say it would be wrong period to have any sort of change to the original assets, I do think the gameplay could have been significantly improved in this release if they had done something to make those switches stand out more against the general textures they are sprayed upon.  In most cases this could have easily been solved by making the switches a higher resolution than the rest of the assets, and while this would conflict with the rest of the game's presentation, could have been something to toggle on and off through the menu as an ease-of-use option.  I would gladly play with it on if it were available, just because the main reason I ever got lost in Duke3D was due to having no clear path forward, and the way to generating that path being accessed by finding and activating one of these unintentionally far-too-well hidden switches that blend in with the textures.  Again you can just google to figure this out most of the time, but a simple change like this would have made that unnecessary and saved a lot of frustration.
I recommend this because despite missing the three licensed (but unofficial) expansions, the mouse input not being as good as has been seen in Duke ports in unofficial engines (though still very playable once vsync is forced off), and several sound effects still having distortion/audio clipping issues, this is the best official collection that has ever been available. If all these issues were fixed, this would easily be a 9/10.  If they had done all this and also included bug-free, hi-res, multiplayer supported versions of the N64 and PS1 takes on Duke3D, making this the truly definitive all inclusive "World Tour" version of Duke Nukem 3D, this would be a perfect 10.  As it is, it's an 8.

Okay so basically this game is awesome, but not without a few valid complaints.
It's a remastered(even more so than the Megaton version) version of Duke 3D. It looks even better than the Megaton version although you'd be hard pressed to tell the difference unless you're looking at a comparison or you've played the old game for countless hours.
What's awesome is that the original level designers came in and made a whole new episode( 8 levels) and each one is a real treat. They're really, really good and apparently would have been impossible to make and run on the original engine. There was a lot of work put into this new episode. I personally found it to not be that hard on the "Come Get Some" difficulty like I've heard of other reviewers complain about, but maybe that's because I play so much Duke that I'm used to it. Its got tons of boss enemies in level which I personally have a huge hard on for. I love nothing more than firing away on those large and detailed 2D monsters for what seems like hours until they die.
There's even this really neat commentary feature where, when turned on you have these speakers that you walk up to and if activated will trigger an audio clip of them talking about making that specific part of the map. It's really, really a lot more interesting than it may sound.
They even give you the option to choose whether you want to listen to the original Duke dialogue or a new version re-recorded by Jon St. John. Not that he's the biggest chatterbox but as a big voice acting nerd I eat this stuff up. There's a new soundtrack for the new levels and it's pretty bada** as well.
There's some other features like a reskinned version of a different gun made to be a flamethrower. It's moderately fun to use I suppose. Now when you die you have this unique rewind bar where you can rewind back to any spot you want. I suppose it's alright.
Now what I don't really care for is how, after Duke's right's were tossed back and forth they ended up in the hands of Gearbox. Now I like Gearbox, but they've done some stuff with the Duke property I really don't care for. Mainly not letting a small indie company release an AMAZING full 3D Duke game(the story is complicated but that's the gist) and deleting the Megaton version of Duke 3D off of steam which included all of the original expansions which I hear are hard to find and are extremely expensive to buy the original versions of(luckily I bought the Megaton Edition long before its deletion). And this World Tour version does not have any of those expansions. Who knows perhaps they'll be DLC later on.
All in all it's worth buying without a doubt. It's got the original classic game with The Birth thrown in, it's got the cool level designer commentary, and it's got an 8 level pack made by those original designers that I think is worth the price of admission alone. If you like super large levels filled with personality and plenty of boss and mini-boss enemies to fire at, you'll love this game to death!

I suppose it’s prudent for me to review this game, given my handle, and how Duke Nukem was one of the reasons PC gaming has stuck with me since 1996. The Megaton Edition isn’t available on steam anymore and it’s been replaced with the 20th Anniversary World Edition, which includes a never before released campaign from the original designers and audio commentary, both of which are quite enjoyable. I wish more 90s games released audio commentary with a re-release. Allows players to get a feel for how the game was designed and where a lot of those weird references come from.
The game is still excellent. I’m not sure why people are complaining this is a horrible port. It’s a fine port. And all the content from the Megatron Edition is included in this game.
I can understand why some people got upset over the re-recorded voice work. This is equivalent to people who dislike the Star Wars Special Edition, and want the ORIGINAL work from the ORIGINAL game. That’s understandable, but if you’ve never played the ORIGINAL game you won’t even notice.
There even a new weapon introduced, the flamethrower, which you can use in the new episode which takes you to London, Paris and Moscow. Pay close attention to those levels and turn on the audio commentary if you can. You’ll learn some interesting facts about the design of those levels.

Of what I played from the new episode in World Tour before returning it, the new levels don't contain the same type of flow as the original Duke 3D episodes, and are more liner, with large enemy dumps to progressively clear out of each next area. So, I found the new episode's style to be less engaging.
I think that Megaton is still by far the best Duke 3D release, and that it's a tragedy that it was removed and replaced by World Tour. Hopefully, Megaton will be re-released, or otherwise a presentation that matches the Megaton edition will be released, some day.

Don't listen to those who've only played an hour or two. This is NOT another "modern", front-loaded game that shoots all of its bullets in the first quarter of the game. This game shows its true beauty over the course of the campaign. Much of the greatest stuff only comes after the second hour.
That said, it has its downsides. These are the things you should consider before buying it:
- Don't have high expectations because the predecessor was a seminal game. This one is not. It's still a pretty good game.
- Also, don't have high expectations because it took forever to be developed. That doesn't mean all those years went into actual full time development. Also, don't expect it to be like the 2001 trailer.
- the graphics are a little basic. But in 4k in 2018, it's still quite beautiful. Some areas have a Doom 3 feel to them. And the game doesn't have any post-processing effects - so you can see every model and texture rather clearly. Personally, I wish more games would still used that style.
- also, probably due to technical constraints, the game is essentially a series of mini-levels. It feels like a bunch of short stories, each with their own little plot. Some of these mini-levels are more puzzle focused (non are hard), some jump n run, some shooter, some action-sequence and some have a weird idea at their center.
- again, it is not front-loaded. The best mini-levels come after the first 2-3 hours. Also, the "The doctor who cloned me" dlc is pretty good.
- it's very scripted. That's not equally obvious in all levels. There are also a lot of nice larger fighting arenas - but they too tend to come in the second half of the game.
So if you'd like a reminder of the good old shooter days, with some modern elements to it (no medkits) and are willing to give this game some time to win your heart, you might just enjoy this.

Duke 3D is a classic game that still plays great today.  Unfortunately, this port is horrible.
It's a shame because the true 3D rendering, colored lighting, and ambient occlusion go a long ways toward making the game look a bit more modern without sacrificing its classic look.
20th Anniversary World Tour has two absolutely crippling issues.
First, VSYNC is forced on, and there is some kind of mouse acceleration or something in effect.  Disabling VSYNC in Nvidia Control Panel helps a lot, but you are still going to be faced with laggy mouse controls.  When the game plays perfectly through eDuke or even in DOSBOX, there is no reason to put up with input lag.
Second, the ingame music plays back in MONO for some reason.  The music files themselves are stereo, so I have no idea why this is.  This frankly makes the music annoying to listen to, like it is playing through a little radio on your desk.
Another issue (though minor) is that none of the expansions are included, even though they were included with the Megaton edition previously available of Steam.  I don't mind this so much as I never liked any of them, but it's a bad move indeed to release an updated version of a classic game with content removed.

Many people bash Duke Nukem 20th Anniversary World Tour as being inferior to the earlier re-release of the Megaton Edition that was pulled from Steam and is no longer available.  I've played them both and I feel that the 20th Anniversary World Tour is the better of the two and here's why.
1.  The World Tour version doesn't come with the Duke it out in DC, Life's a Beach and Nuclear WInter expansions or map packs or whatever they are.  I've played those three map packs and didn't like any of them as they didn't seem to fit with the Original Duke Nukem 3D.  The new maps are sort of interesting when looked at thematically as a whole, but overall they are boring.  The individual maps are huge. which sounds great, but it sucks because it takes freaking forever to cross them even at a run and there is nothing really interesting to see.  So they are  long, boring and tedious.  I was happy not to see them in the World Tour version and especially liked that I didn't have to play them for achievements.
2.  The World Tour version comes with creator commentary that you can turn on in the options.  When turned on, you get floating icons throughout many of the maps that you can activate.  When activated you get audio recordings from a couple of the original creators of Duke Nukem.  It was super cool to hear their thoughts and such concerning the making of Duke Nukem 3D.  Their commentary ranged from in-game jokes and pop culture references used in the game to reasons or thoughts as to certain creative decisions to coding or visual techniques that they used in the map making process that were actually quite difficult but look so simple and could easily be taken for granted nowadays.  I found the technical commentary to be very insightful.  Hell, I found almost every piece of audio commentary very interesting.
The commentary in the game easily made the purchase of this version of Duke Nukem worth the price I paid.
3.  The third and final thing that made this a superior version was the new episode built by the original creators who did the commentary for this edition.  It was easily one of the better episodes and "expansion."  The maps easily looked like something made by the Duke creators.  The new episode had the same feel as the original Duke Episodes even though they were able to use newer lighting techniques and improved visual assets, most of the Maps were super creative.  The first and final maps especially stood out to me, but all of the maps in the new episode are great.
The World Tour version of Duke didn't appear to have OpenGL rendering.  While many people may have liked that in the Megaton Edition, I was fine with it not being in the 20th Anniversary World Tour Edition.  There was a setting for improved graphics and I thought it was quite good.  It keeps the pixelated style graphics, but used smaller boxes/polygons so that it looked close to OpenGL rendering, but wasn't and I actually preferred it as it felt more like the original Duke than the OpenGL rendering did.
Probably the best feature was the "rewind" ability.  While you could make save files during a level just like you always could, which is useful if you are going to exit the game midlevel, the rewind ability was great assuming you started the level without leaving the game in the middle of the level.  The game records the player's progression through the level so that if at any point you were to die, a rewind function appears on the screen that allows the player to back up to any point in the level or something before the death and allows the player to try a different strategy,  The player can backup even to the beginning of the level.
The rewind function was pretty awesome since there were swaths of time where I would forget to save the game and end up dead.  The rewind ability just allowed me to backup 10 or 20 seconds (or more) and redo the section without dying.  There was even a couple of times I actually ran into an Easter Egg where Duke would say something, but I couldn't hear it because I was listening to one of the creator commentary tracks, so I would pull out my rocket launcher and kill myself.
The rewind ability popped and I would back up a bit and continue.  The game recordng would also note I was listening to audo track so the track would continue playing where I backed up to; I'd let the commentary finish and then walk up to the Easter Egg so I could hear Duke's Joke.  Super Cool!
The only annoying thing about the 20th Anniversary World Tour was when I was playing the game in Full Screen, if I Alt-Tabbed out of the game, the game would automatically disable Full Screen mode go into windowed mode.  Once I was done with whatever I was doing outside Duke Nukem, the only way to get back to full screen was that I had to go back into VIdeo Options inside the game and turn full screen back on. Duke Nukem 3D: The Name Of This Game Is Too Long is a replacement for the excellent Duke Nukem 3D: Megaton Edition which was removed from digital distribution.
Duke Nukem 3D: The Name Of This Game Is Too Long (aka Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour) isn’t a bad game. If you like Duke Nukem 3D you should like World Tour.
The thing is some parts of the world are missing from ‘World Tour’. It doesn’t include the expansions: Duke Caribbean: Life's a Beach, Duke it Out of D.C or Nuclear Winter.
I doubt these will ever be added (officially). And if so it would likely be as paid dlc.
The game does include one extra episode Alien World Order.
Which takes you to Amsterdam, Mosow, London, Egypt, Paris, the Golden Gate Bridge San Francisco and then the Hollywood sign.
These new levels look nice with a lot of details. But the enemy placements arent so good. There are a bunch of mini-bosses for no reason. Exploration in these levels aren’t so good either.
There is a new weapon the Incinerator. It can be very satisfying when you’re able to hit an enemy with it.
There are new enemies Firefly Trooper. They are able to shrink themselves which make them annoying to hit. They are armed with incinerators.
Lastly you have the boss Cycloid Incinerator. A red reskin of the Cycloid Emperor. But instead of a rocket launcher he has a flamethrower.
Problem is he has the same AI as the Cycloid Emperor. So he uses this short range flamethrower thinking he can hit me from a distance which he cant. Makes him very easy to kill.
There is also Steam Workshop.
There is a rewind feature which is good, so when you die you can just rewind a bit. It does help with the frustration of accidentally dying and losing progress if you had forgotten to save.
But the game still has a manual save/reload feature.
There are graphical improvements such as “true 3D”. But you already had free mods such as EDuke32 that greatly improved the graphical rendering of Duke Nukem 3D.
And sometimes true 3D makes the game look worse in some areas.
The Megaton Edition looked/sounded better. And had more content.  World Tour has a lot of aliasing (jaggies). The new recorded lines for Duke sound awful at times. Thankfully you have the option to use his classic lines.
So World Tour is really nothing impressive.
It’s a low effort replacement for the Megaton Edition.
I made sure to only get this game on sale, at a heavy discount.
Im giving this a Positive review, not for World Tour, but more for Duke Nukem 3D which is just a great game. Id give World Tour a Mixed review if I had the option.

What can I really say about Duke Nukem that hasn't been said before? 20 years of extraterrestrial butt-kicking, curvaceous babes and cheesy one-liners from a 'roided out protagonist who is the very definition of machismo. Seems like it all flew by in an instant, eh? I've loved DN3D since I downloaded the shareware version when I was still a precocious lad who was probably too young to be playing a game with such mature themes. I would whole-heartedly recommend it to anyone who enjoys prime 90's first person shooters. Great controls, innovative level design, big powerful guns that feel great to use against the numerous foes you encounter. Everything you want in an action game is here.
If you don't already own it, stop reading right now and buy the damn thing. You won't regret it!
For those of us who've been playing for the last couple decades? This particular rerelease, while very good in its own right, isn't completely essential if you already own the game multiple times on multiple systems. There is so much that this latest iteration does right, yet there are certain cons offsetting the pros that make me hesitate to say that it's the definitive version, Despite the minor nitpicks, if you're a hardcore fan of the series, there is enough new content to make it worth your time if you can get it at a good price.
The main draw and reason to purchase this version even if already own the game in another format is the brand new 5th episode, "Alien World Order". This provides 8 new levels set in various locales around the world, designed by Allen Blum III and Richard 'Levelord' Gray, who both worked on the original game. I found all but one of these levels to be very fun and a great compliment to the existing 4 episodes. While they are technically more advanced from a design perspective in some ways, they still have that great old school 3D Realms feel and blend in nicely.
Besides simply getting new levels, this new episode includes additional dialogue for Duke Nukem. Jon St. John returns as the voice of The Duke, with plenty of fresh and funny one-liners. He also did retakes of all his classic lines in a higher sound quality than was possible in a `96 MS-DOS game, so it matches seamlessly between the old and new. I was glad to also see an option included that reverts to his original lo-fi performance if you're a purist. I tend to favour the rerecording for the improved sample rate and consistency, but it's worth pointing out that Jon St. John's inflection and emphasis on words is slightly different in places. Try both versions and see which you prefer.
The last of the new content comes in the form of the "Firefly" enemy and it's associated flamethrower weapon. Some of you will recognise both of these from early screenshots taken during the development process, yet neither made it into the original retail game or the Plutonium Pak. Their inclusion for the 20th Anniversary was a great way to honour the history of the series, while simultaneously giving us something we had not previously experienced in-game before. While I think it would've been interesting to reintroduce even more cut content from the beta versions, this new 5th episode already delivers a great "never before seen" Duke experience just the way it is.
While the new episode is definitely worth playing; there are a couple gripes I have about the overall presentation of the old content. The menu system is streamlined and works well, yet I miss seeing the logo exploding onto the iconic box art when the program starts. I also felt that the gamma correction could've been a little more flexible. I play most of my games using a projector and even with "brightness" set to highest level, certain areas are still too dark. The in-game text also now uses a stencil font instead of the classic fonts from either v1.3d or the Atomic Edition.
The most glaring issue lies with the audio. Certain sound effects like the chaingun cannon firing are very harsh and have too much treble. Others, like the ambient sound of the alien spaceship in E1L5 "The Abyss", were entirely too bass heavy and were abusing my subwoofer. Music has been mastered at a very inconsistent volume with some tracks being so low that they are almost inaudible and others being overpowering at times. Fortunately, the renderings of the classic MIDI songs themselves are quite good, sounding similar to how they would on a Roland SC-55. For someone with decent audio software and a knowledge of modifying Duke 3D; these issues can be corrected and I have done this to my installation, but most people are not that hands-on.
My final point of contention is that while the new episode is indeed enjoyable, there is a bunch of content and levels from previous releases that were not included in this 20th Anniversary package. Unfortunately it does not include the levels from officially sanctioned add-ons such as "Duke it Out in D.C.", "Life's a Beach" and "Nuclear Winter". We also do not get the episode "Plug 'N' Pray" from the PlayStation 1 release, but that is obviously much less of an issue since that was never originally released to PC.
Overall, it's still Duke and it's still great. Despite already owning the game many times over on various computers and consoles, this is the version I probably play the most. Hopefully my review has given players who are familiar with past releases of the game some insight into whether it’s worth an upgrade, or if it would actually be a slight downgrade from the version they’re already happy with. Despite the few issues that I detailed in this port; Duke 3D is a true classic that has stood the test of time better than most. See you all in another 20 years for the 40th Anniversary Holoduke Edition!

Bought the game as a pre-order in 2011, extremely disappointed back then cause I went into it having the PS1 Duke Nukem games fresh in my mind. Somewhere near the end my safe file corrupted and I could not bring myself to start it over again until 6 years later.
Now, with an unbiased mind, I actually really enjoyed this game! Is it a good "Duke Nukem game"? No, it doesn't capture the essence of the classics but those were different times too and things from back then wouldn't translate well into nowadays. The amount of things to do, mechanics and minigames is astounding and none of the mechanics like the monster truck or shrunken parts overextend their stay.
Something that could annoy others, which rather impressed me, is the amount of detail that went into lighting, in a lot of areas the game is just dark enough for you to need to use Duke Vision to fight properly and seconds later need to switch it off because a light source just came into play to blind you with DV on.
Unfortunately it plays like your run-off-the-mill FPS game from 2011, 2 weapons, regenerating health, guns feeling really flat. Would have rather had the option to hold way more different weapons with a lot more ammo like in the old games to mix it up more often (at least the game provides fixed spawns of different weapons constantly)
Maybe enable the option that lets you hold more than 2 weapons. I didn't enable it, it was fine, but running out of ammo was a bit of a problem as not all enemies drop their weapons for ammo and a few weapons having abyssmally low ammo capacity. The character was obviously supposed to be the strong suit of this game, so if you're not into toilet humor and such things you probably won't enjoy.

DNF took 33 hours to complete the main game three times on Easy, Hard, and Insane for 27 hours, and the expansion dlc the doctor who cloned me I beat twice on Hard and Insane for 6 hours, note that the first play through on the dlc was about 4 hours and the second time even while on insane only took 2 hours – once the ways is known its a breeze.
Ive always considered Duke Nukem to be the Punisher with a sense of humor – Dukes personality can seem quite shallow, but it is not – it is simple. Indestructible confidence with a nonchalant persona that considers allies and humiliates enemies, with some chuckles for all, for or against you. Dukes presence was missed: I played the game three times more to remember Duke Nukem than to experience the average fps content, in a way this relic of the past points out the flaws of the “emo” super heroes and heroines of todays standard. Just like Doomguy from the Doom series, Duke Nukem doesnt just get the job done, he starts the fricken party.
While DNF got alot of smack talk when it came out, the hype for it  was worse than the game itself. DNF was good overall, Id rate it for an fps game about 6 /10, its an average fps game with nothing great but nothing bad. I like games where Im shooting aliens, and mutants, and creatures other than humans, and DNF gives you that, aliens, octabrains, pig cops, pregnators, and more – also an interactive environment to play around with but you dont waste all day fussing with every item on the desk (Prey).
DNF represents the Duke universe well, it has many interactive items you can fidget with and use like throwing items playing casino slot machines etc – and it doesnt break the pace of the game.
After two playthroughs the linear levels can get boring, the interactive items sought after for achievements are usually passed up and what made the first playthrough so fun is now  known and fleshed out. The variety of weapons is fun, the added option in the menu to make a 4 weapon inventory helps, try it once with the 2 slots and you'll find it wasnt that bad as people talked about on debut.
I did not have any performance or graphic problem on the main game or dlc. The multiplayer as of April 2018 had 4 server at prime time evevings USA and nobody was playing. The MP has enough maps and a few different modes to get you through the challenges and upgrade your character and mansion, but people have to be playing. The multiplayer is nothing special.
Duke Nukem Forever on sale is a deal, expect 7-8 hour of gameplay value and some incentive to revist it a few times, the dlc is worth it at sale price also. Enjoy Duke Nukem for the unusal but satisfying hero he is – now go save earths women and tear out some alien eyes and pi-ss on their brains!

Duke Nukem 3D World Tour contains five episodes.
Regarding the old content, the four "Original Episodes" were all fun to play. "LA Meltdown" and "Lunar Apocalypse" kept me on my toes with engaging map layout, useful weapons and new enemies to blast. "Shrapnel City" was overall fun as well, but I did not feel it offered as much as the previous two episodes. I got the most enjoyment out of "The Birth" . It included some fun level ideas and my personal favorite of the boss monsters.
The game does not include any of the other expansions/level packs which is mildly disappointing.
The New Content included a fifth episode that was decent at best for me. In comparison with the previous four, it felt more like an extra or "dessert". The maps are fun on their own. The fire fly enemy while interesting felt very underwhelming and, in my opinion, unfinished. The "New" Boss Monster (besides being a blatant pallete swap) was pathetic and seemed far less fun to fight than any of the previous four boss monsters. The new weapon works fine but like the other content, felt underwhelming and rushed.
Overall I had fun with this game, but I will not deny it has its fair share of flaws especially with its new content. I recommend you buy it on sale if you are a fan of old 90s first person shooters with a B-Movie vibe.

A lot of people say this is the inferior version to Megaton Edition. Well, I've played Megaton Edition, let's see what we have here with Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour.
Let's start with a simple list of pros and cons.
Cons :
- The Absence of 3 unofficial expansion campaigns. (Not entirely, will elaborate);
- Price 19.99;
- You will give money to Gearbox, which does questionable things at best (like pulling Megaton off the digital shelves).
Pros :
- New sound and rerecorded Duke Talk (which procs more often I think, there is Legacy as well though)(some are not sold on the new sound);
- Fifth Episode made by Duke's original developers, along with a new weapon and enemy;
- True3D (Supposedly it makes the game better looking, and it does, but when you look up and down it has this weird zoom and I get a headache, so now I keep it off usually, but it's there.);
- Rewinding death feature, no more quicksaving and reloading! (I gotta say, a thing this simple adds a lot to the fun and immersion).
- Out of the box controller support
- Megaton is unavaible to purchase.
Duke3D is an old game per sé and unless you're a die hard fan, I don't feel the price is justified compared to what you got in the Megaton edition (which was at half price); that said, when at a sale, I highly recommend it to people like me, that got late to the party and want to own a registered version of Duke 3D.
You might or might not consider it inferior, but this is still a good version, I like the new Duke Talk, I like that it supports a controller out of the box, I like the time rewind feature, I'm having more fun with this than the Megaton edition (I wanted to own Megaton, but it was already unavaible when I decided to give Duke3D a try). I heard people saying the new sound is lower quality and the new Duke Talk just doesn't sound like him, but I think they're fine, I actually prefer the new Duke (which of course is always voiced by John St John). The True3D, which is a mode you can toggle even in game, is very neat, at first I liked it a lot, but I realized that it does this weird zoom, especially when you watch up and down near walls, and it gives me a headache, so now I play mostly with it turned off.
You have your workshop, which you had in Megaton as well, your multiplayer, but since this edition can only grow and the other you can't find a legit copy (except grey markets, which are not totally legit and are going to finish stock at some point) I would go with this one.
Speaking of workshop, a guy is releasing the levels of Duke it out in D.C., one of the expansions that was missing from this version, so that's very neat, kudos to you mister! Maybe we'll see the other expansions as well, I surely hope so.
As far as the exclusive fifth episode goes, I haven't played it yet, but the general consensus seems to be that it's nothing to write home about.
All in all, I got it at 66% discount, and you know what? I don't regret buying it, I like it and I'm having fun, so it's a thumbs up for me, come get some!
I even nominated it for the " The “Cry Havoc And Let Slip The Dogs Of War” Award", because I feel like a badass playing as Duke kicking alien butt.

EDIT: I rebought this title once it went on a -75% sale as the new episode is really awesome, but this doesn't change anything I had written before - I still consider this to be an unpolished release and still rate it negatively. Read below for the original review.
=============================================================
TL;DR: I am very disappointed with this version as Megaton Edition simply provided a better end-user experience.
The first thing that hit me was input lag on my mouse. I saw that the number of frames per second was equal to my monitor's refresh rate so I figured it has to be the fault of v-sync being on. The problem is - no such option is available in the options menu. I forced v-sync off in my video driver's settings and the input lag disappeared. However, my video card instantly became significantly louder as it started rendering the game in several hundred frames per second and again - there is no in-game option to limit the number of rendered frames. So what's so bad about it? Both options (v-sync and FPS limit) were available in the Megaton Edition...
The next thing I saw was a lack of texture filtering. This means we are bound to see the game pixelated, which looks out of place coupled with the enhanced lighting. And again - Megaton Edition had texture filtering options...
Another flaw is the unresponsiveness of the mouse wheel when bound to inventory cycling. Sometimes you have to scroll the wheel a few times just to cycle ONE item. It works a bit better with the v-sync turned on... but then I have the input lag back! And yup, you guessed it, in Megaton Edition it was working fine.
After experiencing the above problems I ran the new episode, and I have to admit it is really good and enjoyable - it was made by experienced people and it clearly shows. It's just that the first impression was so bad I don't want to play it anymore.
The problem is - World Tour is the only officially available edition right now, which is still being sold. If you don't already have Duke Nukem 3D in your collection, then maybe it would be a good idea to buy it. Alternatively, you can look for a key for the Megaton Edition at 3rd party sites, as it is no longer officially available. The Megaton Edition does not contain the new episode (Alien World Order), but instead has three unofficial expansions (Life's a Beach, Duke it Out in D.C. and Nuclear Winter), which in turn are unavailable in World Tour (which is a puzzle to me). As for other, new features in this release - such as rewinding time after death, or developer commentary - I didn't really bother with them. The enhanced lighting is nice, but I saw it before in a fan source port EDuke32... which also has texture filtering (unlike World Tour). Proper 3D is also cool, but its lack never really bothered me in the first place as far as this game is concerned, so it's not a saving quality by any means.

I was playing Mafia, trying to finish it to play this one, ripping my hair out while I was at it, because that freaking game can sometimes be quite a pain in the bum.
Either way, I've played enough Duke Nukem 3D to offer an opinion about the game, and I've played enough of this version to offer my take on it as well.
For starters, Duke Nukem 3D is simply a masterpiece of a game, one of those games similar to Doom, that won't age in the least, there might be some trouble traversing some levels, but these are games ingenious enough to secure their own replayability through the learning curve they also offer to the player.
Duke Nukem 3D its also a game that masters the craft of what I like to call "the flow of combat" in videogames often times you find yourself in the middle of combat, dodging attacks, switching weapons, using each of your abilities/powers to your advantage, and sometimes, just sometimes, it works as if everything "fits" as if every weapon was made for an specific situation, and yet you never really derive awareness of when you have to use any of them, you simply do, naturally.
Now as for this version, this implements a wonderful system that allows you to, similarlly to a tape recorder, go back to whathever point you where prior to your death, it might not sound as much, but for a game like this, I can assure you it's a game changer, and an incredibly benefitial one, blowing yourself up with your own rpg doesn't present that much of a trouble anymore.
The graphical changes at first seemed subtle, but luckily, and astutely the developers assessed this by giving you the ability to switch from the remastered graphics, to the old graphics.
It's quite a substantial improvement that luckily doesn't sacrifice the essence of the overall aesthetic.
Now for the problems.
They changed for whatever reason the way you change weapons with the mouse wheel, effectively ruining, "the flow of the combat"...
Luckily you can still use the numbers in your keyboard, so there's that.
Sadly v-sync its also, always enabled, and sadly, not implemented very well, the game has some horrendous input lag, and there's no ability to disable it in-game.
This similarly to the last issue, can also luckily, thankfully, be bypassed, by forcing v-sync off in your control panel.
So there you have it, overall for the price I've paid for, which I also did whilst on a sale, I really enjoy the implementations, and the changes, I wish for a v-sync option, that I know, sadly, will never come, I also wish for a way to disable the silly, and tedious mouse scrolling problem.
But I recommend it nonetheless thanks to its new features.

A very poor substitue for the now defunct Megaton Edition. Gearbox, after obtaining complete control of the Duke Nukem liscense, quickly whipped up this inferiour product for the anniversary of the game.
It's awful.
The engine itself has several bugs, not the least of which being it never seems to remember when it's supposed to be full screen. It always starts up windowed, even when full screen is chosen, forcing you to disable and renable it every time, and even then it's a crap shoot that it will actually work and go full screen.
The engine seems to run smoothly enough, which it should given that it's a twenty year old engine that's been very slightly modified. But the controls are a joke. No option to change the quick save/load (saving and loading has no confirmation, and you can't even make custom save names, just the default "SLOT 1", "SLOT 2" etc.) [Edit: One new engine feature, the ability to go back to any earlier point in your playthrough of the level before you died, does mitigate the need for the quicksave/load buttons, and is a nice feature to have], and I can't set anything to the side mouse buttons, 4 and 5. Which is where I prefer to have my Big Foot automatic kick melee attack.
On top of that, the Megaton Edition came with three of the DLC packs available for Duke Nukem 3D, of varying quality. None of those are available here. Instead, we get a brand new 5th chapter. And Steam Workshop support. The latter hosts several maps that are either ripped illegally from other packs, or converted from other games.
Duke Nukem 3D was an amazing game when it came out. Megaton Edition was a fantastic, well modified engine that ran wonderfully on modern systems. This is a pathetic soulless cash grab. The only thing it has going for it is colored lighting, and even that could use some improvement.
That's enough about the engine.  So what about the GAME?  After all, to make up for the mission expansion packs, they added a whole new episode to the game.  Well, a smaller episode.  The theme is decent enough, and the first level shows some great tricks in it.  You're going from location to location across the globe.  The new enemy is somewhat frustrating, since it's pretty versatile, with several ways to hurt you and some ways to avoid damage.  The new weapon is quite fun, a modification of the freeze gun just as the microwave gun was a modification of the shrink ray.  The levels themselves overall aren't bad.  The music is awful though.  It just doesn't sound appropriate for Duke Nukem.  Nor for the levels you find yourself in.  More voice lines were added, and some older ones rerecorded.  I think I prefer the originals, but the new stuff is decent enough.
It's not worth the full price though.  It's barely worth the sale price.  Especially if you were lucky enough to get the Megaton Edition.

At first, I thought Hail to the King Baby we finally have another Duke Nukem game! However, with 15 years in the making, I’d have thought this game would be perfect. But after playing it’s left me with mixed emotions towards the game and here’s why:
Pros:
♦ Voice Acting is some of the best I’ve ever seen (Every character, every NPC, pretty much if it has a mouth it has a voice actor. This is amazing and video games of today could learn something from this as voice acting is a major feature video games overlook or don’t include for some reason, but the voice acting in Duke just makes the game 100% better)
♦ FPS Elements on point (The first person shooter elements are on point, like if you overlook the bugs, annoyances, glitches etc and just purely look at the FPS elements, you can see they are pretty decent)
♦ Boss variety and battles are bosstastic (The boss fights are some of the best I’ve encountered in games. Every boss is unique and challenging making them a great aspect of the game)
♦ Duke Humour is bang on (Like the classic Duke games, the humour is still 100% bang on in this. If you like nothing else in the game, you can still appreciate the Duke Humour which makes Duke, Duke, in the classic Duke games)
♦ Achievements are actually achievements (By this I mean that the achievements give you a sense of actually achieving something unlike some games where achievements are just handed to you as you play)
♦ Nice weapon variety (There is enough different weapons to keep the game interesting)
♦ Minigames inside of Duke are excellent (These are things like, air hockey, whack-a-mole, pinball, hoops, gym etc. These are all gems that just work amazingly, especially pinball which could have been a stand-alone game on it’s on)
♦ Storyline is enjoyable (The storyline to this is enjoyable, nothing spectacular but nothing boring)
♦ Multiplayer apartment customization based on Dukes multiplayer level is a nice concept (Nice concept, except for multiplayer being dead)
♦ Graphics are good (They are not spectacular, but they are good. Could be better here and there but can’t complain)
♦ Money’s worth (If you pick this up on sale you’ll definitely get your money’s worth in hours played. I played 15hours to beat the game which at full price is just over a dollar an hour)
Cons:
♦ Doesn’t have Steam Trading Cards (This isn’t a major issue, just would have been a great addition to Steam to have some backgrounds, emotes, badges etc from one of the most loved video game series)
♦ Slow and repetitive at times (Parts are very slow and repetitive due to walking to numerous places only having to walk back the way you came later on. Also, some ideas and concepts for levels are the same over and over. For example, when in the Monster Truck there are numerous levels where the main goal is to find gas and re-gas your truck, this happens more times than it needs to)
♦ Walk here do this walk back (Annoying specially in the part where you are shrinked for the first time. It's so slow and annoying, really there isn't much fun content in this part)
♦ Mini car buggy (Whilst shrinked at one stage you hop in a remote control car and if you didn't keep the car, you have to die to realize that you still needed it as you spawn in it upon revival. This makes the game annoying as the game doesn’t tell you that you needed to keep the car until you had no-where to go except dieing)
♦Default keyboard controls are weird (This can be seen for example when four weapon mode is enabled. The keys are annoying as by default weapon selection of each weapon is bound to the number 1 key or mouse wheel. However, you can bind a key to each weapon in the control options. IMO, there should be a default setting that has all four weapons set to a key as having it set by default to one key makes it hard to quickly switch between all four weapons with the keyboard easily and quickly. Thus said, switching with mouse wheel works slightly quicker and easier, it's still not ideal. Hence you have to map the keys before you play with a keyboard which again, IMO, shouldn't have to be the case.)
♦ Pipe Bomb auto throws (This concept is annoying as it makes it hard to use the pipe bomb as you can't select it and aim as, as soon as you hit the button it throws it)
♦ If you die enough a part will seemingly become easier (This is annoying as it defeats the challenging aspect. I died like 3 times at one area and then some enemies seemingly didn't spawn... I was looking forward to beating that area...)
♦ Hive Part 2 glitchy (I found this part really glitchy with some enemies not spawning, doors not opening when they should etc)
♦ Can't skip some cutscenes (Annoying as we should have the option be able to skip them if we want)
♦ Alt+Tab out and back into the game causes mad FPS drop (This is weird as sometimes when I alt+tabbed out of the game and back in my FPS would be really low. However, if I kept alt+tabbing in and out, eventually my FPS would rise again and go back to normal. Weird glitch that shouldn’t happen)
♦ Dying at a checkpoint respawns all boxes and items (This makes the game way too easy, if you get a checkpoint and have no ammo you can die and everything will respawn including holo dukes etc, this makes the game way too easy at certain parts)
♦ Game froze and crashed at one point (Refer to:
For a game that took 15 years to make, this is inexcusable)
♦ Ending cinematic sucked (Worst in the whole game. For a game that took 15hours for me to finish playing only to end the way it did made me annoyed. I was expecting something bigger, more awesome and enjoyable to finish off the game. After 15 years in the making, I think they could have made a bigger, better finale for the game)
♦ Multiplayer is dead (This is to be expected but multiplayer looked enjoyable until you realize there are only like 4 random people at most playing it)
♦ DLC is expensive (I say this as one of the DLC’s is almost the same price as the original game and all it adds is Multiplayer content to a Multiplayer that is 99% dead… why pay $13 for a DLC for a dead Multiplayer?)
Overall, I’d give this a 5/10. With that said, there are a lot of cons and slight glitches, bugs and annoyances that show the game is unpolished in areas that it shouldn’t be with a game that has taken 15 years to produce and make. Therefore, I feel if you put the cons aside and look at the pros, there are still decent FPS elements and the typical Duke humour still hits home to the classic Duke games. Thus, if you’re a long time Duke fan pick this up as you will get some enjoyment out of it. But if you’re new to the Duke series, I’d recommend skipping this and buying the other Duke games and then if you love them to check this out as Duke Nukem Forever isn’t a starting point to get into loving Duke. Also, I’d recommend waiting for it to be on sale for about $3-$5 and not paying full price for it.
PS: If I could give this a neutral rating on Steam I would.

Duke Nukem 3D is a great game that doen't need a introduction. Almost every gamer has heard about this game and it's seen by many as one of the best first person games from the 90's. This is the first time I have actually played the game (I tried the megaton edition but the controls were off, can't explain what it was. It was unbearable for me.) It stands the test of time really well (unless you're a social justice warrior). The levels are well designed and reward exploration by having a lot of secrets.
The game has a true 3D mode. This renders the game in real 3D (intesd of the original 2.5D engine). This improves the graphics, adds better lighting and removes the distorion of the original when looking up and down. A nice touch is that you can siwtch between the rendering modes by pressing a button. This allows you to see the improvements in the grapics at any time.
The Build endinge is used to great effect here. There are working pool tables, light switches can be toggled, movie projecters can be switched on and off and Duke can even take a look at the security systems. This version of the game contains 5 episodes. Episode 1-3 is great, although episode 2 has too many of the exploding dones. Episode 4 is tough but still great. Episode 5 was made for this version of the game by the guys who made the original episodes. And it is reaaly good. My biggest complaints about episode 5 is the difficulty and the boss fight. The episode is really hard. I spent most of my time with a health bar that was below 45. The last boss is also a big dissapointment.
There was also a few bugs. The game crashed once during my time with it. There is a wierd bug with the weapons selection. I switched to a new weapons and after firing one shot the game equiped the previous weapon. This happend a lot ( about once or twice per level) and evel ended up in me being killed. Speaking of dying, the game used a rewind system when you die. This is something I like, mostly because I am not used to quick saving (even in games like quake, I save manually) and would have lost a lot of progress if I couldn't rewind. It also allows you to get better times in levels. If I got stuck and took a while to find ou where to go next, I would kill myself and rewind to the point I began searching for the way forward. That way I didn't use a guide, didn't have to reapeat a level and still got a good time.
One thing that does hurt this game is that the expansions included in the Megaton edition isn't here. I hope that this will be added as DLC later. The game is great value for money and really fun. I would reccomend it to anyone who likes 90's FPS games (Although they probably have it), who want to check out one of the best 90's FPS games and anyone who like Duke Nukem Forever.

Have you ever seen the Mona Lisa? The Creation of Adam? The Statue of David? These are all considered to be timeless works of art, are they not? Perhaps you would think so, were you some sort of uneducated, classless troglodyte. Every single one of these said "Works of art" are a complete waste of time, resources and "artistic talent" when compared to the masterpiece that is Duke Nukem Forever.
Duke Nukem is the human form: perfected. His body is better than that of any Greek "God," his fashion sense is striking and simplistic. His outfit consists of a pair of timeless blue jeans, black boots, black shades and a striking bright red tank top. The red colouring on his top created as a representation of the fire Prometheus stole from the "Gods" of Olympus. Duke Nukem is the light, the energy and the life the fire brought to humanity given form in the shape of a glorious, butt kicking, one liner spewing millionaire hero.
Duke wears a pair of fingerless black leather gloves that bear the trefoil symbol. This logo is used to warn people of radiation. The symbol is placed there as a representation of the awesome, unstoppable power that his fists present, warning anyone close by that they can and will be utterly annihilated should they dare stand before him. His character design is no doubt thoughtful. I may even go as far as saying it is a work of absolute genius.
Upon the top of Dukes mighty head, his hair proudly stands. His golden flat top points upwards, thrust towards the heavens as a direct challenge to God. It at once questions the might of our so called lord through its defiance of his "laws" of gravity and acts as a reminder to anyone fortunate enough to bear witness to Duke that he is unquestionably powerful and unnaturally beautiful.
Duke has a flawless personality. He is charming, kind, funny and reliable. He roams throughout the world protecting the weak and vulnerable, signing autographs for children, complimenting women and dedicating his life to saving the planet from alien invasion. He is a hero in every sense of the word. And my God does he manage to entertain us with his heroics. I'm unsure as to how many times I've heard him reference "Porkchop sandwiches" in some way, but I guarantee I'll never get tired of it. His voice is like sweet nectar, flowing smoothly into my ears like warm honey into a hot drink. It sends shivers down my spine, I adore it. As does every single woman in the world, apparently. Duke is so beautiful that every human with ovaries lusts over him constantly. I can almost see Zeus now, looking down from Mt. Olympus, green with envy.
So, now that you know how amazing Duke is, how does the game stand up?
The game is flawless. It is amazing. I loved every single second of it and I promise that I will continue to love it for many years to come. The game has a unique system of health management. You see, Duke Nukem has such a deservedly large ego that it is actually strong enough to deflect incoming attacks. His ego can be increased through completing various tasks or minigames. The most notable of which is grabbing a turd from a toilet with your bare hands. This is satire at its most high brow. I wouldn't expect an individual of lower intelligence to fully grasp the concept of handling feces and the wider implications of such an action upon the world. Truly unbelievable.
The enemies of this game are an alien race made up of pig like creatures. This is smart, as it directly ties back to the numerous references Duke makes to various porkchop related foodstuffs. Genius wordplay, absolutely brilliant. Shakespeare would be quaking in his pathetic little boots were he not rotting in the ground like the miserable excuse for a playwright he is. Duke is the future, and moronic individuals like Shakespeare have rightfully been consigned to history, for they have no right to exist at the same time as Duke Nukem.
The gunplay is absolutely phenomenal. There are a wide variety of weapons Duke can make use of, all of which are masterfully designed, powerful and satisfying. My favourite weapon has to be the classic golden m1911. This weapon is a staple of Duke Nukem’s design. It’s golden colour a representation of opulence and beauty. The trefoil on the handle a symbol of power. Were Duke Nukem a gun, he would be this weapon.
The level design of this game is absolutely phenomenal. I admire how the developers made the levels as complicated as possible and gave absolutely no pointers to the player as to how to reach their end. In my opinion, this is a fantastic feature, as it means that all the low IQ imbeciles that would otherwise play this game are deterred to make way for the intelligent individuals to truly appreciate this wonderful game. The puzzles are well thought out and not at all overdone. The shrinking mechanic is used repeatedly in the game throughout multiple levels. I’m glad the developers repeated this mechanic so much as it is incredibly entertaining, and properly shows off the ability of the developers to think on different scales to give the player a varied, exciting experience that won’t soon be forgotten. The valve puzzles would be good, but Duke says he doesn’t like them so I don’t either.
The driving sections are simply brilliant. I’ve played my fair share of driving games. Burnout? Dreadful. Forza? What a joke. DiRT? Awful. Assetto Corsa? Pathetic. Test Drive Unlimited? Are you serious? None of these “games” even come close to capturing the thrill of high speed driving. The monster truck in Duke Nukem Forever handles like a dream. And indeed you may feel as though you are dreaming the greatest dream of your life as you race through the desert. Speeding over the sand in your monster truck while flattening all manner of aliens and performing the same jump over and over. It absolutely does not overstay its welcome and is not at all repetitive or overdone. I’d play an entire game dedicated to the driving sections in Duke Nukem Forever. I live for them, I breathe for them. I’d marry that damned monster truck.
The boss fights are absolutely fantastic. These alien creatures of epic proportions stand before Duke like dominos before a raging tornado. They are big, they are ugly, and I guarantee Duke will mention this. You fight them using the explosive weapons in your arsenal. These weapons are powerful and exceedingly entertaining to use. They definitely do not have too low an ammo supply. Even if they did, there’s always an ammo box sitting nearby for you to use if you’re a moron who has absolutely no skill or tactical thought process. I suppose we’re not all perfect, are we? You finish off the bosses with a humiliation move. I’m fairly certain all of these moves involve genitalia in some way. How could they not? These finishing moves are the epitome of adult comedy and only serve to cement the intelligence level of the game and its writing. The finishing moves are always followed by some sort of one liner. However, they’re all so funny that I’ve forgotten them.
Overall, I believe this game may perhaps be the greatest one ever made. It’s far better than any of those other games people love. If you think that any game is better than this one, well… I’m sure your parents are really happy living a life pretending not to be disappointed in you. I’d give this game a numerical rating, but I believe it surpasses such simplicity. Such an elegant masterpiece cannot be rated, it can only be experienced and loved.

Not nearly as bad as some critics made it out to be when it came out. It's actually a pretty fun game that stays true to Duke's character and the playful, humorous nature of the series. You'll encounter all sorts of funny and cool things here and it's far from a dull "serious" generic shooter. However, not all is as great as it would suit Duke - the cardinal sin of the game is that it feels somewhat console-oriented - low FOV, bad mouse sensitivity, weapon limits, health regen, lots of QTEs, etc. This sort of design makes it a bit hard to take it as a proper "old-school" shooter that harkens back to the old times, when action heroes could hold a truck load of weaponry while sprinting without getting out of breath and used med packs to heal themselves rather than waiting in a corner to auto heal. But, if you don't mind this too much, you will find a solid and fun game here that doesn't take itself dead serious and is rather a parody of the FPS genre and what it (used to) stood for.

If you're looking for a hard, carbon copy original of Duke 3D this is not QUITE it, but very close.
Pros:
- Main game environment is still basically the same -- if not more polished -- as long as you turn off the extra 3D rendering/occlusion and use the "classic" HUD. Everything else was left exactly as it was.
- You can change the control settings if you're like me and once again want to play it how you did in the 90's, since some of the controls have adapted to a new genre of gaming.
- Not that I care for them much, but more levels to explore.
- All cheat codes from the classic have been preserved. So yes, mess around as much as your little heart desires!
Neutral:
- Music has been updated slightly. This won't bother some but I truly loved the grungy, bit-ty music from the original (although I guess it depended on your sound system.) Instead of the creepy, suspenseful music it's now become a little more upbeat.
- Not really a huge issue, but the text that appears in the game (like what you've discovered, etc) is different, I just don't feel like it meshes well with the environment/my old memories.
Con:
- There is an option to load custom maps. But no map maker included... so...
- No spinoffs included.
TLDR: Besides some nitpickery, there are no "real" problems in this release, and would still recommend for anyone that wants to indulge in their nostalgia.

Duke Nukem is back with new promising things. However, while the port is intesting, it's no match to the defunct Megaton Edition, which was wayyyyyy more.... eeer.... complete in terms of adventures you can play.
Duke Nukem 3D was released 20 years ago and was in the pure line of FPS back then. Duke Nukem was also a colorful character, interested in booze and babes, if you allow me to use the term often used in the game. Well, let's just say that some alien civilisation is invading Earth and kidnapping women to use them for breeding. Yeah, just that.
Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour has the four original episodes (L.A. Meltdown, Lunar Apocalypse, Shrapnel City and The Birth) and includes a new one: Alien World Order. And this is where the disappointment begins, because the Megaton Edition included other campaigns: one in a tropical paradise island that I really loved and another one in Washington DC, with many known landmarks. Unless the future of the game includes these episodes, I would say that the 20th Anniversary World Tour is already inferior to the Megaton Edition in terms of content.
You're going to say that a new weapon has been included in the last episode and I will counter back to you that while a flamethrower is nice, I didn't expect to have a new enemy that can do the same for you and that I never expected to have a sort of lava when missing my target and hurting because I've stepped in it.
As for the rest, it's still nice to have a mighty foot, to use a simple pistol, a shotgun, a minigun, a rocket launcher, pipebombs, a minimizer/maximizer, a ice gun (which can hurt you too), mine lasers (that I don't use at all), the Devastator. They can be used underwater, which is nice.
And apart the traditional armor, you can also count on
Enemies are still the same: you still have simple troopers, the pig cops, the minigun lizard that is quick to die with shotgun but not with the minigun, the octobrain, sharks (yeah, simple sharks), turrets and many others. The bosses are still hard to defeat (and guess what, the new one is using fire - new weapon, new enemies, everything has to do with fire).
But you know what's caught me a few times? The way to change my weapons. I don't know why it was so hard to do it but I ended up with the wrong one (or I can't press the right button or it's just that the little inventory with them felt slow to jump from a weapon to another).
I didn't really pay to the graphics: for me, they're the same. They didn't really change a bit from Megaton Edition. But well, I'm still in awe in front of the levels: the death row, the space station, the city and with the new episode, I really liked the fact that we were visiting some cities, like London, Paris and Moscow. And it's still a pleasure to discover restaurants, Duke Burgers or even a supermarket. Oh wait, there is also a kind of weird level where the hookah made you really high on drugs (or not). Really, it's still a pleasure to play these levels.
The soundtrack is nice but.... why put the default sound volumn so low that we can't really enjoy it? Is this for Duke to say his famous lines to which I didn't pay attention?
Another thing is the achievement. They're classic but I wish some of them were included. We have easter eggs about Luke Skywalker, Serious Sam (new episode) and the DoomGuy that are worthy of an achievement but Indiana Jones or even the Star Trek bridge aren't? And what about the Kurt Russell one? And why not to have an achievement about finishing some levels with all secrets discovered? And while it's nice to see an achievement about enemies being scrunched or incinerated, why not one about being iced and destroyed by the mighty foot? Or being blown up because of the maximizer? It would have been great to have more achievements.
I didn't try the multiplayer and I don't intend to do so.
If I have to resume my experience with Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversay World Tour? I prefer Megaton Edition. More content. For those who own it, the 20th Anniversary World Tour is only worthy of being in your library for the new episode, only when you have a discount. At 20 bucks, i don't feel like enough has been done - putting developers commentaries, a new episode, a new enemy, a new boss and a new weapon isn't really enough as I didn't see a difference in graphics or in soundtrack. I've still enjoyed the game, though I must say that my first experience with Duke was with Megaton Edition, so, there is no nostalgia trip for me.
Great then, great now. Nuff said.

The game engine itself has no improvements or advantages over the old JonoF port that came with Megaton Edition, or the eDuke32 port. If anything, some of the quirks and additions make it worse. The mouse control is a bit off and it seems as if Duke is trying to move through molassis. Using the mouse-wheel to scroll through weapons painfully slows down gun swapping because of the new mini-hud. These two effects combined makes in-game reaction time feel slow.
The original DOS game had no option to switch between auto-aim on or off. It was always 'on'. I recommend you leave it that way for this port or several weapons, particularly the pistol,  end up being frustratingly useless.
The Alien World Order episode is enjoyable for the most part. The maps are well designed, detailed, and constructed; with the exception of the final map, Hollywood Inferno. A few maps have odd enemy placement, as well as poor distrubution and location of weapons and healing supplies, with Hollywood Inferno being the worse offender of the lot. The incredibly easy final boss fight didn't help improve the perception any.
The anti-climatic final showdown, and only getting 8 maps instead of the traditional 11 that are in the original episodes, makes the overall experience merely good instead of great.
I'd recommend purchasing this, but only when it's on sale. Especially if you already own other versions.

The game itself is pretty good and I love the new level, enemy, and weapon. Not only do you get to play levels made by the original creators, but you can play levels made by other player that have been uploaded on the workshop or online. It's the  amazing singleplayer experience and modding community that make this game such a masterpeice.
But wait, it's not the game and gameplay that's the problem (it's a really good). It's the port that has the flaws.
The sad thing about this port of the game is that no one's playing the multiplayer. I eventually bought the game for my friend as a gift so we can play multiplayer, but the darn multiplayer keeps disconnecting!
The game also doesn't include the DOS version of the game (Duke Nukem 3D: Atomic Edition) or the expansions such as Duke Nukem: Nuclear Winter, Duke Carribbean: Life's a Beach, or Duke it out in D.C., which means this game has less content than the Megaton Edition which did include them.
I like the lighting this version of the game has, but the status bar and textures are still pixelated while the Megaton Edition had an option for smooth textures and a redone status bar. Maybe pixelated is nostalgic, but it would've been nice to have the option. Imagine playing with this with smooth textures and sprites, and a redone status bar, plus the games amazing lighting! That would be amazing!

After years of awaiting, the game's fate has been determined to be a controversially historic piece in video game history. Duke has taken the longest path to return righteously but ultimately serving audiences potential in moderately small doses.
