It would be easy to label Duke Nukem Forever as a bad game when it was released as well as in the present landscape when we have more true-to-form old-school FPSs like the Rise of the Triad Remake, DOOM (2016), and to lesser extents, the Serious Sam Games, Painkiller, and the Shadow Warrior reboot. If you examine it on its own as a modern-take on old-school FPS games, it's mediocre at best--and that is if you include The Doctor Who Cloned Me and PC version.
At its core, DNF is not faithful to the old-school FPS design philosophy; instead, it chooses to redefine Duke Nukem 3D in a modern age as well as reinterpreting what made the Build Engine so appealing to many people. The problem is with these changes they have removed too much complexity from the classic, and it’s only with the update on PC that added four-weapon slots and the Doctor Who Cloned Me comedic value that the game comes something beyond mediocrity.
If you recall the infamous moment from Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare of “Press F to Pay Respects”, then the problem of modern games like Duke Nukem Forever reinterpreting the interactivity in games becomes much clearer. As video-games have become more complicated in narrative, visuals, AI, etc. they have often forgotten to add the same complexity into actions, which on face-value shows simplistic it is for the creators to make a character express a complex action through telling them what to do and how to feel. That is ultimately the flawed foundation that DNF has built itself from.
What made the original Duke Nukem 3D games was not his character himself but rather how his character was expressed through the gameplay, and more importantly, the Build Engine. The Build Engine is perhaps the real cornerstone of Duke Nukem 3D more than Duke Nukem himself, and it’s what led to the beloved icons such as Lo Wang in Shadow Warrior and Caleb from Blood. It wasn’t the level-complexity and character of their weaponry that gave them life but more so how the engine allowed for a sandbox appeal with the levels from messing around with pinball machines, remote control devices, and small puzzles and secrets utilizing the open-ended levels of these games. Interactions worked alongside the combat, exploration and playfulness of these games that make them hold up to today’s standards because of how enjoyable it is to play these levels to find all its rewards.
DNF understands this well enough that it focuses exclusively on the interactivity as a reward for the player rather than making it a means of expression embedded with the level-design itself. At first, moments like the RC control puzzle harkens back to the same usage in Shadow Warrior Classic as it becomes a part of the exploration, yet the game slowly ditches these gimmicks to funnel the player through these arena-fights given ammo-boxes before each major encounter with only a few interactable means given in vehicle sections and non-combat areas.  As much as people complain about the EGO-meter and the way you increase it with fiddling with objects as small rewards, the concept does retain DN3D’s ideas behind them with more fleshed out mini-games than the simple press E to find secrets. However, the problem is not how these “secrets” are handled but how they are separated from the level design, resource management and enemy placement to add more character to the levels.
While combat was a major aspect of the original, DNF takes away all the complexity of scavenging for resources and the ability to create levels encouraging the usage of the player’s arsenal. Even with regenerating health, which isn’t as much of a problem as the original DN3D and DOOM games encouraged players to pop-and-shoot from corners for certain enemies/encounters, the design could have benefited had they not limited the player’s weaponry and streamlined ammo conservation into a minor inconvenience that is solved not by finding supplies but rather supply boxes. DOOM (2016), while having traditional health that can be refilled as quickly as regen health from its glory kills, shows that changes to the health systems do not have to be detriment of the old-school experience.
Before the Doctor Who Cloned Me update, players were limited to a two-weapon system which encouraged ignoring the more interesting, gimmick weapons like the Shrink Ray in favor of the weapons that provided more utility such as the Shotgun and Rocket Launcher combination. As someone who likes the idea of a two-weapon limit for certain games, such as Max Payne 3, there are games in which it hampers the gameplay to a fault. This decision mainly affected the practicality of the Freeze Ray, the new alien weapons, and left the weapons like the Ripper and the Railgun options for long-range fights provided there were ammo-boxes near the player. With the update, however, the player can make battles more engaging by having these extraneous weapons add more character to every fight and not rely on the same strategy in every engagement.
What cannot be redeemed is the simplicity of the level-design that is designed around a set-path forward with cutscenes and closed arenas for combat. Although the comparison is more of a parody than the actual game, the infamous 1993 vs 2010 level design comparison has some merit in the case of the two Duke Nukem games:
. Even in the cases of outside environments and the vehicle sections, the areas are more set-paths forward with an occasional puzzle to turn the player around to throw barrels to shift the weight for a typical seesaw and valve turning puzzle. If you can excuse this setback of what is a major part of the experience, then getting DNF with the DLC at a steep discount can be enjoyed for what it offers as it still plays as action-packed as the original with its own quirks and interesting levels like the crane area and the Duke Burger action-figure size level that reminds me of the spectacle found in Prey (2006).
It’s somewhat fitting that the storyline of Duke Nukem Forever casts him as a character out of place with modern times as far as him being a cultural icon in-game with all his fame proceeding his actions as the other characters criticize his heroics. As a character who began as a conglomeration of ‘80s/’90s action heroes, the set-up is fitting to make a game that works off his comedy as a trope himself. This is perhaps why I enjoyed The Doctor Who Cloned Me because it returns to the appeal of The Birth expansion of DN3D by having Dr. Protos Return with movie/game tie-ins to the level design and focusing on the comedy that pokes fun at the tropes like himself.
As a result of this one expansion that is somewhat shorter than the main experience, it’s easy to see how DNF could have been a great game for what it is had it been in the hand of more competent, committed developers, not outsourced to various developers with their own ideas. Unfortunately, DNF is perhaps the last game we’ll ever see for some timeas Gearbox seems content to squander his fanbase in rereleasing his one-hit-wonder along with adding Duke Nukem as a playable character in Bulletstorm. Perhaps Duke Nukem is relegated to end in obscurity, which isn’t due to him being dated in the modern landscape but misunderstood by developers who seem him only as an icon meant to be mocked or paraded around as fanservice to entice the die-hard fans to enjoy one more adventure with the King himself.
If Shadow Warrior and DOOM’s reboots have proven as well as the old-school inspired games like Serious Sam and Painkiller, these icons of old can stay relevant to modern gamers with changes made that stay true enough to the original. (Now where on earth is BLOOD’s reboot, Monolith?)

Duke Nukem Forever is a perfect example of an okay game that had the potential to be a great game. It is built around solid--albeit generic and boring--shooter gameplay, and relies heavily on it's protagonist, the embodiment of a cartoonish understanding of masculinity, and the raunchy and gratuitous world of babes and bad guys that exists solely to feed his monumental ego.
Story:
The Duke character, who is established as a virtually invulnerable and unassailable badass. It nails the invulnerable badass character, and the story around it fits very well, but I can't help but feel that such a premise is impossible to turn into a good story. The fact that Duke is static in his greatness makes him a dull character, and therefore the story falls completely flat. I couldn't care less about stopping the aliens and getting all the "babes" back, disregarding the occasional messages my d**k would send me. I can't imagine playing this game as somebody who doeesn't enjoy boobs, cause they're just about the only motivation the game presents to keep shooting people, cause god knows it isn't very fun.
Gameplay:
The gameplay was very diverse, and very ambitious; it goes from fast paced shooting, to monster truck driving, to goofing around in a strip club, to simple physics puzzles, to boss fighting, and back to shooting all in a very short period of time. There's so many different things to do in this game, especially for a linear shooter game, but as with most games with so many different things to do, none of them are really developed enough to be very good. Every aspect of the gameplay falls short of impressive, and therefore so does the gameplay as a whole.
For example, Duke Nukem Forever introduces the potentially very innovative shrink mechanic, where the player can shrink enemies and be shrunk, which creates situations where the player finds his/her situation drastically changed on the basis of scale. There's a part where the player finds himself shrunken and encounters full sized alien enemies. For a moment, it was very reminiscent of Shadow of the Colossus, and I felt very helpless against my giant foes. I found myself leaping on boxes and hiding behind appliances just to survive. However, I soon found that, as the story established, I am not supposed to be helpless; I'm supposed to be Duke Nukem, the unstoppable badass. It turns out that I was actually just supposed to shrink them and kill them the same way I always do.
This sort of thing happens with every new gameplay mechanic: sooner or later, I find out that it isn't really all that different from the core gameplay or simply isn't very well designed. For example, during the monster truck segments, I attempted to crush a car with my monster truck--as anyone would--and immediately affixed the small are between my tires with the hood of the car and was stuck. Later on, I discovered a forklift. Surprisingly, they actually gave me the ability to raise and lower the forks, despite the fact that the only purpose of the forklift is to slowly splatter enemies with it, regardless of how high the forks are.
Because the game has so many different parts, none of them are fully developed. The developers wanted to make a shooter game, but for some reason weren't content with the lack of sweet monster truck jumps and shiny t*ts, so they spent more time on stuffing the Duke Nukem Forever with extra sh*t than they did making the core gameplay unique or interesting. But, in the end, the extra sh*t proved to be a very much necessary break from the lackluster shooting gameplay. In fact, the game mixed things up enough for me to not care all that much about how uninteresting any individual part was.
In summation, it's not a bad game if you don't need a story. In fact, if shooter games are your favorite thing, play this game. You'll probably like it. Hell, I kinda liked it. I was just a little disappointed. The game fell short of it's ambition, but it's still very stable, in no way unplayable, and is pretty self aware. Probably.
Overall Review = 5.3

UPDATE: Nov 28 2016
Since the writing of this review, the following issues have been fixed:
Sound Quality has been restored to the original quality present in the DOS and Megaton releases.
Original Review:
Long time fan of Duke, figured I'd give this version a try despite owning the originals and Megaton edition, for the sake of comparing them.
This version is inferior to both the Megaton Edition and the fan-made port eDuke32. The sound effects in this version of compressed to an inexcusable degree. Everything sounds like it's underwater.
The newly recorded voice lines don't really carry the same feeling as the original lines, either. John St. John didn't give it his all in his performance and Duke sounds more bored than anything else. Gearbox were considerate enough to allow us to select the original voice lines, but like the sound effects and music they're compressed beyond belief.
The new graphics are kinda nice looking, but they're no better than eDuke32's "Polymost" graphics. In fact, they're basically identical.
This version of the game also uses the "rewind" system from Megaton edition, which I don't like at all. Basically, when you die, you're given the option to rewind the game to any previous point in your playthrough of the level. This removes a lot of the challenge from the game, removes all consequences for failure, and there's no way to turn it off.
The game has no option to disable VSync as far as I can tell, and the game has mouse acceleration enabled with no way to disable it. There is also no way to adjust the FOV. All of these features were present in the Megaton Edition.
Also, and this is the most damning thing, this version of the game includes none of the game's expansions, with the only reason given being a smarmy "those aren't 20 years old yet :)" from Randy Pitchford. Megaton edition included these expansions and their exclusion here is inexcusable. The only feasible reason that they were excluded was so that could be sold later as DLC.
All in all? Don't buy this version. It's inferior to the Megaton Edition and costs twice as much as Megaton Edition. Chances are, you probably already own Megaton edition since Devolver practically gave it away for free numerous times. If you don't own it, unfortunately there is no other option for you. Thanks to Gearbox's underhanded business practices, Megaton Edition has been removed from all official online retailers and the original versions of the game have been removed from GOG. Legally, this is your only option for playing Duke Nukem 3D, and that's absolutely sad.
Save your money. Don't bet on this Duke.

Well this is the laziest rerelease I've ever seen in my life. The Megaton Edition, which was removed because it provided 5x the content this does for less money, was superior in just about every way. It's hard to wrap my mind around how they actually made this edition WORSE when they already had the Megaton to work with.
The remastered Duke voice is higher fidelity, but the voice acting itself is clearly phoned in and un inspired.  They did no remastering with the original sounds and so the stark contrast with the voice is distracting and grating more than enjoyable. Ignoring the voice issue, I don't even know how, but the sound effects sound worse than in Megaton edition. It sounds like they ported from a Gameboy version. The strangest things have been removed. The intro menus look nicer than Megaton, but all in-game graphics and HUD are pixelated and ugly, they got rid of the reskin and pixel smoothing Megaton allowed you to turn on or off. You can't rename your save games, it's just "Slot 1". Why? Such a trivial change that would require you to actively change code to remove functionality.
They added colored lighting, a feature present in every Build source port for the last, what, 5 years? 10? No updated textures, no 3D models, none of the other functionality offered for free by EDuke and others. Only new weapon added is a variant of the freezethrower that's been lurking as dead code in Duke 3D since day 1, which was never implemented because it didn't add an enjoyable experience to the gameplay. Only one new enemy I've encountered so far, a trooper with a flamethrower. All the expansion packs have been stripped out, presumably so they can sell it to you again as DLC.
I'm not done with the campaign yet, but I will say the new levels are very well done so far and the new music is good. The rewind feature is a nice addition to complement traditional save game system.
Overall though this release could have been so, so much more, and it turned into a petty cash grab. Think about it... 20th anniversary edition. Think how much that means, how much content and functionality they could have given us. Think of what countless fans have been releasing for free, purely out of love for the game, for over a decade. Think of what Bethesda did breathing new life into the Doom remake. Think of how Gearbox could have seized this opportunity to make amends for the travesty of Duke Nukem Forever. Instead, we get this trash. I don't think Gearbox cares about or respects their customers, and I don't think they love the Duke IP.
Don't buy this. Don't support this kind of corporate greed and consumer gouging. I don't condone piracy, but I sure as hell won't be surprised when the new campaign files find their way on the torrent sites just to sidestep this abomination. At least wait for a 75% off sale to get this. I wish I'd paid $5 for it. $20? Get that crap outta here.

In this review I discuss two things: the game itself and the business practices of Gearbox. My negative rating is due to the poor business practices of Gearbox and does not mean in any way that I think what actually is here is bad. I love Duke Nukem and I enjoyed the 5th episode and the cool features this release has. But...
The problem with this release is that it's clearly a cash grab, not-so-subtly confirmed by Randy Pitchford himself (CEO of Gearbox) via various tweets (more on that later). To concisely put it, the new episode is awesome, the additional features and graphics are pretty cool, but this is missing 3 expansions found in the now removed Megaton edition. The missing expansions perhaps aren't a big deal, but a complete edition of DN3D which will include those expansions, the 5th episode, and more, has practically been confirmed by Randy to one day be made. So what does that make this? A cash grab.
The new episode features 7 main levels and a secret level created by the original level designers of DN3D, also the guy who did the original music is back! That's pretty amazing to be honest. Read About their thoughts for each of the levels, including the interesting tidbit that each level took approximately 2 months to make:
The new levels are really well done, and fairly tough too I think. They aren't as compact but are bigger and more spread out because they don't have to deal with hardware limitations like they did 20 years ago. The new incinerator gun is op; ammo is plentiful, it holds 99 shots, and the shots 1 hit kill the regular enemies and do massive damage to the others. It sucks against enemies that can't be set on fire though. The new firefly enemies are annoying (in a good way), but they tend to be glitchy because sometimes when you shoot them the shots don't register. It's nice seeing completely new areas and artwork. I also really like the new music too. Basically it's a worthy addition to Duke Nukem and deserves to be the official 5th episode. My only complaint is that we got just 1 new enemy.
The game has a true 3d render which you can toggle on and off (the original render was 2d sprites which stretched when you looked up and down). The rewind feature from the old DN3D release on consoles is finally on pc. When you die you can rewind all the way to the beginning of the game and any point in between and start over from whatever point you choose. Really cool! I'm a big fan of developer commentary and some of the things they have to say are interesting, I just wish there was a lot more. I'm not a big fan of the re-recorded Duke voice lines, fortunately you can toggle the legacy lines back on.
It's all straight from the horse's mouth, Randy Pitchford. Here are tweets where he mentions a definitive edition:
Here is where he tells you the only reason to buy this game is if you want to play the 5th episode as soon as possible, like I did, and assuming you don't already own DN3D:
The difference is when a company like Bethesda is going to make a complete edition they don't remove expansions for sale, release a new expansion, then tell you if you want the old expansions along with the new expansion in one package with some more goodies then you'll have to wait and buy the complete edition later.
Here he suggests waiting for a sale:
Yes everyone knows almost all games get a sale eventually, but as a developer it's bad business to
your potential customers to wait for one. Plus I already told him I bought it. Reading comprehension deficiency?
Here he confirms there will be no dlc, free or paid:
I guess it's good he won't try to nickel and dime us by making us pay for what should be there, but why can't the missing expansions be free dlc?
If only we knew what you know so we could understand these baffling business decisions.
Duke Nukem is as great as ever. If it weren't for this being an incomplete edition due to a feeble reason then this would get all my thumb ups. I was priveleged to be able to play Duke Nukem 3D back in the 90's. It was one of the most impactful games of the decade for a number of reasons, from its smooth and highly optimized gameplay, to its level variety. Many focus on its sexual content, but that was really just a backdrop of the game that provided a few chuckles due to how ridiculous it was—assuming its style of humor resonated with you.
Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour hasn't tampered with anything that made the original fantastic. In fact, it makes it better.
All four original episodes are included, in addition to a new one. They're just as you remember, except you can use a rewind mechanic to revive yourself quickly upon death. This is a key component of this re-release as Duke Nukem 3D is a very difficult game when compared to most modern titles.
Gameplay feels fantastic with keyboard and mouse, ensuring that quality of life isn't impacted by the original game's age. However, it is worth noting that games from Duke Nukem 3D's era tend to lack the entertainment values of modern titles. Because fo this, it does struggle to hold your attention in the long run.
With all this in mind, Duke Nukem 3D: 20th Anniversary World Tour has arrived with great execution. It's a trip down nostalgia lane that makes no compromises and feels authentic to the original script, albeit with some minor additions to make it feel fresh. It might not entertain newcomers who aren't deeply interested in discovering what extraordinary games from its era were like, but that's okay. There's a sizable audience who simply wants a reason to rewind 20 years and see what made headlines.

(Originally written 6/11/2011 - my effusive praise being representative of how much I liked the game at the time, not being aware in years to come how I'd regard it pretty much like the rest of the community. Decent, not as great as all that. Still will represent here what I wrote back then.)
The King is back; does he still reign? Spouting one-liners, kicking alien rear and wooing all the hot babes like he always has, I’d say he does.
The story picks up around fifteen years after Duke’s last adventure, just like in real life. Duke is living high off of the fame and worship of his adoring public; the world simply loves Duke Nukem, and why not? He singlehandedly saved Earth with an impressive arsenal of weapons, secured the safety of the beloved women of the planet, and undertook many grand feats all over the world! After all that, he lapsed into semi-retirement in Las Vegas; he bought a casino, surrounded himself by beautiful women as is his wont, and parlayed his fame and marketability into media enterprises, fast food chains and more!
When the aliens come back under a pretence of truce, however, he is warned to keep out of their way by the President himself, saying he’s in talks with the Cycloid Emperor himself, whom Duke defeated in his last encounter. His General friend and handler grudgingly agrees, that maybe the aliens are here to make peace, but all that quickly becomes moot; his secret hideaway, the Duke Cave, as well as Vegas itself, is under attack! Just like before, the aliens made the first move, and now it’s up to Duke to make the last.
Gameplay is definitely a throwback to classic FPS’s, and seems like a tribute to the real fans of Duke from years past. It works really well, but has, unfortunately, also worked to turn off fans of “new-school” gameplay, who have blasted the game for lack of originality as well as its use of several modern gameplay mechanics mixed in with the old, including regenerating health, and limitation to two weapons carried at one time [This was patched soon after release; now we can hold four weapons].
That doesn’t, however, mean a thing to me. Things have to change, and I think Duke Nukem Forever brings just the right amount of change to keep things fresh, and the new turret and vehicle sequences, as well as fully interactive minigames including pool, pinball, video poker and others, mean you’ll be playing the game for a very long time.
Multiplayer, again, samples from the new-school without being in it. The persistent leveling system and challenges of many other recent FPS’s make appearances here, with the reward system relating not merely to gameplay enhancements, but additions to Duke’s personal penthouse! That’s right, when you’re not bashing the aliens’ heads in during the campaign, or those of your buddies in multiplayer, you can walk around a multi-room museum of Duke’s accomplishments and conquests, which are unlocked as you level up in multiplayer. The replay value is definitely there!
So, as Duke says, COME GET SOME! Five out of five!

Ah, Duke Nukem Forever. One of the most infamous titles in history for its prolonged development cycle and the rather savage beating it took in the press once it finally was released. In 2011, I just took everyone's word for it that the game was a total disaster and stayed away. That wasn't easy for me since I had been a huge fan of the series, even going as far back as the first two DOS platformer games. I know I'm late to the party on this one, but when you've been waiting since 1998? Waiting 6 more years to finally put hands on the unholy grail of vaporware doesn't seem all that long.
Overall, I would have to say that I was pleasantly surprised. For a game that's almost universally reviled; I was expecting much worse. I'm not really sure what people were expecting from a game that can't help but have one foot in a previous decade. If this had come out even close to being on time, say 2001 to 2004 at the latest? I think its reception would've been significantly better. It possibly would’ve even been considered groundbreaking if it had beaten Doom 3, Unreal 2 and Half-Life 2 to market as intended. The graphics are perfectly serviceable and in keeping with the overall visual style of the previous games. Nearly all of the classic alien monsters are back with fresh designs that look great! Some might find having to repeatedly bash the space bar to break free from enemies when they're right in your face to be gimmicky, but I didn't mind. The gunplay is good, at least with the weapons it has in common with Duke 3D. Your mileage may vary with the new laser based firearms that dead enemies drop. My experience was also benefitted from playing this updated PC version that allows the player to carry 4 guns as opposed to the 2 of console versions.
That's not to say that it doesn't have its problems. What passes for humor is consistently childish, boorish and chauvinistic. All of the pop culture pastiches are oddly anachronistic; either referencing things not fitting the time of its early development or things outdated by the time it was finally released. The level known as The Hive does feature some uncomfortable moments where the player has to kill bound women who've been impregnated with aliens. However, none of these things were nearly as distracting or offensive as I had been led to believe. Duke 3D wasn't so different in terms of adult content and it's considered an all-time classic. I think it's more that the world has moved past such things and Duke hadn't kept up.
Despite enjoying most of the finished product, I can't help but feel that the real tragedy of this entire saga is the older versions we missed out on. The E3 2001 trailer in particular was mind blowing to me at the time of its release. I couldn't wait to play THAT game! Most of the backgrounds from Duke’s casino in Las Vegas, to the Nevada desert and the Hoover Dam did make it into the game, but what about all those cool moments and characters? Would it have been that hard to include the pick-axe wielding miner character in the desert section, if just for a cameo? I mean for being a focal point of early screenshots, you think he would’ve made the cut.  Where was Duke’s female companion, Bombshell? Upon beating the game, I couldn't help but wonder... what about this took 10 more years to complete?! If they spent over a decade tweaking and refining the game, why is so much missing from what we were promised? It seems all the delays were mainly spent scrapping and entirely redoing the art assets; trying to be competitive visually with whatever game Valve, Epic MegaGames or ID Software had on the horizon. Although the downloadable content episode did eventually include Duke’s original nemesis, Dr. Proton, and the Terminator-esque robot characters, even that didn't find a way to fit in all the missing content we'd been shown from the 1998 and 2001 demos.
I suppose we'll never know what could've been if the management at 3D Realms had been more disciplined in their approach. After 14 years of hype, it would’ve truly had to been the greatest game ever made to live up to everyone’s expectations. Although it often succeeds on its own merits, the unnecessary delays and multiple graphics engine switches negatively impacted the game. Perhaps that's why it was lambasted in 2011; other games had already long since done was this is trying to be and do. In particular, one can obviously tell the developers were greatly influenced by the original Half-Life's cinematic approach. Trading in Duke 3D's exploration based levels for fixed action set pieces didn't have to be a bad thing, but the execution left something to be desired. They were never going to win the race by standing in place and observing what the other runners were doing, telling themselves that they'll reach the finish line "when it's done".
In summation, if you've ever enjoyed a Duke Nukem game in the past; give this a try. I guarantee there will be a moment or two that makes you remember how much you loved those games. If you're easily offended by sexist jokes, cartoonish gore or dangerously hyperbolic levels of machismo? Stay far, far away. If you're looking to play a modern first person shooter with up to date graphics and game play? This probably won't be your thing either. However, if you're interested in the process of game development, I.E. why certain projects descend into so-called Development Hell? This is a fascinating object lesson. Truly an anomaly in the computer game industry as a product released out of its proper place in time, it's worth experiencing at least once. You might be surprised how much fun you'll find yourself having. Check your unrealistic expectations at the door, recalibrate your mindset to the early 2000’s and as Duke would say, “Come get some!”

Duke Nukem Forever is an old-styled FPS with a modern makeover...
what the devs would like to trick you into believing. Actually, Duke Nukem Forever is your standard shooter from the early 2010's with very little old-school about it. It reuses the narrative theming of the original shooter but borrows little from the original's gameplay, and that's a bad thing.
Try to picture your generic FPS from the 2010's and you got the gist of Duke Nukem's gameplay. Linear levels, 2-4 weapon slots, regenerating health, cutscenes, action setpieces feautring QTEs, and a smaller array of enemies. The devs use a smaller array of enemies compared to DN3D and designed certain classes of enemies to have varying firearms, but it all just feels samey when over 75% of enemies you encounter are a reskin of the soldier-with-a-gun enemy archetype.
One of the game's biggest sins is limiting the amount of guns Duke can carry. The player is limited to 2-4 guns at any given time and trust me the devs had to scale back the complexity of enemy encounters to accommodate the fact that the player can only carry two weapons.
And the weapons aren't particularly great either. Many of them are a variant on the rapid-fire assault rifle archetype and not all of them are adequately powerful. I stuck with Ripper because it felt good to use.
Keeping on with the modern touches of DNF, Duke regenerates health over time (or 'ego' as the game calls it). I don't think regenerating health is an interesting gameplay mechanic and in most other games I'd consider it a big problem however in DNF I almost welcome because it makes sense that a big macho guy like Duke Nukem would literally walk off any kind of injury he takes.
The linear levels of DNF might be game's biggest flaws. They're linear, like you would assume. This is total contrast to the delightfully open-ended levels of the DN3D. Despite taking place in similar urban environments like the original, none of the environments feel like they're supposed to thanks to rampant linearity and a lack of mechanical character within the levels. Occasionally you'll get to play around with some level objects and increase your maximum health, but that's barely enough.
And the places you'll venture through are varied but not inspired. You got casinos, desert highways, alien hives and even hydroelectric dams. If you got a taste for urban warfare, DNF at least has that going for it.
The game tries to mix up pacing by adding in vehicle portions or setpieces where Duke is shrunk to miniature size, but those twists don't do too much to make the game fun.
Many of these actions sequences go on too long, especially the “mini-Duke drives a RC car” sequence in the beginning and the “Duke drives a monster truck across the desert highway” sequence toward the end. It's filler and in the cases of Duke getting shrunk down, that just seems odd in a super-masculine story like DNF. Duke getting shrunk happened in the original but it was for a short sequence and was a key to solving a puzzle.
Speaking of puzzles, Duke Nukem has them and although some are a little too gamey and uncharacteristic of DNF, many are acceptable. For all of its modernizations, DNF does not have an arrow on the player's interface telling them where to go next. The game allows the player to figure out how to get to the next room or progress and oftentimes it requires exploration or using a weapon in a creative way, which works with the game's style.
In this latest edition of the Duke Nukem saga, the story is more cinematic as expected in a modernization of a classic shooter. More swearing, more boobs, more violence. It's not drastically different from the original DN3D but DNF doesn't have the same vibe.
I'm sure the developers put in all the sexiness and machismo in good fun but with how better and more “realistic” the presentation of DNF is compared to the originals, the character of DNF grows old quickly and becomes tiring and unlikeable. The original didn't shove its humour and spunk down your throat every minute so even if you don't like the sexualization of bodacious babes or the overly machismo attitude of Nukem, you weren't suffocated by any elements you found unpleasant.
There is an audience to Duke Nukem Forever. If you don't mind overly long levels, driving set pieces, boobs, juvenile humour, and outdated celebrity jokes you might dig Duke Nukem Forever. The best things I can say about it is some guns feel really good to shoot and sometimes the linear level design is inspired in how it directs the player.
If you don't fall within that bullseye of a recommendation, you're better off playing something else.

This is a decently fun game overall and does not deserve all the hate it gets. The reviews slating long load times and dodgy frame rates must be referencing the console versions because, on PC, none of this is the case, the game was incredibly smooth on my meagre setup so you shouldn't have a problem getting it to run well on most systems.
The game is a flat out stupid affair in terms of plot, characters and references to other games. The plot is that aliens invade, take the Duke's girls and he follows in pursuit doing what he always does once he runs out of bubblegum. The references themselves are poorly implemented, hamfisted ones but then again what else can they be if inserted within a comedic game? I guess what appeals is how audacious the game's tone is and how I can't really fault it when it comes to pacing. It's a fast moving game that takes in a good variety of settings, adds simple puzzles and . One of the things I really liked was how messing with the environment gifted you with more health, meaning that not everything break from combat felt like pointless scene-setting up to the next gunfight.
Like most modern shooters, health regenerates which sucks but isn't a complete deal breaker. At least the idea has run its course for the most part these days and developers are slowly re-establishing the much better idea of having health packs in their shooters. This makes combat relatively uninteresting for the most part; its made up for, however, by the weapon selection which is near identical to that of Duke Nukem 3D. They are all overpowered, fun to use, punchy and cathartic and really help make every combat encounter just one long relentless blast-fest like all the early 90s shooters were like.
Overall, the game is basically functional and relatively exciting to play through, though it has plenty of half baked ideas, like the mostly useless alien weaponry found in abundance, a driving sequence which unfortunately becomes very monotonous to the detriment of the otherwise good pacing and some bland boss fights, characteristic of most 90s shooters. There is also some bad platforming sections but thankfully are over quickly before you get too annoyed by them.
I'd say it was definitely worth playing for the tiny amount I payed for it (less than a quid). If you can't get it for as cheap as that, less than £5 is decent price to pay. It's certainly an adequate game, with enough strong elements to keep you invested, and isn't technically broken as reviews suggest (my guess is that is has been patched to hell and back).

The game 15 years in the making...
Granted this game has been torn apart by critics, and Duke fans alike... is it really as bad as they make it out to be? Actually no in my opinion, Here is why
The game was released in 2011, around 15 in troubled development. Forever is a direct sequel to Duke Nukem 3D. The game was first announced in 1997, reannounced in 2001, and again reannounced in 2007. The game then saw life breathed into it around 2009 as they (Gearbox Software) confirmed they were finishing the game. The game plays like a game from that era of FPS games. Limited weapons, sometimes overwhelming enemy numbers, but I personally find it enjoyable like that. If you do not like the limited weapon numbers, you can change it in the ingame options menu. The gameplay is just fine, it is nothing super special, but it functions on a basic level and can actually be pretty fun at times, when enemies try to surround you, and you have to use the right weapons in the right circumstance. The game also runs well in my testing of the game. Without V-Sync enabled (highly suggest you use that) the game can hit access of 1500 FPS, while with vsync, the game is locked at a very stable 60. The game also has many varied environments, but the colors used are kind of washed out, and overly dull in my opinion.
Another thing that has always bothered me about this game is the rebounding health bar. I get that when it was released, those were and still are the most common way of health regeneration in these types of games, but for a Duke Nukem game, that was a questionable decision. Although it really does not affect gameplay to much. The voice dialouge by Jon St. Jon (voice of Duke) is honestly really good. I think this is the best version of Duke, even if he does say some of the lines a bit to often, or if he repeats some of the older games lines, they are still enjoyable to hear. The game also loads so much faster than the console counter-parts in my playtime of the game.
Overall, the enjoyment factor for you may vary when compared to me personally, and that is alright. The game is really not as bad as people make it out to be. The controls work, and are actually pretty good. The weapons are standard for FPS games, and the variety in environemts is actually a nice change of pace for this game. The voice acting for Duke himself is also a highlight. Negatives include repetitive gameplay, some cheap deaths, the extremely crude humor (not really a negative for me personally, but some people may not like it to much.) The pointless side activites, and the overall lack of replayability. I say if you can find this game dirt cheap, give it a shot. I personally enjoy the game, and maybe you will too if you actually give it a chance.

This isn't a bad game nor is it the worst Duke Nukem game. Sure, it's not great and its a bad Duke game when compared to the likes of DN3D, it's prequel, but there's fun to be had here. I can see why it wasn't well received and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥people off. I wouldn't pay full price for this on launch. Not to mention the changes they made to the gameplay after launch (more weapons slots) were pretty significant. Very significant.
Let's get one thing out of the way first. The Visuals. They are nothing to write home about but won't make your eyes bleed either. There's a distinct lack of colour even when i bumped up the vibrance in my GPU settings. I can only imagine how dull this looks without the extra colour vibrance. On the PC, the textures are a huge step up from consoles. There are still some ugly ones but overall not really that bad to look at. This game gets a lot of♥♥♥♥♥♥for its crappy textures and I can assure you most of them come from console players or reviewers. Not every texture is a sore to look at.
I have nothing much to say about the audio besides the fact that its lacking a whole lot in everything. The music isn't engaging and the guns all sound pathetic. They lack punch in terms of effectiveness in game and the sounds they produce. One thing I really appreciated and liked is Duke's One liners and Banter. I chuckled quite a bit but then again maybe it's nostalgia. I don't care. I liked it.
Now let's get to the meat of this review. What matters in a video game of this type. The gameplay. It's easily the worst aspect of the game and that's bad news for a video game. It's such a mess of mixed ideas. The initial 2 weapon limit was absolutely stupid. Who thought that would be a good idea. Granted they patched in 4 slots but 4 slots are not enough to do justice to Duke's badass arsernal. To add insult to injury, the weapons all lack punch. You're not sure if you're shooting actual bullets or nerf bullets. Even the Devastator feels weak. It takes away all the fun in the gun fights. The gunfights themselves are boring af. At first I thought there was a certain sense of strategy involved in the fights but then I realized all I did was hide behind ♥♥♥♥ing cover. This is especially true thanks to the EGO meter, which I don't mind as much, but It kinda seems like the whole gameplay was designed around accomodating the EGO meter. This isn't Call of Duty. Boss fights can be infuriating at times and I found myself often exploiting the game environments to defeat bosses.
The gameplay isn't restricted to gunplay. There are puzzles in store which although are quite easy to solve and often times tedious, was a good distraction from the god awful gunplay. I liked the inclusion of it. The pacing could have used more work though and the loading screens are far too many but hey at least on PC its quick to load. I bet it lost points for that on consoles. Speaking of consoles, this game oozes of console design choice. Heck, even the control schemes seems skewed towards using a controller over a keyboard and mouse. There's this dreaded mouse smoothing which can be minimized but it still feels like trash to use. What's worse is the god damn way weapons are switched with no clear slot for your weapons so you'll have to shuffle through till you find what you want even if you bind some hotkeys.
The game has some other interactive segments like Driving and Platforming. The Driving though linear was surprisingly well done. It wasn't as open world as say HL2 but controlled WAY better than HL2. Then there are those dreaded platforming segments. I believe they didn't work too well back in the day and it still doesn't in this game. I hated them, especially when you get shrunk and have to do platforming. Creative ideas in there but fighting while shrunk is a whole other pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Still, I like how it tries to be old school with its interactivity and design in certain areas.
All in all, a lot of the♥♥♥♥♥♥this game gets can be equated to the platform it was played on, some console focused design choices, lackluster gameplay at times, the state on launch and the price paid on launch.
I got this as a part of one of the humble bundle deals and keeping that in mind, this was a steal. I had fun playing this and if it gets cheap enough for you to want to spend money and play it keeping in mind the points I mentioned in this review, then go for it.
Like I said: It's not a bad game. It's a bad Duke Nukem game but NOT the worst Duke Nukem game.

A lot of people try to defend this game as being "dumb fun" or say stuff like "It's not supposed to win awards", but in order for a game to be dumb fun, it has to be fun at all in the first place. What we have here is a game that completely disregards the concept of pacing and instead makes you slog through dull chores and sit through unfunny comedy sketches more than it makes you shoot aliens to death.
Duke Nukem is supposed to be an action game, and yet it takes a good 40 minutes before you get a gun, and even then you're not really in any kind of significant battles. In a game like Half-Life 2, where you actually care about the worldbuilding and are trying to convey a certain theme or message, this would be compelling, but Duke Nukem's world is inherently shallow, it exists solely as a delivery mechanism for crude jokes. Duke Nukem is a simple character by design, so forcing us to learn about him and his world for almost an hour is a terrible way to start a game. For comparison, Duke Nukem 3D has you blowing something up in the first seconds of the game. The game continues in much the same fashion, you're usually navigating an empty environment or trying to solve some kind of puzzle. In one section, you get shrunk down and have to drive an RC car, which sounds really creative on paper, but you aren't actually doing anything in this scenario. You literally just drive the car down a very long hallway and don't fight anything or try to navigate anything other than "go forward". When you finally do get into a gunfight, it's usually with only two or three enemies at a time and then it's back to the slog.
Most of the actual individual puzzles would be fine, and even very clever in many cases, if they were breaks in the action instead of the main action itself, but you're really left with a game that feels like it's constantly leading to something, only to never get there. This game didn't need to be groundbreaking, it didn't need to have the best graphics, or the best animation, or the best story, it just needed to give you lots of things to shoot at and fun ways to kill enemies, but it fails at the most basic action of a first person shooter, which is that it needs to have lots of shooting. Overall, if you want a fun, over-the-top first person shooter, try Bulletstorm, Serious Sam 3, Shadow Warrior, Doom, or even the original Duke Nukem 3D. Only play this game if you want to actually sit down and academically study what can be bad about a game.

After a few attempts of trying to make a professional review introduction, I've decided to say "F**K IT!" and just be perfectly blunt about my opinion of this game:
It's a waste of time, money, and computer memory.
Now, I understand a lot of issues occured during this games making; numerous delays, downsizing, and even a lawsuit between two developers. That being said, this game took 15 years to make! That gives a developer plenty of time to look at their product and say, "Hmmmm... Is this a good game, and if not, how can we make it so?" Allow me to point out The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly things on this game.
The Good: The humor is fairly nice and well-timed for the most part, and reminded me very much of Robot Chicken, Famliy Guy, and it even has hints of classic TV shows like GI Joe and Popeye. This was almost enough to carry me through it.
, being the key word here. I also enjoyed the enemies; a combination of wordplay and mindless minions which made me grin a little every time I remembered their names.
Now for The Bad: The combat is trying to be a mix of Call of Duty & Halo, and while it is acceptable most of the time, it can get repetitive and boring. New weapons and gadgets try to freshen things up, but they can get a little boring as well after making a Pigcop explode for the tenth time. In addition to gear, Duke can increase his overall Ego (or rechargeable shield; pick your poison) by doing "manly" and "badass" things like lifting weights, shooting three-pointers, making popcorn, using the bathroom, looking in the mirror... Just a lot of ways to do it; maybe too much.
Let's get The Ugly: F**k Duke. F**k him and his sh*t-eating grin wearing, dark sunglassed, cigar-smoking, beer-chugging face. He's tolerable at first, but over time, I grew to despise him. He's only good in small doses, personally. It doesn't help that he insults various games like Halo and Gears of War, and (spoiler):
Then there's the bosses: uninspired, boring, cookie-cutter bullsh*t. The physics also don't help things; the aforementioned Ego system uses the game's physics a healthy percent of the time, and these Ego challenges can range from stupid to nearly impossible.
In short, Duke Nukem Forever is an excellent example of how even big-named icons can take a big tumble when handled poorly. Oh, and fun fact: a month after the game release, it was estimated that less than half a million copies were sold but there was enough sold to make a profit. That says a lot, doesn't it?

Duke Nukem Forever... It has been a long time coming. One of the few first person shooters I had bought virtually day one in hopes of the gaming industry redeeming itself and bringing back the golden age of first person shooters. Unfortunately like many before me, I was dead, dead wrong. The real question to ask is what DNF does right rather than wrong. But I can barely scrap together any real coherent positives about the game. Instead I am just going to give a minimal rundown of some problems I had in the extremely long list of excruciating issues involved with DNF:
The guns are limited to two. TWO WEAPONS AT A TIME. IN A CLASSIC GOLDEN AGE FPS SEQUEL.
Regenerating health. Why on God's green earth was this considered an okay notion in a Duke Nukem game. The basis in use for regenerating health is to hide behind something or take cover until your health gradually recovers. When you put this into context for Duke Nukem, it make almost 0 sense.
The ego system. Although the idea seems fitting in retrospect to Duke's Alpha male personality, once translated into gameplay it becomes nothing more than a gimmick that breaks up the action makes the game feel like a poor man's POSTAL 2 somehow.
Gearbox lying through their teeth. Gearbox have made their fair share of half decent games in the past, but in these recent years with games being released under their alias such as Aliens: Colonial Marines, Battleborn and Duke Nukem Forever, I have grown to despise them. The lies from both DNF and the Alien game about the promises being made, its visuals from E3 "demos" and rumours/facts that the company outsourced most of the work to newbie developers really makes me question the work ethic over at Gearbox.
The problems stack up against it more and more and I could rattle on about it for far too long, but I never even bothered to finish the damn thing. It is visually revolting, runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥ weakest gunplay I have seen in a game, and literal "♥♥♥♥ you" to anyone who ever gave a damn about bringing Duke back. I don't care about how long the game was in development hell, and I don't care that Gearbox just think they can't bring old classics back into action. If modern ID Software can bring DOOM back to life, then what excuse do Gearbox have?
R.I.P. Duke, hail to the king, baby.

Worth playing through on the cheap as a curiosity, perhaps, but ultimately not much more than a mishmash of new and old ideas that the developers couldn't form a cohesive whole out of. The writers managed to wiggle a few good jokes in here and there, but the majority of the dialog is dated, unimaginative, and sometimes inconsistent in tone. Level design is occasionally clever but largely made up of bland arenas in which equally bland battles take place. Nearly everything about this game feels unfinished and confused—the elements they chose to take from modern titles serve only to restrain the player and prevent the developers from fully embracing elements from old school shooters that could elevate it beyond the underwhelming, unfocused game it turned out to be. If Gearbox decides to make a new Duke Nukem at some point in the future, they would be wise to take notes from the new DOOM, which successfully combines past and present in a way that DNF failed to.
TL;DR: 14-years of development condensed into ~9-hours of mediocrity.

More detailed description but careful *some small spoilers*:
I have played the original Duke Nukem 3D back in the '90s on DOS, then the Duke Nukem Megaton Edition that got released on steam in 2011 (I think), played Duke Nukem Zero Hour on the N64 and the two games on the PSX (Time to Kill, Land of Babes) and I must say that Duke Nukem Forever is the worst Duke Nukem game and one of the worst FPS I have ever played.
The Duke Nukem Universe
----------------------------
When it comes to the levels you visit kind of the same places you also visited in Duke Nukem 3D. Duke Burger, Hive, a Space Station and the game is kind of lacking a mindblowing scenario that lets you make "wow" that is kind of nice.
Everything looks boring and somehow uninspiring. You are following a total linear path through the levels and are
not able to vary the way you finish them.
Remember the annoying remote driving parts in the original "Shadow Warrior"? Where there was a key on a car or a boot
and you had to remote controll it, so you get the key. Well, yeah. They put this in.
Duke has no health.
He has an ego meter that you can upgrade by playing pinball or looking at magazines or working out.
When you get hit twice the meter starts to blink and as long as you don't get hit again, it recharges like a shield.
So no health packs. No health items.
I've played on the highest difficulty level and even with this the game is way too easy.
There are a lot of squences where you have to use a gattling gun and shoot ships. You can't just walk away from that thing.
No. You got to use this weapon so the story goes on.
And.... even more.
Driving sequences. Yes, driving in a car and killing enemies. Jumping above cliffs.
Sequences, where you get shrunk and you got to jump through the level to procede. Wow, just a 3D Jump and Run.
The enemies are boring as well. There are not so many enemies types and definitely no new ones. They not even included the acid alien from the fourth episode of the original Duke Nukem.
The whole game "feels" like a hybrid between Halo and Mass Effect with a little bit of Duke in it.
Weapons
-----------
You can only damage boss enemies with the rocket launcher or the devastator. Not with the other normal weapons.
In the default setting Duke can ONLY CARRY TWO WEAPONS!!!!!
So if you don't know when there is gonna be a boss fight you will always have a rocket launcher with you.
In the option menu you can change the amount of weapons to four at a time.
But still: Why not let him carry all the weapons like in the original Duke Nukem 3D.
There are no new weapons in the game. They just took all the original ones. In the DLC "Doctor who cloned me" you get
a weapon like a small acid grenade launcher, but that's it. No new stuff really.
When you shoot at enemies you also get the feeling that they don't care. The weapons don't have a specific strength on certain enemies. You will find yourself using the shotgun a lot.
Items
-------
Steroids just make you punch like the "Doom-Guy". But you can not shoot at that time. Awesome, while all
the other enemies have projectile weapons.
In the option menu there is a shortcut for the Jetpack. But YOU CAN'T FIND THE JETPACK in the SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN!!
So why even implement it? There is also no scuba gear.
Disturbing moment (*spolier*)
--------------------------------
There is one very disturbing moment in the game. Your girlfriends get kidknapped and you find them in the Hive, while they are literally being♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by the alien hive itself. Then they burst open and little alien creatures appear.
So. First you played through levels that were derpy shmerpy, happy here, shot there and a joke.
And from one moment to another... this stuff.
This is completely inappropriate. I mean even in the alien games (AVP, Alien Colonial Marines) aliens burst out of hosts, but not like that. The developers really went the wrong path here.
Multiplayer
------------
Apparently there is a multiplayer, but nobody seems to play this, so you will find yourself in an empty level.
DLC - Doctor who cloned me (*Spoilers*)
-------------------------------------------
The beginning is kind of nice but then the story will very quickly start to disappoint again.
The last fight is on the moon against the Alien Queen.
It is one of the most annoying boss battles ever. You are really gonna be happy when you finish this boss.
Summary
-----------
Well, DON'T BUY THIS GAME! Let's hope that there is never again gonna be a new Duke Nukem game.
This concept worked in the '90s, but not today anymore.
Super disapointing, game was outdated on the day of its release.

Forever Alpha
The game as it stands shows signs of incompletenes, there are just so many many things that are broken:
* NPCs have no interaction and lack expressiveness
* Load times are relatively long, no optimization whatsoever
* You can only use two guns at a time, which is awkward ...
* Any use of vehicles is interesting but lacks any dept, and the physics is a little off
It just has absolutely no polish; it's an excellent alpha that never fully matured. It really doesn't need that much to be a masterpiece, just open development tools and in the span of 3 years it would have lived up to the hype on fan love alone.
But that is the real issue. This was in a way a dead end for the hero I, and perhaps others, waited 12 years to make a return (I bought Duke 3D when it came out). If only it had been given a chance, we would have Borderlands as well as Duke franchises to follow.
So in sum, I love it, I really like Duke Forever. Yes it has childish pimple ladden humor, and never really tries to connect in a deep level (that's for♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's fun, that's all it is, and that is all it ever needed to be (it's a game for uhm playing in your spare time not a second career or something) The game has a lot of variety, the music is great, graphics are interesting and expressive (yes I'm sure you can find something that could melt your PC this isn't it), puzzles are fun, it has relentless action and if you think highly of Frank Zappa humor (which is all it is) Duke really shouldn't be that offensive to you (just don't expect him to grow up at all, he's trapped forever in the 90's which is ok).
And who knows, if the powers that be ever release modding tools (or simply allow people to actually make them), this could the shiny diamond it was conceived as, and live up to its hype... And just maybe ... catch the interest of a broader fanbase and lead to a sequel, and hence more Duke awesomeness :D
For now take this as it is, something that's incomplete, partially broken, but with glimpses of genius. And rather than think about it, have fun !

I bought this game expecting something terrible, considering it's less than stellar reviews on release. I just bought this game in December of 2016 and I must say that I was pleasantly surprised.
The graphics are like an early PS3/Xbox 360 game. By today's standards, it's pathetic. Ugly textures and the like, none of which are particularly important to me.
The animations are sickening and downright laughable, they are unnatural and when characters speak to you, they are hardly ever focused on you. The voice acting is weak and the sound effects are just as bad. Just generic repeated sounds for almost everything you can think of, including the water, cars, explosion and some of the critters you'll see about.
The game has one major thing going for it, and that is gameplay. The action sections of the game are insanely entertaining. The shooting feels natural and visceral. It's quick and fluid, there are plenty of reasons I enjoyed the action parts of the game, which basically makle the entire game, because... well... the rest of the game is awful. Pathetically designed platforming sections that make you want to tear your hair out, driving sections that control like an early driving sim. I had more toruble in the driving and platforming parts of the game than most of the action bits. But don't take that as the game being easy, because it couldn't be farther from the truth. This game is relentless in it's enemies difficulty. The enemies will not stop until you are dead, naturally. The excellent gunplay helps keep you on your toes and getting the last satisfying hit on your enemies before they turn you into a Duke Burger.
Besides the drawn out driving sections, the annoying puzzles and overall visual and audio downfalls of the game, it is still genuine fun and I am really glad I went through with it. I bought it during the sale and can say that it was at least $5 worth of fun. There are plenty of little hidden secrets in the game and even a virtual pinball machine.
If you are looking for a fun shooter, you can't go wrong with Duke Nukem Forever if the price is right.

The only real positive to the game is that once you beat the single player mode, you get access to concept art and videos from the game.  One of the videos were the original E3 trailers of Duke Nukem Forever that was released around 2003, which were awesome trailers then and still looked like it would have been fun as heck even today.  Those bonus videos just made me wish that that was the game us Duke Nukem fans had gotten instead of the game I has just beaten.
There were a couple of neat/amusing moments in the game such as a couple levels where Duke has been shrunk and has to work his way around a kitchen without touching the floor, or having to drive RC cars through a casino, etc.  The shrunken Duke levels got boring pretty quick as the novelty wore off yet Duke keeps getting shrunk.  The 3D updated aliens of Duke Nukem 3D looked pretty cool.
Overall the game wasn't that good though.   Most of the levels were boring, or tedious.  The colors felt washed out and bland for the most part.  I found myself wishing I was playing the Duke Nukem Forever game that we were introduced to in the 2003 - 2005 E3 game trailers.  The color tones used in this release made me not care about how a single level looked.
Several of the levels are tedious or poorly designed.  The most annoying thing was the number of times I died in the game because of technical problems in the game.  There are clipping issues everywhere in the levels..  Say you get jumped by a group of monsters so you start moving around strafing and weaving through cover to avoid damage while trying to do some killing.  Out of the blue, you get snagged onto some object in the level.  You know you hit an object so you try to slide around it, or jump it or something, but no....Duke doesn't move.  You are forced to move the exact oppsite direction you were moving when you hit the object to get off of it. (e.g. You strafe left into an crate, you can't move forward, or backward then continue strafing, you have to strafe back to the right.)   By the time you figure it out you are usually cornered and...dead.  The aliens don't  have large hit boxes, but they have huge collision boxes.  If one gets right up on you, it's hard has heck to get around it because you can't strafe around, or jump.  You have to move directly away, yet you can't easily get enough distance to strafe around before the alien almost kills you, and many times does.
The water levels suck.  Not once did I die to an enemy under water, but I died 20+ times because of all the clipping issues in the levels.  A doorway (because you didn't go precisely through the middle of tghe doorway, or piece of seaweed, or something stopped me cold and I couldn't get around it fast enough.  Duke is so sluggish swimming in water that you can't afford to get stopped since you are trying to get to air pockets to breath.  Duke kept drowning.
Sadly Duke Nukem Forever was barely worth the $2 or $3 dollars I paid for it on Steam.

Duke Nukem Forever is a great game, not the best Duke Nukem game but I certainly wouldn't write it off as a series killer. The game has a great story full of long detailed levels which have a lot of variety in scenery, location and scale. It's jam packed with weapons an gadgets and tons of ways to boost your health bar. The enemies all look alike and are mostly simillar within their own 'species' but there's enough variety all together I think. It controls extremely well, which is a god send as the game has first person platforming, it's not too bad but I'd rather not be made to do it to progress. The games a bit easy on normal so Hards your bread and butter really. Dukes cool like always if a bit more cheesy than usual, but I'll put that down to age. The vehicle sections handle well and aren't too long. There's some underwater sections that are just bad, simple as that. All in all it's actually a great game and It's aged better than a lot of other games from it's release date. I give it a 8.5/10 I really enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone AND to top it all off, the multiplayer is still a bit active!

Reviewing this game is one of those situations where I wish Steam had a more detailed rating thing in its review system, as I feel the current, simple recommend/not recommend system is not good enough to state my feelings in a in-a-nutshell way and may even slightly misrepresent them.
From a technical and gameplay point of view, I guess DNF is sort of okay. It's not strictly terrible, by any means, but it's also not good enough to be memorable, which I find to be hardly acceptable for a modern day sequel to one of the most iconic games of PC gaming. It was supposed to be one of the best games on the market, but instead, it turned out to be yet another bland not-terrible shooter. True, it's fun, I guess, but I expected more, even after reading the devastating reviews.
Also, the fun itself is present only for the most part. When it's not present, it's because the game gave me some of the most frustrating level segments I have ever seen. First one is that one platforming segment involving spinning cogs, where the player needs to aim his jump at certain holes. Because of how everything is spinning, the last part can be frustrating. (By the way, what the hell is platforming doing in a Duke Nukem game? Was it present in Duke Nukem 3D too? I wouldn't complaing if this was a 2D platformer, like Duke Nukem 1 and 2, but DNF is not that, it's an FPS.)
Another ones are both underwater segments. Dear. Mother. Of God. I was THIS close to just ragequitting the game because of how I-want-to-pull-out-my-own-kidneys-out-of-my-body-in-frustration-and-throw-them-at-computer-screen-at-full-force they felt. Whoever thought those segments were a good idea deserves to be ♥♥♥♥ing shot. Now I know EXACTLY how all those people feel when they complain about underwater levels.
Amusingly, after 5 and a half years that at this point have passed since DNF's original release, there are still some people playing this game in multiplayer. True, it's only two or three servers, but still. I expected that the multiplayer would have died a long time ago.
Also also, the game can be beaten in some 10 to 11 hours, when played on Medium.
So, after I collected my thoughts and feelings and wrote what I did, what do I have to say at the end? Is Steam's simple recommend/not recommend system good enough? Actually yes, it is.
Sadly, I cannot recommend DNF. If this was a game set in an original IP, I probably would have recommended it, but a sort-of-generic shooter that's trying too hard to be modern does not deserve to wear the Duke Nukem label, because that label is, in video game market, too damn important to waste it on games like this one.
Simply put: for what it's called, it's a too big disappointment.

Duke is Back!
Duke Nukem, hero, babe magnet, gun enthusiast, and hater of extraterrestrials.  A man of few words, unless you've read his book.  When this game came out players and critics alike were hellbent on telling people how horrible this game was.  But is it really?
I can honestly say that after playing it for well over a year now that the game is quite good.  It's certainly not the best by any means, but is enjoyable.  The game has the same dirty humor from the past installment along with new jokes and pop culture references and topless girls.  All of the guns from Duke Nukem 3D are back along with a few new toys, the aliens are back with all the familiar faces and new ones, and best of all John St. John returns to reprise his role as Duke.  There's a great deal of interactive objects including a couple of minigames.  The multiplayer is entertaining and keeps players on their toes in eight man Duke Match complete with lots of laser trip mines and rockets.  The story is even goofy and generic like a "B" action movie.
The game however is not without its cons and flaws.  Parts of the environments and DM arenas feel somewhat rushed.  Some places still have bugs that from time to time get exploited by other players.  On rare occasion you can fire at a target and have an explosive blow up in your face after hitting an invisible segment of wall.  The controls are fairly descent (though you'd have to ask someone else how it handles with a keyboard and mouse) albeit a bit stiff.  The AI, while relentless, can at times seem too predictable.  Lastly, the stages seem a bit too cookie cutter and getting through them is basic wash, rinse, repeat.  You'll take down a few waves of enemies and solve a puzzle then move on.
Now while these things do bring the game down somewhat, it doesn't ruin its playability.  The game itself was a rushjob (after taking 12 years to complete) and while some things are inexcusable other things are forgivable.  Thankfully there have been a few updates including the addition of carrying four guns instead of two.  Also the DLC is very entertaining.  If you're an old Duke Nukem fan or a shooter fan I recommend trying this game out.  In the end it's good, mindless, fun.

After playing the originial duke nukem forever for xbox 360 and ps3 i have carefully decided to buy the pc port of the game its very crude and humorous it has its clean moments within the game the main information is here Twelve years after he saved the Earth from an alien invasion, Duke Nukem is a worldwide icon, and has achieved great fame from his heroic deeds. After sampling a video game based on his past heroics (the game Duke plays is a revamped version of the final level of the third episode of Duke Nukem 3D), he arrives on the set of a talk show for an interview. On his way to the show, Duke witnesses a news broadcast announcing that aliens have once again invaded. Unlike previous encounters, the aliens initially appear peaceful and at first seem to pose no harm to the humans of Earth.
Duke's talk show appearance is cancelled to allow television stations to cover the alien invasion, and Duke retires to the "Duke Cave", his personal home. There, he receives a call from the President and General Graves of the Earth Defense Force (EDF). The President orders Duke not to harm the invaders, and adds that he is in diplomatic talks with the alien overlord. Duke obliges this request, but he and Graves remain uneasy about the whole situation from start. Before he can leave his chambers, he is attacked by hostile aliens who are swearing revenge on Duke.
Duke is forced to disobey the president's orders and fight his way through the alien hordes in an effort to save Earth. Whilst fighting through his casino, Duke witnesses the aliens abducting women, including his two live-in pop star girlfriends. Graves tells Duke that the women are being held in the Duke Dome, and that the aliens have a vendetta to settle with Duke. He also warns Duke that the aliens are using the Hoover Dam to power a wormhole so more aliens can come through. Duke travels to the Duke Dome, using a wrecking ball to damage the building to gain access. Inside, he finds swarms of Octabrains and the missing women, who have been impregnated with alien spawn; Duke's girlfriends die after giving "birth" to alien babies. Duke finds the Alien Queen in control of the Duke Dome and kills her, but is wounded in the process and blacks out.
After regaining consciousness, Duke fights Pigcops and aliens in through the Duke Burger. Soon, he travels to the Hoover Dam in his monster truck; after battling through the dam, he finds his old friend Dylan, mortally wounded. He tells Duke that the reborn Cycloid Emperor is at the dam, and that the only way to shut down the portal is to completely destroy the dam. Before dying, he gives Duke his demolition charges and wishes him luck. Duke places the explosives and destroys the dam, but the currents nearly drown him.
Duke is revived by an EDF soldier, and awakens to find the portal gone. The President, who was also at the dam, rages at Duke for ruining his plans to work with the Cycloid Emperor, revealing that the President was actually intending to have the aliens kill Duke and he would cooperate with Cycloid Emperor so he could control the Earth, and that he has ordered a nuclear strike at the site of the dam to wipe out the remaining aliens, intending to leave Duke there to die as revenge for foiling his plans. The Cycloid Emperor emerges and kills the President and his security detail, revealing that he intended to kill the President after the deal. Duke kills the Cycloid Emperor and is rescued by Graves just as the nuclear bomb explodes.
The game ends with a satellite surveying the detonation area and listing Duke Nukem as killed in action, to which Duke replies off-screen, "What kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ending is that? I ain't dead. I'm coming back for more!" In a post-credits scene, a short video depicts a press conference, where Duke announces his intent to run for the 69th President of the United States.

This is a case of a game not getting a fair shake from the public to the hype it garnered from its 15 year development cycle. I found the game to be entertaining and funny. The levels may be linear but it makes up for it with platforming, vehicle sections, optional mini-games, physic based puzzles, and a surprisingly interactive environment to make sure the game never gets tedious.  The guns were all enjoyable to use and the enemies provided a good challenge. And the most important part to a Duke Nukem game, the Duke himself is still charismatic and enjoyable to listen to. Both him and the game are overtop in all the best ways. If people view it as a Duke Nukem twist on the Half-Life style of FPS (like how Duke Nukem 3D was a Duke Nukem twist on the Wolfenstein 3D/Doom [1993] style of FPS) they'll see that the game does the task with aplomb and that the game was better than what journalists initially appraised it.

This game has a serious fetish for puzzles....Puzzles inside a FPS.  Otherwise the gameplay is solid plenty of shooting and classic lines.  Sometimes a bit tacky but that's why you play this game.  Good for one solid playthrough =)

Go buy this game. I've bought it twice (once on PS3 and again on PC) and I've played it through twice, and am partially through my third time. It holds up. It's fun. What more could you ask?
You might ask: why am I recommending this game when everyone else has panned it? Because it's a great satire that went over everybody's heads. Duke was always a parody of '80s action heroes, and here he is, still being a parody of '80s action heroes except now everybody thinks '80s action heroes are dumb now, so they don't see the irony. This game is The Expendables before The Expendables was awesome.
Also, the action is solidly fun through the entire game. The shooting feels good, and it has all of the elements of more popular shooters (such as Doom (2016)'s executions) before they became cool. This game came out before everyone started raving about "throwback" level design, so it got lambasted for being, basically, a more polished version of Half Life 2 with a coat of comedic paint thrown on.
The comedy is low-brow, I'll grant you. Again, we see that Duke came out just a few years too far ahead of his time. I mean, he's less debauched than the new Deadpool movie, and that did pretty well by critical standards.
Sometimes someone needs to break ground so other people can be successful, and they take their lumps for it. Duke Nukem Forever is one of those games. It did a lot of things that everyone is all too pleased to rave about in popular entertainment today, but it did them before they were considered cool.
Not that this game is for hipsters. I don't think Duke Nukem would come within a mile of someone drinking Pabst Blue Ribbon or some skunky craft beer.
UPDATE: I'm just adding a plug for the DLC, which is also good and worth your time, if you're a fan of The Duke.
