Solid game, not worthy of all the bashing reviews it received. Actually the game reminded me quite a bit of the Half Life series: 1) first person shooter 2) aliens come through portal to invade Earth 3) lots of non-shooting portions with puzzles 4) platforming 5) driving sequences 6) some similar levels like the factory
SOUNDTRACK
One advantage it has over Half Life is that it actually has a soundtrack (and a pretty good one) during gameplay. The trend of games without music needs to stop - other big names are also guilty of this such as the Bioshock series. Also the music is in MP3 format in a folder in the game directory if you'd like to copy it onto your computer before uninstalling the game. Most games hide the music and make you use 3rd party tools can be hard to find and/or difficult to use, so this was a nice bonus.
GRAPHICS
They're decent but even on my very powerful i7 4790 with GTX 750 TI, there were framerate and performance issues for 10 to 15 seconds when  starting or restarting a level, and then the problems resolved automatically. On this system I was hoping to play at 3840 x 2160 resolution but performance was too poor.
GAMEPLAY
Boss fights were the best part of the game - challenging but fair and well designed. For the non-shooting segments, which are fairly plentiful, sometimes I wished the game would just move on (mostly during the first half of the game). But I solved everything myself without any help. If you want an all action game all the time game, you should look into the Serious Sam series. But even the original Duke 3D was not all action. Also, the underwater levels were not my favorites. Finally, the game gives you the option of carrying 4 guns (I believe default is 2) - take advantage.

There was a lot of controvery around this game when it came out, not because it's offensive, but because it's a Duke Nukem game. "Duke Nukem 3D" is considered one of the great old school shooters among the likes of "Doom", "Quake", and the like. After being in development for nearly two decades the game was released to a less than stellar recetption. Did it deserve that? Not really.
If you're a die hard fan of the Duke Nukem franchise there's a chance you may be disapointed here. The game had a hype it needed to live up to that it just couldn't. But what if you're like me and fired this up before you ever played "Duke Nukem 3D". In that case there's a lot to like about this game. It's a fun shooter with sometimes rauchy humor but it plays well. Jon St. John is on point as Duke Nukem and the game has a lot of enjoyable weapons.
After spending some time playing "Duke Nukem 3D" I can see exactly why fans were disapointed, but I also see where the game was paying tribute to its predacessor and I think it did that quite well.
I'd say this is a game worth picking up, though catch it on deep discount. I snagged it as part of the $1 tier of a 2K Humble Bundle and I was fine with that price. I'm very excited to pick up the games DLC "The Doctor Who Cloned Me" but not until it goes on sale for several dollars again.
The game's multiplayer is dead so it's safe to skip if you're looking for a game with longevity and replayablity through an online component, but if you're looking for a fun 80's-movie-esque single player campaign with a fun world (and a willingness to poke fun at itself) then I'd say pull the trigger and grab it on sale.
I did play the game using the expanded inventory mode, though I may go back and redo the game with the title's limitation to two weapons and see how that plays.

Duke Nukem Forever is a controversial title. It's release in 2011 was met with a lot of hatred: and rightly so. It's poor production values are obvious. Anything that isn't directly in front of the player (including things that are in the distance) are a horrific blur. For a title released in 2011 it was unforgiveably ugly. Not to mention feeling incredibly dated with Arcadey-shooter game mechanics that were the norm more than 10+ years ago, in 2011 Duke Nukem Forever felt, well.. Very out of place.
With driving sections that were poorly designed and terrible puzzles (because when people think Duke Nukem, they think PUZZLES)
To understand part of the hatred, you need to go back. I mean way back - to the 90's. Duke Nukem was at the height of it's popularity. For fourteen years after the last Duke Game, many fans awaited this installment. Duke Nukem Forever has been in development hell for ages. People pre-ordered the game in the early 2000s', then had those pre-orders cancelled.
Shady business practices aside, what is Duke Nukem? It's very much a game that shines light on Duke Nukem as it was in the 90's: a game full of cheesy jokes, pop culture references, and crass humour. To Say Duke Nukem Forever isn't exactly what the fans deserved is, well, unjust. Duke Nukem forever IS an Arcade shooter in every sense of the word. It hits all those notes, and, if I admit, in 2016 it doesn't feel as terrible as it did in 2011 when you get past all the drama of it's long-awaited release. It's an O.K game. Would I have ever recommended someone buy it for 69.99CAD? No. There are definitely better games out there. But Duke Nukem Forever is fun for what it is.
But that's just it: it's fun for what it is, and what it costs NOW. There are better games out there that I think people could be playing. Is it absolutely horrible? No. Even for it's current price I couldn't recommend it for anything but a blast to the past - to see why what worked 20 years ago simply won't work today. And I feel like that's what Duke Nukem was trying to be. It was trying to be the same game it was from the 90s', and for a lot of people this brand of humour just isn't the thing that makes us laugh anymore. It tries to capitalize on nostalgia, and I always feel like without innovation or real passion behind a project, that capitalization is bound to fail.
Unless you've got a few dollars and LITERALLY nothing better to do? Play it. If you're a stingy bastard, you know, go and buy something your money would actually get you more enjoyment out of.

Originally published Jan 4 2012
After the legendary development hell, and the near legendary last-minute rescue by Gearbox, Duke Nukem Forever had no chance to meet any kind of expectation. Reviews were poor to scathing though the game sold more copies than expected, perhaps at the cost of longtime PR companies' reputation.
As a historical relic, it is a fascinating journey through trends in game design. Almost in chronological order, the game meanders it's way from era to era, adapting the conventions of the Half-Life 2 era, moving on through Doom 3, and eventually settling on Halo-esque recharging health and COD cover based shooting.
It is a startlingly ugly game both in tone and look. The early levels have a post-processed spit-shine, and depth-of-field is abused like a crack ♥♥♥♥♥'s dignity. Later levels become exercises in how unfinished the game can appear and still function.
Following a Duke who made famous by his world-saving exploits, locations include parts of Vegas and the desert. Women are plastic and disposable, thought they are obstensibly the point of the plot as saving them is the driving force for what resembles a plot.
The blantent mysoginy culminates in a unintentionally disturbing trip through a dark underground Hive where women are not only naked, and glued to columns but actively being impregnated by alien spiders. The only recourse is to watch them explode into baby spiders or to explode them by shooting them before they blow up.
As an independant exercise in circle-strafing, DNF can be fun and early on the unapologetic sexism results in some funny moments but the game wears quickly.
DNF is longer than expected or wanted, and after fighting the same three stage boss 10 times, I quit Duke 4 chapters from the end, but not before Duke quit me.

So the Duke Nukem 3d 20th Anniversary World Tour is going to be released soon, so in order to celebrate I decided to play Duke Nukem Forever again, to see if I hated it as much now as I did when I preordered it. So, do I still think it's the worst game ever? Well...no. I've certainly played games that were much worse. But I still think it's pretty bad.
Duke Nukem Forever is guilty of using just about every gimmick and cliche used in FPS games made in the 2000-2009 era, and I wish I was joking. Magically regenerating health, limited stamina, only being able to carry two weapons, forcing you to solve puzzles to progress, events where you either have to take control of a turret or drive a vehicle...you name it. But out of all these tired and overdone cliches, what really seals the coffin on this game for me is that this game is made up entirely of quicktime and scripted events, and the levels are so linear there's no room for any exploring whatsoever.
In other words, instead of the fast-paced and intense gameplay in a large map that required us to explore high and low for secrets, health,  ammo and keys to progress, while at the same time trying not to die to entire armies of aliens? That's all been replaced with linear paths, scripted events and NPCs that refuse to let you progress until you've either killed a few aliens the game wanted you to kill, or force you to listen to meaningless dialogue that adds little or nothing to the game, but thought you should listen to it anyway.
So did Duke Nukem Forever do anything correctly? Kind of. Duke is still that womanizing horndog that we got to know and love in 1996 that spews one liners and cracks jokes. However, unlike Duke 3d where it was done with some moderation, this game feels like it was filled to the brim with almost nothing but toilet humor and nudity galore. Not necessarily a bad thing, but my goodness does it tend to get old quickly.
I didn't exactly expect Duke Nukem Forever to be a masterpiece after waiting for more than a decade for it to come out, but I did expect it to be something refreshing and new. Unfortunately it was neither of these things, and while I don't think it's the worst game ever, I've played far too many games that were just like it. 1.5/5.0
Not as bad as you may think, if you expect a bad game, you'll enjoy this, if you expect AAA wonder, turn back.

It's difficult to view and judge Duke without taking his past into account; and this is partly good and partly bad. It's good because Duke is a legend in the gaming world, therefore anything involving him gains automatically a lot of value. And it's bad because seeing how the game Duke Nukem Forever, after taking forever to be completed and relased, didn't turn out as glorious as Duke the man deserved, it's somewhat unfair.
That said, Duke Nukem Forever is not a bad game; it's a generally nice game and on certain occasions it's very good. It has well-made environments - sometimes particularly atmospheric, like the Ghost Town in the main game or the Tunnels in the DLC; the music is fine and fitting; there are several known enemies making a comeback (the Octabrains are back with a vengeance), and of course Duke is his usual badass self, with his hilarious lines and his ever-mighty boot.
What doesn't seem to work that well is the general gameplay design; it feels rushed and incomplete. Some of the puzzles look complicated, but in fact they are so easy, you may end up solving them without realizing it. The vehicle mechanics are frustrating at times, and some of the boss fights drag on too long. And you may find that, apart from wanting to get certain Achievements, there is probably no big replay value. I guess that all that went wrong with this game is due to the fact the development team didn't remain stable from start to finish and at the end they had to complete the game somehow and release it with no further delay (just like it happened with Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness).
Still, I did enjoy the game to some degree, which is why I am recommending it; also for sentimental reasons, because Duke Nukem 3D was one of the very first games that I played years ago.

This game is a mixed bag of funny parts and some crappy game design ideas.
Instead of pros and cons let's take a look what's fun and what's crappy.
Fun:
- weapons are fun
- enemy design is also fun
- ego boost mechanism - it's always fun to have some minor advantage by finding some secrets
- vehicles
- humor in the DLC
- shooting aliens
- 4 weapons option
- The Doctor Who Cloned Me DLC is probably better than the whole DNF vanilla game
Not funny:
- turd jokes can be fun but not when encountered en masse. Overall the humor in the baseline game as well as in the DLC can be really crude and primitive sometimes
- 2 weapons option - really, in a modern shooter? What were they thinking! (line borrowed from AVGN)
- level design - in some levels you must go from point A to point B and it takes about forever
- not that much shooting in a shooter game, I would rather call it a walking/running with a gun and pressing buttons simulator
- vehicles when you need to spend there too much time (like in this canyon level or moon level from DLC)
- boss fights are scripted and somewhat disappointing
- no bots in multiplayer - and you bet that servers are pretty much empty now
To be honest - I've had a great time playing DNF some time ago (about a year or two after release) and I've got a great time playing this fun DLC - The Doctor Who Cloned Me not that long ago. I would rather not play single player campaign again. Not that it's not fun because it is fun but because those not funny elements are dominating over funny ones - large levels where you need to run from point to point and shoot about three enemies in the meantime or some puzzles that you need to solve in order to proceed forward.
In conclusion, this is a shooter game with a moderate amount of shooting. Well, I call it a Duke Nukem Adventure Game rather than a shooter game. Those shooting scenes can get pretty intense, but after that there is a prolonged scene where you need to walk here and there and not much is going on.
I give this game thumbs up, for the fond memories of it. If you've never played it then go on, it's not that bad. Definitely try the DLC The Doctor Who Cloned Me. It's short and it's fun. It's what's good in DNF without boring parts.

To begin with, I am not a Duke Nukem super fan. I did play Duke Nukem 3D a long time ago and completed about one episode of it and few levels of other episodes. I do love classic FPS games such as the original Doom, Heretic, Hexen,Star Wars Dark Forces and Blood.
The only good thing I found about Duke Nukem Forever is some of the complexity in level designs, especially the parts when Duke becomes tiny and everything around you is huge.
The rest of the game is either average or bad.
Graphics and animations feels very rushed like the game did not take its time (apperantly 12 years aren't enough). You can easily spot bad textures and you can notice how some 3d objects in the map have poor details. Animations for monsters are about as average and Duke's animations are horrible. Story is very uninspired and has no plot. This detail can be overlooked but just like a bad porno, the game can't stop shoving flat uninteresting character to your face. Gameplay as mentioned above, can get interesting with how complex you travel inside the level. Some shining moments were such as trying to get an item from a locked room by controling a remote car. The game's asset is also extremely repetitive. It feels like every place in Duke's world owns barrels and wooden boxes. The Duke is finally back, but should we hail the king or blow it out our asses? Aaron checks out Duke Nukem Forever...
Alright, I admit it. Back in the day, I was a bit of a Duke Nukem fanboy. Duke 3D was amazing, and it was, in my option, the best FPS of the time, beating even id's Quake. So, it goes without saying that, when the next Duke Nukem title was announced after Duke 3D's release, I was very excited, indeed.
As the months and eventually years rolled on, this excitement started to wane. Setback after setback, no-show after no-show ate away at my enthusiasm, until I was left, much like every other fan, with nothing but a bitter taste in my mouth. Duke soon became vapourware and we'd all but given up on his return.
After the fiasco of 3D Realms' closure, the final nail was, seemingly, hammered into the coffin. Did I care? No, not really. By that time I couldn't care less if Forever ever arrived. Sad, but true.
When Gearbox Software announced it had resurrected the title and that it would finally see the light of day, I hardly jumped for joy. In fact, it was more 'meh' than 'yeah!' Still, if only for nostalgia's sake, I had to play it, but I was hardly pumped.
So, why then, despite the fourteen year wait and the heavily unoptimistic outlook of the title did I start to grin like a five-year-old when I finally fired up the game?
Yep, even with nothing but cynicism in my noodle, as soon as the familiar drum hits and guitar riffs of the Duke theme rocked out of the speakers, I was instantly ready to kick♥♥♥♥♥and chew bubblegum (and yes, I was all out). I was a very happy chappy, and memories of 1996's frag fest soon drifted back.
Sadly, though, this feeling didn't last all that long.
As we all know, Duke Nukem Forever has been in the kind of development hell that no other title has ever faced. Over the years, the project has seen several game engines, redesigns, staff changes and more. It's amazing that anything coherent came out of the development process, even after being hammered together by the talented guys over at Gearbox, and it's not long after starting the game that you begin the see the results of this tortured evolution.
You immediately notice that, visually, Duke Forever is a bit of a mess. To say that this looks like an original Xbox title may be a bit of an overstatement, but it's not a statement that's all that far wrong.
There's no antialiasing to speak of, leading to jaggies everywhere, texture pop-in is rife, and although many textures look great, there's a shocking amount of amazingly ugly, low res decals strewn about the world. Object modelling is often basic and notably rushed, and the overall feeling is very unpolished and disappointing.
Duke Nukem Forever can, at times, look fairly decent, and although not a patch on today's cutting edge graphics engines, it still packs in the character and feel of the 90s titles. It's just a shame that it looks so dated technically.
Still, graphics aren't everything, and you can overlook a lot, if the game underneath is a winner. Unfortunately, this isn't quite the case.

The core FPS gameplay in Duke Nukem Forever is as straightforward as it gets, and there's nothing in the way of complex game mechanics or originality to be found here. It's full-on run, gun and kick, and nothing more, really. Duke can interact with the environment, solve a few rudimentary puzzles and even drive a couple of vehicles, but for the most part, the game is basic shooter fare.
Enemies are as dumb as their Duke 3D counterparts, and many of the advancements we've come to expect in today's FPS releases are missing, right down to polish, silky smooth controls and buttery aiming. Duke is often clunky and sluggish, which is a bit of a problem when many foes zip around the screen at high speeds.
The vehicle sections are decent enough, but controls are iffy, often leading to untimely deaths or bouts of wall-kissing as you get hung up on scenery, and load times are excessive, leading to prolonged pauses if you die and have to reload over and over, something you'll be doing a lot on higher difficulties.
Even with these flaws and lack of TLC, Duke Nukem Forever's gameplay is solid enough, and a couple of enhancements have been made. Duke no longer has a health bar, but instead packs an Ego meter. This functions like everybody's favourite Spartan's shield, and as you take damage, it's depleted. Once it's gone, take too many hits and you're dead. Stay out of harm's way and it'll recharge. Simple, if wholly unoriginal stuff, but welcome nonetheless.
As you explore you can increase the size of Duke's ego by performing certain actions, such as lifting weights, winning at slot machines, signing autographs and even smashing a blatant Christian Bale-alike in the face. You can even play a fully functional pinball table to earn more ego.
This time Duke can engage foes in hand-to-hand combat, and can perform executions on wounded enemies. There's also a few QTE-style button mashing events to open doors, finish off bosses and the like. The inventory system has been mapped to the D-pad, making it easier to access items, and you can use a nifty ‘Duke-vision' system to see in the dark. These may be very basic changes, granted, but every little helps.
The problem is that, despite these few simple additions, Forever's a game that's never quite made it out of the late 90s, and it's painfully obvious that this game was conceived over a decade ago. Simply put, it shows its age.
Shake it, baby!
Luckily, even though it was released many years ago, the original Duke 3D had some unique ideas that have stood the test of time, and have returned here. Most notably Duke's arsenal of weapons still packs an enjoyable punch (even if the weapon models are some of the ugliest I've ever seen), and the shrink ray and freeze guns are as entertaining as ever, as are pipe bombs and trip mines.
These lead to some cool moments, and the varied alien horde make for some interesting foes, if often stupid ones. Titanic Battlelords, floating commanders and deadly Octobrains are just a few of Duke's memorable cast, and each has been beefed up for this outing.
The many interactive environments and items add to the enjoyment, too, even if most are nothing more than frivolous detractions, and environments throughout are interesting, taking in such locations as opulent casinos, the burning ruins of Las Vegas and alien-infested hives.
There's also the simple, basic fact that Duke Nukem Forever is just plain fun, in a stupid, over the top way. In a time when we find ourselves wall to wall with ever more unimaginative and downright dull real world military shooters, Duke Forever is a breath of fresh air, and that alone will make the game worth it for some, even if it's nowhere near as good as it should be, and is more guilty pleasure than classic blockbuster.
Then there's the 'humour'. Duke's trademark misogynistic ways and crude style are back in force, and may or may not hit the mark, depending on your appreciation of schoolboy humour and poorly modelled cleavage. It's all a little childish, really, but this is a Duke Nukem game, so it's to be expected.
There are a few pokes at pop culture in there too, such as the aforementioned Mr Bale, and even a dig at Halo's Master Chief. It all adds to the fun, but is hardly a substitute for polished gameplay.

I think the problem with this game, is that its designed to do 3 things:
1. Cool 90s simulator
From the♥♥♥♥♥slapping humor, the referances, to the usage of Beer and Steroids as items. Especially the action figure levels
2. First person shooting with cool guns
After playing Shadow Warrior, Doom 1 & 2, Heretic & Hexen and some Duke 3D: I think I understand what "cool guns" is. Or how its suppose to play.
3. Filler content
Puzzle platforming, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ short "interactive" cinematics, physic puzzles, lots of "oh we can do this in engine like its 2001-2004!"
These 3 things mesh somewhat. But its also problematic.
I.E The irst 2 things don't really mesh, the way this game is made.
You are controlling a very slow elite solider, who can barely move. The gun's generally don't do anything either. Most of them are terrible in their own ways. And as the level design evolve, you spot another issue: Duke is practically blind. The extreme narrow vision don't work out at all.
While its true a lot of 90s fps features very narrow vision, it worked out differently when you could snap across extremely large rooms, in rapid speed. It works out terrible when Duke is slow, can barely damage anything, can't see anything, and keeps getting flanked.
But that also brings us to the next point on the agenda: Enemies don't really deal damage. They don't feel scary. Fighting them feels like swatting flies, slow flies that poke you.
But generally your guns are not any better. The best weapon might even be the pistol, simply because its accurate and has raw damage. Every other weapon has crippling flaws, and generally feels awful.
"Different weapons do better against different enemies", thats what the hint tells you. Not really. The pistol is the best. Even if something like the shotgun is cool, its pointless when it only works as a melee weapon. And all weapons feel worse than the pistol and shotgun.
But then:
Point 3 of the list comes if, you complete a combat section. Either you have to wait for new cinematic and a enemy bash trough something, or you encounter the dreaded physic puzzles.
You can't just become good, and go really really fast. Instead you have to spend a lot of time waiting around, for the horrible cinematics. Some of them are amusing, but most aren't that good. Its just waiting around A LOT for a NPC to stop blocking door ways.
And at some point, you enter a boss fight. Okay, so you need to use explosive weapons. But explosive weapons have practically no ammo. Often there will be a ammo container on the scene. Or a rocket launcher tucked somewhere on scene, so you can obtain a explosive weapon.
It doesn't feel great at all.
Some of the finishers looks good, as in humoristically good. Thats a plus. But most bosses are terrible to fight. The best boss might even be the final one, because it lacks the obstacles earlier bosses have.
Because instead of camping a ammo chest, rocket pigs are his reinforcement.
Because instead of a gatling gun, he tries to be impressive.
The core problem with this game, is that it fails to understand what a power trip is, fails to understand speed, and simply isn't juvenile enough to do any of the things it wants to do.

Duke Nukem Forever is a game that is notorious for having spent nearly 15 years in development hell.
The finished product is built from the all the assets that were created for the game between 2003 and 2009 (as found in pictures that were released when the game was pretty much cancelled in 2009). What Gearbox then did was patch all that unfinished content together, and create a fairly minimal amount of content in order to obtain a game that they could release.
As far as the gameplay goes, the game is unfortunately way too much of a departure from the original, with a 2-weapon loadout made to facilitate the use of a controller (later patched to a 4-weapon loadout in single player), fairly slow movement speed with the possibility to sprint in very short bursts, and some fairly clunky platforming at times. The gunplay itself is decent, but suffers from annoying reverse mouse acceleration which can't be disabled.
Due to the troubled development of the game, the levels are quite a mixed bag. Some of them are cleverly designed (The Duke burger is a favorite of mine), while others feel quite linear and empty, and the graphical quality varies a lot between areas. Exploration is rewarded with easter eggs and collectibles, and the levels are filled with interactive elements.
The story is actually based on the original one written in 1997, and is a straight sequel to Duke Nukem 3D. Just like in D3D, it is extremely simplistic. The writing can get really cringe-worthy at times, with some dated references and (intentionally?) bad jokes. The voice acting is a bit of a mixed bag too, despite John St John reprising his role as Duke Nukem.
The multiplayer is pretty much dead by now, with very few servers to be found.It is comprised of 4 very basic game modes and 10 maps in the main game. The "Hail to the Icons" introduces 3 more modes as well as 4 maps, and "The Doctor Who Cloned Me" also contains 4 maps. There is a progression system in play, with objectives that unlock hats, glasses and shirts upon completion, and a levelling system that unlocks items in a virtual apartment of sorts.
In terms of graphics, the game is very inconsistent It does have a couple of fairly impressive set pieces, but many levels turn out to be very ugly, plenty of low-resolution textures and a somewhat uninspired design. You can really tell the artwork that was created in 2003-2006 from what was made at Gearbox during the last stages of development.The lighting model is very good, though, with a Doom 3-style fully dynamic lighting system that looks genuinely good in some places.
The biggest problem with the graphics actually comes in the form of a poorly implemented, low-resolution, depth-of-field effect. Not only does it kick in at all the wrong times, but it is also so low-resolution that it just drowns the screen into a pixelated blurry mess. And unfortunately, the only way to turn it off is deactivating all the post-process effects altogether (There is a fix for that however in the form of an older build of the FlawlessWidescreen utility).
The music and sound design are pretty good, with a decent heavy metal score and fairly convincing sound effects.
In terms of performance, the game runs fine on a variety of hardware. Loading times are fairly long, and the game suffers from the typical old Unreal texture streaming issues. There is a fair range of graphical customization available, however the options aren't very detailed, with some options bundled in a single menu entry. There are also only post-process antialiasing methods available, which only add to the already blurry nature of the game.
The single-player campaign can be completed in about 10+ hours, with some hidden collectibles to find. The multiplayer is mostly dead nowadays. The "The Doctor Who Cloned Me"' DLC is very good, and adds an additional 4 hours or so of additional single player content.
In conclusion, while it was a bitter disappointment in 2011, Duke Nukem Forever isn't as terrible a game as most would say. I did have quite a bit of fun playing it, despite its many flaws. However, it wasn't worth its full price at the time, and it still isn't worth its current price either. It's one of those "get it when it's on sale if you are really curious" kind of games, and the price does drop quite significantly when it goes on sale. For $5 or regional equivalent, it might be worth it.

Part of the joy of Duke3D was the maps - they were interesting places to explore and roam around, you'd often find yourself doubling back and finding new areas or reaching previously-inaccessible parts after completing some objective.  Sure there were hookers and pixelated titilation, but that was beside the fact.  The unique and interesting maps made Duke3D what is was - fun.
DNF dispenses with this and puts in a rat-run of boring linear corridors sprinkled with tired "jokes".   You just run along a corridor from scripted set-piece to scripted set-piece, listening for the oh-so-funny-and-never-heard-before wisecracks (that was sarcasm, by the way) waiting for the inevitable and unavoidable chokepoint where you are trapped until you've killed the amount of monsters the map maker wanted you to kill then a door opens you are allowed move on.
This wouldn't be so bad if the weapons were any good, but they're not - you're limited to two-at-once (you have to drop an existing weapon to pick up the RPG for instance), and are unsatisfying to fight with feeling underpowered and you feel restricted by ammo.
To be fair there is the odd glimmer of something greater - a few puzzles and parts of the maps hint at what could have been (e.g. the wrecking ball puzzle and other areas around the "Duke Dome"), but they are still ultimately trapped in the boring corridors.
It is a real shame, but I've not given up on Duke.  A reboot that respects its roots and goes back to more open, explorable environments would be great.

Normally I would play a substantial amount of the game or finish its story before writing a review about it, but playing Duke Nukem Forever feels like a chore - a horrible, boring, unending chore.
It is impossible to ignore the protracted and difficult development that this game had, having taken 12 years and 5 studios to actually produce, since it is obvious that Duke Nukem has suffered from the years. The gameplay is boringly generic and offers nothing new to the genre, which is considerable given how revolutionary Duke Nukem 3D was back in the day, whilst the graphics and humour are both horrible outdated; some textures date back as far as 2005 - a whole 7 years before the finalised product - and the environments aren't particularly pleasent to look out. The humour is also extremely poor despite Jon St. John's performance which is, as it was in the original games, fantastic - but the lines he delivers feel a decade past their sell-by date.
In short Duke Nukem Forever is a horrible game that suffered from its hell in the development stage; this could have been a great old school FPS with some witty one-liners but instead suffers from a lack of identity as it tries to be a 21st century FPS whilst retaining the qualities of its heyday and just becomes a glorious mess. There's no fun and Duke Nukem will go back to its dormant state. FOREVER.

I've seen people say this 'thing' is a faithful sequel to Duke 3D, and those are the type of people that have 72 hours in Black Ops 3 Multiplayer and 0.2 in Duke Nukem 3D. So you can make your own opinion on those people.
Level Design:
Duke Nukem 3D's level design was open, it allowed you to enjoy the level in your own way and find secrets. DN:F's level design is about as open as a mole's eyelid and about inspired as CoD 4's Multiplayer Map, Shipment. I tried exploring but it was just so 'chore like' so i stopped trying. From the levels I played, I found only one secret (in the first level) and it was being able to... pick up a soggy turd and throw it around the room. Probably put there to reflect the gameplay.
Gameplay:
Enemies in Duke 3D would spout blood out like a fountain and sometimes even kneel down allow you to kick them right in the face. DN:F's enemies have less blood shooting out of them but when their body parts go flying you feel like you can take the world... Until you run into the horrid checkpoint system, sometimes putting you at the beginning of levels and some times through the actual floor. Enemies may have an interesting gib system but it doesn't make up for how they just become bullet sponges and on higher difficulties kill you quite fast.
Overall Duke Nukem: Forever is a clunky mess with outdated, childish humour, taking you through phallac alien hives with hanging breasts on the wall with the option to 'press x to slap' and 'tickle' a n u s looking gateways and to top it all off, end it with fighting a three boobed alien queen mith matching jiggle physics.

A stunning and unnecessary letdown.
Like many gamers of my age-range I have a very personal connection with this game since I have been waiting for it for more than a decade and on top of that I have avoided playing DNF since its surprising actual release in 2011 until now when I got it via humblebundle. Suffice to say the release of Duke Nukem Forever feels like a historical event. When it was first announced back in 1997 I was in elementary school. A lot has changed in my life, in the world, in gaming since then. It's been so long you could basically make a wonderful period piece about the late-nineties because that era of gaming is obscured to many active gamers just by virtue of their late birth, just as the dawn of gaming is shrouded in mystery for me. It's almost impossible to describe in words what images flash before my eyes when I think of that time. Polygons came and swept everyone away, 3D accelerators arrived and did the same to everyone's wallet. Memories of marveling at the prowess of 3Dfx cards and saving my pocket money to buy the 64mb of RAM required to play Star Trek Elite Force. Hours of sweaty desperation spent trying to translate the levels I had drawn in school into the Build Engine in a time before I was able to properly (or rather barely) speak english - I think it's necessary to underline these precious memories a bit so you can properly understand my frustration and disappointment with this title, because it's so very easy to grab me by the nostalgia gonads and yank my wallet around by it, yet DNF failed to do so.
Through subsequent years and countless 3D engines DNF frequently occasionally reared its ugly stubborn head, changing faces numerous times. Around 2003/4 it seemed even somewhat finished with an intriguing trailer that put it right up there with other FPS of the new millenium like Timesplitters, Red Faction, XIII and the likes. The years gone-by saw the rise of fluent console first person shooters, endless retreads of "tactical" shooters like the Call of Duty series and the development of most gaming genres coming to a grinding halt. DNF could have been a sparkling beacon of the virtues of times past.
We have to move back in time a few years to understand why DNF was such a letdown. It might seem obvious that about 14 years of anticipation could never be matched but I think that anticipation has been overrated when it comes to the critical reception of this game. In the 90s the first-person shooter ruled supreme. In hindsight it's hard to imagine but back then it was one of the (maybe even
) most creative and innovative genres on the PC (consoles would follow several years later because people hadn't figured out yet that you could use a dual analog-stick layout like a mouse and keyboard setup). Doom had pushed the door wide open and the genre originally titled "Doom-clones" went crazy with the formula the next couple of years. Level designs got more intricate/confusing and still manage to impress to this day, weapons and enemies got more outlandish and so forth. Among those many shooters from the late nineties Duke Nukem 3D and its contemporaries on the lovely Build engine like Blood, Shadow Warrior or Redneck Rampage stuck out. Technically inferior to the all-polygon competition of Quake 1 and 2 they managed to trump with intricate level design, off-beat humour, general levels of weirdness and an overall personality that has yet to meet its match. A more innocent time, buckets of gore, really dumb humour, it was
. FPSs would ultimately lose their edge in the following years ironically by evolving. Half-Life and Unreal were shining examples of the genre taken to the next level but many of the competitors failed to grasp what made these titles so unique and just copied the formula more and more. Which is what got us to the stale First Person Shooter world of today. Of course there are always exceptions, this is just a very personal and biased recollection of the last 20 years of PC gaming by your humble narrator.
Being a former hardcore gamer by 2011 I was basically turned off by most mainstream titles. The crazy production values imposed on AAA gaming still prove to be a detriment to the overall quality of games and especially the willingness by creators to take risk and innovate. It was basically the time that gaming connoiseurs used to get into retro- and indie-gaming, two gifts that keep on giving. Finally enter Duke Nukem Forever. Throughout a troubled (oh what an understatement) development cycle (aka hell) there was still hope that it would triumph and personally I wished it to be amazing and even after so many years of waiting and tiredless mocking by the press (DNF = did not finish etc.) there was some hope. DNF has the attitude and braindead humour you've come to expect and love and being a relic from a different time could have worked to its benefit (just take a look at retro-styled indie games) - it didn't need to be the most innovative game of all time to succeed. I think a lot of people were merely clamoring for a fast, relentless, charmingly dumb, politically incorrect old-school FPS with loads of funny weapons, punishing difficulty, complex multi-layered levels etc. It could have worked had it stuck to its original strengths. The big problem here despite the commendable attitude and outdated but welcome style of humour Duke Nukem Forever turned out ot be a by-the-numbers contemporary FPS, painfully bland and unengaging.
Everything boring about the standard FPS is found here. Painfully linear over-choreographed levels, an artifical two-weapon limit (why oh why? Halo wasn't
good), regenerating health, abundance of Checkpoints that take any challenge and punishment out of failing, unnecessary and shockingly uninspired turret sections, the list goes on. Beyond that, the basic shooting mechanics are just not fun, all the weapons lack punch and style. If DNF had been a retro throwback, warts and all, I would have commended it but what we got in the end was a bland experience, symptomatic of everything boring with current First person shooters. It makes fun of all the tropes but still uses them.
In the end DNF is possibly the greatest example of blue balls in the gaming world. It's a fascinating little trainwreck that should have never been released. As is, it's quite interesting to disect. You can cut through it like a tree and see all the rings, all the engine changes, remnants of changing trends in gaming, different developers who just gave up, but that doesn't make the gameplay any less tiring and mediocre. It clearly feels like an unfinished game that was left in the vault for too long, only to be slightly dusted off and subsequently released.
There's a scene in the first Star Trek movie where a beaming accident causes a Spock-stand-in to be horribly mangled in the process and die quickly in a grotesque blob of flesh and guts. I don't remember the exact line that was spoken there but it was something like "What went through didn't live long, fortunately". Almost twenty years after I first anticipated Duke Nukem Forever I can finally put its corpse to rest. Not worth anyone's time. Avoid it, it's really as bad as everyone says.

I recieved this game as a part of a humble bundle I spent $1 on, and I had no expectations from playing previous Duke Nukem games and waiting 15 years for this one. Nevertheless, this game was very disappointing. The game was fun early, but quickly became boring and annoying for me.
The main problem with this game is level design. Despite being a "first-person shooter" Duke Nukem Forever doesn't actually have you doing much shooting. Instead, you spend most of the game doing puzzles and completing lengthy platforming sections. Some of these sections are fun, but it gets boring after a while. The short duration of most of the game's gunfighting segments makes this problem even worse.
Despite all of its other well-documented flaws, Duke Nukem Forever could have been a very fun game if it were a mindless, comical, action-packed, old-school shooter. But the overabundance of physics puzzles and platforming sections simply made it feel like a very cheap Half-Life 2 imitation. The glimpses of juvenile fun early in the game give way to a bogged-down chore. The game features a lot of cool weapons like shrink rays and freeze rays but barely gives you a chance to try them all out. Ultimately, I cannot recommend this game because it is exactly what all games strive not to be: boring.

Bite Size Review - Duke Nukem Forever
The Good:
+MOST Jokes and Puns are in good taste and remind me of my childhood
+Gameplay in some spots remind me of older games like Half Life
+Boobs... I am a simple man
+Has more personality tham most modern shooters
+Fun weapons like freeze and shrink rays and steriods
+Duke nukem one liners!
The Bad:
-Graphics, this game has been in development for a long time, meaning there are parts that look rough
-Gameplay feels underdeveloped in some spots, leaving some levels or bosses boring
-Some jokes are in bad taste and actually take away from the game
-Can only hold two weapons at once? Common this is Duke Nukem!
-No or very little replay Value
-Multiplayer is dead, and no bot support to even just screw around with
-No mod or steam workshop support made available to the community
-No develpoer commentary which would be so great for this game
The Verdict:
This game should not be bought to be enjoyed as a game. The graphics are old and in some spots downright bad, and the gameplay is boring in more than a few spots. This game should be bought as something for players to view and see the history of this game - to see what a game with decades of restarting and redoing content looks like. This game can make you laugh and in some parts be fun, but overall this game has a more interesting story behind it than the game itself. I will say this, I am very much looking forward to the next Duke Nuekm game to see how it improves.

Most of the well beloved humor and quotes from D3D were quotes and references to pop culture back then, just like most of humor in DNF is quotes and references to pop culture of today (including Video Game cliches). The difference being that over time, the public opinion on such practice has shifted greatly. Mostly because now a good chunk of pop culture is related to the internet, and the internet is either very defensive or radically hateful of their "culture".
As for gameplay.
Duke 3D was born in the era of such games as Doom and Quake. And the gameplay REFLECTED this.
D.N.F. was released in the era of more "cinematic" shooters with less focus on pure running and shooting, and more focus on interaction and "Press X to do something awesome" prompts. And the gameplay REFLECTS this.
I'm convinced that if DNF was released at any other time period, it would have looked differently. It could resemble Half Life 2, or the first Half-Life. Nevertheless it would still be peppered with pop culture references relevant to the time periods of when these games were popular.
I suspect that what people wanted and expected was Duke Nukem 3D but with modern graphics, and i wouldn't mind that either, i'm with you on this one.
However if i'm right about Duke Nukem games being parodies of the games popular AT THE TIME of the game's release, then this is exactly what we were supposed to get. And personally, i love it.

Duke Nukem Forever is a first person shooter, developed by Gearbox Software, and published by Take 2 Interactive. Releasing in June 2011 on PC, PS3 and 360, the title was 12 years in the making, and was a highly anticipated release given the popularity of the previous Duke Nukem games.
First of all the gameplay is your regular run of the mill slap stick run and gun action. With Duke Nukem games, you will be used to fast paced action with tons of enemies charging at you, DNF takes a slight different approach and gives you more of an adventure style game world to explore, with plenty of dreaded platforming puzzles to solve. Within the first half an hour I was already sick to death of the amount of jumping puzzles this game had - the action is also very few and far between at times. I was really expecting mayhem from this title but was so disappointed with the honestly boring game play.
DNF has voice acting right the way through, but most of it is just cringe worthy. You have barbie doll type girls with unfunny toilet humor most of the time, with some of the classic lines coming from Duke too. A lot of the time I found myself wincing with emotional pain listening to it; I think we’ve probably just all outgrown the Duke humor now. Visually DNF looks OK. It definitely looks like it was released in 2011, but then when you compare it to other games from that year like Skyrim, it still looks very basic. Not to mention some of the animation of character’s movements look weird as anything!
We do have three levels of difficulty to contend with though, which makes for veteran FPS players looking for that extra challenge can hit their spot, I couldn’t really tell a difference between the normal mode and easy mode though.  In total this game took me about eight hours to finish the story mode. The game also has a multiplayer mode, but this is virtually empty and I struggled to find a game within any sort of respectful timeframe.  Unless you are an FPS junkie, there is little need for a second playthrough, completely linear story and gameplay makes any more than one pointless.
Like I said, this game does offer us something different from the Duke franchise. We have an explorable world on a larger scale than we are used too. With a couple of easter eggs waiting to be found on each stage, and interactive items found throughout too, the level design is definitely the game’s few positive points.
Thankfully the game seems to run OK still, I was able to ramp all the graphics settings to full, and still achieve over 100+ at all times. I did need to turn V-sync off as this gave a strange graphical bug where it looked as if the frame rate was fluctuating when it wasn’t which made me feel a little motion sick, after turning it off though, it fixed the problem. The game is most certainly best played using keyboard and mouse even though a controller is supported.
Duke Nukem Forever had to live up to high expectations, but didn’t even come close to getting past the bare minimum unfortunately. The boring and uninteresting gameplay quite frankly was a laughable excuse for a Duke Nukem game, and the cringe worthy voice acting topped this off to be a pretty poor excuse for a game full stop. I think it’s quite cheeky from the developers to have this game still marked at £14.99 as it isn’t even worth half of that. I wouldn’t even want to recommend DNF even when it’s on sale to be quite honest with you. Sadly I think this will be the last we’ve seen from Duke, but we can all hope for a resurgence like we’ve seen from the likes of Doom and Tomb Raider in recent times.

You've no doubt already heard of this game's reputation.
Allow me to confirm what has been said before.  First though, let's reminisce a little:
Duke Nukem 3D was a defining pillar in the history of PC games.  With quick action, over-the-top kills, great weapon selection, always on-tap (if a bit juvenile) humour and Duke-talk smackdowns, awesome level design with a metric butt-ton of secrets and easter eggs, and delightfully hilarious multiplayer dukematches, Duke 3D absolutely nailed the first person shooter genre, and showed the world what was possible on the PC platform at the time.
So what has fifteen years of development yieded with its sequel, Duke Nukem Forever?
Game freezes on startup, long level load times, absolutely linear levels, boring gameplay, checkpoint game-saves, player limited to carrying only 2 weapons at a time, pitiful and painfully cringe-worthy attempts at humour, and Duke now has all the personality of a limp noodle.
Everything that made the previous game great is missing here.
Bottom line:
F*** you Gearbox for putting out this absolutely terrible and blatantly obvious console port and s***ting on PC gamers who made this franchise great.
A typical example of this shoddiness is the turret level.
Whoever designed the turret level needs to be taken out back behind the barn and shot and p***ed on.  Because of no save-game feature, you WILL replay this level over and over. And over.  You'll see Duke's smashed red blood-stained sunglasses over and over too.  And be forced to wait an insulting five seconds while you stare at them before the game finally prompts you to hit Enter to reload, which takes a further ten seconds.  And then you have to start all over AT THE BEGINNING.
It's an exercise in frustration that is inexcusable given the fact I have the game installed on a Core-i7 machine with an SSD.  I keep saying this every time I buy a game with them, but if I wanted checkpoint saves I'd play this game on an XBox.  I bought the game on Steam, and I'm playing the game on a PC, so f*** off with the checkpoint saves and give me the ability to save the game anywhere I d*** well want.
Final verdict:   Not even on a Steam Sale.

I'm going to tell you how it is, this game is NOT a good Duke Nukem game. This game is not what the series deserves, this game did not deliver the hype because it just isn't right. This is a great FPS, just the wrong series to implement said gameplay.
With that in mind, it is a great FPS. Duke Nukem's character is usually really enjoyable, but he is mediocre in my opinion in this title. The gameplay is modern FPS mechanics, as in only two weapons may be carried and health regenerates. This is not suitable for Duke Nukem.
The lines are mediocre from Duke Nukem. I want to like Duke's character in this game, but I feel he is sorta missing the target just a little bit. His humor isn't god awful, but it just feels lack luster all the same.
The gameplay is fast paced and fun. The weapon, level, and gameplay variety isn't massive but it is a good size. There is a lot of puzzle elements which feels a bit out of placed in how they're implemented but they're not dreadfully boring. In my opinion, the puzzles would be better gone, it only slows down the action and I feel that's a mistake if it's for mediocre puzzles.
The entire campaign is alright. It's not amazing, it's enjoyable though. I feel like it had too many shrinked Duke levels, which is when you're shrinked to a Ken sized doll. I kinda wish it had more space levels, or any for that matter.
There is also online, which is actually pretty fun. Get a group of mates and you'll have a blast for a few hours.
Overall, good game. It did not deserve the hate it got, but that's what happens when you change too much of a series' formula and hype it to death. However, the $20 price tag is attorcious. I suggest wait for a sale.  7-8/10

For the most part, that's what we got.
Do I think the 2001 previews looked and appealed better? Yes.
Do I think the 2001 version might have made a better game? Yes, but that's not the point.
Most of those that were giving this game awful reviews were either those expecting something much, much grander in scope, or were basically kids that grew up on Call of Duty and were just expecting more of that. This is not for those people.
This is more for the Duke faithful that can still fire up and run through the episodes of Duke3D with a smile.
While I still wish for someone to finally give this franchise the love letter it truly deserves, I'm just at least relieved that Duke Forever finally got to see the light of day.

So imagine you're a hack games journalist in 2011. Your traditional revenue streams are hemmoraging before homoncular internet fetuses who play games in videos while making dumb faces and emitting unintelligible noises. Your editor wants clicks, but the people whose fingers you're impelling to do the clicking would have to read after they did that, and that's not what they're into. And then, like a rocket from the sky, the news emerges; Duke Nukem Forever, of all things, has been completed, and is being released. Soon.
Nobody ever actually thought this would happen, and nobody even cares anymore. Even though you weren't smart enough to get a decent job, you're smart enough to understand that it can't really live up to expectations, any more than it can recreate the experience of being 12 and seeing pixellated stripper boobs for the first time, or that feeling of power that occupying the shoes of the world's most famous narcissist can give you. That internet feminism is a thing now too, and Duke Nukem, that rascal, loves to objectify those women.
Looks like you've got a byline, and a perfect opportunity to trash the decent work of a games studio whose work, no matter how good, could never come close to recreating the time and place that was so integral to many people's experience of D3D. So pontificate about how gaming has 'moved on' from the puerile adolescent power fantasy of Duke Nukem, and watch those revenue streams divert ever so slightly from the unintelligible homonculi you despise so much.
I don't know what people were expecting of this game. I also played Duke Nukem 3D as a kid when I shouldn't have been, as well as the tangentially-related originals, although those were slightly more family friendly. This game can't recreate that. It was either going to be a slavish recreation of its predecessor or a faithful transliteration of that character into the (then) modern era of gaming. It is very much the former.
While it irks me that modern cancers seeped into it, such as regenerating health, cover-based action, Call of Duty running, and a limited weapon loadout, these things were not integrated poorly and were very much a part of First Person Shooters at the time this game came out. Duke Nukem is the polyglot ripoff we know and love, Aliens steal his babes, and he steals the alien's lives. The aliens look great, especially the creepy Master Brains, who are translated excellently from the original. The action is well-done and the mechanics change enough to keep things interesting. And the less said about the muckraking journalists who took advantage of political convenience to bash an easy target and the good work of many people, the better. If you want a decent, updated Duke Nukem game with the character you know and love, Godspeed to you. We probably won't ever get better than this.

Let's be honest here. It isn't the worst game ever made, and it isn't the worst game of 2011. It is true that it isn't as good as Duke Nukem 3d by any means, but calling it the worst game ever is a massive exageration. This is a game for Duke fans first and foremost. If you are a fan of Duke Nukem 3d you will get at least some enjoyment out of this game. If you have never played a Duke Nukem game before, go and get Duke 3D. 3D is a much better game,m and this will seem like another generic FPS to you.
Now that that's out of the way, I'm going to tell you that overall I did like and enjoy the game. It has a fair bit of problems but Duke is still a fun character like he was back in 1996. This is the same Misogynistic, Evil Dead quoting idiot who drowns in narcissism. It's a joke and it's intentionally over the top, and if you find that offensive then I don't think you would even be looking at a Duke game. You could argue that Duke is a dated character that should have remained in the 90s, and that might be true, but I still think that having a shallow character fits an action game more than giving us a pretentious character who talks about how horrible killing is before going out and murdeing an entire army.
Duke Nukem Forever is a generic modern FPS with Duke and his weapons being the only standout features. The classic arsenal is all here, we still get the Freezethrower, Devestator, and Shrink Ray . Unfortuanately you can only carry two weapons at a time, and the levels are extremely linear. Remember how in the 90s FPS you had to actually look around and find ammunition? The Developers game you the resources you needed but you had to find
duke forever you literally can run up to a ammo crate an infinite number of times and restock on ammo. You can't even explore the levels as much as you could in 3D.  And this is one of the biggest problems. In a Duke game we should have large complex levels, instead of the simple linear ones we got. The regenerating health is also out of place, but at least they tried to justify it with Ego.
My other biggest problem with the game is that most of the weapons feel underpowered ESPECIALLY the Devestator. The only weapons that feel like they have actual power to them would be the shotgun and the chaingun. The rest aren't much fun to use, and you probably won't be using them.
So get this only if you like Duke Nukem. You will like it. If you have never heard of Duke Nukem before go and play Duke Nukem 3D, it is a much, MUCH, better game and it is one of the must-play classic FPS game of the 90s. Duke Nukem Forever will be just a generic FPS to you.

Forever is a long time. That's what it felt like with Duke Nukem Forever even though it was closer to fifteen years in reality.
This game has a distinct trait that only two other games I played share with it. Those two games are Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas. What do I mean by this? These three games are the only games that stick out in my mind as games I got about two hours into, forgot for a few years, and then completed. The thing is after completing Duke Nukem Forever I felt like it was more an obligation than entertainment.
So aliens break a treaty with Earth and capture all the women and this makes Duke go on a quest to get them back and kick alien butt. All the while you can do little things like play pool, lift weights, and admire yourself in the mirror to boost your ego so you can take more damage before your health gets affected. But don't be fooled; even on lower difficulties you still lose your Ego rather fast but it can be easily replenished by either melee killing a downed enemy or just waiting behind cover like most modern shooters which would be forgivable if this game didn't try to lampshade how "Power armor is for (synonym for cats)" obviously nodding to another FPS franchise that has the same health mechanics. You might have heard of it, it's a franchise that was about giant nuclear metal onion rings in space designed to kill absolutely everything in the universe which will probably never see any more releases on PC because a certain company has to try and justify supporting a certain console.
Driving and puzzles are to be found to try and break up the monotony of shooting things in the face because why play Mario Kart or Portal when you can play DNF? The PC version allows you to turn an option on to carry a whole FOUR weapons! You can even drink beer and take steroids to give yourself buffs if you really feel like it but such actions don't feel essential. Shooting at the pig cops until they die is a valid enough strategy.
Speaking of what you can do, let's talk about the fluff. The intro level to the game allows you to draw on a whiteboard while a soldier speaks the same two lines of dialogue! And your drawing is inconsequential! So is the autograph you sign for a young fan! Do you like to throw human waste for no reason? What about killing yourself by sticking your finger in an electrical socket?
FIFTEEN YEARS!
(I think it speaks volumes when one of the most engaging activities I had was spending almost an hour on the pinball table.)
Multiplayer itself was a fun waste of an evening or two. The most absurd sight I saw playing online was a few guys who obviously spent too much time on the game telling everyone in the match to buy the DLC during the Summer Sale. Maybe if I was even worse with my money than I actually am right now I would have, but it was a novelty and scratched that shooter itch I keep having to deal with.
I think game historians will look back on a game like Duke Nukem Forever and examine it critically, and then look at a game like the newest Doom and wonder how one company could have messed up so bad at trying to modernize an iconic franchise. When I see Duke Nukem as a whole, I can see some potential. Duke is rusty, a reflection of old 80's and 90's macho man types who fought the bad guys and always got the girl. I feel this game had to be released so he coul stretch his legs. The prospect of a new Duke Nukem game fills me with such glee in the amount of outrage he could cause in today's society.
Good luck getting that out of Gearbox though.

Not the Duke Nukem game you are looking for.
Here's the formula for Duke Nukem Forever:
1. Put in a bunch of zero-@ssed internet jokes that any teenage intern could have gathered in an afternoon. The internet isn't funny. We've all seen every meme ever "created" i.e slapped together on imgflip or quickmeme in .9 seconds, at least 6,000 times. They were funny one time. One.
2. Slap in some obligatory attempts at crude humor like picking up poop, drawing a d1ck with a marker, or attempts at being "misogynistic" like having two girls blow Duke while he plays his own video game.
Even if you ignore the absolute lack of soul or personality that went into the humor itself,  Duke Nukem Forever was a boring, uncreative shootfest game whose best moment was aforementioned fellatio scene where you play an homage to the end of Duke Nukem 3D, which took place before the actual game even started. DNF was nothing but a Frankenstein's monster of mishmashed gaming concepts which had proven popular in the years and years the game spent in development limbo - in GOOD games. Like Counter-Strike, or Half-Life, or Halo. The vehicle segments were buggy and boring. The combat was braindead. The Duke quips were 14 years out of place. The levels were uninspired, as was the level progression, and the game's one true callback to the original was a juvenile level full of alien anuses that culminated in fighting a three titted alien who took zero effort whatsoever to kill. There weren't even strip clubs or nudey mags, or keys, and the captured human women were irrelevant (I'm not counting the mandatory, ridiculously bad strip club intermission level).
The fact that this game has 70% positive reviews would be amazing, if it weren't simply more proof that gamers have no taste. In fact, the score went up 3% since I originally wrote this. It has no replayability, and that's a stretch to say it even had playability the first time.

Tens of millions of dollars, over 14 years spent in development, at least two engine switches and four development resets... all for a game that plays nothing like Duke Nukem. The gameplay is mediocre, unsatisfying and generally not fun. There's no exploration in the levels, no secrets and nothing beyond linearity. The weapons handle badly and are limited to a two or four weapon limit, but the levels have all been designed with a two-weapon limit in mind, which means no ammo and the mandatory use of some weapons in certain sections. The game wastes its energy with a poorly written, poorly thought out story that shouldn't even be there. The graphics are horrid and the post-processing (which is the only way to make it look decent) will ruin your eyesight. Seriously. The multiplayer isn't much to write home about, either - it's based on the singleplayer so you have the same terrible weapons, and the level design is generally pretty awful.
The fact that Gearbox considered this fit for release tells you volumes about what sort of developer they are. If you can get it for cheap, give it a try, but keep in mind that this is Duke in name only.

This is it.  When I first heard about it, I pre-ordered.  When I heard Gearbox was involved, I was excited.  When I played, it was fantastic!  I don't care about the hate.  Duke Nukem was a spoof from the beginning, looking hardcore.  Some of us as kids didn't know that he was the poster child of the 80's and early 90's.  We were just excited about the graphics being the best we'd ever seen, and having blood in a game!  He still makes comments like he used to, though by now it's not so much a gimmick as it used to be.  He still has a sweet weapon set, and he's saving the day.  I am not bothered by a linear level layout or a regenerating health bar.  Gearbox made this game playable for CASUAL gamers like me.  For what little story there was, I loved it. He's not a character that grows or matures, and maybe that's sad for some of us who have young memories of him.  Don't forget what Duke Nukem was BEFORE Duke Nukem 3D. Duke Nukem Forever ist probably best know for its development history: after numerous changes of engines, faked trailers, a long silence and a lawsuite, Gearbox Software (today probably best known for the Borderlands games), finished the game. It was probably not the best for their reputation as the game is average through and through. Die graphics is roughly on the same level as Half-Life 2, without the great systems for animations and facial expressions. It follows the blueprint of a classic first person shooter, which includes puzzles in the levels whch are all well done. The rest ist mostly standard fps level design, only in very few instances the genius level design which made Duke3D a masterpiece shines through. I noticed that quite a lot of arenas are in the game, where the player is trapped and has to defend multiple waves of enemies. The weapons are part standards like a pistol and a shotgun and part crazy weapons like the ice- and shrinkray, but nothing that veterans of Duke3D aren't familar with. But they are not as effective (or should I say: overpowered?) as their counterparts in the predessesor. Since only four weapons can be equipped at the same time (two if the option is deactivated), I decided not go for the exotic weapons but more for the standards to be prepared for most situations. The number of emeny types is quite low, also mostly well known foes. But their behaviour has change quite a bit, making them a new challenge. But some more different ones would have been good. The driving stages are no highlight as especially the buggy with its huge tires is a agile as a rubber boat. The game has though bossfights, which range from very good like the one against the alien queen (which does not only require fast fingers but a bit of thought) to average like the one against the Octaking.
But that can be the summary for the whole game: nothing is really bad, but the highlights are far and few, making the whole game quite average. For fans of classic fps games it is worth picking up in a sale.

My personal review on Duke Nukem Forever. Hey, Steam told me to update it so here we go
🔵 Pros
+ Duke Nukem
+ Return of Duke's iconic arsenal and his voice actor
+ Pacing and story telling is identical to the Half-Life series
+ Variety
+ Women
🔴 Cons
- Outdated graphics
- 70% (or less) of the actual DNF 2009 we could've gotten before 3DR's financial crisis
When you search "developmental hell" on Google, the first thing you'll see is Duke Nukem  (no joke you should try it lol). A sequel to the cult classic Duke Nukem 3D, Duke Nukem Forever, was in development hell for 14 years: from 1997 to its release date in 2011. The main reason for this development hell was the owners of Duke Nukem Forever felt that the game on their hands was not good enough, so they kept adding, changing and delaying the game to the point that they ran out of money which ultimately led to their bankrupcy.  In 2009, the rights to the Duke Nukem franchise were sold to Gearbox Software, who eventually completed the game and released it in 2011.
🎮 Gameplay
Duke Nukem is a first person shooter that borrows a lot of the pacing and story telling of Half-life and gunplay of modern shooters. The game alternates between in "survive the ambush", puzzles/platforming, driving, and boss fights much like Half-life. The two weapon limit, regenerating health and sprinting is borrowed from modern shooters. Later, Gearbox decided to enable the four weapon limit but I found that the original two weapon system worked better; it had me running out of ammo and struggling to find another weapon on the floor, which brings some excitement. Most bosses have to be taken down by explosives and turrets, yet you can take out a regular sized enemy when you're a little Duke with a normal weapon. No mighty boot, but you can smack your enemies with your gun with the melee key.
🤝 Multiplayer and Community
My Community
for Duke Nukem Forever Multiplayer
The game still has people playing regularly to this day. Steam charts report ~30 people that still play. However, community is so sensitive to "good players" that they just accuse everyone of being hackers. This game does have a pretty cruel history on hackers. Hacks like the ripper hacks and speed hack were dominating the multiplayer in the past and with no real support there's nothing people can do expect live with the agony. Now to this day, the hackers seemed to have died out. Literally in the case of Grumpy, the most notorious hacker in the game died of cancer a few years back. You might see people play with the tag "GBF" beside their names, which stands for Grumpy's Best Friend to pay respect to him. Now the community still has some smack talk but not as toxic as what it once was because the 'real' hackers had left the scene
A level system is in the game, where you gain experience from killing opponents, complete challenges to unlock different clothing for your Duke and items your Digs. Customize Duke to your unique choosing and have him wear a Jester's hat with 3D glasses and a nice skull shirt. Leveling also unlock babes in your dig which you could talk to, and have an amusing conversation. Challenges are fastest ways to level up, stuff like "Kill X amounts of players with Y gun" or " Run X miles."
📖 Story
Aside from having his long-awaited sequel turning out like this, the events of this game would've been Duke's darkest hour had DNF been any other game. The aliens came back hungry for revenge, destroyed everything the protagonist built for the past 12 years in a matter of hours (Lady Killer, Duke Dome, Duke Burger), killed everyone he cared about (the Holsom twins, at least), being unable to save almost everyone he encounters ("Not even I can save you now" in The Hive, among many others) even though they all depended on him to protect them and believed he could do anything, getting knocked out all the damn time, and the President blaming him for the alien attack so logically speaking, the people who lost their family members to Pregnators/Pigcops would be angry at him for letting all this happen.
But since this is Duke Nukem, everyone is happy that he kicked the aliens' asses again and cheered for Duke(inator) to be President. I know he's a badass and all and these things don't bother him, but his adventures turned from happy-family-friendly to bloody-ultra-violent real fast between DN2 and DN3D. Now I wonder if he steals one-liners and has women between his arms and legs every night is because he wants to hide his pain (of that, as well as not getting any good games since Manhattan Project).
💰 Content & Pricing
Priced at $20 as base tag, and takes around 8-9 hours to finish the first playthrough. A completionist will take around 20 hours to complete. The game includes two dlcs $10 each. One is a set of 4 new multiplayer maps, paradying other game maps; namely Call of Duty, Doom, Team Fortress and Sandbox. The other one is a 3 hour singeplayer campaign featuring a more mature character of Duke Nukem and couple new weapons. It also comes with 4 new multiplayer maps and game modes. On sale, the main game plus dlcs can go as low as $7. What a bargain!

With♥♥♥♥♥♥and explosions.
Well being that was just reaching puberty this sounded wonderful. I was hooked, like everyone who played DN3D I was a fan for life. To this day I can go back and enjoy it the same as I did on day one. But this isn't about DN3D, this is about Duke Nukem Forever. And the introduction is the base problem.
I just drowned in nostalgia over Duke, and expected a game in development hell for over a ♥♥♥♥ing decade was going to be anything similar. I didn't just buy Duke Nukem Forever, I pre-ordered. I spent a whopping amount of money on the initial release on console, (Xbox 360), only to be greeted with a two weapon limit, dodgy graphics and horrible load times that made Gen 1 PS1 games look fast. It was awful.
I sold Duke Nukem Forever soon after reaching the "Octaking" boss, but was gifted the game and DLC by a long time friend who wanted to make sure "I gave it a fair shot"
He was right.
The PC version of DNF is substantially better. Does this mean it's a great game? No. It's not. But it's something many games fail to be these days. Fun. It's a good game. Not great. Good. It's like 7 dollar 4 hour porno DVDs you buy from the gas station with a pack of jerky and a six pack. You know it's not going to be the prettiest or cleanest thing, but you get your fun out of it and you didn't have to spend a lot.
If Duke Nukem Forever had been released in it's current form with DLC for a lower price point no one would be complaining as much as they are. But first impressions are everything. And I can honestly say - yeah. I hated it when it came out. I hated the turret sections (Though, I like the monster truck, Gearbox driving is never a bad time) I hated the attempts to out-edge the original Duke Humor (The twins are just outright cringe worthy). Shadow Warrior is a much better example of how to update a classic FPS to the modern day. Same with Rise of the Triad. I just feel like Duke Nukem got too big for it's britches.

I recommend Duke Nukem Forever for the sheer fact that it's a lesson in how not to develop a game. Passing it off to a bunch of people like a Thai ladyboy at a bachelor party to whoever wants to take a shot at it next. In the end we're all left a little dirtier and devoid a few bucks.
