I did not wait long for this game. I have heard about it here and there on my time on the internet but I never played the original till two years ago. This game is infamous for its 10 year development cycle. The game has been scrapped many times and unfortunately this is the weakest out of all the rebirths. The 1998 trailer and the 2000s one looked much more fun than the final product. Does that mean the final product is a horrible game?
Who am I kidding it's not great but not bad.
Story:
10 years after you defeated the aliens in Duke Nukem 3D they come back to take revenge. They take the women and Duke's steady girlfriends (yes that is plural). You are placed in many interesting situations in your quest to take out the aliens. In one part you are shrunk and have to use a race car to traverse a casino, in another you have to find three items for a stripper so she can perform a lap dance, the list goes on but what I am trying to say is that the game is not a typical shooter.
Gameplay:
This is unfortunately a regenerating health linear shooter. No maze like levels or health packs. The health system is unique. You can gain more health by defeating bosses or interacting with certain world objects. Some actions that will give you health are: urinating, benching, shooting a basket, getting a highscore on a pinball game, and much more. Unfortunately you only see these in the first half of the game. As far as I know the second thirds of the game have practically no ego boosts other than the bosses. Another bummer is that while the first two halves of the game are interesting (for the situations I have stated) the final third takes place in the corridor heavy Hoover Dam. It is very dull compared to the rest of the game. Imagine if Duke Nukem 3D's third episode took place in a dull military base. People would be mad. Also in the dessert there is a minecart area and it is ridiculously short. The trailers made it out to be longer with more action. But you don't kill anyone in it.
Your enemy variety is low. Most are pigs but you will occasionally find flying teleporting aliens, shielded ones, and octabrains. It would have been nice to go after assassins hired by the corrupt president (like Bombshell in the first trailer). Instead you get the same old same old.
The weapon system got a lot of controversy because you could only carry two weapons. They have an option in this version to carry 4. The weapons are not very good mostly because of the lack of enemy variety. You use any random weapon without consequences. The rocket launcher only holds 5 rounds (Picard shame pic) and the ripper is just as weak as it was in Duke Nukem 3D. The rail gun is an interesting weapon because it kills most enemies in 2 shots. You can also quickfire pipes and tripwire mines with a bound key. A big disappointment is that the Freeze Ray is ridiculously weak. I unloaded an entire clip on an enemy and he still would not freeze.
Surprisingly some people play multiplayer and DNF supports dedicated servers. It is pretty fun and you get the cool weapons from the game and more like the Expander.
Conclusion:
The first two thirds of this game are interesting. I only played to the end after I reached the Hoover Dam because I just wanted to say "I beat a game that was in development for 10 years". Duke Nukem is still a cool character and I did play all the way through despite its flaws. It is definitely a game that most will enjoy but there are many better shooters than this like F.E.A.R. and Half Life. And if you are not satisfied just play the DNF mod for eduke32.

I really tried, but this game was unbelievably generic and stupid.  It was almost written and programmed with the target demographic of teenage boys and people who haven't played a decent shooter since the early 90's.
And perhaps that's just it - they attempted (and failed) to make a piece of video game nostalgia that gives a middle finger to the games that preceded it, as if it's doing something better by being simpler (and dumber).
Here's a Halo joke, here's some big-breasted women in private school uniforms, and here's a bunch of random set-pieces with moving targets to shoot.
The whole Duke Nukem Forever design timeline is a real shame.  I heard the developers kept scrapping each current project when a new game engine was released, rebuild for the new one only to do the same once a NEWER engine was announced.  This is really telling and goes back to my early point that these developers started working on this project during a simpler time in "shooter game design".  There was still an audience for ultra-violent, silly shooters that were devoid of puzzles, platforming or paid DLC.
Basically an "early 90's shooter ethos" mixed with an "updated" engine minus time/patience to polish off the jaggedly, crap-covered edges equals Duke Nukem Forever.
Rest in piece, Duke.  The king shall be hailed no more.

Is it worth the wait? Of course not, don't be ridiculous. How could any game possibly be worth waiting 14 years for, especially one that only ever aspired to be a low-brow comedy first-person shooter? There's no reinvention of the genre here, no real attempt at grandeur. More than anything, Duke just wants to party like it's 1997.
Check unrealistic expectations at the door and forget the ancient, hyperbolic promises of self-deluded developers before you even consider buying this suddenly corporeal ghost of PC gaming history. The development-time-to-awesomeness ratio isn't impressive. If you can do that, Duke Nukem Forever can at least mostly succeed in its aspiration. After all of its tumultuous history, it's ended up as an entertaining FPS wrapped in juvenile, smut-laced humor. Its gameplay is a hybrid of old-school and new, and it won't wow players with stunning visuals—its window of opportunity for that passed years ago—but it does put on a good show of alien♥♥♥♥♥kicking by working what it's got.
The Cycloid is one of the cooler-looking bosses, but his bark is worse than his bite.
Like a hyper-violent, over-sexed Peter Pan, Duke Nukem refuses to grow up. Though 12 years have passed since the events of Duke Nukem 3D, he's the exact same trash-talking, cigar-chomping, muscle-bound man of action, still rocking that '90s-style buzz cut and red tanktop. The source of his superhuman action-hero powers is his own ego, which doubles as a literal recharging shield over his (also recharging) health. It's reinforced by an entire world of people who worship him as an infallible man-god and sex idol—women want him, men want to be him. He's the stereotypical teenage boy's power fantasy personified and turned up to 11. Sure, he's a ham-fisted action hero parody, but Duke remains one of the most memorable characters in gaming history for a reason: he's simply more fun to play as than SERIOUS FACE ARMY MAN.
As two-dimensional as Duke himself, the story gets right to the point: intergalactic sex-criminal aliens are re-offending, and Duke must defy orders and step in to defend Earth's chicks. Even that flimsy B-movie tribute plot is resolved (sort of) half way through—DNF becomes simply about shooting aliens 'cause they're ugly, and bits of the script are little more than profane Mad Libs. Lazy writing or pointed critique of the state of story in first-person shooters? I prefer to think of it as the latter.
Incoming canned goods!
Reloaded
Action-wise, the single-player game fulfills its obligations as a successor to Duke Nukem 3D. It's fast-paced run-and-gun battle against diverse, love-to-hate 'em monsters, using weaponry ranging from conventional boomsticks toover-the-top sci-fi, and fought through a long series of corridor levels where there's almost always something unique to see and interact with. Almost every original weapon (except Duke's boot) returns—and after taking the Shrink Ray and Freeze Beam for a spin, it makes me wonder why few shooters have appropriated the joy of killing enemies in two-step attacks. Sure, shrinking enemies and then squashing them or freezing and shattering isn't as efficient as double-tapping to the head, but it's more fun. There's also the Devastator, a ridiculously powerful, double-barreled, rapid-fire rocket launcher that never pauses to reload until it's spent.
I just want to be looooooved!
Duke's trusty pistol, shotgun, Ripper chaingun, and rocket launcher may not be anything particularly unique or special (and certainly not realistic, lacking even a hint of recoil) but they're loud and potent alien killers. The new weapons, a rail gun sniper rifle, an alien laser, and a triple-missile-launcher called the Enforcer Gun are pretty ho-hum—no new classics here. The biggest sadness is that DNF has adopted the Halo-style two-weapon system, which frequently forced me to abandon my beloved Shrink Ray for lack of ammo. Even with all of that heavy weaponry, I still died quite a bit—despite the regenerating health system, Duke Nukem Forever is one of the more challen­ging shooters I've played in years.
At least the signature remote-detonating pipe bombs, laser tripwire mines, and Holo-Duke decoys (plus melee-enhancing steroids and pain-mitigating beer powerups) exist outside this limitation, allowing you to set all manner of devious traps in the diverse range of linear, corridor-style levels and lure enemies into them. Duke battles the aliens through his high-tech Duke Cave, his self-styled opulent casino, the aliens' disgustingly organic hive (complete with Prey-style sphincter doors that open when tickled), a Vegas skyscraper, a Dukeburger restaurant, Hoover Dam, construction sites, Nevada canyons, underwater, and more.
This little piggy is coming for blood.
Oh yeah, and there's a shameless strip club level with no combat—it's mostly a showcase for boobs and a playground for the many interactive games (pinball, air hockey, billiards, video poker) and gross-out moments in the bathroom. No two settings are alike, and with plenty of Easter eggs scattered around that boost your health when interacted with, exploring the world is a frequently rewarding high point.
Blast from the past
At the end of these levels lie some old-school-tough boss battles. Almost all of the hulking beasts took me out at least once before I figured out and exploited their attack patterns (notable exception: the final boss). Fights against a mothership, a massive alien queen, an underwater leech, and others are more about the spectacle of fighting huge unique monsters (plus an excuse for Duke to nut-punch something for an ego boost) than creating interesting gameplay.
It's Duke vs. Goliath.
The old-style design is probably due to the fact that DNF should've come out years ago. (Hell, 2K's recommended PC is built from five-year-old hardware.) Here and there, it shows; while alien monsters look pretty cool—particularly the iconic Pig Cops and flying, tentacled Octabrains—humans and many of the environments look well behind the curve. But thanks to the aliens' comical massacre of EDF (Earth Defense Force) troops, you don't spend a lot of time looking at people, so it only really offends when the incompetent President waves his unarticulated fingers in your face.
Pop culture references are similarly out-of-date—even growing moldy. Considering that the freshest ones I caught date back all the way to 2004's Team America: World Police (excluding reenactment of Christian Bale's 2009 meltdown in the opening and a crack at Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare tacked on at the end), most of Duke's one-liners were probably recorded in the early half of last decade. Though Duke still delivers several chuckles per level by quoting '90s films like Pulp Fiction and Starship Troopers and jabbing at Halo, it's noticeable that he's been living under a rock for quite some time.
Eh, it's Vegas. They were probably going to tear that hotel down and build a bigger one anyway.
Meatheaded
I encountered a lot more puzzles (of the jumping, physics, and switch-throwing varieties) than I'd expected, and few are befitting of Duke. Dropping barrels into one end of a shipping container to tilt it and create a ramp is too mundane a task for a super badass—Duke's not making fun of the puzzles other shooters started using a decade ago here, he's imitating them. Poorly.
The more innovative puzzle gimmick is shrinking Duke down to a few inches tall and sending you scurrying through levels made for man-sized play. Being action-figure sized gives you a new and interesting perspective on the world—jumping around a vast kitchen battling rats and mini Pig Cops among the shelves while using mustard jars as cover is a very different experience, and one encounter in particular makes an epic battle of what would normally be a one-shot kill. However, running any significant distance on tiny legs can get tedious.
80/100

It goes without saying that Duke Nukem Forever isn't an amazing game, but I think it gets more hate than it deserves. The writing is pretty awful most of the time and the jokes are a collection of time capsules full of internet memes ranging from Team America quotes to things that even people at the time the memes were popular might not recognize like GI Joe PSA Edit references, and some of the gameplad setpieces just aren't fun at all, like one where you have to drive a monster truck through a level and constantly stop to get gas. But when it does do things right, DNF is a passable shooter, and if nothing else it's at least fairly interesting in its design. The 10 years of development show very obviously, and the game is pretty much a random collection of ideas thrown into a game, so you never know whether you'll be shrunk down to size jumping through a Rats version of the Duke Burger kitchen or sent to a strip club to collect items for a dancer. The thing that this game is most notable to me for is the almost excessive level of interaction in the environment; you can use microwaves, poke power outlets, and more. You can probably name any number of FPSs that are more fun than DNF, but I doubt you can name one that not only lets you use the water cooler, but also individually switch on either the cool or uncool water. The result is that the best parts of the game are the parts where you aren't actually in combat, and can just enjoy the environment and find all the things you can do in it. It doesn't make up for the rest of the game's frequent mediocrity, but it's something that I wish more games did.
It's worth noting that the DLC, The Doctor Who Cloned Me, was not made by 3D Realms, and as such it's a lot better. It still has a few pitfalls, like the return of Dylan, one of the worst characters in gaming history, and the final boss is a bit of a letdown (the boss in the middle of the DLC is a better fight, really), but it's actually funny for the most part and parodies things that are more relevant to the time it released compared to the original, and the campaign as a whole is more fun than DNF. It's decent enough that it's worth the $5 or so the collection goes down to when it's on sale. DNF as a whole isn't a game that you should buy at full price, but it's not the Big Rigs of its generation like people will try to convince you it is.

Duke Nukem Forever if a FPS game that is a direct sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, came out in 2011, was developed by 3D Realms, Triptych, Gearbox, Piranha and it's famous for taking 15 years to complete. As you can see, it kind of had way more expectations that it should be, making people wait forever. While non-awesome spin-offs and even FPS Duke game on GBA were coming out.
It also came out for PS3 and Xbox 360. They are known for having technical troubles like framerate, some textures are always low-quality and long loading times. Also, didn't get patch which gives player an option to increase amount of weapons he can hold up to 4. Yea, PC is the way to go.
Shame that DLCs aren't available in Russia, maybe I am missing out on some good single-player stuff. Can judge only base game.
Multiplayer community isn't dead, there are a few people playing it regulary. But you will only get Deathmatch and Team DM modes. Sadly, all of them seem to use infinite ammo mutators.
And this game had a huge development history. In nutshell, one of the main people in 3D Realms wanted to make it the best game ever and so they would go and chase the goose of what was cool at current time, often going to change engine and having to remake stuff. All while they were throwing oil into fire of hype, screwing around publishers who really wanted them to just release something already, while giving no final product.
There are interesting trailers laying around. Like, the game started as a Half-Life clone set in some desert with female AI running around and even turret section that you all love. Then went into something with tentacle-infestation, though they say that a lot of stuff in 2001 trailer was made up for it. Then it went into more sci-fi-like stuff of clunkyness, then into more of Halo and such.
Just don't tell me about "looked ten times better", I have enough experience to know that stuff always looks better in trailers than what it truly was. Not to mentioning that some stuff didn't look particulary interesting.
And you know, that's the way development hell works: you don't spend time polishing and adding, instead you often remake core because you got better ideas all the time. And it just can go on forever when trying to reach perfection, especially during those times when technology was moving fast!
In the end, 3D Realms finally started to fall apart at "so I heard Halo is cool" iteration. In the end Gearbox, Piranha and Triptych (apparently fired DNF developers) ended up glueing and polising single-player part, adding multiplayer and spend 1-2 years doing legal mumbo and some stuff. And so they finally released at least something out of that embaressment. While also making people hate it because they had to fulfill all their "once Duke Nukem Forever comes out" joke promises. Now we have to do "once Half-Life 3 comes out", but it's not as fun because Valve promised nothing and don't even plan or tease anything.
Dammit 3D Realms, if not your stubborness we would have had an interesting Duke FPS franchise that would follow FPS genre evolution.
Anyway, the plot of this game is that aliens came back, all while Duke was enjoying his infamousness, having saved Earth more than once. And it doesn't take long to find out that Aliens are here to wreck and and grow huge tentacles everywhere and to ruin Duke's little ego paradise.
The setting and Duke in this game is awesome. They didn't just take some generic game and slammed Duke's one-liners on top, aka Manhattan Project. They took what makes Duke game a Duke game and increased it by two times. Remember how people would give you example that in second level of Duke 3D you can shoot at ball on the billiard pool to make them roll around and that it somehow makes the game better than Doom (it doesn't)? Well, now it's an actualy playable mini-game winning which will increase your Ego (still doesn't make it better than Doom, STFU)! Actually, there are a lot of interactive fun stuff to do that increase your max Ego, what a wonderful idea for Duke 3D sequel.
All while going from the silly stuff like Duke's Vegas location, into the depressive The Hive, all while giving lots of variety and pacing. Platforming is nice, yes, don't tell me things. Shame that it's linear, more than say HL2.
Heck, remember those maps for your favourite old FPS where you are a tiny being placed in a huge room of a house? Jumping on bed, hiding behind boxes, exploring mouseholes and such. Well, you now finally get to experience such thing in single-player campaign of Duke Nukem Forever! I think it's the first in single-player FPS games. Maybe.
It's a shame that toward the second half, when you go into Wild West thing and Dam, it deflates down. To be honest, Duke 3D deflated down fast as well, but not as hard. Not to mentioning that developers later released Atomic Edition which had awesome episode, being sorry for all non-awesomeness in base game. Then again, Forever got some "Doctor Who Cloned Me" DLC and people say that it's better too.
Not as much fun interactive stuff. Not as much sillyness. And when you will be exploring dark generic corridors of the Dam you will be wondering if you are playing a proper Duke Nukem game or some kind of Duke It Out DC.
As for gameplay, Duke doesn't need any stinking syringes to eat out of medkits and is powered up by his allmighty and menly EGO alone. In other words, it follows some of the modern popular stuff, like here you have both regenerating Health and regenerating armor that is his Ego. Don't worry, monsters are now more vicious and you can't just camp behind a single barricade or anything because some can correctly teleport behind your back.
You also have only 2 slots for a weapon. Game is kinda designed around it, by trying to make you swap weapons by throwing lots of them and always giving RPG and ammo for bosses when you need, while each of them has low ammo. So stop it with always carrying RPG around. So it's not as tactical, but lets you relax and change around. You can also execute some enemies with melee punch or kick if they drop onto knees when almost ran out of health. Doing this will restore your Ego immeditly. Freezer weapon is actually balanced this way: it's not all that strong, but it gives 100% chance for execution to gain ego back during battle.
And even then you can increase amount of slots to 4, but game was designed for 2, so I would recommend to stick to two.
Items are more useful now too. Holoduke is now actually useful, as it also makes you invinsible to monsters. Steroids are now useful too since boosted melee can now 1-2 hit enemies. First thing's first, I put this game off for way too long and having just beat it I felt the need to post a review for it.  I had heard the game was terrible and, as I didn't want to ruin the nostalgia that I felt for Duke Nukem, I decided that I was going to avoid this title.  I was so, so wrong to judge this game before experiencing it first hand.
The game may not be perfect, but it is definitely fun.  I found it to be as enjoyable as any first person shooter that has been released in the last few years.  Duke is back in all of his glory and the gunplay is a blast.  His crude one-liners are more than welcome after the decade plus that I've waited for a worthy return and I found myself laughing frequently.
The mechanics of the game run flawlessly.  I didn't experience a single issue the entire time I played and the aiming and character controls are top notch.  Every single death and missed shot in the game felt like it was 100% my fault and not some aspect that was overlooked by the developer.  Another aspect of the game that I enjoyed was that, although the number of weapons to be found is about on par with the other games, all of the remained viable throughout the game.  They all have their pros and cons that you can use to your advantage for each situation that you find yourself in.  It also should be mentioned that, unlike the vast majority of FPS games out there, the game never felt monotonous to me.  One moment you'll be running and gunning, the next you'll be platforming after being shrunk down to the size of a can of soup, and the next you'll be manning a turret as hordes of alien ships and reinforments are en route to kill you.
There are two parts of Duke Nukem Forever that keep it from being an absolute gem, however.  First, is the restriction on the number of guns that you can carry.  Duke Nukem used to be a walking arsenal.  Every weapon that you found in the game you kept for the rest of your campaign and could use it at any time as long as you had the ammunition for it.  The second improvement to the game that could have made it a classic would be the vehicle controls.  Driving Duke's monster truck, while fun to run over aliens with, was a bit more of a hassle than I would have liked.  It wasn't absolutely terrible but it was enough that I was less than excited when I saw it ahead of me and knew that I would be driving instead of running and gunning which I would have preferred.  Fortunately, you don't spend very much time in it.
I recommend this game to any first person shooter fans and especially to old Duke Nukem fans.  I had a blast and played it from start to finish in about ten hours over the course of four days.  This -is- the worthy successor to Duke Nukem that I had hoped it to be and I had to get the word out about my experience!

Duke Nukem: Forever has recieved many mixed opinions throughout its time with new players and those already acquainted with the Duke Nukem franchise. I myself was an avid fan of Duke Nukem 3D on the N64, and played it regularly with my brother anf friends for a long period of time. So, being familiar with Duke Nukem myself, I can say that my review will be based a little on my appreciation for Duke Nukem franchise, however I will try to be as unbiased as possible.
Duke Nukem, having previously saved the world from the alien invasion, is now regarded as a celebrity and world superstar amongst the global population. The aliens once again attack the earth and steal the babes (only the hot ones) in search of revenge against their nemesis and planet earth. As a result, Duke Nukem goes back into action to save the world from the aliens once again.
With a really nice graphical update from its predecessor (this game has been in development for a
), as well as Duke's classic inappropriate wit, I definitely enjoyed reliving the Duke Nukem experience. Some may say it goes a little over the top, however Duke's personality as well as those of other character such as Captain Dylan, make this a very comical FPS experience, with plenty of cheesy lines and film references to boot. Although a simple storyline (very typically Duke Nukem style), the FPS experience is still enjoyable, with classic weapons such as the shrink ray, expansion ray, trip mines, holo Duke etc. Ego boosts such as lifting weights, or shooting hoops can increase your ego (which acts as a health bar) as you progress through the campaign. As well as ego boosts, there are also other hidden Easter Eggs to find, making the levels fun to explore. A game worth getting for any Duke Nukem fan in my opinion, especially during the sales, and also worth playing for those new to the franchise.
Pros
+ The full Duke Nukem experience with bucket loads of comical quotes and references
+ Classic enemies and weapons
+ Hidded Easter Eggs (Ego boosts + more)
+ DLC for an extended storyline, which is also great fun for those who love the base game (cheap on sale)
+ Achievements
Cons
- Fairly standard FPS mechanics
- Some frustrating and tedious section (such as using a turret against incoming ships)
- The occasional bug can make AI enemies and companions become stuck
- When pig cops jump at you they kind of float in mid-air towards you rather that having a fluid jump
My Score: 7/10

For better or worse, Duke Nukem Forever has all the qualities we now associate with modern FPS games.  Linear, corridor-like levels.  Recharging health.  Epic set pieces.  Vehicle sections.  The ability to carry only a few weapons.  Turrets.
As a huge fan of Duke Nukem 3D (I played through the original when it was released and still play through much of it yearly), I would be lying if I said DNF is a worthy successor to that DOS classic.  However, Duke 3D still works and we can always go back and play that whenever we want to.  The sad fact is, if you want to sell a FPS today you need to compete with COD, and that means playing by modern FPS rules.  A game like DUKE3D, with its large and sometimes mazelike levels and enemies that can tear through you in seconds, could not be released today by a major company.
Which is not to say that DNF gets a free pass for its faults.  The strict limit on the number of weapons you can carry means it very seldomly makes sense to take the risk of carrying some of the more unique weapons.  I played through the majority of the game with a pistol, shotgun, minigun, and rocket launcher, and while I wanted to play around with the freeze ray and shrink gun, they just seemed like suboptimal choices.
The vast majority of the game takes place in linear corridors, though this is sometimes broken up by larger areas you need to travel through in vehicles.  There is one section toward the end where you finally get our of a corridor and under water, but your oxygen is so limited that you basically have to follow a "corridor" of pipes letting out crucial air bubbles.
The corridor design works sometimes.  Toward the end there is a stage where you have to escape from a collapsing structure and even though it is totally linear and you cannot fail, it's pretty exciting the first time through.  The intro level is also pretty fun just because there is so much going on you forget you are travelling in a corridor.
Sadly, the middle sections (a good 1/3rd of the game) are extremely dull, and have you (literally now) running through corridors fighting the same 3-4 enemies, never in any real danger because of regenerating health and generous checkpoints.  Never mind the awful parts where Duke is shrunk down- this works nicely the first time it happens and you get to explore a "giant" kitchen, but the game repeats this trick another couple times and it gets dull quickly.
The weapons all feel pretty decent, though some of them (minigun especially) should have packed more punch.  There are also plenty of items to use.  They add some flavor to the game, but I was able to get through the game with no problem without using them at all.
The game looks surprisingly good with all settings turned up to max, especially considering how much review at the time complained about how dated it looks.  I ran it on a top of the line gaming laptop hooked up to a nice monitor, and it looked really decent.  Granted, much of the game takes place in a hallway.
I didn't touch multiplayer.
As for the Duke stuff... as a fan of DUKE3D it was nice to see how a lot of stuff was updated for this, from the enemies, to the items and weapons, and the one-liners.  There is some really childish/lowbrown "humor" here that was totally absent from the classic game.  DUKE3D had some raunchy locations, but avoiding stooping to such low levels.  This stuff is few and far between though, and the Duke character is still charming.  Just like in DUKE3D he is a mixture of cool and lame, an action hero who doesn't realize that he is a little out of touch with the times, but at heart a decent guy who wants to save the world.  I especially like his final one-liner to the end boss, which is so ridiculous and over the top that you imagine he was trying to come up with the ultimate macho burn but instead came out with this crazy nonsense (though true to his word he does exactly what he promises).
Duke Nukem Forever is not nearly as bad as its reputation would have it, and I certainly enjoyed the ~10 hours I put into it to completion.

People wanted this game to be bad, and that's the only reason people say it's bad.
The game is far from perfect and the wait for it was far, far too long, but that does not mean it deserves a score of 52. The three main points people bring up for why this game is worse than the holocaust are very easily countered and I honestly don't think can really be used as "cons" at all.
1.  Duke Nukem is too sexist.
The fact that this complaint actually gains any traction whatsoever is really, REALLY stupid and it kind of pisses me off to some extent. Really? Duke Nukem being sexist? WHAT A HUGE SHOCK! That's the entire point, don't you guys remember? I could understand if you didn't find the jokes funny anymore, but that's not the devs' fault because they aren't any less mature than the ones in Duke Nukem 3D. If you didn't find the jokes funny then you simply grew up and don't find it funny anymore. Duke Nukem games aren't supposed to be some deep observation of the human spirit or the definition of heroics. Duke Nukem games are about guns, boobs and swearing. You get all three of those in this game, if you didn't like them here then you didn't like Duke Nukem 3D either.
2. The graphics are terrible.
Uh, no, they really aren't, especially for 2011. It looks almost as good as Far Cry 2's max settings or even RAGE's high settings, just without DOF. This game looks REALLY good.
3. It wasn't as groundbreaking as Duke Nukem 3D.
Seriously, guys? Duke Nukem 3D wasn't very "groundbreaking" either. The engine it used had already been used to make Witchhaven and Powerslave (on the PSX and PC, not on the Saturn) and DN3D didn't do anything with the engine that those two games didn't. Another thing I'd like to point out is that Quake came out before this one did, and Quake is an actual fully 3D game, DN3D is still 2.5D. Hell, Marathon came out a full two years earlier and that game's engine stomps BUILD's testicles.
Was it a disappointment? Yeah, of course it was. I was pretty disappointed with Half Life 2 because the violence was somewhat toned down and there weren't nearly as many weapons or enemies to fight. I felt like I waited too long for something that would have more in certain areas but way less in others. Disappointment does not mean horrible, though. Is Half Life 2 terrible? Not in the slightest. Is Duke Nukem Forever as good as Half Life 2? No, it isn't nearly as good. At the same time, though, Duke Nukem 3D isn't way more amazing than Doom 2 or Marathon or Quake or System Shock. All Duke Nukem 3D ever was was an interactive mid 90's action movie. Duke Nukem Forever is the exact same thing, except this one wasn't released in regular theaters and only got distributed through Grindhouse because there's quite a few♥♥♥♥♥♥here.

There are a lot of gameplay elements that I love in this game, and I hate that they're in something so profoundly marred.   Women only appear in this game as sexual objects.  That's been a core part of Duke Nukem since at least 3D, but that doesn't make it OK.  And it ends up going past sexism and into misogyny.  Then you reach the Hive level and mix in body horror; it's disgusting in ways I don't think the developer intended.

CAVEATS:  1, I'm not a fanboy - I played Duke Nukem 3D as a kid, but other than that I really didn't care if or when this "next game" would be made.  2, I bought this during a STEAM sale for ~$5 which, quite frankly, was the only price point I was "ok" with.
PROS:
- Plenty of vulgarity / nudity / "suggestive content"
- A resurrection of the corny, over-the-top, mostly bulls hit FPS gaming of the mid to late 90s
- More interactivity and engagement than one might expect from a title like this (jokes, minigames, reactive environment, etc.)
- Relatively low key, low frustration, high gratuitous violence kind of gaming.
CONS:
- The entire thing is map driven... just like the old games.  And, just like the old games, each map could fit on an old 3.5" diskette.  I mean, on the one hand you can rest easy knowing you're *never* very far from a checkpoint / level warp... but on the other, the maps are goddamn small.  It's like traveling the world... 10 goddamn feet at a time.
- The game is old (4 years as of this writing), and plays even older.  Same stuff you heard at release - graphics are dated, engine is clunky, mechanics are simplistic.  For a Duke Nukem game, it's just fine.  For a "game we waited 12 years for", its an astounding disappointment.
- It's short.  It took me 10 hours on "standard difficulty" to just plough through the whole thing, and that was with me wasting time to do stuipd sh!t like "Win an air hockey game 7 - 0 at the strip club".
- The production values are rough.  The few cutscenes look like PS2 era graphics, or are literally "flash animation" type moving pictures.  After its done you can see that the "Triptych Offices" were an abandoned condo with a kitchenette and two chairs.  The game is an accurate reflection of what those kinds of resources get you.
So, why is this a positive review?  I enjoyed it.  As I said, I have no vested interest in the Duke Nukem franchise (trust me - I understand why they're upset), and I got the game for practically nothing.  As such, it's easy for me to simply not care about a lot of things.  If you're of a similar mindset, or can snag this during one of STEAM's sales (or both), I think it'd be worth your time / money. Despite the negative reviews, Duke Nukem Forever is actually quite a good game in its own right, as long as it isn't viewed comparatively to its predecessor Duke Nukem 3D.
The game's single player component is a linear shooter campaign reminiscent of the Halo series which featured regenerating health & a 2 weapon carry system. The latter didn't work too well in DNF due to the power structure of the game's weapon set, though upping the carriable weapons to 4 in the game's option menu resolves any issues. The game featured lots of variety throwing in driving, platforming, turret & minigame sections, which were actually excelently placed, alternating nicely with the standard first person shooting gameplay sections so you never had too much of one thing at a time. Wolfenstein: The New Order notably had a problem with doing just that as the game threw non-combat after non-combat section at you in the middle portion of the game in a maybe 4:1 ratio with the first person shooting & bundled up all of the game's fps at the beginning & ends, so kudos to 3D Realms/Gearbox for getting that right.
Forever's FPS component is actually a lot of fun despite the regen health, limited weapon capacity & the slow movement speed. Shooting aliens is still shooting aliens, & DNF does it well.
Story wise, it's whacky & expected. Basically the aliens from 3D come back to earth, attack & abduct all the women, & you, being Duke Nukem have to defeat them & save everyone. The writing frequently makes nostalgic references to not only DN3D but also other games from the time period like Doom & System Shock 2. The one liners are also enjoyable in the game, as always. One particular segment I liked was where Duke, shrunk to the size of an action figure navigates across a pantry shooting shrunk aliens.
The multiplayer is reminiscent of arena shooters. Despite having a 2 weapon limit in a set clearly not designed for such a thing, it also works quite well, the teamplay mode in particular
feature some cooperation between players using different weapons to their advantages.
Overall, DNF isn't a work of art, no one really expected it to be, & it doesn't live up to 12 years of hype, or the awesome 2001 trailer, or its predecessor Duke Nukem 3D, but if you were to use one word to describe it, it would be fun. DNF is just that, a whole lot of whacky fun to be enjoyed for the right price. I payed $7.50 & don't regret it.

We all thought that Duke Nukem would never see the light of day. So, I agree with Gearbox: "Duke Nukem Can't Die". And so, thanks to Gearbox & 3D Realms, Duke Nukem is back from my MS-DOS Childhood Days to Next-Generation HD & he is here to stay!

3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games really knocked it out of the park with this game. After 15 years of development hell the first true masterpiece in video games is here.
The game takes a lot of cues from modernist fiction. Much of the game is about topics such as sadness, loss, addiction, alcoholism, failure, family, mental health, morality, PTSD, fame, chaos, masculinity, spirituality and isolation. The structure of Duke Nukem Forever reinforces this and the entire game is split up into vignettes all structured like a recursive fractalic ionizing radiation symbol.
The game is set years after the first alien invasion and chronicles the post-war life of duke much in the same way the Greek dark age poem The Odyssey talks about Odysseus' struggle with post-war life and the hard transition for him. The game picks up shortly after the alien war. Duke has fallen on hard times, after an unsuccessful spout in politics, his failing business ventures leave him facing bankruptcy. The game switches then to 7 years later, duke is no longer remembered as the savior of earth and is forced into private life as a used car salesman married to a woman who doesn't love him and who is cheating on him. Duke falls into a deep depression and visions of his past haunt him at night, slowly the visions creep into the day and this vignette ends with a violent outburst in which duke believes the aliens have come back to earth.
Now it's 3 years later, duke is an a mental facility dealing with the horrors of his past. His wife has left him and he struggles with a lot of health problems in this chapter. One of the patients in the facility recognizes duke but slowly over the course of the vignette the player realizes that the patient thinks that Duke is the great king Gilgamesh a champion of masculinity from the ancient near eastern epic poem.
Duke next transition is into the desert, set only a year later duke is living on the outskirts of Las Vegas. Duke is forced into an emasculating job as a male prostitute who is forced to do disgusting acts for peanuts. Duke is slowly drinking himself to death in an attempt to kill the pain in his life. At several times during the course of this phase in his life he wanders drunk through the desert, in the last of this section Duke is lost in the desert for 40 days before reaching civilization and being tested with addiction by a strip club and gives into his desire. This section mirrors the temptation of Christ but twists the ending.
The next section takes place only 3 days later, Duke is an emasculated, mess of a man make impotent by the drink. Duke jumps off the Hoover Dam but fails and lands onto a child.
Duke wakes up in a prison hospital missing his left leg. Duke has been sentenced to life without parole for drug possession and killing the child at the end of the of previous chapter. In the hospital the doctors discover Duke has prostate cancer from the steroids duke took during his youth. Duke loses all masculinity after his surgery and develops into a fat, sexless man confined to a wheelchair. Duke yet again falls into a deep pit of depression and wants to kill himself but just can't do it. It's implied that Duke is bottom to his cell partner. Duke dreams of the aliens from Duke Nukem 3D returning and him regaining his former glory and fame. Duke wakes up and starts crying, he reflects on his life and all the paths that brought him to his current state. Duke hangs himself in his prison cell.
This game is a truly bold move for the franchise and has entered gaming into a brave new world of creativity and story telling.

The problem with Duke Nukem 3-D, set aside the technology, was it is a PERFECT GAME. You can't improve prefection! Yes they could of improved level design and made new ways to interact with the enviroment but these were technological limitations. Technology as expanded a lot more since then.
The red flags. New and interesting hits were coming out with their own hard-core following. Namely third person shooter like Tomb Raider. Duke Nukem decided to up their game and follow that format... and made two bricks that surprisingly I enjoyed just the same just because I like Duke Nukem that much. But I know half of their base was miffed off enough to think twice about buying their next game. Duke Nukem Time to Kill and Duke Nukem Land of the Babes just don't click right with Duke. They took a pure FPS that was a reactive shooter and threw him into a 3PS where he controlled like a tank, moved like a tank and reflex got lost and the controls felt clumbersome. The only saving grace was his corny one linners and his semi-naked chicks peppered thought the levels. Duke was still Duke even though he drove like a tank.
Now if the developers only took heed of those two flops. Nope. They messed up and still didn't reconize their winning formula which was the orignal FPS formula. They reconized the FPS part but were still trying to stay ahead of the curve and started ripping off aspects of other new hits. One of my ther favorite games but a bain to Duke... Halo.
Halo wrote it's own rules and played it's own way and worked great, the game was designed around itself and was new and fresh and a different experience. Duke Nukem is not. Halo you accepted the rules as you played but the winning Duke rules are already set, his fan base expects them and are happy with the way he was in Duke Nukem 3-D.
Major mistake number #1
Duke is his own man. He can carry around as many weapons as he wants. Chef or Chief even with his power suit can only carry two... wimp. That was the worst thing they did to Duke. He had an incredible selection of weapons with many creative ways to blow things up... suddenly he can only carry two weapons (four if you own the PC version)? I know they think they are forcing you to play smarter but there was a smart way to play Duke already... Always try to save your biggest guns because they are too easy to use and you really need them at the end of the game. The conclusions of Dukes fights were always hard on the final boss and you have better of saved your biggest gun.
Major mistake number #2
Ego health. What the?!? Where's my health? What's this ego crap? Where's my armor? Health and armor are what built tension in Duke Nukem 3-D. Armor was always in limited supply so if you found all the armor on a level and needed more, you were out of luck. Health mostly to except if you broke a water supply, ugh, toliet, urinal, water fountain or fire hydrant. But healing from those literally took minutes and another fifteen second fight later you might be almost dead again. Tension Builder. Duke's ego health threw all that out the window. Ego is your shield, take a hit and ego goes down. Wait a little while without taking a hit and it recharges just like Halo's shield. Ego get depleted and you invisible health bar goes down showing you by how red the screen gets between hits and your health bar is three to four hits period. This turns our manly Duke a more effective chicken. Retreat until ego comes back and try again. Never thought I'd head Duke cluck.
Final mistake number #3
Half of Duke's cool gadgets! Yes half of them seemed silly but they all had points in the game where you really needed them! My personal favorite was the mobile health pack. You always had an extra 100 health points but you never really want to use it if you think you can find health and save it for a boss battle. Night Goggles, useless thoughout 9/10ths of the game except for those black rooms. Jet Pack, about a minute of flying without worrying of falling down difficult jumps. Protective Boots you didn't need to worry about acid or lava while they held out. This is only the list that got dropped though they did add a new one... beer. One can of beer and a drunk Duke could take twice as much damage before his ego went dry.
Unfortunally Duke Nukem Forever got glammered by Halo and the two formulas will never work well together. Hopefully the next game will be call Duke Nukem Returns Baby! as in a return to the formula that made him great and still has a lot of punch left even this late in the game and so many dissapointed Duke Nukemers.
Recommend this game? This one is so close to the line. I loved this series so much I can't let it go with flaws and all and am sorely dissapointed with a lot of it. I also can imagine un-installing it either. If you are a hard-core Dukem fan, yes. If not... no. I'm barely recommending it... barely.

(When 2K/Gearbox got the rights, they pretty much patched it up to a playable version and shipped it, just to finally ship it.  This is not a bad thing. The story's not particularly great.  It takes jabs at other serieses.  There's this entire driving sequence that the game could have done without.  But there are some interesting mechanics.  The graphics are good.  The gameplay works well enough.  If you really enjoyed Duke Nukem 3D, then yea, this game is entertaining.

I rate Duke Nukem Forever 3/5. OK but it certainly does not live up to the genius of its predecessor.
It is an extremely linear game and as a result severely lacking in replay value. There are almost no true decisions to be made in this game. It almost plays itself. For that reason (and due to the relatively simple controls) this would be a good game to play if you had never played an FPS before and wanted to learn (but UT2004, a very different kind of FPS, is even better for this). The game has good graphics (in a style sort of half-way between Doom 3, Prey and Half Life 2) with an engine that seems closest to Prey's graphical engine. There are moments of irritation in this game and moments of greatness (the monster truck travel section was great). This game however loses itself in its focus on Duke Nukem's personality rather than on the potential of its various environments (In Duke Nukem 3D it was the amazing environments and complex level design that were the actual focus. In that game Duke seemed to merely be there along for the ride in many ways). Overall, Duke Nukem Forever is less intelligent than its predecessor and feels like a game paying homage to its predecessor (and it largely fails to be satirical). Parts of the game often remind me (perhaps this was done intentionally) of a few other games; mostly Doom 3, Half Life, Prey, Revolt and even, occassionally, bioshock. The jokes made in the game often feel stale or fall flat and Duke's personality (and the game's focus on his personality instead of on the potential mysteries of the aliens he's fighting or the possibilities of his environment) is even irritating at times. The game is often exciting (at least the first time through) with some parts reminding me of parts of the Alien and Aliens movie/game franchise (good but possibly derivative). The Steam version of the game I played ran wonderfully and had very few bugs...but with such an extremely linear game (no branching side-paths, no alternate endings, etc.) there's not much here to be buggy. Somehow this game was at once exciting...and
different ways. The sexism in this game was no worse I think than that found in Duke Nukem 3D..but it would have been nice (even predictable for the modern social climate) if the game had an equal/opposite female heroin that Duke could "interact" with from time to time (like an ex-girlfriend or something), but alas no. Duke Nukem's personality alone does not provide enough interest for a game to focus on in such an exclusive manner...the result was somewhat irritating.

"Always bet on Duke." So reads the catchphrase to the manliest of men's latest outing. A testosterone fueled rage across the state of Nevada in search of serious payback. An unrelenting rampage of gunfire, one-liners, dismemberments, eviscerations and urinating on your foe's cerebral cortex. Nothing quite like it. Except that I wouldn't bet on it.
The thing about Duke Nukem is that you're looking for that 90s feel of a game. Where you shoot before asking questions and where cover if for the weak. You go, face first into the fray, killing and disrespecting the invaders of earth as you brutally reduce them to porkchops. Which makes it so weird that
holds you back for what seems to be a large portion of the rather short game. The first hour is spent toying with lewd buttons, curling dumbells and drawing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on whiteboards. The following shooting section is to brief to qualify for a jump in adrenaline and all the subsequent shootouts are few and far between.
I mean, think about it; You're Duke Nukem, the blueprint of masculinity. Any blogger from Tumblr would cry in irreversible horror at the binary gender appropriation this man radiates. Yet the game makes you look and play like what Arnold "The Governator" Schwarzengger would refer to as "a girly man." You are weak; you can't take a lot of punishment, and when you add up the score you don't really murder that many aliens. It gets worse. As the game progresses, you're sent into more and awkward set piece stages that have no place in a testosterone fueled shooter. It even sends you to fight a boss underwater. Something the game wasn't calculated to handle as the swimming controls are set in stone and you're even weaker than before.
does have its moments. Usually in the form of banal comedy or the sudden change up where you're shrunk to seven inches and you have to ride an RC car through a hotel while dodging kitchen appliances. At times you'll have fun with the physics engine while playing a game of pool or you spend a good few minutes listening to Duke's baritone giggles as he slaps a set of mammaries that are attached to wall (true story). However,
is lacking in so many areas, and in particular the design and refinement that you'll be glad when it's over.

A quote from Duke that just about sums up the game - its cheesy, its lewd, its gross, its damn fun, and it should never be taken too seriously! But Duke is exactly the hot-headed chauvanistic egomaniac who would say that. And the whole game centers around that idea. Whether you're ripping the spine out of a bad*** giant monster, driving a big-wheel truck over pig-aliens, playing pinball or air-hockey (yes really) in a strip-joint filled with bimbos, navigating over furniture as a tiny-duke or whatever whacko level you find yourself on, its meant to be fun yet challenging but never meant to be taken too seriously. Alright, this game has gotten many bad reveiws ever since it first came out. It wasn't what most people expected. But I assure you most of these people are C.O.D fanboys that expected a serious, realistic game. No, this is a unique experience in it's own gener of gaming, fun. You may not have the same level of humor as me but the jokes and one liners Duke makes give me a smile and a laugh.
SINGLE PLAYER- Overall this game takes after the years of Duke but the aliens have come back for revenge. I'll admit, some of the gameplay controls do feel sloppy at first when you start but I mostly have no problem what so ever taking out the bad guys. People conplain about the gameplay mecanics like driving and shooting but this is the case of either the player or the game itself that is doing something wrong, for me it's the player, nothing wrong with the game. Throughout levels you'll come across the small, interactable things witch make it more entertaining just to play and if you're searching for acheivements then you'll get them pretty esay as you play. You may die a few time to faults made by mistakes that can frustrate people, depending on your PC build the loading time will get annoying.
MULTIPLAYER- The multiplayer takes the exact same elements from single player to this. Same gunplay and controls but is still fun to customise your own Duke in a few variety of ways. What makes multiplayer worth playing is the unlockables to use in "Your Digs". This is Duke apartment, when you first enter everything will be in storage crates and you need to be a certian level in the game to unlock. From different interactable props to unlockable babes makes the place more lively and more enjoyable.
Lag can be a problem for me and many other players but is capable to get used to. As long as you shoot someone when your crosshair is red then you'll always hit them.
CONCLUSION- Nukem has aged ever since his retro years but is still very enjoyable. I personally give this a rating of 7/10. I first got this on Xbox 360 when it first came out and wasn't disappointed and got it again on Steam when it went on sale, so if you're sceptical about this game, best to wait for a sale to come across.
RECOMMENDED TO- People who want to enjoy a laid back game and want to have a good laugh. Those who'd like to relive Duke.
UNRECOMMENDED TO- Hardcore type gamers who are compedtitive, proberbly to those who get frustrated easily to.

I agree that this game has a lot of flaws, some of which eventually got patched out (like the dumb 3-weapon-limit ostensibly influenced by today's shooters).
However I don't think that this game is as bad as the press and people are making it. Sure, it's no masterpiece by any standard and not even remotely close to being an exceptional game, but at the end of the day I had a lot of fun playing through it.
The levels are really great and possibly one of the best features of this game. During the story, you get to see tons of environments. Unfortunately, not all developers do that anymore today. In today's games, you often get just one scenario and then they stick with that during the entire game. Not so in this game. You get a Casino, Las Vegas, the Canyon, some Burger-tower (which is kind of cool), a construction site, some alien world, and tons more.
The weapons are mediocre to me. Sure, you get "The Ripper" and the RPG, but all in all the weapons are nothing worth mentioning. As a fan of Duke 3D, that's disappointing.
The voice of Duke is really awesome. Like it's really great, as it has always been. I agree that the one-liners and what Duke is saying is really 80's-like, cheesy and macho, but anyone being surprised by that clearly has never played any of the Duke games ;) It's sad that so few of today's heroes lack a personality. In this game, Duke still got his. And that's really great!
The difficulty is a strange one. To me, the game feels kind of unevenly paced at times. Some parts I had to re-play more often than necessary (the first boss fight for example), while others were too easy. The pig "cops" are also extremely annoying in this game and jump around on speed. I liked the pig cops from Duke 3D way more.
Also what I think harms this game more are all these ""modern"" (yes, double quotes) elements like the weapon carrying limit (what the hell is the point of that anyway??) and the self-healing (why are medkits so taboo nowadays??). They should have left these elements like they were in Duke 3D. Nobody gives a damn anyway. And here the criticisms are most definitely justified. They should have left all "old-school" elements in there. It would have made the game better. Instead, there's an "old-school" component and a pretentious "modern" component. Apparently they tried to cater to all those Halo or CoD-players that don't know games without self-healing existed. It doesn't work.
In the end, it's by no means a bad game. I think it's a nice time capsule for what it is, if you ignore those pretentiously added "modern" elements.

Does it live up to the hype? Hell no. Is it a fundamentally and objectively bad game? I don't think so. This game's main problem is that it tries to be a parody of crummy modern first person shooters, but it's executed sloppily and as a result it becomes what it tries to parody. There's some frustrating sections, and the game lacks a lot of polish, but it's honestly dumb fun if you're able to numb yourself to the game's glaring flaws. It's not worth it's full price (currently $20) but if it's on sale and you have some money and time to waste, this game might entertain you for a bit. Otherwise, I'd avoid it if you're expecting the sequel that Duke Nukem 3D deserved.

I don't think I've ever seen a game as bad as this.
I'm not talking about the "humor" or the innuendo. Bad, as in "Mouse moves faster horizontally than vertically". Or bad, as in "during a scripted sequence a badly made monologue is repeated five times in a row".
I watched myself jump in the mirror - and regretted it immediately. Duke jumps with his feets - no movement of the torso or even hands - those just hang idly down...
The graphics are outdated, which is OK, but also uninspired and boring. The best part, sadly, was a room in the museum where screenshots of the old games could be seen.
The game either holds your hand, telling you what to do, or it just leaves you alone to figure out what the hell you're supposed to do.
"Press LMB for brake" seems simple, right? But does it mean "press and release" or "press and hold"? Actually it meant "press and hold until the F-Gauge is full, then release and immediately press and hold again. Repeat several times until the next part of the sequence starts."
In case you don't see the pattern, you'll be reminded every time you release the brake.
The voices are partly OK and partly annoying - this might be a matter of taste, but I found the shrill voices of the twins to be quite annoying and not at all sexy (which I have to assume they were supposed to be).
Did I mention that the mouse movement is quite unexpected? Apparently the mouse moves at a fixed speed while in the menu, and in a setable speed while in the game.
Which of course means you can change the mouse speed in the menu, but not try it.
I usually try to finish games, often with cheats, unless there are repercussions (i.e. no achievements - I'd rather not finish a game then, or try it without cheats, I'm stupid like that), but I'm not sure if I WANT to finish this game.
Sure, I'd like to know how the "story" progresses, but I'm not sure it's worth the pain...

If growing up you were a fan of 'Duke Nukem 3D'...and boobies, then you'll love...erruhh...should...erruhh...might enjoy this game. Or maybe you won't, I mean who can really tell with this one. Over however long in development, with countless engine updates, and one or a million developer changes, I still to this day, have no idea why so many knuckleheads held this game to such high standards. I suppose it was their undying love and fond memories for the Duke Nukem of the 90's, but still, how good could this game have been when it was passed around more times than some lame joke about a girl who is very promiscuous? Actually...pretty damn good, if you ask me!
This game was destined to fail ever since year five in development, so it really doesn't matter now, but like I said, if you were a fan of the original 'Duke 3D' game, then this game should be pretty enjoyable for you. Or maybe it won't be, who cares, either way get f'd and buy it cheap. But still, 'Forever' manages to be more imaginative than 75% of new shooters out there today and maintains some of the humor and feel of gameplay from the original. The storyline is the same 'save the world from the aliens' but what else did you expect, and each map feels fresh and fun to play through each and every time, with small puzzles and challenges along the way.
Overall, this is a game most people have most likely already forgotten about, but it's still incredibly fun if you ask me. And even though it's probably not the game that the developers originally set out to make, I'm still thankful to have been able to play this version. So pick this one up for a few bucks during the next sale if you're a fan of Duke Nukem or shooters in general. Because 'Forever' is a pleasant change from the mundane, everyday shooters that most people play day in and day out.

, probably one of the most anticipated and hyped up games of all time, but did it live up to the expectations of Duke Nukem fans? Not exactly. Does that mean
is a bad game?
Unfortunately,
was not very well received by critics and fans when it was eventually released in 2011 after
. The most popular places to read PC Gaming reviews all shunned
shortly after it's official release and it was deemed as the worst game in the series. Despite all of the negativity and bad reviews surrounding the game, I decided that I would try it myself to see whether or not it is as bad as everybody makes it out to be... After playing it through a good number of times, I do not think this is a bad game at all, in fact, I truly believe that this is a game worthy of the
title, even though I seem to be very alone with that opinion. I believe that this is a really great game, flawed mainly by it's release date, if it was released back in 2004, it would have been considered a much better game as it doesn't really meet todays standards.
Sure, it's not the most phenomenal game ever released, nor is it revolutionary like
or
were, but it's not a bad game either. When it is looked to as the "successor" to
, the game will naturally be compared to it's originals, but if you look past that,
is a good game within it's own right.
It's lengthy, fast-paced and very interactive single-player campaign is an example of what modern games should be looking to set as their goals, it's very, very rare you will find any singleplayer games with any more than 8 hours of singleplayer game-play in this day and age, so that is a big bonus. The game is also very atmospheric, comedic and  varied, you can tell this game has come from an era from the past, though unfortunately many years too late.
All of your favourite weapons from
make a return, so there is no problem there, excluding the fact that you are limited to how many you can carry now (more about that below), there are a few more new weapons to play with such as the Railgun and the Enforcer Cannon which are both satisfying to use, there are a few more but nothing glorious.
Graphically, the game isn't exactly groundbreaking but it's still a very pretty and well-made game, you can tell that a lot of work has gone into it. The humour is the same as it's always been, cheesy and crude, but funny (most of the time). There are also endless references and easter eggs that you will come across throughout the campaign that are bound to amuse you.
The game has it's flaws, as most of you will already be aware because the critics love letting you know about it, but there are only two things that spoil this game for me. The first issue is that some of the maps feel linear and relatively simple, especially when compared to
... General exploration is limited and there are little to no secrets to discover in the game, which is a shame given how much fun it was to explore in
, but health bonuses are non-existent anyway now so finding a secret area may not be as great as it once was.
Secondly, the two weapon limit is frustrating and can ruin the experience more often than not, there is an option to enable a four weapon limit as opposed to the two, but this is still an issue, the reason being is that some weapons are mandatory to destroying certain enemies, with a limited inventory, you are constantly made to pick and chose between the weapons you want on the spot rather than keeping everything at once like you could before. This ultimately damages the singleplayer quite a lot, it also makes exploration and any secrets feel a bit pointless as ammunition and hidden weapons are now more of a burdening choice than they are a bonus.
So, flaws aside, I will stand by and defend
by saying that it is a good game. Rather than avoiding it based on what most critics had to say, you should ultimately decide for yourself if you like it or not after playing it through, I know lots and lots of people are on a bandwagon preaching hate to the game when they haven't even given it a chance, and that's just lame. Rather than paying full price, I do recommend buying the complete set (DNF & DLC) during a sale. Don't believe everything you hear, try things for yourself before you make assumptions.

Christ almighty where to start with this game.
Now, i'm a car guy. I like cars, and sometimes when you buy a used car, especially that was someone elsee's project, not everything's all there. Sometimes the back seats are missing because the previous owner wanted less weight, sometimes the dashboard is cracked from years in the sun, sometimes there are just problems that don't need to be there.
Duke Nukem Forever is a used project car that you can't finish. You can see the tape on the wiring, you can see where parts were spliced into it, It's a mess.
First off, enemies are bullet sponges. This was a problem in DN3D, but not at this level. Good news is that headshots do seem to work on some enemies, and they do an entertaining cartwheel ragdoll. Some enemies like the floating fat guys and the octobrains are given way too much significance and are almost boss battles.
The game offeres a few  modern FPS no-nos, like limited weapons, limited enemy count, Regenerating health, Corridor levels, it's really sad to see these anti-fun measures applied to duke.
The game's humor is pretty good, Some pop-culture references fall a little flat in this age of the internet, but they're really no better or worse than classic OJ Simpson trial references found in Duke3D. The DLC campaign is another story though. The humor is god awful, and they even try and work some social justice into it, but with anthony burch writing for the game, Just like his wife by other men, it's going to get messed with. in particular there's a part where you're supposed to reject a "slap-a-hoe" arcade machine, then the game celebrates you NOT playing it. Why was it even put in in the first place? There's no reason for it to exist.
Which brings me to another point. Much like classic dook, there are tons of interactables in the environment. Sadly, these are often more fun than the rest of the game. Duke Nukem was never an original game. It was always a pop-culture spouting rip-off game. Duke 1+2 were contra/metroid rip-offs, Duke 3 was a doom/ROTT clone. This duke you can trell when it tries to emulate first HL2, then Halo, then CoDMW respectively. And the problem with emulating 3 games is, it doesn't know what it wants to do. Duke 3D took the platform of Doom and made its own adventure. These newer ones don't stray a terrible lot and are really bland.
This game DOES have multiplayer, the multiplayer IS dead, but when it was alive, it was absolutly fantastic. It was fun, Fast paced, challenging, and had a ton of unlocks that don't really affect gameplay, but unlocked activities for you to do in your hotel room, like pool, or darts or pinball. So there's no one who slogged it out and got the super ultimate gun and beginners are scared off. But, the MP is dead so it's a moot point.
On it's own, if this game was called Mr. shooter guy, had NO ties to duke nukem, this would be a forgettable, mediocre game. But this game was a sequel to one of the best games of the 90's. This game is an insult. It's a tragedy that this will be Duke's last adventure. This COULD have inspired a whole new generation to love dook with his witty humor and great gameplay, but instead it's a lazy hodge podge hastily thrown together from years of most likely rejected content.

Hardly the shambolic mess people pretend it to be, DNF is the result of mixing a more traditional FPS experience with the modern features and trappings of the same genre. This combination was not fruitful and its positive effects mostly tepid, but the game is still polished, free of bugs and mostly very entertaining. Pacing is a serious issue, with the "meat" of the gameplay taking over one hour to properly arrive. Good weapon and enemy variety, multiple interactive objects and minigames, competent vehicle segments and even considerably high challenge on the highest difficulty - There's definitely fun to be extracted from this game, and occasionally you'll even bear witness to brief flashes of genius. Just don't expect anything more than what it is: a solid but uninspired linear shooter, yet not without its own share of cool rollercoaster thrills.

Download size: about 8 GB
Playtime: about 10 hours
Duke Nukem Forever (DNF) was the follow-up to Duke Nukem 3D from over a decade prior, which means nostalgia and high expectations played a large part in how the game was originally reviewed. As Duke says himself near the beginning of the game “after 12 ♥♥♥♥ing years, it better be (good).” Sadly, the game was thoroughly mediocre and nobody was impressed. Strangely, DNF has a 55 metacritic rating which is rare for a big name game but the Steam player reviews for the game are “mostly positive.” I’d guess that’s because no matter how disappointing the game is, it still isn’t “horrible.”
It’s been so long since I played the old DOS game Duke Nukem 3D (Or Duke Nukem 1 & 2 before that) so I can’t really recap it. Fortunately, you don’t need to have played to older games to get what’s going on in DNF. An alien fleet is looming over the Earth and the US president is confident that peace negotiations are going well. It’s a good chance these are the same aliens from the previous Duke Nukem games so the president is worried that our hero Duke is going to pick a fight and start a war. Naturally, the aliens attack (and start stealing Earth’s hot women) so it’s up to Duke Nukem to kick their asses once again.
Gameplay for Duke Nukem Forever is straightforward first person shooter with no real innovations, except a few places in the game where you get shrunk down to the size of a Barbie doll and need to navigate terrain puzzles while avoiding the huge (normal size) aliens. The puzzles in the game are not too difficult to figure out, which is a good thing because DNF doesn’t have a “hint” system (where you hit a button and it shows you where you’re supposed to go next). Usually the door you’re supposed to go through has an orange flash, but it is still possible in a few places not to know what to do next (like one level in particular involving a crane wrecking ball).
When I first played through the game about a year ago, one of the gripes I had was the limited weapon inventory. For a first person shooter there’s actually an adequate variety of guns to choose from, both human and alien (pistol, shotgun, machinegun, rocket launcher, etc.) The problem was that you could only carry 2 weapons at a time like in Halo 1.  When you run out of ammo, you can drop the gun you’re holding and pick one up from a fallen enemy. This would have been fine except that one of the game’s Steam achievements requires you to carry the pistol for the entire game, leaving you with 1 other weapon. I believe the developers patched it though, so now you can carry 4 weapons at any given time. The game’s health system is the now standard regenerating life system except that instead of being called health, it’s called ego. You can raise your maximum ego by doing various environmental things like looking a porno magazines or lifting weights that you find lying around on various levels. Most of your ego boosts will probably come from killing bosses though.
Pros:
+Fights with giant alien bosses are always a plus in my book. Unfortunately, only a couple of these fights involve outside the box thinking. For example the giant alien queen requires pipe bombs and dodging alien impregnators. Most boss fights just require spamming rockets and circle strafing. All bosses can only be hurt by turrets and explosive weapons.
+Decent variety in enemies and environments. The game’s graphics aren’t bad when it comes to the grotesque alien enemies that you’re facing. You get an up close look at a few of the melee enemies. I wasn’t a big fan of the alien hive level because of the weird night vision system that the game uses (Duke Vision) but at least  it changes things up a bit. The underwater level was kind of fun where you need to swim from air supply to air supply.
Cons:
-Outdated humor. The game makers tried to keep the feel of the old Duke Nukem games by having Duke constantly spit out one liners and other macho stuff. The problem is that he seems to say something every time you kill an enemy so some of the quotes keep repeating over and over (“Wonder how many pork chops I can make out of you” after killing a pig alien which is one of the most common enemies in the game). Since you’re killing aliens every few seconds a ton of the quotes are heard about a hundred times by the end of the game. Have you seen the Expendables movies with Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger? You know how all the old washed up action heroes keep using quotes from their successful movies? The DNF humor feels kind of like that.
-The game just doesn’t stand out in any way. If this wasn’t supposed to be the glorious return of Duke Nukem, the game wouldn’t have been such a disappointment. People would have just said, “meh nothing special about the game. Play it and forget it.” But of course the fans seem to feel like the 12 years since the previous game should have been spent perfecting Duke Nukem Forever.
A friend was using the Steam family sharing thing to play DNF off of my account and I asked why of all the available games he would be playing a game so mediocre. He said it was because he hadn’t tried it but had played the previous Duke Nukem games. I guess it’s like the Aliens vs. Predator movie franchise. Everyone seems to think the movies suck, but I like Aliens and I like Predators, so might as well see the movie once. Make sure that you don’t pay too much for the game though (less than $5). As for the game’s DLC “The Doctor Who Cloned Me,” the DLC is actually pretty long (about 5 hours I think) and doesn’t really add much new to the experience. I think there’re only a couple new weapons, but there are a few new bosses to fight.

So, here's the thing... It's Duke Nukem. You can't expect it to seem good to you if you're expecting something serious.
While I wasn't a fan of the Duke Nukem games before, because I was born a bit too late and I missed the "Golden Era of DOS Games", I became a fan now. I had finished the game once before, when it just hit the market, but I wasn't very impressed, mostly because of the reason mentioned earlier.
However, the game grew on me, and I decided to buy it for myself and finish it on the hardest difficulty - which I'm currently working on.
I always choose to play 3D shooters on the hardest difficulty because the harsh challenge makes the game extremely fun, and the more difficult it is to finish the game, the more rewarding the feeling you get when you finally manage to do it. Besides, even when played on "Come Get Some", the game seemed pretty easy to me, most of the time. The real challenge comes when you're able to play it on Insane. A piece of advice: arm yourself with a very good weapon besides the rocket launcher or the devastator when you're going to fight the Octaking. It is by far the most difficult boss battle in the entire game.
So, why didn't I like the game when I first played it? Well, like I said, it had to do with the overall immature style of it, but I wasn't aware it was supposed to be immature. If that was also your first impression, give it another chance and play it on a hard difficulty. Trust me, you'll love it! Played like that it's an old school shooter at its finest.
Oh, and by the way, I think the shrink ray is actually trying to make another reference - like many others you will find during your playthrough, and it's intentionally made to look like something right out of Portal. It's Duke Nukem humour... I guess you have to be a fan to understand it. :)
Being a fan of old school 3D shooters, I'd give it a 10/10.
