This game has problems, yes. There's no denying that. I mean, the humor of Duke Nukem was that we always knew he was a complete tool, but here, we're supposed to think he's actually a righteous dude. That makes his treatment of women, his terrible one-liners and everything else feel less like satire and more like, you know, things that are okay and cool. Certainly, that's one of the biggest cruxes here.
But as for everything else? I've never understood, and likely never will, the hatred the rest of this game gets. The level design is remarkably creative, and the core gameplay is visceral and satisfying. And while, perhaps, the graphics are a bit dated, good graphics don't make a good game. Ah, yes, and the sound design is actually pretty good as well. The guns sound great, the music is 90's cool, and Jon St. John delivers as Duke... as always.
So, yes, as a guy who considers myself a feminist, a lot of the humor is kind of screwed-up in a way that doesn't feel ironic, and that's definitely a knock against it in my book. But it doesn't make me hate the rest of the game. On a sale, if you can overlook some issues, this is a fine way to spend 8-10 hours, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, brainless shooter.

Someone's Half Life 2 homage took a dump all over Duke. Face-palming ensues.
The Good:
+ They nailed Duke's persona spot-on
+ Jon St. John is back voicing Duke
+ The "go mess around" levels are sometimes funny
+ The gratuitous T & A fit Duke perfectly
The Bad:
- puzzles
- platforming
- driving
- the fact that the above 3 are even in a Duke 3D game
- the "go mess around" levels got old fast (slow-paced & no action)
- unintuitive maps, puzzles, etc ("where do I go?", "what do I do?")
- short oxygen meter & forced situations using it (cheap deaths)
- short action sequences that force you into killzones (cheap deaths again)
- short action sequences that are a joke (infinite ammo and rocket launchers)
- action / gun-fights in general are treated like side dishes instead of main course (argh)
- DLC has more of the same, but replaces Duke with another person doing all the trash-talking (!)
Before I get started, the Duke of old, 2D platforming days is gone. When they released Duke Nukem 3D they totally rewrote who and what Duke was. THAT is the Duke that this game was meant for. However, I suppose for nostalgia's sake, they decided to push him back into a 3D version of his old 2D game world.
It doesn't work.
When you think "Duke" from Duke 3D days you think action. So, what should have been a straight-forward run-n-gun (a la Serious Sam) was instead developed as a puzzle / platformer / driving / mini-game / turret-shooter with action elements thrown in. Duke is thrown in the middle, and is forced to flounder around like a fish out of water.
As Angry Video Game Nerd (AVGN) would say "WHAT WERE THEY THINKING?!"
The irony is when Duke voices your frustration as if he, too, is insulted to be a part of this game:
EG1: Duke approaches a puzzle with pipes and valves. "I hate Valve puzzles." Oh, lol, a quip about Valve's puzzles in HL2. So hilarious. Yeah, screw that. Duke's gonna punch his way through this one instead of doing the stupid puzz... oh... ok, nope, Duke has to do the flipping puzzle. Wut? (Even Angry Joe beat the game for that one.)
EG2: In the DLC you get done with another stupid puzzle and Duke spouts "FINALLY!" Yeah, finally! Why am I stuck doing stupid puzzles?! Where's the flipping action?! If Duke himself is tired of this garbage, how do you think I feel?
I'm not ticked off at Duke, though. I'm still a Duke fan, because this game merely mis-uses the Duke Nukem IP ... horribly ... and doesn't represent Duke well. Duke was thrown into the middle of this mess, and you're stuck feeling sad for him having to muck through it. You're frustrated at the game, but you're empathetic of Duke being stuck in it.
Duke fans went in with certain expectations, and the game defied those expecations in ignorance, spite and / or neglect. But, that's not Duke's fault. That would be like buying a game that has Barbie in it and finding out it's a Mortal Kombat clone. It's not Barbie's fault, it's the fault of the ignorant developers / publisher.
The sad part is this isn't a bad game; it's just not a good Duke game. It would have done better had it been a stand-alone title starring a different lead character. Instead, Duke was shoe-horned in, and it doesn't work. As I said, they should have emulated Serious Sam, not Gordon Freeman.
The DLC is even more disappointing then the main game.
Dr. Proton (who? ... he was your antagonist from Duke 2D platforming days) starts as your chief antagonist, and it seems like a novel concept. But, they don't leverage his robots or Duke clones much, and you waste him 1/2 way in. What's left? Oh, you're stuck fighting more aliens like in DNF ... how original.
And, they took everything that grates about DNF and put more of it in the DLC ... more puzzles, more driving, more platforming, more ball-scratching as you try to figure out where to go and what to do (which makes you feel like an idiot).
In addition, they neuter Duke mid-way through of his last, remaining machismo (his mouth) by having  some jack-a** side kick making all the wise cracks. So, the DLC is just insult to injury.
Basically, if you're looking for a decent Duke Nukem 3D sequel, then go play Serious Sam. Sam picked up the baton that they made Duke drop, and has been running with it for the past years. Even playing Duke in Bro-Force is more entertaining than this. At least there's more action and more explosions.
Likewise, look at my play time... 20 hours in 2 weeks. I'm on winter break from college; lots of time on my hands to catch up with my gaming. I spent ten hours a week on DNF. That's sad. When I really like a game I'll make a day of it. But, I found myself making excuses to not play this game... laundry, dishes, folding, vacuuming ... my apartment has never been cleaner. I started playing the game to see what all the fuss was about, and once I started I wanted to see it through. But, I found myself waffling hardcore getting there. That speaks volumes.
If you get this game, go in with expectations set per above. Don't go in thinking Duke is about action. In fact, don't have any expectations. Even 12yo's are ranting about how they're insulted that they used a lot of T & A to lure them into this stinker. That's saying something, too.

Duke Nukem Forever is one of those odd little games that are usually overlooked because of it's flaws.Yes the game isn't perfect . The storyline is very predictable and the game isn't exactly a graphical powerhouse. This game is however one of the most satisifying first person shooters I have ever played. Almost all of the games weapons are unique and fun to use and this game makes one of gamings greatest sins, backtracking, actually enjoyable. This is done with clever implementation of a device that shrinks Duke to action-figure size. You will go through a level as tiny Duke, and then go backwards as the normal sized Duke. Each version of Duke (tiny/normal) will face different obstacles. This is level design done right.
The game does have a few new weapons to play around with, but most of them aren't very interesting or just plain underpowered, but they make up for this by always having ammo within reach, thus making it an expendable weapon, and also the ultimate backup in case your main weapons empty out.
Some things are just downright stupid in this game. Duke can only carry 2 weapons at a time. This can be icnreased to 4 on the pc version. A Duke Nukem game should let you carry lots of weapons. Just look at half life 2, Gordon Freeman can carry 10+ weapons, so having a maximum of 4 is just unnacceptable.
The game has plenty of references, as you would expect from a Duke Nukem game. None of them break the immersion from the game too much, and it's actually really nice to see them in there. You can tell the developers had fun with this game.
Even after the long wait, Duke Nukem Forever is still just a Duke Nukem game. Aside from it's flaws, I'd say its a pretty fantastic game that many people can enjoy. Duke Nukem Forever, is a game I would recommend. Just don't go in expecting it to be perfect.

To everyone who was disappointed by this game, my question to you is: what were you expecting?
Admitted, my experiences with Duke Nukem only go as far as the N64 games, so I may not have the same nostalgia as some fans, but from the perspective of someone looking for a fun video game, this is a fun video game.
It's a first person shooter, as the later Duke games were, and as far as shooting action, it's pretty average. I played through for the first time on hard difficulty, and aside from frustration with a few of the bosses, it wasn't overly challenging. The weapon and enemy variation is small, but it does the job.
Where this game shines is all of the extra stuff available in the game. Interacting with the world is actively encouraged as it raises your max health, but there's plenty of stuff that offers no game benefit yet really adds to the atmosphere. I probably spent a good hour just reading all the labels in the Duke Burger level. There's 9-ball, air hockey, pinball and more stuff that you don't need to even look at to finish the game, but would be missed if not included. The humor of this game is crude (as you would expect), but it's still fun to experience.
If you're looking for an innovative first-person shooter, this isn't your game. If you're the type of gamer that enjoys exploring every nook and cranny of a level for secrets, then you'll have a good experience. If you enjoy boobs, ballshots and other crude humor then this is your Game of the Year.
tl;dr: It's fine.
If you can get this for a few dollars when it's on sale, then go for it. If not, then don't buy it. It'll last you a few hours on your first playthrough, and provides a decent challenge.

I wanted to like Duke Nukem Forever. I really did.
When early reviews criticized the game for poor graphics, crude/outdated humour, dumb AI, and linear levels, I gave the game the benefit of the doubt and hoped that the bad reviews stemmed from unrealistic expectations - expectations that were inflated to reflect the 10+ years that the game was supposedly in development for.
Having spent many, many hours with DNF, I regret to say that the game is indeed a disappointment. It isn't all bad. Aside from inexplicably playing too much like a Halo/COD clone for my liking, I find the game's biggest issue to be the technical problems that have put me in a position to constantly replay the beginning of vehicle-based levels because something about those levels significantly ramps up the extent to which the game locks up/freezes on my computer.
Here is an analysis of the major factors that comprise this game:
PLOT: There is a plot, but it's pretty weak and uninspired. If anything, it gets in the way of the action that this game revolves around since there are instances where you're foreced to wait for NPCs who are blocking your path to stop talking until you can proceed to your next objective. Listening to these NPCs should be optional!
GRAPHICS: For the most part, they look fine for what they are. Duke Forever never aspired to be the graphical successor to Crysis, so it's silly to compare it to such graphically astounding titles. Although the enemies look cool and much more menacing than they did in Duke Nukem 3D, some of the backgrounds seem very bland (i.e. Duke's Hotel) or feature details that stand out as very, very pixelated (i.e. Sunshine reflecting off of the wall of a large barn in the 'Ghost Town' map). The game looks a little too dark and gritty for my liking.
SOUND: The reworked theme song notwithstanding, the game's music is nothing to write home about. The sound effects, on the other hand, are very well done. Jon St. John's voice acting for Duke is superb; it lends the game personality and makes me laugh because it is just as buffoonishly over the top and anachronistic as it was when Duke first started speaking in 1996.
Critics who whine about how dated Duke Nukem comes across in DNF need to get their heads checked. Telling anonymous women to "Shake it, baby!" wasn't politically correct in the mid- to late-90s, but most of those who condemn Duke for continuning to objectify women in a similar fashion in 2011 incorrectly imply that his behaviour was excusable in D3D because it was in-line with the times. It wasn't. Duke was - and remains - a parodic embodiment of sex, drugs, violence, and machismo taken to absurd extremes.
My favourite element of Duke Nukem Forever is the re-worked Holoduke accessory. Whereas it was conceptually cool but not very practical in Duke Nukem 3D, using it in DNF cloaks you in a Predator-style skin and produces a holographic replica of Duke that messes up his catchphrases. These botched lines ALWAYS crack me up! An added bonus is that the holographic image of Duke is now genuinely distracting to human foes: it moves around and appears to shoot like an actual multiplayer opponent would.
GAME DESIGN: Sadly, DNF's maps are super linear. Whereas levels in D3D could be navigated a multitude of ways and were chock-full of secrets that encouraged and rewarded exploration and taking chances, navigation in Duke Nukem Forever can usually be summed up like this: move into a corridor; defeat all of its enemies; move into the next corridor. Rinse and repeat.
One of Duke 3D's very best levels - Hollywood Holocaust - was recycled into DNF as a multiplayer-only map. The redone map gives away all of original's secret areas; you literally need do little more than walk or fly around to discover virtually every inch of this map. Now there are no switches to trigger, no walls to blow up, and practically no skill is involved to see everything there is to see. This remade level is a microcosmic representation of what what you get when you compare the spirit of D3D's level design to that of DNF's.
The game's shooting mechanics are solid, but the weapon, ammunition, and health systems they are closely linked to really detract from my enjoyment of the game. Because the game arbitrarily imposes a low weapon limit, most enemies will become sources of ammo or new weapons once they're slain. Players feel no incentive to fight carefully, conserve ammo, or seek it out in hidden places, because they're practically guaranteed to have an ample arsenal whenever the dust of a skirmish settles. The health system is even worse; Duke's health regenerates over time. You can be completely careless about the way you fight and have the confidence of knowing that you'll come out with 100% health so long as you're patient enough to wait a few seconds before advancing to take on the next batch of enemies.
To the credit of DNF's developers, they found a creative way of excusing the shift from a traditional health system to one aping that of Halo/COD: It's not Duke's health that gets hurt in battle, but rather, his ego. So long as Duke's over-confident, over-inflated sense of self worth remains above a set threshold, he keeps on going. He doesn't need to pick up health packs; he just needs a few seconds to clear whatever abuse he just withstood from his mind to feel as good as new. I don't like this new system, but I like the logic that went into implementing it into Duke Nukem Forever.
CONTROL: For the most part, the game controls fine. I really only have two gripes about it. First, in-game VoIP Chat is spotty. Whereas I can count on Left 4 Dead to always broadcast my voice when I'm wearing a headset and I have the game configured to read any input from it, I have had mixed results getting others to hear me in DNF. On a more serious note, I recently gave up on playing the game because of a long-standing conflict between some of 2K's titles and Steam: a bug triggered by the Steam Overlay prohibits you from moving around. I have spent considerable time trying to un-do this bug, and have given up - mainly because I have already spent tons and tons of time struggling with a problem that has plagued me since I first started playing the game: Intermittent freezing.
TECHNICAL QUALITY: DNF freezes on me. A LOT. Every time it freezes, the game's window locks up, the sound stutters, and I have to manually launch the task bar and force DNF to abort its operations for my system to be useful again. The freezing symptoms seem to happen at random, but occur a HELL of a lot more frequently when I have to get around by monster truck rather than on foot. Because players are forced to spend the first half of "Ghost Town" zooming around in a truck, I spent way more time loading, aborting, and restarting that section of the game than I would like to admit. It would almost always freeze within 3 seconds of playing the stage, and fiddling with the game's graphical and sound options didn't make a damned bit of difference in terms of reducing the problem.
My computer's hardware is  more than capable of handling DNF on max settings, yet no game I've attempted to play has handled anywhere as poorly as DNF. My drivers are all up to date. I've tried compatibility modes. I even reluctantly made the switch from Windows 7 to Windows 8, yet not even that resolved the freezing issue.
CONCLUSION: Duke Nukem Forever is not a great game in its own right, but I still enjoyed it enough to want to reach its climax. However, the crippling bugs I outlined not only soured my impression of the game, but convinced me to never, ever spend money on another PC port by publisher 2K Games (The freezing bug also affects Bioshock).
QUICK RECAP: Mostly good graphics. Superb sound. Mediocre music. Lame level design. Servicable plot. Decent AI. Tarnished by regenerating health and low weapon limits. Crippling bugs. Skip it unless you are a die-hard Duke Nukem fan.

The game might have some flaws, but overall it's pretty much what I expected from Duke Nukem: Over the top, silly and just fun. Not at all a game that deserves a metascore of ~50/100.
The interaction with the game world is great. You can lift weights, play pinball or pool, sign autographs, drink beer, take a leak, etc. Especially the beginning and the strip club level shine in this regard. This interaction with the world makes the game pretty unique. The action is solid and the fights are pretty challenging (I play on hard mode). The only thing that's not fun is the driving: The game is filled with driving sequences and they get a little annoying over the time.
Pros:
- Great interaction with the environment
- Silly Duke Nukem humor
- Solid shootouts
- Simple retro fps: No unfitting skill/experience system (The new Shadow Warrior is doing this unfortunately...)
- Lenghty campaign: Much longer  than your average modern fps
- Cool weapons: Shrinking cannons, freezing cannons, etc. The game keeps the cool weapons from Duke 3d
- Variety of different environments: Casinos, deserts, organic alien environments, etc. The levels don't get boring
Cons:
- Dated graphics: especially outdoors, but the game has its moments (sometimes it actually looks good).
- Almost no blood! This really bugs me. Enemies often explode into meaty pieces, but leave no blood decals. I would expect much more blood from Duke Nukem.
- Unfitting weapon restrictions / regenerating health: Strange modernizations in an otherwise old-school game. It should use health packs and it should let you carry all your weapons at the same time. While initially you were only allowed to carry two weapons, a patch changed that number to four. Still: This shouldn not be restricted at all.
- Tedious driving sequences
- No mod support: Duke Nukem 3D had a great modding community, and it even has today. Not supporting mods for this one is just stupid.
~75/100 would be a fitting score, I would go as far as giving it 80+.

With Duke Nukem Forever, you're either on the one side who bashes the game because a "reviewer" from Youtube said they hated it and overact for no reason other than attention, or you're on the side who understands the game's faults and respects it for what it is. At heart, this is still a Duke Nukem game. It's not like an edgy reboot that ruins the integrity of what the original game was or a spinoff that stars an edgy character because they lost the rights to a certain character (*cough* Bombshell *cough*), this is a relic of the 90's that was released in 2011. Of course, it's going to be outdated. There are some funny lines and gags that go with what Duke Nukem is all about. The controls can be sluggish and the combat can be clunky, plus the puzzles range from clever to lame. Overall, however, if you're a Duke fan, you can appreciate it for what it is. If you aren't a Duke fan, there's plenty of games to choose from, so stop wasting your time bashing a game that no one talks about now except for lame Youtube videos.

I was a big fan of Duke Nukem 3D. I remember those weekends listening to Don Henley's greatest hits, playing that game, and messing around with the build editor (my first and only experience designing FPS maps) quite fondly. At the time the next Duke Nukem game was a huge freaking deal to me. After a few years I lost my patience and moved on, like any normal person. Fast forward another decade or so and finally Duke Nukem Forever arrives, and it's garbage. No wait, that's just what they say right? I'm more than capable of playing games and formulating opinions on them, so who cares what they say.
So I played through it....
Duke Nukem Forever is ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥ I hate using bad language in reviews but DNF deserves all of it and more.
The original Duke Nukem 3D has a linear format, you go from one stage to the next. However those stages are large, varied, and include numerous optional paths, secret areas, and methods of exploration(jet-pack, steroid-boosted jumps, etc). Duke Nukem Forever is entirely linear. For the most part in DNF you're either shooting a handful of aliens in quasi-arena areas, doing some ridiculous puzzle, partaking in a vehicle-section, or doing some ego-boosting activity. Oh and for the entirety of the game your sensibilities on what makes for quality game-design or at least in-offensive content are dragged through horse manure.
Vehicle sections - All too often FPS developers feel the need to include vehicle-sections. They use the word "variety" which is short for "we decided the actual game wasn't compelling". Some developers can rise above, and that's because they use vehicles in an intelligent manner. Half-Life 2 is a good example, well I think it is at least. Yes a good chunk of the game is spent on a boat, but there are occasions where you have to be on foot to get things done. It feels organic, and makes for good pacing. The Halo series is also a good example, since vehicles feel like very much a part of the game, and are even optional depending on the circumstances.
Duke Nukem Forever just didn't care. The developer looked at a checklist of what popular FPS titles did and said "We need this, but let's not put in the effort to make it quality." Vehicle-sections are a constant in DNF, and none of them are entertaining. Early on you're controlling an RC truck, a stage or two later you're driving an RC truck, not long afterwards you're driving a monster truck (that runs out of gas at specific points), then you're riding in a mine-cart, driving a forklift(wtf?), and so on. I'm probably forgetting a few instances but that's probably for the best. The main point is that DNF has vehicle-sections because they needed to pad the game out somehow.
The combat/gun-play - When you're making a first-person-shooter the shooter aspects should be compelling. There are several games that get this most basic element right. Duke Nukem Forever...doesn't. For a 1996 game, Duke Nukem 3D still holds up in the shootin' department. It's fast-paced, crunchy, and aliens make all kinds of nasty and gratifying noises when you splatter their guts. Shooting aliens in DNF isn't fun because there's no satisfying feedback. The over abundance of pig cops are the perfect example. They barely react when you're firing away at them, until they just sorta collapse when they die. If feels disconnected, like Duke didn't really kill them. What's also ridiculous is the lack of new enemies. Fifteen years should have been plenty of time to come up with some new aliens to design. With the technology available we should've seen some really creative stuff that pushes the envelope. Instead it's mostly the same enemies we saw back in 1996. Everything's the same, just crappier. This is especially apparent with the final boss fight against the Cycloid Emperor. He's the final boss of Duke Nukem 3D, the first boss of Duke Nukem Forever (in a nod to the first game), as well as the final boss. Good Lord.
Puzzles - When it comes to puzzles in an FPS, I'm firmly in the neutral camp. A little something to break up the action never hurts, as long as it isn't overbearing and doesn't screw with the pacing. DNF fails in this regard as well. Duke Nukem 3D was never the "thinking man's" shooter. Yes there were puzzles but they were more along the lines of flipping certain switches. The most elaborate puzzle took seconds to figure out. Naturally DNF has lots of puzzles. Alot of the time I felt like I was playing a seventh-rate Half-Life clone. None of it fits, very rarely is it clever, and it's just not fun. Defeating the Alien Queen requires bouncing pipe bombs off of trampolines. This is terrible. Every second Duke is hit by something that puts him into critical health. This is terrible crap.
The most bewildering addition is the ego system. In this game Duke recovers health (aka ego) when not taking damage. Boosting ego is done through a variety of actions, and they're almost all ridiculous. I can understand pumping iron giving an ego boost, but looking at pictures of women? What? It's a nonsensical system, but it's also kinda necessary because otherwise Duke dies too easily. This is the same guy that says "power armor is for♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;. Yeah, and taking cover almost constantly just to recover health is totally badass.
What really gets under my skin is that the humor in DNF is forced, painfully unfunny, and oft-times just plain awful. The timeliness of most of the jokes are just brutally bad, like the Olsen-twins esque pop-stars in the intro, "America, ♥♥♥♥ Yeah!", and well..you get the idea. Over the course of DNF's development hell, all of the jokes were kept in, even though most of them ceased being funny almost a decade ago. There's also this secondary character named Dylan. I still can't believe anyone thought he was a good idea. When he got killed off I kicked his corpse into a pool of electrified water. Naturally he returned in the expansion alive and well. I hate this game.
And yeah I played through the expansion. I'll admit, there were some neat moments (the clones mainly). The final boss is a vehicle section however and that's just unforgivable. Multiplayer is also available and uh...it wasn't that bad, at least compared to the rest of the game. It's not saying much sure, but at least it says SOMETHING.
There's a lot more I could be discussing about Duke Nukem Forever. There's that dream sequence where Duke is in a strip-club doing menial tasks for a lapdance, the plot(?), the misogyny, the--- eeeggghhhAHAHghhh! Forget it, I'm done talking about this mess.

Biggest shame is that 3DRealms didn't manage to release this themselves, they had a lot of it done and I cannot help, but wonder what went wrong. This game marks the end of a special era in video game history, before it became incredibly commercialized and big money. The whole way of doing business as 3Drealms was unique and I feel somewhat saddened looking at their website now and remembering what could have been if they hadn't spent 12 years on a title they ultimately never finished themselves. Its a darn shame, but Duke Nukem Forever will always represent the spirit of the old - though more in name than in game.
Buy it, play it and consider what it went through. Its a slide down in memory, that features multiple roadbumps, but its a slide worth taking in my opinion.

Duke Nukem: Forever is the sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, a classic game from the 1990's that inspired hundreds of games, mostly due to it's entertaining gameplay, well designed levels, and humour. Duke Nukem: Forever had big shoes to fill, and while it doesn't live up to the hype surrounding its release, it's definitely an enjoyable game despite the flaws.
This game has you once again playing as the Duke, living life as a celebrity after crushing the alien invasion in the previous game. The intro of the game has you reliving an awesome fight from the previous game before navigating your house and heading to an interview. While you'll notice the dodgy animations and skewed voicework, you'll also notice the astonishing amount of interactivity and abundance of items in the environment. Numerous posters and various memorabilia concerning Duke Nukem is scattered around the levels, and displays an enormous amount of fan service. You can interact with a large number of items in the environment, including pool tables, telephones, DVD players, toilets, vibrators (?), food, arcade games, weights, basketball, frisbees and even an actual turd (?). This lends itself to the novelty and humour of the game and was definitely one of the standards.
While the actual combat in the game isn't awful, it does feel clunky and dated by today's standards. Many of the weapons lack punch, and end up feeling as if you're firing a glorified water gun. The only satisfying gun in the game is the shotgun, which is relatively to find and locate ammunition for. The rest of the guns are clumsy and spongy to use on enemies.
Unfortunately, the level design is also quite linear. There's little exploration to be had, and it's relatively easy to find objects like ammo pickups. The constrictive and repetitive level design gets repetitive pretty quickly, and the blandly grey environments don't help this very much.
The boss fights in this game are surprisingly solid, and reminded me of old school games like Doom 3. These fights are entertaining and bombastic, but frustrating in that you can only damage them with a single weapon type. This limits the players style and actively forces you to play the game in a specific way. The game's real problem is the lack of creativity and restrictive mechanics, which contradicts the content found in Duke Nukem 3d.
The best way to experience Duke Nukem: Forever is the same as a popcorn action movie; turn your brain off, play it once, and don't look too carefully into it. The fun moments in this game make up for the bad ones, and the nostalgic value of this game probably elevated my score slightly. 7 / 10

Finally finished this a little while ago but only just now decided to write a review because it's hard to talk about this game in a way that doesn't make me seem like a double standard making jackass. Plus the standard negative stuff about DNF has been beaten to death over and over again in a way that would make Duke himself blush. So I'll try not to fall into that trap.
It's hard to talk about Duke because the games and the man himself is 80% gimmick and 20% one liners. This was no exception. So I can't just say it was too gimmicky. Because no♥♥♥♥♥♥Sherlock,  it's Duke Nukem. Problem is, there was 98% gimmick, 10% one liners and 0.5% things to kill. That was the big negative to me. There was too much focusing on memes that were sometimes not even duke related. There was too much gimmick happening and not enough shooting stuff. Like the minigames that are almost memes themselves at this point. It was like the game was trying to make up for lost time in the self-referential humor and thus you got huge spans of non-action sequences like the strip club. Make no mistake, Duke has always been about being cheesy and awesome and killing swathes of enemies. But this didn't have much of that all things considered.
Now let me get something straight, I'm a straight man and like any straight man I like women and I like boobs. I've seen and touched many of both in my time. So believe me when I say that there were way,
too many instances of "omg look boobs!" Just way too many, it's what you'd expect either a kid or a sexually frustrated adult to put into a video game. Like I said before lots of boob is perfect for Duke because he's Duke. Which is why the strip clubs in the original games were just fine. It was over the top and just great. But this is over the top to the point where someone fell down and broke their neck.
Other thing that almost made me create a review just to rant was the ♥♥♥♥ing hoover dam underwater ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Holy crap. This level frustrated me almost to the point of just stopping right then and there. I don't like underwater levels in 3D games in the first place but I do acknowledge they can be done right. This wasn't. It brought the pace of the game to a screeching halt even worse than the non-action sequences. I died more times in the leech fight and the area near it than anywhere else in the game including the final boss (which I actually died 0 times on so that should say something). Simply because I couldn't move fast. I know you're  thinking "you just have no skill". Maybe that's true, but this was not a matter of skill. There's just not enough gameplay and too much pandering and meme-whoring and not enough of what made the series great in the first place: Killing things. After this, you get about 20 hours worth of incredibly linear shooting galleries with brain dead AI, poorly executed sex jokes, and one of the dumbest ideas in video game history, which I will describe after the line break for emphasis.
OK, that was the line break. Now, one of the major selling points of this game was the variety of weapons. All the trailers up to the ones just before release advertised the huge variety of weapons. Well, Mr. Pitchford, if you're so proud of the game's wide weapon variety, WHY THE FLYING ♥♥♥♥ WOULD YOU IMPOSE A TWO/FOUR WEAPON LIMIT?
OK, that's the single player out of the way. The multiplayer nearly - NEARLY, you understand - made the game recommendable. Now I know what you're thinking: "But you seemed to like it, why would you not recommend the multiplayer"? Well, it's quite simple. I liked the multiplayer because it reminded me a lot of Unreal Tournament, one of the greatest multiplayer games ever. It then struck me that it would be a much better idea to just go buy one of the Unreal Tournament games instead of buying this for its multiplayer component. Duke Nukem Forever had a lot of hype surrounding it when it first came out, and the unreasonably high expectations made a lot of gamers feel let down when they actually played the game. The game attempts to reference Duke Nukem's past, and they do an alright job of it. The storyline itself is rather longish, with different puzzles, interactive scenes and boss fights to keep you occupied along the way, The voice acting could have used more work (especially the way they made Duke Nukem generally sound), and even though the storyline is longish it still seems like once you've finished the game it was too short.
The DLC "The Doctor Who Cloned Me" gave the game a bit of a boost along with it's nearly dead but still alive multiplayer community. These two should give you a bit more gaming time. I would recommend getting this game when it's on sale because the normal price to buy it is currently too much in my opinion for what this game offers. Hardcore Duke Nukem fans would probably enjoy this very much, but younger gamers or gamers that are not familiar with the Duke Nukem series would not understand the raunchy references this game makes or the style of humor that Duke Nukem has always used.
Overall, this game on sale + the DLC and multiplayer would be pretty fun for a casual gamer to play. There are also many references to other games that came out around the time that Duke Nukem Forever came out; casual gamers would definitely enjoy that.

I didn't expect a good game. I expected a Duke Nukem game. I didn't get either.
I've always been a Duke Nukem 3D fan because it was my first game I've ever played. I've played countless hours of DN3D through the years and was finally hyped for DNF. I've preordered DNF and even thought about getting myself the Balls Of Steel Edition. I've counted every day, hour and minute for its release. When it was finally released, nothing else in the world did matter.
I finished the game in just ONE sitting, in the hardest setting. Got 60% of the achievements in one swoop. I wasn't even rushing, I was taking my time to enjoy the game. I was dazed and confused. What went wrong?
Well, I got it down what went wrong AS A DUKE NUKEM GAME:
- The game offers no challenge whatsoever. Everything feels easy.
- I could only use two guns per time. TWO guns. Screw you, you're only holding 2 guns at a time.
- The game is linear. No keycards, no switches, nothing. Just straight forward.
- No puzzles. I only got like one or two of these and they weren't memorable. You won't be spending your time with them.
- The level design is just awful. As I said, the game is a corridor, so don't expect those rooms and layers you're used to on a normal Duke Nukem game.
- The soundtrack didn't seem fitting. I miss that bassy MIDI songs.
- Health recovery like CoD or Halo games killed 50% of the fun. You won't be begging for medikits, you just get behind a cover and wait.
- Gun impact felt bland. Gunplay was very dull.
- Shooting sections feel cheap. They lock the room and throw enemies at you. That's pretty much it.
And what went right:
+ I like the new guns.
+ Multiplayer was a fun mode but it was condemned since day one.
+ It's Duke Nukem. He's that guy full of one liners and wrong jokes.
But that's about it. Duke Nukem Forever feels and plays like a unfinished and unpolished game. It feels like a beta through the whole game. Get it for REALLY CHEAP if you're a hardcore fan, if not then just don't.

Okay... let's put it this way. I am going to say yes, but it is yes with a HUGE amount of caveats!
I'm NOT going to defend it's glaring, straight-up sickening misogyny, it's juvenile humor, and the fact it shows just what happens when you have too many cooks at the pot (so to speak). It is a game from another era, one that should have grown up with it's peers, but it didn't.
Still, if you can get past all of this, it actually is kind of fun. I know that is a LOT to get past, but I played "Send in the Clones" and enjoyed a few good chuckles, and it was just kind of fun to step back into the shoes of the narcissistic Duke. The main game is a little tedious in places, but it is still fun, the achievements are actually fun to go after and it has a sense of humor about itself. Don't get me wrong, I think the cutscenes in the alien hive were some of the worst the game has to offer (trust me, hit youtube and look it up if you haven't played this... you'll understand why).
This also isn't a game I'd let my kid play (if I had one), as it has some SUPER adult themes (and if you don't know what a glory hole is, maybe you shouldn't be playing it either), and I wouldn't want any kid thinking that Duke is a role model in any way, shape or form (especially for his treatment of women). 3D was more fun back in the 90s, but there is a little humor, charm and a halfway decent FPS under all of this crap.

Let me start by saying this game is bad, but it's not as bad as everyone says it is.  It certainly didn't live up to the hype, nor did it even come close to being as good as Duke Nukem 3D, but it's competent and there are occasional funny moments.
The main problem with this game is that it was too ambitious and it had some horrid scheduling problems.  Whomever is to blame is up for debate, but bottom line: this could've been an amazing game and it isn't.  It had some good ideas going for it, but they all seem extremely disconnected, only adding to the overall feeling that (despite the astonishing timeframe it took to make this game) it felt rushed.  It's disappointing, but playable.  If you're looking for the return that the old-school fps fans deserve, check out Shadow Warrior.  It actually lives up to the hype and has gone surprisingly unnoticed.
If you're looking for something great, look somewhere else.  If you're looking for a decent way to kill a few hours, I'd recommend it.  Oh-- and don't even bother with the multiplayer, no one plays it.

One one hand, I liked this game enough to play through it twice. But it is not a good game. ESPECIALLY taking in to account the twenty yaer wait. it should have been at least as good as, you know, a name-brand game with a normal developement time.  While it has some strengths, like some genuinly awesome moments and a reasonably solid shooter mechanic, the game is unfocused at best, assuming that the ood, out of place gimmicks that have been awkwardly inserted are actually fun. If they are fun, then the game will have you doing them until you hate them.
The biggest problems for me were:
1) Sexual innuendos, nudity, etc. This is duke nukem ,so we expect them to be there. BUT THEY WEREN"T FUNNY.at best it was sort of sad, most of the R-rated content in the game felt like it was tacked in as an afterthought, The pointless ♥♥♥♥♥ city level is the best example of the lack of thought put into the game.
2) Checkpoint saves only? REALLY?! The 90s game let you save whenever you wanted, The checkpoint save means you get to repeat furstrating, difficult parts over and over again. the platformer style puzzles in particular are a hellish nightmare because of this.
3) genuinely fun features, like the monster truck for instance, are ruined by beign constantly repeated and continued long after they sop beign amusing. even worse, stupid gimmicks like the shrunken platformer puzzles, racecar driving, and looking for junk in a hullucinated strip club, are alos drawn out.
Overall, if you can get this game cheap, its probably worth trying, its also worth grabbing if your a fan of the classic games. The DLC is shockingly good value, it adds a full new campaign, and is worth getting if you like the main campaign well enough. Basically, all the elements of the classic duke nukem games are there, but the're diluted in a bunch of other junk, and it really shows. The fact that it came out at all is impressive, but thats about all thats noteworthy about it,

I got this from GS for 3 bucks in a box and everything, figured I'd give this game a try, I heard ...really only negative things about it. Till this day I like me some Duke3D so I was hoping for some good times here.
Turns out the game isn't that bad, it's by no means great, the visuals are dated and there's some silly parts but it's more amusing than the slew of games trying to be as real as possible. Is DNF a dumb game? Heck yes it is, it's dumb as hell and that's why it's good- it's not trying to be story driven, it knows what it is and rolls with it like a good b-movie.
Since it came out it's clearly been updated, 4 weapon limit instead of 2 (that's a nice fix there) and I've not had many crashes so far. The guns have a nice feel to them, the alien weapons less so but the guns really feel powerful, and if that's not your thing you can always hurl weights into the faces of aliens which looks even more hard hitting.
The visuals are dated but that's how Duke 3D was, Quake was out shortly around Duke 3D and that didn't stop it from being fun eh? The game looks fine, I don't get the hate for this stuff especially with the slew of retro games that GoG puts out that get so much love. Yes this game came out looking like a slightly nicer Doom3 years later but screw it that's not what makes a game.
For 60 the game would have been a major let down, but for 3? I'm MORE than happy and I'ds say even up to 15 it's not a bad time. I'm not saying this game is great, I'm saying it's good, it's not bad and it's certainly not as crap as the reviewers lead you to believe. See it on sale? Nab it if you like silly shooters.

Well, I finally sat down and played it, and I have to say that I loved it and all the bad press it got was unwarranted! Duke Nukem Forever was a blast to play! Everything from the strip club mini-games to the hardcore gunning action to the anti-air missions. For those of you who aren't familiar with the textbook case of "Development Hell", Duke Nukem Forver was a sequel planned almost immediately on the heels of its acclaimed predecessor, Duke Nukem 3D. Unfortunately, stuff happened, legal stuff happened, and a game was spat out around 2011. After seeing bits and snippets and reading up on some negative reviews, I finally bought it and played and, like I said, LOVED IT! Duke Nukem, having accumulated fame, fortune and everything else (a casino, a restaurant franchise, a strip club, etc.) from saving the Earth, gets his mood ruined when bastard aliens show up with less than diplomatic intentions. Duke Nukem has aspects of the Gears of War, HALO, Doom 3 and every other big name shooter instilled into its mechanics and is peppered with mini-games on the side (some pointless, some cool, some kinky), all the while staying true to its original origins of one-liners, violence, machismo and BABES. The mechanics were smooth, the gameplay was a little hard but not too hard, the graphics were beautiful, the weapon selections was great and the setup for everything was beautiful. So why did it get negative reviews? Not sure, but if I had to nitpick what may have been wrong with it, I'd say it was a little too linear. It had a very clear plot and story that the player has little choice but to follow along with. It's reminiscent of games like (2006 sleeper) Prey and Bulletstorm in this sense. Aside from that, it's everything you'd expect from a Duke Nukem sequel, so give it an honest try. It'll be in the bargain bin for the rest of its days, so what have you got to lose?!

Duke Nukem Forever is a first person shooter 15 years in the making. Back in the 90s most of us fell in love with Duke 3D. Not for its movie cliches or paying women for money, but for its non linear levels with a lot of exploration and guns. Well Duke Forever took away the non linear level design. Now Duke is stuck in some one dimensional levels. You'll visit the desert, a damn, a bar, an alien hive, his underground complex, get shrunk in a Duke Burger all on your journey to a tower. Duke isn't as fast as he used to be, so now he has vehicles every so often. You'll sit on and drive remote controlled cars and a giant monster truck that squashes enemies and uses nitrous boost for the jumps.
I think my issue with this game is the first two hours felt like everything but first person shooting. The game throws a lot of distractions at you. An interactive museum dedicated to Duke, punching, playing pinball, driving, first person platforming and a turret section. It just seemed like the shooting was 15% of what Duke Forever was.
Once you get over the giant hill of the first two hours, the game feels like a Half Life 2-ish game and that's good. Duke's world has been taken over by aliens. If it didn't sound Half-Life 2 enough for you, Duke walks and drives his way to a massive tower with a beam of light extending to the sky. There is a checkpoint system and no exploration or secrets. There are a few simple physics puzzles here and there. Moving barrels to weigh things down. Stuff like that.
The game uses a typical Unreal / Gearbox with controls to thumbstick crouch, thumbstick sprint (forward only), weapon switch, grenade, trip mine, zoom aim, fire, melee, jump and actions / reload. There are quick D-pad controls for Duke's night vision, holovision (duke clone to distract enemies), steroids and beer.
You can only carry 2 weapons and switch between them. There is a good variety of weapons. A laser sighted pistol, alien laser, shotgun, triple barreled ripper machinegun, rail gun to snipe, RPG, chaingun, devastator, freeze ray, triple stinger missile launcher, trip mines, grenades and so on. Nothing feels like it has impact.
The enemy intelligence is pretty good. Berserker pigs will charge, pig soldiers will shoot at you, and if you hide, they will grenade you. Alien soldiers hover, teleport in and out and actually try to flank you. It makes for a nice dynamic. The only problem is a lot of the maps are so straight forward, they don't allow for being flanked. The boss fights are pretty easy and that's not a complaint. Just RPG them until they're low on health, run to them and uh button mash them to death.
Other enemies from the franchise make their return. Octobrains swim, hover and shoot projectiles at you. Preginators jump and face stick onto you so you'll need to button mash to take them off. Hovering assault commanders that fire missiles at you. Overall, it seems like there aren't that many enemies, just different versions of them.
There are a few sections that confine you to an area and just have enemies flood in. It feels like a cheap way to extend gameplay, even if it does highlight enemy intelligence. Some enemy rooms are so simple that you see the enemy dropping in, so you can be there to shoot them point blank, taking away any kind of challenge or fun.
If this game wasn't Duke, I would have kept playing to realize there is an enjoyable game here past the first 2 hours.

This game is absolutely abysmal, even by 1997's standards (the year they first started working on this).
To start, on the upside, you are a badass throwing out cheesy one liners whenever you kill enemies. That's pretty much it. From here on out, it's going to be nothing but downhill. I had to force myself to keep playing and even then, I simply couldn't take the pain anymore. The story goes - aliens attack and it's up to the Duke, an aging sterol junkie and narcissist to defend Earth. That sounds cool but in reality, the Duke rarely speaks and there is little humor (forget Bulletstorm, Borderlands, or Portal - this isn't even a warm up to comedy). The gameplay is nothing more than equip yourself with generic assault rifles and blast linear swarms of generic aliens. You do this several times before the pace is abruptly halted by generic platforming or unnecessary dialogue. The reality is the game doesn't know what it wants to be (think Postal but worse) so it tries to be everything. It tries to be humorous, fast, witty, serious - but it's not any of that.
The Duke is living in the past and you can clearly tell by the random ideas lumped together right before release. At best, this game was average for 1997 but by 2011's standards, it has fallen way, way, way below average. The score is nothing more than a bland overtune that puts you to sleep. The graphics and textures are very pixelated, bland, blurry, blocky, and poor. The AI is broken and commonly gets stuck on things. The multiplayer servers are deadier then Jake Lloyd's acting career. You could probably get it to run on a toaster but I doubt it (which is a good thing because the toaster might blow up and you'd need a new one). What's funny is the game is so bad, the developers realized it and took the time to make jokes about it. This does not excuse the fact that you had 14 years to make a game that played like it was done in just 14 days. Duke Nukem Forever, the long awaited sequel to Duke Nukem 3D arrived 2,5 years ago.
Most people expected (a lot) more of this game and even though it's not far as good as Duke Nukem 3D was, I still think it's a decent game worth at least one playthrough.
Just like it's predecessor DNF is a FPS full of little jokes and mini-games. Things that would've been funny back in the days but things have changed. DNF still makes you giggle once in a while but for the main part the jokes are pretty silly and childish.
DNF tries to add a little story to the game which doesn't really add anything to the game and some of the maps can be very annoying, especially when playing on the hardest difficulty. It took me around 10 hours to finish the game on the 'Come Get Some' difficulty (the hardest mode except for Insane mode).
Even though DNF is not the game everyone was hoping for I'd still recommend it to anyone who can't get enough of Duke Nukem, FPS and childish humour.

It was released about 3 years too late than it should (the final build, that is), and that made it immediately dated and unimpressive (both visually and design wise), resulting in bad reviews and disappointment. But from a perspective of time, it doesn't really matter that much. I mean the game is 7 years old as of now, so mediocre graphics and dated design is a given. Too bad the multiplayer is pretty much dead by now, it was a real blast (from the past) back when the game was still new. But the singleplayer is decent too, except the first part in the hotel, which was dreadful. But it gets much better as it goes on, and the DLCs are probably even better than the main game.

I wanted to believe. I wanted to believe that Duke Nukem Forever was going to be a good game. I wanted to believe that Duke Nukem Forever might justify its insanely long development time. I wanted to believe that somewhere in Duke Nukem Forever was something absolutely worth playing. I was wrong.
Duke Nukem Forever is not a good game. It's a dated game. It feels like it was released in 2005, not 2011. The levels themselves are by no means interesting. The jokes aren't funny. The references are dated. I mean, it has the absolute laziest Portal joke of all time. There's a strip club scene that is not only gross, but immensely sad. John St. John delivers all of his bad dialog as well as he can, and the funniest parts are the reactions he has to fishing a turd out of the toilet.
For all of its time in development, there's one new gun, and it's a railgun. There's a two-gun limit, or there was until they patched it so you could have four guns. The action doesn't even hold up to Duke Nukem 3D. There are quick-time events. You spend too much time as a tiny Duke doing some dumb platforming. None of the action is all that great, and it's been done better many times over by other games. Bulletstorm is a better Duke Nukem game than Duke Nukem Forever.
It's real difficult to find anything positive to say about Duke Nukem Forever. In the extras, there's a selection of demo videos from the multiple iterations this game has gone through. There's one in the middle of the timeline that looks like it would have been a really cool game if it had come out on time. Then it's immediately followed by another video that's absolute garbage. Get this game only if you absolutely must play a piece of gaming history, and get it as cheap as you can. It's not worth your time otherwise.

Sex crazed aliens invade the planet and steal all our women. It's up to you to wipe out the space vermin while saving hookers and strippers from unpleasant deaths. There is nothing new or inventive on this one as far as the gameplay is concerned. Gunning your way through each area is linear and there aren't any well hidden secrets or divergent levels to explore. It's fairly straightforward as far as first person shooters go, but I really dig the junior-high school humor and trashy one-liner jokes throughout Duke Nukem Forever. As Duke you can enjoy a beer, take a pull off a cigar, blow away some green skinned intergalactic perverts, and slap a few bOobz along the way. It just doesn't get much better than that. The raunchy dialogue and huge b00bies everywhere made me laugh and made up for some of the dull aspects of gameplay.

There are many negative reviews out there about this game, so many people say it's a terrible game and poorly made. Hearing those things made me a little hesitant to try it out but it looked good to me and I saw it was on sale so I decided to give it a shot. Due to all the negative feedback this game has received I expected to see some serious problems with it.... glitchyness, boring gameplay, bad graphics, just something that would really make it too undesirable for me to want to play and finish it. I played and played, waiting to find the reason(s) so many people dislike this game but from the beginning to the end I found nothing significant enough to justify the hatred so many people have for Duke Nukem: Forever.
The gameplay was fun, the environments were interesting, the graphics and physics were good, the weapons were pretty diverse, the difficulty was well balanced, and most of the jokes and puns were funny enough to give me a little laugh. The game kept me interested enough to play it through to the end over the course of a few days and it never disappointed me or made me feel like it wasn't worth the money I paid for it. It was really an enjoyable experience and pretty much the opposite of what all these negative reviewers made it out to look like.
So, the question is; why was this game so bad in the eyes of so many? My best guess would be that it's due to a few different aspects. Maybe the game had problems when it was first released which have since been patched. Maybe it was hyped up so much that many people were expecting a groundbreaking game and were disappointed when they saw it wasn't. This game was supposed to be released many times over the course of about a decade and each time it was announced that it was to be released soon it ended up not happening each time. The reoccuring disappointment from that would be enough to make many gamers critical on it when it was finally released.
There were a few negative things I saw in this game, minor though they are, they're still worth mentioning. I saw a few small glitches such as that the pigcop freezes for a second in mid-air when he lunges towards you if you move out of the way. I also didn't find the characters in this game(other than Duke Nukem himself) particularly interesting or memorable, they were all pretty bland. The enemies didn't exactly have colorful personalities either but in a game like this they really don't need to do much else than look fierce and give you a good fight and those were two features they certainly had. Another thing is that to me there doesn't seem to be much replay value in this game, you pretty much see everything the first time around. Though after beating the game it unlocks a few bonus options and cheats which you may find interesting enough to play it through once again.
Everything considered I feel like this is a good game. It's no Halo or Half life 2 or grand theft auto or Shenmue or Max Payne or Resident evil or any other groundbreaking game with a terrific storyline that will make you sit back in your chair once it's all over and say "Wow, that was an incredible game" but if you want a non-serious shooter with some comedy, pleasing visuals(B00BIES 0.0), fun gameplay and stupid things to play around with(dry erase boards, minigames, turds in toilets, light switches, microwaves, etc.) then this might just be the game to suit your needs. Just remember that game reviews are simply based on the opinions of that particular reviewer and a game they call bad could be a game you will thoroughly enjoy. If this game looks good to you, give it a shot. If it looks good but you're pessimistic due to the negative reviews you've seen then wait for it to be on sale and pick it up. I enjoyed it, maybe you will too.

This is not an "amazing-knock-your-socks-off-and-blow-you-away" game. That said fact, it is not bad, either. The critics were way too harsh. Sure, there is a lot of puzzle solving elements that can get repetitive, and sure, the graphics look several years dated, but graphics are not what makes a game good and even the old Duke 3D has similar puzzle solving. Also, the long load times that people complained about are a non-issue on PC. It's less than 10 seconds, compared to up to 45 seconds for the console versions. And also, unlike on the consoles, you can carry up to 4 weapons (enable "expanded inventory" in the options menu) instead of only 2. This may not seem like a big deal, but carrying more weapons really does add to that older Duke feel. Honestly, this is not a bad game. Certainly not nearly as bad as most people claimed. If you can get past the dated graphics and a little reptetiveness at times (What game doesn't have its reptetive moments?) then Duke Nukem Forever really can be an enjoyable game.
One more thing I would like to add is how well PC optimized this game seems to be. Just start and play, no tweaking needed. That really is a breath of fresh air from so many poorly-ported console games on PC. I was honestly not expecting the game to be so smooth.

I made a review a long time ago for this game but i decided to redo it since its been a while.
Duke Nukem Forever, is there anyone who DOSENT know this game in some way? For those that have been living under a rock the past... decade, DNF is a game that has been promised, over-hyped and even killed off and brought back from the dead for YEARS with hundreds of thousands of avid fans from all over the world hoping and praying for its eventual release. Did this game live up to all the hype from delay after delay? (Did Colonial Marines?) I think the general consensus is "NO." but even with that in mind, lets take a look at the game and see what it's got going for it.
Duke Nukem Forever is the long awaited sequel to the FPS Classic Duke Nukem 3D. It has all the crude humor, over the top violence, and macho-man attitude its predecessor is known for, but its lacking some things that helped previous titles become hits: Charisma. This game might have the violence and T&A the series is known for, but is lacking in charisma, class and not to mention the humor is far too low brow (even for a duke nukem game) to be funny. Now, at times it does have its funny and witty moments (driving around in a remote controlled car for example) but these moments are too few and far between, not to mention the level design can be incredibly frustrating and even dull at times. There is a multiplayer aspect to the game, but it's the most bare-bones pathetic excuse for multiplayer that nobody wants to play it, and speaking of multiplayer, this game made the ultimate sin of NOT HAVING CO-OPERATIVE GAMEPLAY. Many people wanted to like this game, but its makes itself very hard to like, is that dukes fault? No. If i had to put the blame on anything, its remaking the game too many damn times. The original trailers for the game looked nothing like this, and honestly, probably would have been better. But who knows? The companies responsible sure as hell didnt.
PROS:
> Duke is back
> Delicious Uncensored Boobs
> Customizable Penthouse
> Occasional fun
CONS:
> Multiplayer is horrible
> No Coop
> Incredibly low-brow humor
> Confusing level design
> Waiting 15 years for a lukewarm game
> Unrewarding gameplay
> Far too expensive for price of admission

You'll notice an overwhelming theme in reviews for DNF, where the leading reason for negative reviews are purely based on the hype that was built up for the game, or the fact that it wasn't DN3D for the modern generation. Most of the people that I know who hate on the game haven't even played it, but because IGN said it was bad, well, darnit, it must be terrible.
If you are expecting Duke3D, you will be disappointed. This is not the high-speed retro action game that represented the  technology of the Build engine.
Go into this title remembering that it is from 2006. The current build of the game, graphics and otherwise, are from the last build of the game that 3D Realms worked on, which was abandoned and then picked up by Gearbox. While the graphics definitely aren't to par with titles that were released alongside it, nobody really should've expected otherwise.
The game itself doesn't break any new ground. Like most modern shooters, expect to be ducking under cover to allow your health to regenerate, swapping out weapons to accomodate the two weapon limit, and having gameplay mixed with driving and turret segments. However, one thing that Duke Nukem games have always had is an incredible amount of interactivity with the environment, something you just don't see in other games. Getting sodas from vending machines, playing pinball, writing on markerboards, seeing your current time reflected in the in-game clocks; they're mostly small touches, but something that more games need to embrace.
The combat is fairly straightforward. Unload in the direction of the nearest alien until there isn't much left. There isn't much need for ammo conservation unless you're toting a Shrinker or RPG, as you come across fresh guns and ammo caches fairly frequently.  The two gun limit was, admittedly, a major letdown, as no one really wants to use the Shrinker or the Freeze Ray as a primary weapon due to ammo being scarce, but being able to have one handy for whenever you DID want to use it was nice. They did patch in a 4-weapon limit, but since the game was designed around 2, there isn't much indication in the HUD which weapons you have or what key they're bound to.
The level variety is another place where DNF excels. From casinos, to dusty Vegas streets, to being shrunk in a fast food kitchen and fighting across the shelves, DNF does a great job at mixing up the levels. The driving segments were definitely underwhelming, with some pretty wonky vehicle physics. Luckily, none of those segments are too brutal and checkpoints are plentiful, so it's definitely not gamebreaking by any means.
The music is mostly forgettable, with some of the renditions of GrabBag standing out, but otherwise its fairly mundane battle music. The weapon sounds are hit and miss, with some weapons, such as the Ripper, sounding punchy and brutal, while others, namely the Shotgun, just don't feel powerful at all. The voice acting is also hit and miss, with some great performances by Jon St. John, and some mediocre work from pretty much everyone else. Some of the civilian NPC's are a bit painful to listen to.
Overall, Duke Nukem Forever definitely wasn't the groundbreaking title everyone wanted, and it certainly wasn't Duke3D all over again, but that doesn't make it a bad game. The fact that it was released at all was pretty incredible, and if you can overlook the dated 2006 graphics and engine, and don't go into it with the mindset of some epic godly title that will blow your socks off, there is alot of fun to be had.

It's vague, unreliable and frequently comes to a halt because of unclear objectives. Yet when this dinosaur works, it can be somewhat of a spectacle, but one which needs to be kept away from human populations. There are some moments in which the potential of Forever shines through -- perhaps these were Gearbox's efforts to elevate the material -- but you can't spitshine, if not a turd, a rusty old relic indicative of its day but better suited in a museum.

If it's for cheap like a Daily Deal, then you save yourself the buyer's remorse I get for having bought this $60 at launch. But then I wouldn't recommend that unless you have a few bucks to spare and a sense of morbid curiousity for bile. That is to say, Duke Nukem Forever is not a broken game. It's not an incomplete game. Infact, nothing is overall glitchy or messy, and it's competent.
But does that make it good?
Forever tries to cash in on nostalgia to Duke Nukem 3D, but it reaches a point that Duke himself almost feels like a parody of his younger self, and that nostalgia is hollow at best with art design, ripped or altered quotes, and wholesale references. The Duke's lines seem like they were written by Comedy Central writers on a boring weekend, and a few very specific moments are just plain.. Unnecessary or even downright vexing as to how anyone thought it was a good idea.
When the game you're referencing is better than the your own game, however, that becomes a significant issue. And in all regards, Forever falls down the cesspit that is a modern shooter without much ingenuity. Regenerating health (coined as 'Ego', but extremely inconsistent on how much damage you can actually sustain), bland gunplay with no real kick or impact beyond the shotgun blast, dumb-as-bricks enemy AI that either stands perfectly still or rushes you, turret and vehicle sections thrown in for 'variety' that drags players down when they last way too long, rudimentary puzzles to pad out the game time, boss fights that arbitarily can only be hurt by explosions with magical infinite ammo reserves somehow implemented to keep you going...
For all of the callbacks, mythology gags, and attempts to appeal to the Duke 3D fans, the game plays nothing like it beyond being of the same genre. There's no depth, beyond finding boosts to your Ego meter by winning minigames or doing things like photocopying your rear end (and some objects you interact with give Ego, including easy-to-miss ones, but others that might reasonably do so.. don't). You can only carry four weapons at a time plus handheld explosives, and only two if you toggle that patched-in option off. Things like the Beer power-up are completely useless and outright detrimental. And it just keeps dragging
and
...
There is a multiplayer function to the title, make no mistake. It's fast-paced, much more so than the actual campaign mode of the game, and there's even a basic unlock and customization system. .. if unlocking aesthetics around a penthouse is your idea of a worthy set of unlocks, or being able to change Duke's shirt color, try on different glasses and put on hats is your idea of fun customization. At times the multiplayer's a bit
hectic, though, making it rather hard to keep up with and a likely cycle of 'die, respawn, die' with larger player counts. I don't have much to say, since this is basically Call of Duty meets Quake without any real polish.
If this were just another crummy modern first-person-shooter, no one would've given it the time of day. But because it's Duke Nukem and been in the making for twelve years, it's not even a case of expectations being too high; I went in with middling to low expectations even at launch, and this game was so medicore, so boring, so
that despite getting to the last portions of the game, I just don't feel like I'll ever properly finish this game. And considering I loved Duke Nukem 3D, as well as having had this game since day one, it breaks my heart to say that.

It's normal to have high expectations on a game that's been in development for more than 10 years, but to judge it it's important to know a little of its development history to understand why they took so long to finish it.
It was remade from scratch many times because of the engine or graphics being outdated, they wanted it to be perfect, or at least as groundbreaking as the original Duke Nukem 3D was at its time. Due to this fact, many of the original ideas planned for the game didn't make it to the final product as can be seen in its many trailers.
But then, when all hope was lost (with 3D Realms closing) Gearbox appeared and saved the day buying the Duke Nukem license. And then the game was released. Was it groundbreaking? No. Was it awesome? I wish... Was it bad? No, and that's what it's important.
If you don't know the history of its development, the final product (at least the bulk of it, not counting the makeup and multiplayer Gearbox added later) was finished by 2009, and due to budget and legal problems, the game felt a little old even for that time. So probably most of its ideas were nice and new for 2005 maybe, its not bad! But not as impactating as they wish they were (if they decided to change it, it probably would have never been released).
Plot wise, it isn't something jaw dropping, it is something you would expect from a Duke Nukem game: Duke is loved and desired by the women, men admire him, and kids want to be like him, it's all going well until an alien mothership comes to Earth. The problem is, they're not being hostile... yet. As the story unfolds (doesn't take too long actually) everybody finds out that the aliens plan on abducting the women, and kill everyone else, ESPECIALLY Duke Nukem, so it's up to the King to go rescue the babes and save the world once again.
Graphically, it isn't outstanding by any means, but Gearbox did a really good job poilishing it, the blur and depth of filed effects are really well implemented. You can notice a few low res texture here and there (most noticeable on the console versions) but it shines at times like in the Cycloid Emperor fight at the start of the game or in the Mothership battle a bit alter on. What really is kinda of ugly, it's the animations, the characters move unnaturally and don't have many facial expressions, reminded of Quake 4 NPCs. On the other hand, the enemies are very detailed and in general really well done.
In the Sound department, it lacks a more compelling soundtrack, but the voice acting is really well done, Jon St. John returns as Duke doing a really great job. The other NPCs sound a little ridiculous sometimes, but that's intended. The one-liners return and (fortunately for me and unfortunately for others) the old ones come back too. There aren't many good ones within the introduced in this game, but some really have the spirit of the franchise.
Gameplay was one of the most controversial things about this game, I thought it was too linear run and gun with regenerative health (ego) as most FPS games are nowadays, and that's what disappointed me. Don't get me wrong, it's fun to play, but I expected it to be more open ended like Duke 3D. I was hoping for something that would really differ (in a good way) from all the games we have today. There are puzzles here and there and I enjoyed them, to reduce the pace a little to not get too repetitive. The other games references were funny and not offensive like most people think they were, Duke Nukem 3D featured a "dead space marine.." (Duke's voice) and played just like it, guys at Id found it hilarious and not offensive, it's more of a homage than an offense. The guns for the most part don't feel very powerful (with the exception of the shotgun), and the classic funny ones can't be used as they were in Duke 3D because of the 2 weapon limit (4 as an option with a later released patch), the Shrink Ray is overpowered, since it's almost One Shot One Kill, but the Freeze-Ray is underpowered because it takes a lot of time to actually freeze the enemy and puts you in harm's way since it only works in close range.
The loading times aren't as huge on the PC as they are on the console versions, but it is still a little big when you are dying constantly in a specific part of the game. You can't save whenever you want, instead the game uses checkpoints, which actually makes the game more challenging (too much at times but oh well).
Multiplayer is old school. Features deathmatch, team deathmatch, CTF (CT Babe in this case), and King of The Hill. All old school fast paced, not many people play it, but its fun for a while. Weird that when any player dies, they blow up instead of having ragdolls, probably because the guys at Gearbox didn't have time to implement it.
As a game released these days, I'll give it a 6, which is fair, it shares a lot of similarities to other popular FPS games these days (including the complaints). But knowing that it was supposed to be released a long time ago (talking of the actual build, not the old ones), when the ideas were actually "new" for the time, I would give it a 7.8. I think that after all that the developers been through, they deserve a little understanding.

There are worse games out there, in as much as Duke Nukem Forever has never crashed my computer, it's possible to get from the beginning to the end, and you're unlikely to get stuck, uncertain of what needs to be done to progress. That said, it's an ugly game that cribs from other shooters without any understanding of why certain things work and why they don't... Rather than allowing puzzles to function as a break from action, it interrupts them for more tedious "here's two enemies, now here's two more, rinse, lather and repeat" action. The "execution to restore life" idea never pays off because the player never knows if they'll actually get to perform an execution unless they get the freeze weapon... And though they finally included an option to increase the stupid two-weapon limit to four, the player is still going to end up mostly using the weapons that ammo is actually provided for on a given level. The "interactive" elements, like pinball tables and computers, mostly serve to try to distract from the obvious narrow linearity of the levels (and fail to do so). The humor is flat and off-putting, drawing an irate "you thought I would laugh at THAT?" from the player. The use of ugly green dark-vision through much of the game suggests a lack of confidence in the work of the texture artists. And perhaps worst of all for those who fondly remember Duke Nukem 3D, this iteration of Duke is a wuss... Drunk on one beer, constantly having to run for cover in every encounter, and departing more than one major fight flat on his back and passing out. I understand why some people might feel compelled to bear witness to the train wreck when the game is available at a sale price, but honestly... Spare yourself the time and go watch some of the video reviews of DNF online instead; there's probably a lot more genuine entertainment value to be found there.
