Duke Nukem Forever is a 2011 first-person shooter video game for Microsoft Windows, OS X, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 developed by 3D Realms and Triptych Games and finished by Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is a sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series.
Intended to be groundbreaking, Duke Nukem Forever became a notable example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; the game was released in 2011 after fifteen years of development.
Plot
Twelve years after the events of Duke Nukem 3D. Duke is a worldwide icon, and has achieved great fame from his heroic deeds. After sampling a video game based on his past heroics, he arrives on the set of a talk show for an interview. On his way to the show, Duke witnesses a news broadcast announcing that aliens have once again invaded. Unlike previous encounters, the aliens initially appear peaceful and at first seem to pose no harm to the humans of Earth. Duke's talk show appearance is cancelled to allow television stations to cover the alien invasion, and he retires to the "Duke Cave".
There, he receives a call from the President and General Graves of the Earth Defence Force . The president orders him not to harm the invaders, and adds that he is in diplomatic talks with the alien overlord. Duke obliges this request, but remains uneasy about the whole situation. Before he can leave his chambers, he is attacked by hostile aliens. Duke is forced to disobey the president's orders and fight his way through the alien hordes in an effort to save Earth. Whilst fighting through his casino, Duke witnesses the aliens abducting women including his two live-in pop star girlfriends. Graves tells Duke that the women are being held in the Duke Dome, and that the aliens have a vendetta to settle with Duke. He also warns Duke that the aliens are using the Hoover Dam to power a wormhole so more aliens can come through. Nukem travels to the Duke Dome, using a wrecking ball to damage the building to gain access. Inside, he finds swarms of Octabrains and the missing women, who have been impregnated with alien spawn; Duke's girlfriends die after giving "birth" to alien babies. Duke finds the Alien Queen in control of the Dome and kills her, but is wounded in the process and blacks out.
After regaining consciousness, Duke fights Pigcops and aliens in through the Duke Burger. Soon he travels to the Hoover Dam in his monster truck; after battling through the dam, he finds his old friend Dylan, mortally wounded. He tells Duke that the Cycloid Emperor is at the dam, and that the only way to shut down the portal is to completely destroy the dam. Before dying, he gives Duke his demolition charges and wishes him luck. Duke places the explosives and destroys the dam, but the currents nearly drown him. Duke is revived by an EDF soldier; he awakens to find the portal gone. The President, who was also at the dam, rages at Duke for ruining his plans to work with the Cycloid Emperor and that he has ordered a nuclear strike at the site of the dam to wipe out the remaining aliens, intending to leave Duke there to die. The Cycloid Emperor emerges and kills the President and his security detail. Duke kills the Cycloid Emperor and is rescued by Graves just as the nuclear bomb explodes.
The game ends with a satellite surveying the detonation area and listing Duke Nukem as killed in action, to which Duke replies off-screen, "What kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ending is that? I ain't dead. I'm coming back for more!" A short scene after the ending credits depicts a press conference, where Duke announces his intent to run for the President of the United States.
Gameplay
Duke Nukem Forever is an action-oriented first-person shooter. Players take control of Nukem as they navigate through a series of levels which take place on Earth and beyond. The game allows players to interact with various in-game objects, including urinals, water coolers and whiteboards which allow players to draw their own images. The gameplay is similar in some respects to the first-person shooter games of the late 1990s and early 2000s, with each level culminating in a boss battle in which Nukem has to fight and kill a large, significant alien.
Unlike in the previous games, Duke can only hold two weapons at any one time in a manner similar to the Halo series, although pipe bombs and laser tripwires are considered inventory items and as such are not limited by this restriction. The PC version allows Duke to hold four weapons in the single-player campaign. Items that have an effect on Duke can be picked up by the player; these items are steroids, beer, and the holoduke. Steroids increase the strength of Duke's melee attacks by a great deal for a limited time. Beer makes Duke much more resistant to damage, but blurs the screen. A holoduke creates a hologram of Duke Nukem that looks and acts in a very similar way to Duke, but often says slightly twisted versions of his one-liners. Whilst the holoduke is in effect, Duke becomes invisible and the AI characters do not recognize his presence. The jetpack also returns, but only in multiplayer.
Instead of the health system featured in the previous Duke Nukem game, in which health would be depleted when Nukem was injured and would only increase upon finding a health pack, drinking water from fountains/broken fire hydrants, urinating or using the portable medkit special item, Duke Nukem Forever employs a system involving an "ego bar". The ego bar depletes when Duke is attacked; once it is fully depleted, Duke becomes susceptible to damage, dying and causing the game to reload the last checkpoint. If the player avoids further damage, then the ego bar is restored as is Duke's health. The player can increase the size of the ego bar  by interacting with certain items throughout the game, and by defeating bosses. The game employs a save system that is solely based on checkpoints.
Development
Originally in development under 3D Realms, director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, first announced the title's development in April 1997, and various promotional information for the game was released between 1997 and 1998. After repeatedly announcing and deferring release dates, 3D Realms announced in 2001 that it would be released simply "when it's done". No official video of the game was shown for almost 8 years, until 3D Realms released a new teaser trailer in December 2007, but the game "submerged" yet again soon afterwards.
In May 2009, 3D Realms was downsized for financial reasons, resulting in the loss of the game's development team. Statements by the company indicated that the project was due to go gold soon with pictures of final development. Take-Two Interactive, which owns the publishing rights to the game, filed a lawsuit in 2009 against 3D Realms over their failure to finish development. 3D Realms retorted that Take-Two's legal interest in the game was limited to their publishing right. The case was settled with prejudice and details undisclosed in July 2010.
On September 3, 2010, after 14 years, Duke Nukem Forever was officially reported by 2K Games to be in development at Gearbox Software. It was originally confirmed to be released on May 3, 2011 in North America, with a worldwide release following on May 6, 2011. This was, however, delayed by a month to June 10 internationally, with a North American release on June 14.
On May 24, 2011, it was announced that Duke Nukem Forever finally "went gold" after 15 years. After going gold the launch trailer for Duke Nukem Forever was released on June 2, 2011, quelling any doubt that release was anything but imminent. On June 27, 2011, Aspyr Media announced that Duke Nukem Forever would be making its way onto Mac OS X in August 2011. It was made available for pre-order on June 27 via their online game distribution platform GameAgent.

There were quite a few fun moments and some good jokes. I will, however, point out that this game, unlike Shadow Warrior's execution of a 90s-styled-shooter, often missed the mark and did a multitude of things terribly wrong. What could have been its biggest strengths come off as its biggest weaknesses. For instance, in the 90s, you would have 8-10 guns at any time, whereas modern games usually go for a realistic 2-3 at most, but that's mostly because the guns are so similar in modern games...such as different assault rifles or different shotguns and such. However, when your game has shrink rays, freeze rays, and other such fun guns, the game needs more weapon slots. At launch, you could only have two weapons on Duke at a time, though I've read that the number has increased to four with a patch. This still isn't really enough in my opinion.
So that's how the game fell short on the retro side of things. As for its modern shortcomings, the technology for quality NPCs, storyline, interesting events, etc. exist, but almost all of these are quite poor and forgettable in this game. But I digress...for all the game's shortcomings, it's still pretty fun, though the multiplayer is typical fare and a bit of a ghost town. Only buy this if you're bored and curious. I'll just barely lean toward recommending it over not. =/

Believing the hype is doing yourself a disservice. Personally, as a fan of older FPS games, especially DOOM and Duke 3D, when Duke Nukem Forever was finally released to the light of day, the initial reaction from casual gamers was very obvious: "OMG - IT'S NOT CALL OF BOOTY - WHERE'S MY ADS AND PERKS - DAFUQ!? 1-5, STUPID GAME!" because... well... not very many games are like Duke Nukem.
The origins of the game itself span back to the land of DOS: a wondrous age of gaming, where anyone with the basic understanding of coding could program just about anything they set their minds to, which lead to the creation of Duke Nukem: a simple side scrolling 2D platformer. Years later down the line, Duke Nukem 3D, the game we all know and love, was set out onto PCs, with a tongue-in-cheek sense of humor, a ton of explosions, and a direct competitor to the ever-famous Doom.
While not as successful as Doom was, Duke 3D revolutionized the way a game was designed, with an emphasis on exploring your environments, multiple level paths, and a lot of pop-culture references, specifically to the Evil Dead series of films. Duke Nukem 3D was, itself, an odd one in the bunch, just like Forever is the odd one in the regenerating health, pushing your skull into the middle of the screen, level-up, gray mess of modern games.
Forever is a simple game, that actually has a lot more for it than meets the eye. Initially, I played the whole game in a few days, and was not even disappointed. The humor, the action, the exploration (although limited) was there, and I ultimately walked away from my computer, satisfied, smiling, and nodding to myself, "I'm going to end up playing this a few more times in the future, I know it..."
Yes, it's buggy. Yes, it's weird. Yes, it's catering towards the modern generation of gamers with the limited items, linear paths, and regenerating health - but - as a whole, Forever really is a good and fun gaming experience, because isn't that what a game is INTENDED TO DO: make you have fun? Remember a time when a game was fun, and you didn't have to shove eight different filters of gray and blue on a game, focus about 70% of it to cut-scenes and quick-time events, and were able to finish it by using your wits and cunning - surveying the landscape for health pickups, ammo, and routes around enemies and puzzles? I do... and so should you.
Drop that 60$ right now, modern, hipster, Skrillex-listening, Minecraft-loving, indie-pushing gamer - and that copy of Call of Duty: Ghosts of a Dead Series - and put it into getting Duke Nukem 3D, 1, 2, and Forever - and spend your leftovers on something to drink and munch - you're going to sit down and enjoy a game for what it is: fun.

One of the most despised games in existence, and for good reason. Duke Nukem Forever begins with the best of intentions, and the first hour or so is actually moderately entertaining. But in short order, what begins as a dead average first-person shooter degenerates into a series of platform jumping puzzles with little in the way of actual combat or action between them. A drought of weapons simply highlights the fact that this game is a shooter in name only. Progression means enduring one stale problem-solving exercise after another, occasionally punctuated by a horrible boss fight. By the time you realize that these aren't just intermittent elements but are in reality the entire game, you think you've sunk in enough time already and that the game will be over soon, so you press on. But the game doesn't end. It plods on so ridiculously far past the point where an ending would have been a welcome reprieve and only becomes less bearable as the player's patience wears thinner and thinner. For sure, Duke Nukem Forever earns a lot of scorn simply because as a long-awaited entry to an otherwise great franchise, it fell far short of lofty expectations. But the game is horrible even when you try to set it aside from its predecessors and analyze it on its own precious few merits. The fact that this frustrating, disjointed abortion probably killed an otherwise good series off only adds a slightly superficial complaint to a long list of valid reasons to hate Duke Nukem Forever with the intensity of a thousand suns.

For all those kiddies who barely hit puberty and really don't have any clue what Duke Nukem REALLY is, this is for you. (And also for those who just want to know what DNF is really like)
First off: Duke Nukem Forever HAS BEEN IN DEVELOPMENT for 12 years, but that does not mean Gearbox has been developing it for 12 years. Got that? Good, let's go.
1. For the Graphics Players:
The game is not Crysis. It's not Far Cry 2. It's not even CoD. So, if this is what you base a game on, then don't even bother. DNF is more Serious Sam HD meets HL2 in my opinion. Some textures look awesome, some look really old. Overall, IMO, it's acceptable. I like eye-candy, make no mistake, but this is not what DNF is about. It never was, nor will it ever be.
2. The Profanity, Toilet Humour:
Duke is a dirty SOB. It's been like that ever since he first got voice. It will always be like that. It's part of the Duke Nukem "thing". It's even rated for it. Expect cursing, expect spending 20 minutes throwing poop around and jarateing on ♥♥♥♥. It's how it is. Get over it.
3. Gameplay:
This is where I have a serious issue with the game. So, I have broken it up into parts:
3.1 Linear Gameplay
This is my first problem with the game. WTF Gearbox? All DN3D maps were never linear. Sometimes you had to backtrack your way. There were also several ways to get to an objective. From what I have seen so far, there is only one way to get to your current objective and this totally ruins it for me. TotalBiscuit has a video which you can watch of the first 45 minutes of the game, be careful, it might contain spoilers.
3.2 Scripted Events
Although all games have scipted events, there're few things that jarate me off more than a developer who forces you to watch or listen to them. Gearbox will actually block your path so you HAVE to wait for the scripted event to finish. Because it's a linear game, there's obviously no way to skip the event.
3.3 Only 2 Weapons
DN3D and all older FPS games allowed the player to carry all the weapons with the player. At the start of the game, the load screen says: "Duke Nukem can bench-press 600 pounds". Yet, he is unable to carry more than two weapons...
4. Mouse Smoothing
You can scale it down, but you cannot disable it completely. I assume that once we actually delve into the config files, we should be able to. Although, this should be doable in the optons menu.
5. Regenerating Health
Thanks JoeB for reminding me about this. Regenerating health isn't really such a big deal to me, although, it's way off the bat when it comes to Duke Nukem. We're used to health packs to bring our health back up. The game did amuse me with it's own "health packs" though. To regain health, you need to boost your ego. There are several ways to do it in the game. My favourite is admiring yourself in the mirror. This really gave me a laugh. I really think that's one of the game's true Duke Nukem elements. Duke is a narcissist and you get to be one in game.
6. Saving the Game
Kudos lagrenouille for bringing this to my attention. You also can't quicksave in the game. Or save for that matter. The game is based on checkpoints. Yes, isn't that meant for consoles?
7. FOV (Field of View)
Something has been bugging me and I couldn't put my finger on it until just now. The FOV is really annoying. I believe it to be around 70-75. I think 90-100 would make this better. Probably easy to change in the config files, although I haven't checked yet and just couldn't be bothered to be honest.
For now, this is what I have experienced. Not to happy about it and I hope Gearbox actually listens to the community and undo the f-up that they have caused in the game.
Overall, I think this game is not too bad. It's by no means the next Half-Life, but it's playable and I think the modding community is what's going to give this game a longer life.

To be fair, there is some merit to this game. The environments and enemies look well enough, certainly not cutting edge but well past the limits of the sixth generation. There's even a small bit of platforming and puzzle solving, such as the remote control cars, running around in miniature, and bouncing inside an alien mother ship. There's lots of items strewn about with which the player can interact, like a fully functioning pinball machine, and boss fights usually depend on some gimmick instead of firepower.
Unfortunately, none of these distractions are fully realized or satisfying, and only serve to interrupt very claustrophobic gun-play through narrow hallways and trenches. There a plenty of scripted set-pieces that reinforce this sense of linearity, creating spectacle at the expense of freedom, like being lifted by a crane or manning a turret against enemy spacecraft. I enjoy linear games, but the level design here did little to excite me.
The other big strike against this game is its personality. For instance, in Duke Nukem 3D, the titular protagonist was fairly quiet except for the occasional musing. Forever is packed with quips, but without any restraint or comedic timing. Lines like "I've got balls of fail" or "Strange silicon-based life form" wear out their welcome immediately, and the title is full of such groaners.
Other stabs at humor and shock value are more questionable. When playing through an organic alien lair, the walls are decorated with disembodied breasts. Here, the player finds abductees who have been implicitly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and thus impregnated with enemy fetuses. The player may either euthanize these women or allow said monsters to incubate. While I can appreciate the "No-win" scenario, the whole scene felt extremely sadistic and underscores the problems with the game's mean-spirited attitude. I didn't buy Duke Nukem Forever to watch women suffer, and after having experienced that I generally feel worse as a person.
Between tedious game-play and troubling jokes, I couldn't bring myself to finish it. It's a functional if not boring game stymied by what I consider to be poor taste. If you find yourself defensive or dismissive while reading my review, then you'll probably enjoy this game in part or full. I would not recommend this to anyone who enjoyed Duke Nukem 3D.

Alright it's obvious that Duke Nukem Forever is a horrible FPS game filled with frankly juvenile humor and shout outs that really felt right back when it was Duke Nukem 3D but really doesn't fit now, but let's talk about WHY it sucks and just WHAT it did right.
The first third of the game - the Las Vegas missions - are fun, brightly colored, and chaotic romps through an alien battleground. The weapons feel good and are great fun to utilize to smash through your enemies. The story makes no attempts to be anything serious either, it's just Duke being Duke and everyone who disagrees with Duke is wrong. That's it. It's a fun campy game - for the first couple hours.
By the time you reach the desert and the Hoover Dam after that, the game loses its color and becomes highly repetitive and frankly a chore to play through. Weapons are fun to use until you realize you can only use two (or if you enabled an option, four) at a time and eventually it just stops giving you anything new to play with. By the time you've finished you're relieved to be done, and then you play the DLC chapter. The DLC feels more like what Duke Nukem Forever probably should have been, a short story rather than an "epic" and plays better than most of the main game did.
Duke has unfortunately outstayed his welcome, which should surprise frankly no one. If this game tried to be more like itself rather than a modern shooter I think it would have done a better job, but in trying to parody something that's already a parody it doesn't stand very well on its own.
If you want to give it a shot, I'd pick it up on sale because the beginning segments are certainly enjoyable.

Pure Puken = The epitome of FPS stupidity.
This is not the 90's anymore kiddies, I mean developers.
You wanna know why Duke and Doom were so popular back then? Because there were no other shooters. So playing the first ever 3d shooter while constantly sprinting and blasting at warhogs while carrying tons of weapons as well as having an occasional laugh at what the Duke or his enemies were doing was a blast.
But on the other hand, how do you make an FPS interesting wherein you simply mow down rows of enemies? I don't know, Serious Sam did it and that game had co-op. Bulletstorm did it. To tell you the truth, when I was watching the gameplay trailers I was trying not to think: "what? that's IT?" because for some reason I was believing that there was something more to the gameplay and the game itself that was being kept secret, some spice. That was denial at its best. The game turned out to be a mix of Quake 1, Serious Sam (minuses various and funny enemies), some random kindergarten puzzles thrown in the mix and.....that's pretty much it. And sorry devs, Duke's supposedly hilarious quotes and outburst just don't cut it. Sure, there are some non-cliche moments in the game but they usually last a couple of seconds.
However, at least you can only carry a couple of guns at the time, which is supposed to add more realism - if only that was not overshadowed by so many other things. For instance the AI is either charging at you or simply standing still and shooting you from afar (think Killzone 2,3 and how smart your enemies were, the smartest AI in all gaming in fact). The driving stages are okaish, except you are always confined to carefully crafted small areas that are either canyons or areas blocked off by garbage and other nonsense. The Big boss battles are the same: keep on moving, shooting, collect ammo drops, keep running in circles and the enemy won't hit you. No tactics required.
The aliens of course are kidnapping the white blonde hot-bodied chicks only. No other ethnicity apparently exists on Earth at the time. The whole sexism and overt insecure alpha male heterosexuality shows with almost each one of Duke's outbursts, but I guess there just has to be one game that has its own niche to fill. So I can't comment to negatively on this, I'm just glad that it's only one game that does this sort of thing.
Some things I can't complain about however. You actually CAN see your legs and you DO cast a shadow and you DO have a voice, and what a voice that is! if only all shooters had those extra three things I usually ask for. But in this case, this rare treat is absolutely wasted on this horribly pretentious game.
I bet that new Serious Sam (which only took a few years to develop, I reckon) is going to have a similar run'n'shoot hordes of enemies premise, however I think it's going to be pulled off better than this Puke.
Ultimately, most of us have grown and matured since 1998, some of us didn't. Some jokes aren't as funny anymore. If this game were released the mere years after the last game, then the similar age-minded audience would clap in awe. I understand the whole old-school nostalgia thing which CAN be delivered with so many recent 2-D platform remakes of the old NES classics. However this game is not a re-make nor does it feel like Duke Nukem part 4 or 5 or whatever. I'm not sure if this is a re-boot either because I doubt any more Duke will be made.
Rest in Peace, Duke. It wasn't the aliens, it was the fanbase killed the Duke.

It's Duke Nukem, nuff said. But seriousy, speaking as someone who had the game at launch, I loved the game. I expected to find my love mirrored when I went online, but it was not.
The Good: Duke himself. The witty one liners. The immature humor we're used to from Duke. I don't know why people bashed the game for that so much. That's how Duke has always been, why would he change now. If you don't like the humor because you're older and more mature now, fine, but don't knock the game for what the series has always been. That's like going to a bar and complaining that there's alcohol sold there. Was some of it predictable, yes, was it still awesome, yes! The graphics were pretty good to me (at least for the fact that it was in development hell for forever). The gameplay was pretty good with some issues pulling it down at times (see below).
The Bad: Some of the pacing for the game could have been adjusted. I could have stood for some more variety in baddies. I'm not sure about their choice of only being able to have 2 guns at a time. Part of me likes the idea, but part of me wants the old Duke that could carry an arsenal back. The levels could have been a little better, but were by no means horrible.
Summary: I loved the game. It had it's flaws, but if you can put asside the hype it is a good game. It is by no means perfect, but it's not as horrible as the mainstream reviewers would have you believe.

Everyone should play this game.
But only because it is the most hilarious mishmash of 90s and 2000s era gaming that I have had the pleasure of playing.
Well, to be honest, it isn't the worst game I've ever played, contrary to what many believe, but it sure is fun as hell to pick up for a laugh and to kill a bit of time with.
The game tries to be modern and current with its use of the two weapon (or four weapon if you go expanded inventory option) system, the linearity of the levels flanked by some horrid and one dimensional characters, regenerating health (now classified as Ego), sprinting and an awfully familiar grimy colour palette.
On the other side of the pond though, there is a lack of ironsights and aliens to kill. So that's nice, I guess.
Probably the most startling thing is that the humour is pretty schoolboy. Granted, my sense of humour is probably too pretentious but Duke is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ instead of his campy awesome action hero persona (probably comes with being a celebrity), the characters we meet are awfully written that all they do is swear a lot and a whole bunch of other stuff that could be covered if one does a Google search.
At the same time though, as much as I reckon they wanted DNF to be successful, I reckon they knew twelve years wasn't going to be enough to satisfy the masses. My theory is that they put all these new game mechanics here to show that Duke is, indeed, a relic from the old ages and cannot keep up with the current style at all.
By all means, if you wanna kill some time and shoot the breeze, pick this up. It's in the 'so bad it's good' category.

Duke Nukem Forever. 15 years in the making and yet here I am, considering if it couldn't have used a couple of more years in development. The truth is though, 5-10-15-20 years it wouldn't have mattered. The problem here isn't lack of development, it's the direction of the development.
All the fluff is there though. Playing this game you will never doubt that this is a Duke game. Scantily clad women are everywhere and you will rarely walk more than ten feet between the various pop culture references, jokes and other nonsense. If anything Gearbox deserves some credit for getting that part of the franchise right. The humor is there, the silliness, the crazy. What they got wrong, is the mechanics.
Playing Duke Nukem Forever is like playing every FPS made in the last 10 years. Gearbox certainly did. They added every cheesy feature the genre has ever experimented with. You got your vehicle sections, your turret sections, your button mashing quick-time events and so on and so forth. Any sense of the fast paced, old school style of FPS that made Duke Nukem 3D the icon it is today is long gone. Instead we have a Duke that's become old and arthritic. This Duke isn't the badass Duke of old. This Duke leans on stamina bars, regenerating health, limited weapon slots, scripted events and linear maps.
Instead of the sprawling maps of Duke 3D, that had you running, jumping, flying and swimming all over the place, looking for secrets and keycards you play through entirely linear and fully scripted sequences and fights you do not allow you to progress until you've killed what the game wants you to kill and listened to whatever irrelevant dialog the game wants you to listen to. The entire experience is slow and dull and there is little to look forward to besides the naked ladies and the occasional proper joke.
Duke Nukem 3D was a masterpiece of adolescent insanity, of old school fast paced shooting, of innovative map design. Duke Nukem Forever has captured the adolescent part but lost everything else in the shuffle. What's left is a mediocre shooter with a bunch of nudes thrown around.

All in all. For those that have been waiting, hoping for a good old school style shooter, this ain't it. And for those that just want a decent modern shooter to pass the time, this ain't it either. They might get the crude humor right but everything else, just ain't Duke.

Duke Nukem Forever is not one of the worst games I've ever played. That is me trying to be as objective as possible. The game was in development for years and drove it's parent company 3D Realms completely out of business. I followed it like a hawk and was extremely disappointed with what little Gearbox did to it.
Duke Nukem Forever has a lot of flaws and many people incorrectly assume it's because "Duke Nukem is outdated". Infact if this game had been a Serious Sam style old school first person shooter, I would be defending it til the day I die. That is not what this game is at all. It has all the outdated elements of Duke Nukem 3D along with a lot of modern concessions. While the game does implement new elements to the design they tend to fall flat. You have new weapons you don't use, new quotes you don't enjoy and new elements you dislike. What we get is regenerating health, and a two weapon limit. Yes Duke needs to hide behind cover and stop feeling depressed when he gets shot.
The game is certainly not unplayable, fully patched it runs at a stable framerate with FOV options. Since it's an U3 game it generally shouldn't have too many bugs. It's just not the game we wanted and that's what utterly kills me with it. It doesn't appeal to new players and it alienates old ones.
I actually feel the one thing Gearbox could have done to fix all this was to add modding support to the game. Duke Nukem 3D had a very large map editing community that still survives to this day. Fans could have created their own Duke Nukem Forever in it's former glory.

Wow. Where do I even start with this game?
Okay, I'll start with the most important part: The graphics. The graphics in this game are downright delirious. You will not believe that this is a videogame. You will think you are IN the game, shooting aliens and women. It's incredibly realistic, and everything from the TT-BLWs (Tactical Turd-Based Lobbed Weaponry) to the FMRs (Funny Meme References) are rendered in amazing detail.
The gameplay is in a class of its own. Not only is there a spectacular amount of quirky and interesting weaponry available to you, you can even carry more than one of them at once, allowing previously unseen levels of tactical depth as you can choose which weapon to use, depending on the situation. Do you use the pistol, or the shotgun? This is a game that really forces you to make some decisions.
The plot is amazing. Without spoiling too much, I will say that you're going to see some incredible character development - the Duke really matures as a person over the course of the game, and it deals with emotionally complex issues, like love, loss, and shooting women. Who said that games can't be art?
The audio design is top of the line. Kickin' guitar riffs mesh and mingle with Nukem's classic, ever-original one-liners such as "Hail to the King, baby!" and "Looks like you're ♥♥♥♥ed!". The excellent voice acting is only improved by the impressive quality of the script. There will be laughs aplenty as you shoot aliens, go to strip clubs, and - if you're lucky - maybe even get to visit the Secret Level.
All in all, I can safely recommend this game to anyone. Even people who aren't gamers. Hell, I can even recommend it to CASUAL "gamers", that's how marvellous this gem is. Don't let this obscure indie smash hit pass you by... or, to quote Duke himself -
"It's good!" - Duke Nukem

Screw the haters. Understand what kind of game this is, and you'll enjoy it.
Allow me to elaborate: This game is not the pinnacle of game design, or full of fresh ideas, or show-stopping in any way. What it is is a fun shooter with plenty of throwbacks and references to the 90's/early 2000's. It's not without its flaws, but it is plenty of fun and worthy of a collection, especially for a tenner.
Graphics- No, they aren't great. No, they don't push the limits of anything beyond a low-midrange computer. But they get the job done and do look good while doing so. Pigcops, certain cars, certain weapons, octabrains, and bosses are modeled very well, and you can definitely tell what they are and what they were modeled after (meaning you'll recognize a battlelord right away if you've played Duke3D). Plus, since this game doesn't push high-end setups, it's accessible to everyone.
Sound- Not much to speak of here. The sound is done well. Guns have enough punch. Music is done well. Stereo separation and directional audio does what it needs to.
Gameplay- Honestly, this is where it matters most. You do buy a game for gameplay, not to just look at graphics. Again, don't expect this to rule the gaming world with fresh, innovative play. But, if you're looking for a shooter that's fast, precise, and doesn't do much of the cover mechanic, this is it. Plenty of stuff to shoot, plenty of guns to use, plenty of bosses to fight and die against.
Overall, good for several playthroughs and some multiplayer. This is a basic 2011 shooter with 1998 roots, and they show. I happen to like gameplay like this. If you also do, buy and enjoy. If not, go ahead and move on.

Duke Nukem used to be a gun mayhem shooter where you feel like a badass using kickass weapons while spitting cheesy one-liners. You got to explore the map to find secrets to keep yourself better equipped and encounter various fun intractable objects. Now, imagine that game with none of that. Mostly.
While some of the guns are fun to shoot, because you're limited to 2 weapons (or 4 if you choose "extended inventory", which was added after the game release), you don't get to carry around all of them which makes it the worst part of the game. Bosses pretty much require you to carry an RPG, so you’re limited to one weapon most of the times. This game would have been a lot more fun if you could carry all of the weapons just like the classic games.
They added first person platforming which is awkward, but at least it didn't make the game unnecessarily harder to beat. There are occasionally puzzles, but uninspired and mostly easy.
Dodging enemy projectiles and attacks while blasting your way out was a fun part of the original Duke Nukem games, but that is also gone here. Enemies shoot fast (unless they carry heavy weapons) and lock on you, you cannot perform any advanced maneuvers, especially when the maps have so many objects you can run into and most of the battle areas are very condensed.
This game fails to deliver that original Duke Nukem experience and made something that no one really wanted. It’s a bad shooter, but it’s really a good one either. To be fair, it wasn't boring at least, but then again why your precious life waste time on such a mediocre game? There are so many other options if you want to play some kickass mindless shooter (e.g. Serious Sam 3), this game is NOT RECOMMENDED, even for a cheap price.

To borrow heavily from Scott Tobias, Duke Nukem Forever deserves "the gentleman's F." It is neither a good game, nor a terrible game (ok, from a technical standpoint it IS pretty terrible), nor does it entail any of the fervor associated with either descriptor. It is, to further paraphrase Tobias, a "failure...try[ing] for nothing and flopping, [achieving] no payoff for compromise." There is potential for good in Duke Nukem Forever; the first two levels or so are likeable enough in a juvenile way, and there are some genuinely great set pieces -- the ghost town, the mine cart bits, the underwater section -- and I found the shrinking mechanism to be enjoyable, in the Duke Burger level anyway. Unfortunately, this game is ultimately dull, rote, and uninspired (and in places rather glaringly offensive), and must neither be recommended nor disparaged for its shortcomings. It truly does deserve to be dropped from a great height.

You have no idea how much time I put into Duke Nukem 3D as a child, hundreds and hundreds of hours, on more than one platform. Duke Nukem 3D helped shape the FPS genre. It's totally fair to say Duke Nukem Forever had some serious shoes to fill.
You have no idea how much I ♥♥♥♥ing wanted to love this game.
I badly wanted, nay, badly needed to love this game! and the good news - it is a fun game. In parts.
The game opens with you replaying the classic 1996 Football field Boss Fight. As the one liners start flowing I breathe a sigh of relief. it's clear they haven't missed the mark too much, but this leads to one of Duken Nukem Forevers' core problems.
It hasn't advanced much at all since the 90's.
Maybe this was the point you may say, but I don't think so. Duke pokes fun at moderns shooters then uses features taken directly from them, such as an Unlimited regenerating health pool and only being able to carry two weapons at any given time.
You can't take the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of a game then directly use features from it.
At it's core Duken Nukem Forever is an old school run and gun game. The levels have little coherence and could just as easily be a selection of random events that Duke comes into shooting and shouting one liners.
There are good parts, the combat is entertaining and has a 'classic' feel, the weapons are fun to use (even with overly large models) there are lots naked women, Duke ripping aliens heads off, Ball punching, Beer drinking, and crude humor that the child in me did enjoy.
Huge mini boss encounters are also fun but then you are soon back to some filler moment, when all you really want to do is blow up more aliens with a Rocket launcher.
To it's credit this game has no cut scenes. everything happens through the eyes of Duke. This is important, and I'd like to see more of this 'Half Life' approach in other FPS's.
The really bad moments in the game come from a driving level, broken up with a pointless "Oh no I've run out of gas" moment... and horrible and unavoidable control a shooting turret sections, mixed wioth lots of filler moments.
You have no idea how much I ♥♥♥♥ing wanted to love this game.
Duke - it's great to have you back, but this isn't the game we deserved.

I recently finished Super Castlevania IV for the first time and have come to the conclusion that Duke Nukem Forever is not a good game.
After playing Castlevania IV I was hugely impressed by the ability to whip in 8 different directions in comparison to the normal 4 and I thought this was a huge leap in innovation for the gaming industry. As a result, when I first decided to play Duke Nukem Forever (a game which was released 20 years after Castlevania IV) I expected to see the same innovative ideas. To my shock (and horror) I discovered that Duke Nukem Forever does not feature 8 directional-whips, in fact, Duke Nukem Forever doesn't have whips at all! This was most disappointing because I was really looking forward to whipping in 16 different directions but maybe 20 years isn't enough to create digital whips that whip in that many directions.
Whereas Castlevania IV has the player advance through various themed (and spooky) stages until you arrive at Dracula's Lair and defeat him in a climactic end to the only good Castlevania game, Duke Nukem Forever has you save American pornstars from Kotaku writers. Personally I think that saving the world from Dracula is more important than saving American pornstars but I am not a cis-gendered feminist so what do I know.
In conclusion I would recommend Super Duke Nukem IV over Castlevania Forever because there are a lot of innuendos and sexual jokes about ♥♥♥♥♥♥s and those are my favourite types of jokes.

Before the likes of Crysis and Metro 2033 dethroned it, Duke Nukem Forever long bore the crown inscribed "best looking game ever". Like so many superficial titles, it was a double-edged sword. Whilst Duke Nukem Forever ascended to legendary status, it also raised disinterested glances from those who saw it only as a pretty face, and dissapointed ones from those whose hardware couldn't handle it. Five years on, Gearbox's masterful expansion and adaptation of ideas originally worked into Duke Nukem3D  has finally found its place. This what happens when "ahead of the curve" becomes "of the curve"; a shooter that bridges the gap between old-school mentality and modern hardware. Duke Nukem Forever is still one of the most technologically astounding games out there, sure, but it's real draw is its flexible sandbox gameplay, allowing for any combination of stealthy or agressive tactics. It veritably oozes polish, cinematic flair and European design intellect.

Duke Nukem Forever (DNF) got bad reviews overall, but do yourself a favour and mostly ignore them. Have in mind most reviews are biased, and this is suppose to be an old school FPS, with a lenghty campaign (it will take you between 10 and 15 hours to complete if you are an experienced player) and a very fun MP with a lot of customizable options. Have in mind this game was intended for release in 1999, a time when FPS's were simplistic and it was all about firepower and testosterone driven characters, and Duke delivers on both ends. As a direct sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, DNF delivers the same amount of insanity, action and adrenaline as it's predecessor. Compared to todays shooters, it is a dinosaur of a game, outdated in structure and gameplay mechanics, but it still is a lot of fun, and a great throwback to the 90's, a decade that revolutionized video games.
This is how old school games are suppose to be, and if you like crude humour, naked chicks and epic one liners, this game is for you. It took 15 years for this game to see the light of day, so when you buy this, you are getting a piece of video game history. The worlds most famous vaporware is ready to be played. It took forever (no pun intended), but it's here.
Always bet on Duke.
The Good
-Old school badassery in spades
-Easter egg galore
-Fun shooting mechanics
-Epic one liners
-Lenghty campaign
-Awesome firepower
The Bad
-Too simplistic when compared to more modern shooters
-Difficulty level can be a problem to some players (Personally I love a good challenge)
-Style of this game appeals mostly to hardcore gamers
6.5/10

What is there to say?  DNF is a very very fun game.  It's not stylish, it's not demure, it's not refined.  It's raw, sexist, brash, alien-smashing fun.  The disjointed style between the levels shows its long development time, and I think it's clear which levels were originally designed 10 years ago, and then "Gearboxed" into the 21st century.  This was a FUN game.  It won't win any awards for style, but for sheer humour, it's worth it.   This game is NOT for anyone expecting a serious simulation of an alien invasion.  It's for people who want to remember the good old days of Duke Nukem, when games could be sexist, crass, but slightly less technically impressive. DNF is all about fun: shooting aliens, solving some puzzles and killing giants bosses. Don't expect a well written story, because it's almost non-existent. The very good voice acting and the interaction with many objects makes the atmosphere quite enjoyable. So why everyone keeps telling that is a bad game? Because it should have come out 4 years ago. It's obvious by looking at the gameplay mechanics that the game was made on the HL era: shooting while making your path straight, puzzle, tough enemy. The whole game feels like a rollercoaster: there are some memorable levels, but there are levels that you want to finish quickly. Finally, I think the worst thing about DNF are the jokes: even though the charisma of Duke Nukem is still there, most of them are stupid, out of the context and sometimes repulsives. The multiplayer is very simple but fun too. Despite it's flaws, DNF is enjoyable experience, I recommend it to anyone who likes black humor and shooting aliens just for fun. 7/10

This is a hard one to talk about... DN3D is one of my favorite games ever. From its over macho sense of humor, to just phenomenal level design. You can't beat 1997 Duke.
First off you have to understand no game EVER is going to live up to 13 years of hype. It should be considered a miracle that this game even is out at this point.
singleplayer:
The game starts off slow... VERY SLOW. For a old school shooter sequel there isn't any shooting for at least a hour into the game. Really got annoying after awhile. Then the 4 weapon limit... argh. Just not fun when you're not a walking tank in a Duke Nukem game.
The guns also feel very floaty. Not a lot of bang except for the shotgun, and even that started to lose its fun in the end game.  The levels were also very very very linear, with no freedom of execution like in DN3D. That in itself should be considered a sin.
Interaction with your environment is still pretty insane, though most if its pretty useless/not funny. Boobs are still here, but they aren't as magical as they were to a 13 year old me. The game does also push the boundaries of sexual content, to the point where I shut down the game near one of the bosses due to a grotesque death sequence.

I have been a long time fan of the Duke Nukem series and I enjoyed this game like any other first person experience. I found this installment to be a little different from the previous ones but with the technology changes over the insanely long devolopment period of this game, it is fair to say the game will be different. I will say I have a few complaints myself but I enjoyed the game overall. I am glad to see that the game did not receive a large number of DLC to seem like it was a money pit. I thought that the Doctor Who Cloned Me to be rather fitting for the game and it was worth the price I got it for. Okay, back to the base game. The graphics are much better from any previous installments and are pretty impressive for the time of its inception. The UI and AI are fully functional and it provides a challenge but definitely possible. The level design is fairly linear but sometimes allows other approach options and the environment in each level is finely made into a very believable scenario. The control and overall functionality of the game is solid as well as sticking to realistic arsenal choice. Allowing you to carry only two weapons or four if you allow it in the options, you are deciding what weapon is best for each encounter or just to fit your preference. Also, the EGO system makes it similar to Halo's shield system or anything like it. I like that they decided to do something different but I think the old formula of medkits and armor is sufficient. Also, the arsenal is not to far from your arsenal in Duke Nukem 3D but that is not bad. The weapons that are new are the Expander and the Impregnator Gun. Also, the Freeze Ray can't shoot projectiles but only a continuous beam that recharges. Then the Shrink Ray is not a weapon but a story component that changes the combat somewhat since you will be very small. Well, to conclude, I thought this game was a success and I found it very enjoyable and well thought out. Even though it took practically forever to release, the game was good, I would recommend this game to any that wish to play another entry in the series or first person shooter fans.

It's got the classic style of strafe and shoot but the modern style of carrying two guns at a time, and with so many awesome weapons to choose from, this was a poor design choice. Who was this game for? Duke Nukem fans. But even they are deterred by the poor choices that designers made. Some of this stuff is even too immature for Duke Nukem. A lot makes sense, like the beginning, sort of. But then you get things like punching aliens in sensitive bits Duke assumes they have, or picking up a turd and throwing it around. Yes, we were able to urinate in Duke Nukem 3D, but that doesn't mean there needs to be more bathroom jokes, or nut-punching. I like the fourth wall breaking, I liked kicking a cyclops eye through a field goal post, I liked the finishers of kicking enemies in the head, or increasing my ego with minigames or looking at myself in the mirror, because Duke will be Duke.
This game has your standard Duke story; Duke gets mad at aliens for stealing his favorite girls, Duke sets out on revenge mission, President hates Duke, Duke flips off aliens AND President, Duke swears and does immature things, fun shooting, fun shooting, fun shooting, minigames, minigames, minigames, and so on and so forth.
But this game makes me think that Duke's time has come to and end. In the late 90s, it was like Duke ruled, but his reign quickly ended with an array of crappy games and this one is no different. Duke has one good game, and unless some serious changes are made, that's all there will be.
I do have one idea for the future of Duke: A game about him getting older and him going in search of a son he didn't know he had, his son is the antagonist, mad at Duke for killing who he thought was his father, but Duke is his father. This gives you all those opportunities for movie references, bad jokes, but having a new experience with new enemies, a new antagonist, and a plot-twist. This would even make it so Duke's son becomes the protagonist in a sequel that could possibly be funded if the game really does change Duke. Possibly even a 2-player co-op sequel where one player is Duke, and the other is...  you guessed it... LUKE. That's right, you'd hear "Duke. You killed my father." "No. I am your father." "That's not true! That's impossible!"
Anyways, onto PROS and CONS:

+ Reference to the long wait for this game
+ Ego instead of health
+ Ego boosts

Duke Nukem Forever is a shallow, crude imitation of better games released before it. In other words, it's bad. Read on at your own risk.
It's even more puerile than
, and with even less relevance. When 3D came out in early '96, at least that game's aesthetic was an earnest step in a new direction: video gaming entering its adolescence. It may not have been particularly tasteful or mature, but at least it was a better direction than the cynical, even-more-outrageous toxic masculinity and objectification of women on display here.
The developers at one point said their world-building was genius because everyone in-universe takes it completely seriously. It more often comes across as tired, aggressively moronic, disgusting, or a combo thereof. Hamfisted, outdated references galore in a sad, unnecessary attempt to mimic what Duke once was: a parody of then-relevant action movies. In 3D, this sort of stuff, while still pretty lowbrow, ultimately played second fiddle to the great gameplay. Here, the
seems like it plays second fiddle in both quality and importance.
The only plus I can give the writing is that it's an unwitting dystopia. Duke is our hero for saving the world multiple times as humanity is more vulnerable than ever. We see massive monuments erected in his honor, awards bestowed, his own fast food chain, and even a Vegas casino dedicated to him. Thanks to his hero status, normal people are emulating his forceful personality enough that American society has become more aggressive and sexist. One wonders if the world is even worth saving again.
DNF makes its alien invasion story feel tiring quicker than it has a right to. There's a couple characters here and there, primarily Duke's friend General Graves and his boss, the less-than-perceptive US President. You'll see the plot 'twist' concerning him a mile away. Captain Dylan the infantry commander is notable for how vulgar he is. The rest are unremarkable or cannon-fodder, with two in particular I'll get to soon.
There are a couple inspired touches, but they're needles in a haystack. For example, whenever Duke is knocked down or kicks open a door, there's a nice sense of presence to the animation - it's satisfying to kick open doors. The dynamic, breakable lighting is also a nice touch, as is keyboard navigation in the menus ala 3D.
Then you see another low-quality texture right out of 2004 and you remember what game you're playing. I mean, the graphics aren't the worst thing about this game by far, but they stand out pretty early as a sign of things to come. It makes DNF seem like a prolonged boxing match between the power of human talent and the ravages of time.
The writing reaches its nadir in the alien hive, about midway through the game. Here we have - trigger warning, folks - rather graphic depictions of sexual violence against women by the alien invaders. I know this was sort of a thing in 3D, but it wasn't nearly as graphic or tasteless. In DNF, we hear Duke cracking wise at all of it like nothing is out of the ordinary.
You soon come across two characters that were never more than one-dimensional parodies and servile sex objects for Duke, and this is the important part, right up to their final painful moments.
we come across alien boobs embedded in a wall which Duke can play with and snark about while women scream in pain and horror all around him. The most he can do is mercy-kill them while unconvincingly stating it's 'better this way'. The whole thing is, and I'm saying this with
charity, not the best fit for a parodic series about a manly dude blowing stuff up and obsessing over babes.
Now, the gameplay.
It is largely derivative of Half-Life and Halo, but not as good. The game was dated when it came out, really. Maybe if you're a 'retro gamer' you can appreciate that, but you'll still feel the game should have came out at least 6 years before it did.
DNF's gunplay is pretty mediocre; albeit not totally awful,  it really is more like Halo than Duke. The option to carry four weapons (because 'Duke isn't Halo!') makes the game easier at the cost of destroying what little verisimilitude it had and making it hilarious when Duke literally wishes out loud that he had three guns late in the game.
My favorite weapon was actually the pistol, a relatively modest weapon that rewarded accuracy. Most of the other guns felt sloppy and unsatisfying, although the shotgun deserves credit for stopping power. The aiming and movement are a little off, too. Occasionally the movement gels well with what's going on, but oftentimes it's just weird.
I was initially surprised by how quickly I was progressing through the campaign, but there's a decent amount there - enough frustration and filler, at least. It took me around 10 hours the first time on Hard difficulty. Some of the puzzles and player directioning hint at competence on the design team, but not enough of it got through. There's enough world interactivity to match DN3D, but without the benefit of being new or unique.
The game's linear structure is a far cry from 3D's open levels, which would be forgivable if it was good. DNF's story may be in the background, but it's ultimately more of a driving force than 3D's. Said predecessor is masterful in comparison, building off Doom with its labryinthine levels and mostly unintrusive plot. DNF really wants to be more like
, with linear progression supplemented by spoonfuls of "story" and even vehicle sections.
Those sections aren't the
driving, like how a leftover $1.50 pizza bagel isn't the
snack. It certainly can't make up for long loading times & small level sizes comparable to Invisible War in their ridiculousness.
I didn't entirely care for the way you increase your regenerating health (or "ego"). Although it becomes a blessing on harder difficulties, you still have to run away from combat to regenerate - that's hardly badass. It feels like Duke is more vulnerable and washed up than he thinks he is, whether he knows it or not; further evidence of this is that he only needs to drink ONE beer pickup at a time to get really drunk. It also gave the devs an excuse to mash Call of Duty's influence into their potpourri of a campaign, but I digress.
Overused QTE events, mediocre turret sections, rote boss fights, annoying enemies and encounters that border on unplayably difficult round out DNF's list of features. The Grand Canyon-esque difficulty spikes in those battles indicate a lack of playtesting.
In fairness, the final level & boss battle was surprisingly decent. The giant Enforcer-versus-mini Duke battle was also inspired, even if you had to juke it to win. It's not worth playing the rest of the game to get to either point. Ladders meanwhile are probably the most interesting thing in the entire game: you press a key to get on and you actually
the things. It sacrifices juking potential for actual ease of use.
Multiplayer is decidedly old-school yet not done well enough to be considered retro, with a small population of diehards still playing. The starting pistol at least proved powerful enough that I didn't die
the time to the weird hit detection, because the weird hit detection also worked in my favor. The My Digs feature might have been interesting if it wasn't partly sexist and if the game was good enough to play and unlock stuff.
DNF is a big disappointment if your expectations are anywhere above the level of 'budget shooter'. Duke was a product of a specific time, a vehicle that didn't need to be revived so acrimoniously to create what is essentially a parody of action blockbusters by way of Adam Sandler. Don't even buy this if you're a masochist. It's not worth it.

First things first, Duke Nukem Forever isn't as terrible a game as everyone makes it out to be. It may be an antiquated, haphazard, unpolished game. But honestly I've played many other FPS games that had far lower investments into themshelves. And too its credit DNF does have things that are sorely missing from modern shooters, or all games for that matter.
Duke Nukem Forever is, for a lack of better term; a varitable cross section of FPS delevelopment. Like the real rings of a tree, you can see all the growth of the genre. And for better or for worse, its a neat little history lesson or sorts. But in some sections this trip down yesteryear way does wears thin.
Ultimately, if you ask me, DNF is a victim of circumstance. Not because it took thirteen years to come out, but because during that time the FPS genre had become standardized. Today a shooter isn't a shooter worth playing if it is without a robust multiplayer, a sense of realism, over the top melodrama, HATS, and if it isn't military shooter. Forget about it. Than comes a game from an era that didn't have rules. And because of that, we simply scroffed at our roots.

Hail to the King, Baby. Duke Nukem Forever is the sequel to 3D Realms' classic Build engine first-person shooter Duke Nukem 3D. After a VERY long (and troubled) time in development, DNF was finally released in 2011. For the most part, the mainstream gaming media panned and generally sh*t on it. Many oldschool fans of DN3D who had waited a very long time for this game's release also cried foul. I am one of those longtime DN3D fans and i have to say, after playing through DNF the first time at launch and more recently a 2nd time, i still truly don't get all the hate for this game. IMO it's great fun, a fitting continuation of the franchise, and a decent return to gamedom for Duke. Usually intense, often amusing, occasionally frustrating, but immediately enjoyable and entertaining throughout. While not perfect, it's certainly not a bad game and i feel it definitely deserved better scores than what it received. Don't let the negative press decide for you, try it for yourself.

The problem is, the entire premise of Duke Nukem is ‘pickup n play for ♥♥♥♥♥ n giggles’. Duke isn’t meant to be Gordon Freeman, Sam Fisher, Agent 47 etc. Duke is meant to be Duke.
The bottom line is, if you want a decent game, that’s got some good moments, and can put up with annoyances of the modern FPS additions, give it a try.  But classic Duke this is not.

Duke Nukem Forever may not be as horrible as disappointed fans make it out to be, but it is certainly far from Game of the Year.
Pros:
- Duke's personality is entertaining, which sometimes adds to the feeling of the fight.
- Fun weapons such as the Freeze Gun and Shrink Ray.
- Inventive puzzle concepts, though some poorly executed.
- Great final boss battle true to 90's shooters.
Cons:
- Absolutely terrible minigames that don't function well.
- Horrible and stupid achievements that require aforementioned mini games.
- Poor difficulty balance. Most of the game is too easy while other parts are frustratingly difficult.
- Campaign is full of filler sequences.
- Extremely distasteful imagery involving killing naked, bound, pregnant women.
- Terrible voice acting.
Duke Nukem Forever plays like a mildly entertaining 2004 sci-fi shooter, but there is no king to be hailed to in this game.

DNF has been forever in the making & has finally arrived. DNF might lack story & character depth [that's for sure] & the graphics might look 5 years OLD, but DNF surely can be a lot of fun b/c when DNF is on, DNF is on point. When it's not, well...it's not.
DNF is a shooter, but it often tries to be more than a shooter - also having a puzzle-physics elements & tons of interactivity w/ objects in the game-world.
The on & off early part of the SP portion might throw the player for a loop, but don't quit yet - the game gets better once you leave The Lady Killer casino...A LOT better. Later on, a few levels are pointless [the strip club] or often repetitive [the get gas 3 times for the truck mission] - which unfortunately also drag the game's quality down a quite a bit.
The MP feels like a throwback to the good old days of DN3D; Quake 2 + 3 glory; and UT days, which is welcome - but, if only there were more maps & game modes.
DNF certainly might not be worth the original $60 price-tag, but DNF surely is worth the $20 or less that it is often going for now.
Grade: C+

I wish it took more cues from the earlier Duke game, Manhatten Project, and left his Ego meter as a health meter with health pick-ups, not this. That and ammo is almost instantly replenished. This is not the game I expected, and didn't exactly want. I honestly wanted to like this game, but there's so many flaws that now I don't even recognize Duke. I don't know what other reviewers were expecting from DNF, but all I wanted was a Duke Nukem game, and I got exactly what I was waiting fourteen years for.  It's not groundbreaking, and the game shows its long development cycle, but the elements that made DN3D groundbreaking are all there.  The humor, the heavily interactive environment (which few games even now bother to have learned from DN3D), the references (something I dearly love), the crazy enemies, the zany weapons, Duke and friends' over-the-top personalities; everything you could ask of Duke Nukem.  The love and care of the developers is obviously present, even if the game shows its age.
Now, if you get terribly upset about the objectification of women or swearing, just walk away now.  There's nothing in Duke Nukem for you.  But for those of us who've kept the faith, who cut our teeth on Roddy Piper and Bruce Campbell, the Duke is back in fine form.
It's not perfect, not even after fourteen years.  But I really like it.

My rig with a quad core does handle it better but still, it uses way too much processor power for what it is.

Graphics: The graphics may not be quite up to date like many games, but graphics don't make a game, right? Duke games have always had a unique graphic style. which is the case here. Think of the graphics as a 2008 Xbox 360 game with 2011 particles.
Gameplay: The gameplay is, of course, blasting aliens just like the classics, but with a twist, you can only carry 2 weapons! This was most likely made for balance and realism, honestly you shouldn't be bothered by it. You get many weapons and powerups such as RPGs and steroids. There is more to do than blasting aliens on foot, but I'll keep that a secret. There is also multiplayer which is similar to old games like Quake. It has some lag issues, but nothing too serious. After beating the game you get cheats and some extras. Interacting with the world lets you obtain many items. Sadly there is limited replayability unless you play multiplayer.
Overall, this is a great game for fast action and fun, while retaining stuff like great music!

15 years. One and a half long decades. That is how long the world waited for a true sequel to Duke Nukem 3D. Stuck in the longest ever known development hell, switching engines multiple times, and winning a crapton of vaporware awards, Duke Nukem Forever seemed destined to never see the light of day. But see the light of day it did, thanks to the combined efforts of Triptych Games and Gearbox Software!
Triptych Games was founded when 3DRealms closed it's doors back in 2009, and they worked out of their own homes for no pay to make DNF what it is today. Then in 2010, Gearbox Software bought the franchise, hired on Triptych, and helped them polish their work, resulting in the badass beast we know today.
The Duke Nukem series has always been known for it's balls-out irreverent sense of humor, and DNF continues that fine tradition of debauchery with gusto. The traditional Duke charm is firmly imbedded in the game's design, managing to give fans a good laugh along the way and in the process completely offending those who don't get Duke's particularly awesome brand of humor.
The gameplay is a melting pot of what's best about classic FPS games, and the best of their contemporary counterparts. Gone are random medkits and stimpacks, now we have a regenerating EGO bar that represents Duke's Dukeness. Let it drop to nothing, and he might not be able to shrug off that next bullet. Dive behind cover and rest a moment and you'll be back in action in quick order. Or you can take the manly route and use an execution move on an enemy, this instantly refills Duke's ego bar.
The signature interaction introduced by Duke Nukem 3D is back in force, with pool tables, pinball machines, weight benches, arcade games, air hockey, and more ready to entertain those who want to take a break from the carnage and just mess around.
Most items give you a permanent EGO boost the first time you use them, to try and mess around with anything and everything. You can even recreate the infamous microwave scene from Maniac Mansion.
Dukes signature arsenal is back in former glory, and this is where the Xbox 360 version takes a bit of a sidestep from the PC counterpart, on PC they patched in the ability to carry four weapons at once, but on the console as of this writing you can still only carry two. Still, the game is amazingly balanced, with plenty of guns lying around to take your pick from. During boss fights you can usually find an ammo crate to keep the rockets flying, so don't be afraid to use your firepower.
Multiplayer returns big time in DNF, with Dukematch, Team Dukematch, Capture the Babe (capture the flag, but easier on the eyes) and Hail to The King. A diverse array of maps are included, based on locations seen in the campaign. My personal favorite is Duke Burger, which sees the players shrink down to action-figure size, and let loose in the kitchen of the iconic fast-food joint. Earning EXP in multiplayer earns you new items to decorate your personal penthouse, and completing challenges gives you new shirts and hats to customize your Duke.
Duke Nukem Forever may not be the greatest game of all time, but despite some long loading times on the Xbox 360 version it stands tall and proud in representation of the Duke franchise, and in my humble opinion it should be played by fans and newcomers to the series alike, as it finally brings closure to the most epically insane development saga in the history of gaming.
